38 J. Rosen et al.
Structure and Composition of o-MAX Phases
The first o-MAX phase was discovered by Liu et al. upon M element alloying in Cr2TiAlC2 [6]. The phase is a M3AX2 structure, with the Ti layer sandwiched between two outer Cr carbide layers [6]. This finding was soon followed by synthesis of Mo2TiAlC2 [9–10], Mo2ScAlC2 [11], and Ti2ZrAlC2 [12], all in a M3AX2 structure, and Mo2Ti2AlC2, in a M4AX3 structure [10], exemplified in Fig. 3.2b, g. Further signs of ordering have been demonstrated in the (Cr0.5V0.5)n + 1AlCn system for n = 2 and 3, while n = 1 displayed complete disorder between Cr and V [13]. Due to the ratio of the M elements, however, the ordering observed was not complete, with partial intermixing evident from neutron diffraction analysis.
The displayed out-of-plane chemical order in M3AX2 and M4AX3 o-MAX (see Fig. 3.2b, g) is M element specific. For M3AX2, the first M (Mo, Ti, Cr) occupies the 4f Wyckoff site, next to the Al layer, while the second M element (Ti, Sc, Zr, V) occupies the 2a Wyckoff site. The o-MAX formation has been suggested to originate from the second M element breaking the energetically unfavorable stacking of the first M element, whose binary carbides do not crystallize in the rock salt structure (Mo and Cr), thereby avoiding occupation of the center layers. This explanation is valid for some o-MAX phases, but not for Mo2ScAlC2 and Ti2ZrAlC2 [10–12, 14]. Instead, the formation of Mo2ScAlC2 may be promoted by Mo, the M element closest to the Al layer, having larger electronegativity than Al, resulting in fewer electrons available for populating the energetically expensive antibonding Al-Al orbitals [11].
3 In- and Out-of-Plane Ordered MAX Phases and Their MXene Derivatives 39
Synthesis and Characterization of MXene from o-MAX Phases
The synthesis of o-MAX phases also spurred interest in possibilities for chemically ordered MXenes. In 2015, Anasori et al. experimentally realized the first chemically ordered double-transition-metal MXenes: Mo2TiC2Tx, Mo2Ti2C3Tx, and Cr2TiC2Tx (where T is a surface termination) (see Fig. 3.2f–h) [15]. Later, Meshkian et al. demonstrated the first Sc-containing MXene with chemically ordered doubletransition-metal Mo2ScC2Tx (see Fig. 3.2a–e) [11].
With the discovery of ordered double-transition-metal MXenes, new insights have been gained. Since etching is a kinetically controlled process, MXenes with larger n in Mn + 1CnTx usually require stronger etching and/or a longer etching time. At the same etching conditions, Mo2Ti2AlC3 (n = 3) requires an etching time twice as long as its n = 2 counterpart Mo2TiAlC2 [15–16]. Moreover, although Mo2TiC2Tx and Ti3C2Tx are isostructural, their different outer M layers make them display significantly different electronic properties as seen in Fig. 3.3. The former exhibits semiconductor-like transport properties, while the latter is metal-like [16– 17]. Moreover, magnetoresistance measurements of the two materials also show
40 J. Rosen et al.
opposite sign, suggesting fundamentally different transport mechanisms [16]. It should be noted that the MXene surface terminations likely also influence these properties; however, a crude estimate based on EDX analysis indicates that the Odominated surface composition is similar for the phases exemplified here [16].
In Ref. [18], the electrical and thermoelectric properties were measured for Mobased MXenes (Mo2CTx, Mo2TiCTx, and Mo2Ti2C3Tx). Mo2TiC2Tx was found to have the largest thermoelectric power factor, reaching 3.09 × 10−4 W m−1 K−2 at 803 K. Based on theoretical calculations, and an assumed fully O-terminated surface, this was explained by Mo2TiC2O2 having much larger portion of flat bands near the Fermi level as compared to Mo2CO2 and Mo2Ti2C3O2 [19–21].
Theoretical Predictions on MXene from o-MAX
In the quest for new chemically ordered double-transition-metal MXenes, Anasori et al. investigated the relative stability of 17 M′2M′′C2 and 15 M′2M′′2C3 MXenes from hypothetical o-MAX phases with different chemical ordering in the form of fully ordered and partially ordered configurations [15]. They predict that at 0 K, 26 ordered double-transition-metal MXenes should be stable with respect to the disordered counterparts [15]. Later, Tan et al. explored the structure-stability relationship for eight MXene alloy systems by mapping the degree of ordering vs temperature using high-throughput computation [22]. For Mo-rich MXenes, (MoxM′′1-x)3C2 (where M′′ = Ti, V, Nb, Ta), the Mo atoms prefer to occupy the surface layers, with the ordering persisting to high temperatures, while a Ti-based MXene alloyed with Nb or Ta shows a preference for Ti surface atoms for a Ti-rich MXene and Ti occupation of only one surface layer for Nb- and Ta-rich MXenes [22]. It should be noted that the inherent chemistry of a MXene is dependent on its parent MAX phase, which is typically synthesized at temperature above 1500 K. At such temperatures, some degree of intermixing between alloying elements is
3 In- and Out-of-Plane Ordered MAX Phases and Their MXene Derivatives 41
typically expected [10, 14, 22]. Moreover, realization of new MXenes is highly dependent on realization of new MAX phases, or identification of precursors beyond MAX phases. Evaluation of the stability of novel MXenes benefits from a discussion on not only the stability of the MXene and potential precursors but also on the effect of type of surface terminations and their surface coverage.
The use of MXenes from MAX as well as o-MAX phases for sustainable production of molecular hydrogen as a clean energy carrier has been demonstrated by hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) via electrocatalysis. Examples thereof are Mo2CTx and the o-MAX Mo2TiCx [23–24]. Selected other MXenes, Ti2CTx and (Ti0.5V0.5)2CTx, have also been theoretically predicted to be effective electrocatalysts for HER under the assumption that they are fully functionalized by either O or OH groups [25–26]. Other functionalizing species may also impact the HER. Handoko et al. performed a combined experimental and theoretical study on Mo2CTx, Ti2CTx, Mo2TiC2Tx, and Mo2Ti2C3Tx using HF and LiF-HCl as etching agents and found that the presence of F terminations in Ti-based MXenes has an unfavorable impact on their HER performance, while low F coverage of Mo-based MXenes shows improved HER activity [24].
For evaluation of transport properties, theoretical studies have shown that pristine MXenes are mostly metallic [15]; however, upon functionalization, some become semiconducting [16, 27]. MXenes to date can thus be divided into two categories, topologically trivial and nontrivial metal/semimetal or semiconductor, which one depends on the strength of the relativistic spin-orbit coupling (SOC). With the introduction of out-of-plane ordered double-transition-metal MXenes came the possibility of alloying with heavy 4d and 5d transition metal elements. Khazaei et al. investigated the theoretical electronic properties of M′2M′′C2O2 (M′ = Mo, W; M′′ = Ti, Zr, Hf) with and without considering SOC and found that they are topological insulators with nontrivial band gaps induced by the SOC within the degenerate states with dx2−y2 and dxy characters of M′ and M′′ [20]. They further propose that W-containing MXenes might be suitable candidates for topological applications at room temperature. In contrast, they find M′2M′′2C2O2 (M′ = Mo, W; M′ = Ti, Zr, Hf) to be topological semimetals.
Several theoretical studies have investigated magnetic properties of chemically ordered double-transition-metal MXenes as function of different alloying elements and terminations. The results indicate that Cr2M′′C2T2 (M′′ = T or V; T = O, OH, or F) can be nonmagnetic (NM), antiferromagnetic (AFM), or ferromagnetic (FM) and either a semiconductor or metal depending on the choice of M′′ and T [28]. This is in contrast to the robust ferromagnetism predicted for Ti2MnC2Tx (T = O, OH, or F), Hf2MnC2O2, and Hf2VC2O2, with high magnetic moments (3–4 μB/unit cell) and high Curie temperatures (495 K–1133 K) which make them potentially interesting for spintronic applications [29]. The predicted electronic and magnetic properties can be further modified through strain. For Mn-containing MXenes, upon moderate tensile in-plane strain (0–3%), semimetal to semiconductor and ferromagnetic to antiferromagnetic phase transitions occur [29]. Yang et al. used theory to investigate Cr2M′′2C3T2 (M′′ = Ti, V, Nb, or Ta; T = OH, O, or F), upon in-plane strain (−5 to +5%), and found AFM to be favorable for M′′ = Nb and Ta at
all strains and terminations [30]. For M′′ = Ti and V, a more complex behavior was found, with preferential FM or AFM spin configuration depending on the choice of terminations [30].
Altogether, the properties of MXenes from o-MAX (electronic, electrochemical, magnetic, etc.) can be tuned through choice of the M elements and terminating species (T). It should be noted that the output from the theoretical studies are strongly influenced by the choice of MXene terminations, which has been shown by calculations to have a drastic effect on the properties. Examples thereof are preferred magnetic ground states as seen in Fig. 3.4 [30] and metallic or semiconducting behavior [16, 28]. Depending on the etching route used, multiple termination concentrations and configurations can exist. Moreover, different MXenes may have a preference for different terminations [31]. Here, experimental input with respect to the nature of the terminations and the concentration of terminating species are crucial for guidance of future realistic theoretical studies of MXenes.
Structure and Composition of i-MAX Phases
MAX phases displaying in-plane chemical ordering is a more recent addition to the MAX phase family. The discovery was made in connection to synthesis of the o-MAX phase Mo2ScAlC2 [11]. During the materials optimization process,
3 In- and Out-of-Plane Ordered MAX Phases and Their MXene Derivatives 43
evidence of a 211 phase was concluded from the XRD pattern. Considering that neither Mo2AlC nor Sc2AlC exist (based on theoretical predictions and lack of experimental observations), we assumed that a solid solution of (Mo,Sc)2AlC had formed. Targeting this new phase through iterative theoretical and experimental efforts, in particular with extensive high-resolution STEM analysis, we soon realized that the M elements displayed in-plane chemical order (see Fig. 3.5). Due to the large Z contrast (atomic mass) between Mo and Sc, there are two bright and one dark patterns in the transition metal carbide layer, which means that the ideal composition must be (Mo2/3Sc1/3)2AlC [7]. Due to a strong monoclinic distortion, the crystal structure of this phase is described with a monoclinic (C2/c) structure, though the orthorhombic (Cmcm) structure is almost degenerate in energy. The crystal structure has been confirmed by Rietveld refinement of XRD as well as neutron diffraction [7].
The subsequent findings of a range of similar in-plane chemically ordered MAX phases coined i-MAX as a collective notation for this family of materials. To date, eight i-MAX phases can be found in the literature, (Mo2/3Sc1/3)2AlC, (Mo2/3Y1/3)2AlC, (V2/3Zr1/3)2AlC, (Cr2/3Sc1/3)2AlC, (Cr2/3Y1/3)2AlC, (Cr2/3Zr1/3)2AlC, (W2/3Sc1/3)2AlC, and (W2/3Y1/3)2AlC, showing a path for introduction on nontraditional MAX phase elements in these materials (W, Y), which in turn suggests an increased range of attainable properties [32–36]. All synthesized i-MAX structures to date crystallize in one or more of the space group symmetries C/2c (#15), Cmcm (#63), and C/2m (#12), although several closely related structures of various symmetries have been theoretically demonstrated to be almost degenerate in energy [33]. The main characteristics of the i-MAX structure are the minority M elements (M2 = Sc, Y, and Zr) extending out from the M layer (M1 = Mo, V, Cr, W) toward the A layer, which in turn display Kagomé-like ordering. This is depicted in Fig. 3.6, where the i-MAX structure is compared to that of a traditional 211 MAX phase; individual layers of M (M1 + M2), A, X, and
44 J. Rosen et al.
M1 + M2 + X are shown in Fig. 3.6a–d with a structural overview of MAX (top row) and i-MAX phase (bottom row). To allow a detailed structural comparison, both MAX and i-MAX are shown with equal composition, here exemplified by (V2/3Zr1/3)2AlC. For the MAX phase, all layers display a hexagonal pattern. For the i-MAX structure, the hexagonal pattern is present only in the carbon layer (see Fig. 3.6c). The top view of the M layer (M1 + M2) also seems to form a hexagonal pattern (see Fig. 3.6a); however, the side view of the M2X layer in Fig. 3.6e shows that V (M1) and Zr (M2) do not form a single layer. Instead Zr (M2) is closer to the Al layer. This is typical for all i-MAX phases found to date, and the larger the M2 atom is, the closer it is to the A layer. The M1 layer has a honeycomb lattice with M2 located in the center of each hexagon. The major structural difference between the i-MAX and the MAX phase is found in the A layer (see Fig. 3.6b), being hexagonal for the MAX phase while closely resembling a Kagomé lattice for the i-MAX, thus reducing the A-A coordination from six to four.
Based on the theoretical and empirical analyses performed to date, rules for iMAX formation can be formulated, to increase the fundamental understanding of the origin of their formation, as well as to allow prediction of further phases to be synthesized. The formation of i-MAX phases requires (i) a 2:1 ratio for M1:M2, (ii) a significantly different size of the two metals where M2 is larger, (iii) an electron population of ideally bonding orbitals only with a minimum population of antibonding orbitals, and (iv) a small-sized A which is beneficial. Of these criteria, the first three are believed to be most important [33, 37]. Furthermore, intermixing of M can also be expected; [32] however, more work remains to show how a deviation from the ideal 2:1 ratio influence the stability and what the implications are for transformation of i-MAX into i-MXene. It should be stressed that albeit the i-MAX phases have been found with three different crystal structures, transformation into MXenes from these polymorphs will result in identical i-MXene structures.
3 In- and Out-of-Plane Ordered MAX Phases and Their MXene Derivatives 45
Synthesis and Characterization of MXene from i-MAX
All reported i-MAX phases to date are Al-based, suggesting that a range of novel MXenes can be synthesized in line with the chemical etching routes used for traditional MAX phases. Using the first i-MAX phase, (Mo2/3Sc1/3)2AlC, Tao et al. demonstrated chemical removal of not only the Al layer upon etching in HF or LiF/HCl but also selective etching of the minority M2 element Sc, realizing Mo1.33C MXene layers with ordered divacancies. A schematic of this reaction, from the iMAX phase to delaminated sheets of MXene, is shown in Fig. 3.7.
Tao et al. also verified the MXene structure of Mo1.33C by atomic resolution STEM on a single sheet of MXene. Figure 3.8a shows an overview HAADF-STEM image of a single flake with lateral dimensions >1 μm, with a medium magnification image and its fast Fourier transform seen in Fig. 3.8b. The experimentally observed pattern in Fig. 3.8c agrees strikingly well with the simulated structure of the parent MAX phase excluding Sc and Al atoms in Fig. 3.8d. A detailed description of the structure of i-MXene can be found in Ref. [38]. It can be noted that the close to ideal structure of i-MXene proves the close to ideal structure as well as composition of the parent (Mo2/3Sc1/3)2AlC. From STEM analysis of the i-MAX phase, one
46 J. Rosen et al.
can distinguish between the two different M sites, in which the M1 site is occupied by a heavier atom, indicating the chemical ordering of Mo and Sc. However, due to superposition, the micrographs do not exclude partial ordering, e.g., occupancy Mo = 0.8 and Sc = 0.2 on M1 site. Furthermore, XRD refinement is not sensitive enough to determine the occupancy on each site. Therefore, the atomic structure of i-MXene is a very strong indicator of the close to fully ordering of Mo on M1 and Sc on M2 site, as the Sc is completely removed upon etching.
Selective etching of chemically ordered i-MAX phases for synthesis of vacancyordered MXene has been shown for several compositions: removing Al and Sc/Y from (Mo2/3Sc1/3)2AlC and (Mo2/3Y1/3)2AlC both produces Mo1.33C MXene, while (W2/3Sc1/3)2AlC and (W2/3Y1/3)2AlC correspondingly yield W1.33C MXene [32, 35, 39]. Another important feature of i-MAX phases is shown through the concept of “targeted etching,” which allows removal of the A layer only, to produce in-plane chemically ordered MXene. The general concept of chemical etching is to remove more weakly bonded elements while preserving the more strongly bonded counterparts. In a typical ternary MAX phase, e.g., Ti3AlC2, Al is weakly bonded to the MX layer and can relatively easily be removed. When the etching condition is more harsh, Ti can also be removed, leaving only porous carbon. For the i-MAX phases, tuning of the bonding characteristics of the M2 atoms and Al, combined with finely adjusted etching conditions, allows formation of either an i-MXene with vacancies or a MXene with in-place chemical order, i.e., targeted etching. This has been demonstrated for (Mo2/3Y1/3)2AlC, for which atomic resolution STEM analysis of the resulting MXenes reveals either sheets with ordered vacancies or sheets with a hexagonal atomic arrangement including both Mo and Y [39]. The tuning potential of i-MAX phases as precursors for MXenes is evident when comparing the bond strength of Sc-MX and Y-MX in (Mo2/3Sc1/3)2AlC and (Mo2/3Y1/3)2AlC, respectively. Sc, which is more loosely bonded to the MX layer, can be readily etched from its i-MAX phase, while the more strongly bonded Y can be preserved in the MXene upon etching.
Surface terminations play an important role for the properties of MXenes. Typically, MXenes are terminated with -F, -O, and –OH, and this is also the case for the vacancy MXene Mo1.33C obtained from etching in HF followed by TBAOH intercalation. The chemical formula from XPS analysis is Mo1.2CO0.7(OH)0.5F1.1 · 0.4 H2Oads, with the identified primary termination being F [40]. This is in contrast to the Mo2C MXene without vacancies, with terminations being dominated by O. Lind et al. studied the effect of surface terminations on the structure and electronic properties of Mo1.33C by first-principle calculations [38]. It was found that the preferred termination sites of i-MXene, irrespective of terminating species, are located close to A but toward bridge sites defined as E (see Fig. 3.9a). E is located in between site A and B, which are the preferred sites of F and O, respectively, on Mo2C. While an O-terminated Mo1.33C MXene is shown to be unstable, a preference for F or a mixture of F and O is predicted. Mo2C, on the other hand, shows a preference for O terminations. The difference between the two MXenes is attributed to the different Mo content, where Mo contributes with electrons to both
3 In- and Out-of-Plane Ordered MAX Phases and Their MXene Derivatives 47
the C and the terminating species. For O terminations only, the vacancy MXene have a shortage of electrons, while for F terminations, with one more electron compared to O, the orbitals can be filled and the structure stabilized. The calculated electronic structure showed the highest charge density for a termination configuration of 1O:2F (close to the experimental observations) (see Fig. 3.9b), which shed some light on the measured high electrical conductivity of Mo1.33C i-MXene.
Properties of MXenes from i-MAX Phases
MXenes have previously shown potential for various applications, including electrode material for energy storage, electromagnetic shielding, catalysis, sensors, etc. The discovery of i-MAX phases and their i-MXenes is very recent, but nonetheless the properties analyzed to date are very promising.
The first i-MXene, Mo1.33C, is an excellent electrode material for supercapacitors [11, 41]. Figure 3.10a shows the cyclic voltammograms (CV) at different scan rates, and a capacitance of up to 1153 F cm−3 (339 F g−1) can be achieved with a 3-μm-thick electrode. Several broad peaks are present in the CV, leading to large deviations from rectangular shape expected from double-layer capacitance alone. Quantification of the capacitive contribution to the total current was analyzed using the approach by Wang et al. [42] and was shown to increase from 45% at 2 mV s−1 to 79% at 500 mV s−1. Thus, pseudocapacitance is the major operative mechanism for a film of the vacancy MXene, as postulated for other MXenes [43]. In a comparison between Mo1.33C and Mo2C, the former display a 65% higher capacitance and three orders of magnitude higher conductivity. See Fig. 3.10b. This difference can be attributed to the formation of ordered vacancies,
48 J. Rosen et al.
though the difference in surface terminations should also be kept in mind. At the time, the analysis showed record values in capacitance for a 2D material, raising questions of whether the vacancies enhance the capacitance by increasing the electrochemically active sites or by increasing the fraction of the electrode accessible to the electrolyte. Being the first evaluation of capacitance for a vacancy MXene, this and more fundamental questions need to be answered. It should be noted, however, that considering further optimization of the precursor i-MAX phase, the etching conditions, surface terminations, and the structure of the assembled MXene, the potential for improvement is very high. Considering the attained capacitance of up to 1500 F cm−3 for optimized Ti3C2/H2SO4 hydrogel [44], significantly increased values are expected also for Mo1.33C i-MXene.
Utilizing the promising pseudocapacitive properties, Mo1.33C i-MXene was found to be an effective material for removing cations and anions [45]. As shown
3 In- and Out-of-Plane Ordered MAX Phases and Their MXene Derivatives 49
in Fig. 3.10c, a promising desalination performance of 15 mg/g with high charge efficiency up to 95% was reported for binder-free Mo1.33C i-MXene electrodes. Notably, the compatibility of MXene for desalination of high concentration saline solution opens new application areas, such as generation of drinking water from seawater. Further, Qin et al. reported solution-processed fabrication of a Mo1.33C iMXene/conducting polymer (PEDOT) composite as electrode material for flexible supercapacitors [7], with resulting excellent electrochemical properties of flexible devices based on the composite. With only a small amount of conducting polymer, a mass ratio of MXene/polymer = 10:1, 1310 F cm−3 was achieved. The enhanced capacitance compared to the i-MXene alone is likely due to increased spacing between MXene layers. It is also suggested that the coupling between the negatively charged MXene and positively charged PEDOT may contribute to the enhanced performance, similar to the mechanism proposed for PEDOT:PSS [46].
The most recently reported W1.33C i-MXene is another promising catalyst for hydrogen evolution reaction [47]. The catalytic activity is compared to Mo1.33C iMXene and a Pt/carbon electrode in Fig. 3.10d. The overpotential follows the order W1.33C (unannealed) < Mo1.33C < W1.33C (annealed), with the overpotential of the annealed W1.33C being ≈320 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. This trend is likely related to the structure and compositional-dependent H2 adsorption free energy on the MXenes, as well as the average valance state of the surface. Thus, the optimizing potential is large, e.g., tuning the structure and composition of the MXene by changing the etching conditions and tuning the surface valence states by modifying the surface terminations. Testing the i-MXenes as catalyst for other reactions remains to be explored.
In summary, despite their recent discovery, both o-MAX and i-MAX phases and their MXenes have expanded the range of metals that can be incorporated in MAX phases and also added new MAX phase members. Their MXenes show a high promise for a range of applications, including energy storage, water purification, and as catalysts. As the number of novel phases increases steadily, these ordered materials will likely soon make a sizeable part of the known MAX phases and MXenes and also have an impact on the general 2D materials development. It is notable how readily corresponding MXenes can be derived.
There are opportunities as well as remaining questions. For example, what is the role of the ordered vacancies on the materials properties? To what extent can we control the formation of vacancies and their concentration and for which materials? Which elemental i-MAX compositions allow targeted etching, i.e., formation of chemically ordered MXenes? Future work also remains to explore these phases with respect to realization of magnetic materials, more catalysts, etc. Moreover, the finding of both o-MAX and i-MAX phases is of utmost importance for the property tuning potential of the MAX phases and their MXenes, through elemental combinations allowing new combinations of properties. Considering the high theoretical stability of these ordered materials, we suggest a potential combination thereof, i.e., phases including out-of-plane as well as in-plane chemical ordering. We coin these hypothetical phases oi-MAX while waiting for their future experimental realization.
50 J. Rosen et al.

sections.heading: Xian-Hu Zha, Jie Zhou, Per Eklund, Xiaojing Bai, Shiyu Du, and Qing Huang
Introduction
sections.text:
As a new family of two-dimensional materials, MXenes have attracted intensive attention since their discovery in 2011 [1]. Based on their abundant chemical elements and various functional groups, MXenes have been demonstrated to show widespread potential applications, such as in energy storage [2, 3], electromagnetic interference shielding [4], catalyst, sensors [5–12], etc. To date, more than 50 MXenes have been predicted to be stable [12], and more than 20 members have been synthesized from selective extraction approach [1, 13, 14]. The success of selective extraction is ascribed to the difference in reactivity and stability between the alternative sublayers of Mn+1AXn phases [15] (Mn+1AXn is also denoted as MAX, where M is an early transitional metal, A is an A group element, such as Al and Si. X is carbon and/or nitrogen, and n is generally from 1 to 3). Because of the high chemical activity of aluminum, most MXenes were synthesized from the Al-containing MAX phases [1, 13, 14]. Therefore, special interest was devoted to synthesize the Al-containing bulk precursors.
However, a variety of transition metals, such as Sc, Zr, and Hf, are inclined to form a new type of layered compounds (MC)n[Al(A)]mCm−1 instead of the Alcontaining Mn+1AlCn phases (where n value is similar in MAX; m usually equal to
Xian-Hu Zha and Jie Zhou contributed equally.
X.-H. Zha · J. Zhou · X. Bai · S. Du ( ) · Q. Huang ( ) Engineering Laboratory of Nuclear Energy Materials, Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology and Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Ningbo, Zhejiang, China e-mail: dushiyu@nimte.ac.cn; huangqing@nimte.ac.cn
P. Eklund Thin Film Physics Division, Linköping University, IFM, Linköping, Sweden
© Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2019 B. Anasori, Y. Gogotsi (eds.), 2D Metal Carbides and Nitrides (MXenes), https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-19026-2_4
53
54 X.-H. Zha et al.
3, 4, etc.; and A usually is Si or Ge) [16–18]. These layered compounds consist of alternative NaCl-type M-C and Al4C3-like Al(A)-C sublayers. Based on the lattice mismatch between the cubic MC and Al4C3 unit cells [19], the relationship between the formed layered carbide and the variety of transitional metals was proposed: the (MC)n[Al(A)]mCm−1 compound is preferred with a small lattice mismatch; otherwise, the Mn+1AlCn phase is formed. To give a more explicit picture, the structures for Mn+1AlCn, (MC)n[Al(A)]mCm−1 (n = 3; m = 3,4) unit cells are plotted and provided in Fig. 4.1. As discussed previously [20, 21], the Mn+1AlCn phase consists of the strong bonded Mn+1Xn sublayer intercalated with the weak metallic bonded Al atomic layer. For the (MC)nAl3C2 and (MC)n[Al(A)]4C3 compounds, respectively, in Fig. 4.1b, c, they can be recognized as using Al3C3 or [Al(A)]4C4 to replace the Al atomic layer in the corresponding Mn+1AlCn phase. A carbon atomic layer is shared by the M-C and Al(A)-C sublayers at their coupling boundaries. Compared to (MC)nAl3C2, (MC)n[Al(A)]4C3 unit cell generally possesses a lower space group number and a larger lattice parameter in the c-axis. According to our previous work [22, 23], this type of layered compounds (MC)n[Al(A)]mCm−1 could also be utilized as precursors for MXenes. Two MXenes Zr3C2Tx and Hf3C2Tx [22, 23] and a new 2D ScCxOH structure were developed based on selective etching of these non-MAX compounds. The details are reviewed in the following sections. Additionally, the existing (MC)n[Al(A)]mCm−1 compounds are also reviewed in this chapter.
Moreover, a non-Al-containing layered carbide Mo2Ga2C was also adopted as precursor for MXene proposed by Meshkian et al. [24] and Halim et al. [25] Compared to the MAX counterpart Mo2GaC, two Ga layers are stacked one on top of the other in Mo2Ga2C [26, 27]. The extra Ga layer causes a significant decrease of elastic modulus; that is why Mo2Ga2C could be etched different from its MAX counterpart [28]. The details are also discussed in this chapter.
4 Non-MAX Phase Precursors for MXenes 55
Synthesis of Zr3C2Tx MXene from Selective Etching Zr3Al3C5
As the first synthesized MXene, titanium carbide has been demonstrated to show promising properties and widespread applications [1–4]. For zirconium and hafnium, in the same group as titanium in the periodic table of elements, their based MXenes may also have excellent performance. According to our theoretical work, the oxygen-functionalized Zr2CO2 and Hf2CO2 are semiconductors with moderate bandgaps, and their thermal conductivities are higher than that of Ti2CO2 [8, 10]. In addition, zirconium- and hafnium-based compounds are generally hightemperature refractory materials [29]. Therefore, we are committed to synthesize these two transitional metal-containing MXenes. In contrast to titanium, zirconium and hafnium tend to form the layered compounds (MC)n[Al(A)]mCm−1, such as Zr3Al3C5 and Hf3Al4C6 [18]. As a consequence, the bulk Zr3Al3C5 was firstly adopted as a potential precursor for 2D zirconium carbide; its atomic structure is like in Fig. 4.1b. The common hydrofluoric (HF) acid was adopted as etchant.
The Zr3Al3C5 powder was prepared via pulsed electric current sintering (PECS) of Zr/Al/graphite powder mixtures. After sintering, the as-fabricated powders were predominantly single-phase Zr3Al3C5 besides a minor amount of ZrC impurities. Immerging these powders in 50 wt% HF at room temperature for 72 hours, more than 70 at% Zr3Al3C5 was found to transform into 2D structure. The corresponding scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of the etching products are shown in Fig. 4.2a, b; accordion-like structures are observed like most reported MXenes [1, 13]. After ultrasonication, the transmission electron microscope (TEM) images of few-layered structures are provided in Fig. 4.2c–e. The 2D configuration shows the
56 X.-H. Zha et al.
same symmetry and similar lattice parameter to its bulk precursor in the horizontal plane; thus the 2D configuration could be sublayer of bulk precursor as reported for MXenes [1]. Based on the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), the 2D structure shows the presence of Zr, C, O, and F, but the signal of Al in precursor is generally removed. Therefore, the Al-C units in Zr3Al3C5 were etched out, and the 2D structure was determined as zirconium carbide. Moreover, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results in the Al 2p region, and C 1s region shows significant decrease in the content of Al-C bonding (from 11.39% to 1.87%) after HF treatment, which suggests that the selective etching of Al-C layer from the primitive unit cell has occurred. Concomitantly, fitted XPS results in Zr 3d region and O 1s region imply the possible formation of zirconium carbide with mixed F, O, and OH surface termination.
Since it’s difficult to determine the carbon ratio from XPS and EDS, the affiliation of the shared carbon atomic layer post etching is not clear. Thus, the first-principles density functional theory (DFT) [30] was also adopted to investigate the atomic structure and physical properties of the etching product. Based on the Zr3Al3C5 unit cell presented in Fig. 4.2f, two models were proposed shown in Fig. 4.2g, h, respectively, denoting the shared carbon atomic layer was etched with Al-C units and retained on the etching product zirconium carbide. After structure relaxation, Model A shows a much lower energy, implying the as-synthesized 2D zirconium carbide is Zr3C2Tx MXene. The Al3C3 unit in Zr3Al3C5 was etched out, and it was then replaced by O, OH, and F surface groups in the aqueous HF solution. Based on DFT optimization, all functional groups (T = O, F, OH) are stabilized on the top sites of the middle zirconium atoms on both sides. The top view and side view of Zr3C2T2 are shown in Fig. 4.2i, j, respectively. The F- and OH-terminated configurations are metallic, and Zr3C2O2 shows semimetal property. Moreover, the oxygen-terminated configuration was predicted to show high mechanical strength, in which c11 value was calculated to be 393 GPa.
Since zirconium-based compounds are generally high-temperature refractory material [29], the thermodynamic property of synthesized Zr3C2Tx was further investigated, and the well-studied Ti3C2Tx MXene was also studied for comparison. According to Fig. 4.3, Ti3C2Tx MXene was determined to partially transform into cubic TiC above 800 ◦C, while the Zr3C2Tx MXene was found to be thermodynamically stable that even approached 1200 ◦C, the highest temperature investigated. The different stabilities were further explained with the aid of DFT calculation. The cubic TiC shows higher cohesive energy than the Ti3C2 MXene (8.741 vs 8.080 eV/atom); thus the latter is transformed into the stable cubic phase at a high temperature. In contrast, Zr3C2 MXene possesses a higher cohesive energy than its competitive cubic phase (8.483 vs 8.468 eV/atom), and it can exist stably even under the elevated temperature.
In this section, we have reviewed Ref. [22] for the synthesis of the 2D Zr3C2Tx MXene from etching of non-MAX phase Zr3Al3C5. Using this new type of layered compounds as precursors generally provides a new approach for fabricating MXenes. In addition, the as-synthesized Zr3C2Tx shows high thermal stability, which enables its potential applications range from electrode materials in electrical
4 Non-MAX Phase Precursors for MXenes 57
energy storage to sensors and catalysts, especially when served in a relatively hightemperature environment.
Synthesis of Hf3C2Tx MXene from Selective Etching Solid Solution Hf3(Al,Si)4C6
After synthesis of Zr3C2Tx MXene, we further tended to synthesize the Hf3C2Tx MXene based on the selective etching of the non-MAX precursor. The bulk Hf3Al4C6 was adopted as the precursor which has a similar structure to Fig. 4.1c. However, the main etching product of Hf3Al4C6 in the HF solutions even with different concentrations was cubic HfC phase with submicron particle size. This behavior could be ascribed to the much stronger Hf-C bonds at the etching interface in Hf3Al4C6 compared to those Zr-C bonds in Zr3Al3C5. As a consequence, activating the Al-C sublayer and weakening the interfacial adhesion between HfC and Al-C units would be beneficial to realize the selective etching process. Previously, Zhang et al. found that the solid solution of Si-Al in the silicon layer of Ti3SiC2 weakened the bonds and facilitated the exfoliation of Ti3(Si0.75Al0.25)C2 [31]. Inspired by this work, we developed a solid solution method to manipulate the interface bonding. A small amount of silicon was alloyed into the ternary HfAl-C carbide with Si on Al sites, forming a Hf3[Al(Si)]4C6 compound. Immersing the solid solution in the concentrated HF solution, a 2D hafnium-containing MXene Hf3C2Tx was produced by selective etching of [Al(Si)]4C4 sublayer from the parent Hf3[Al(Si)]4C6 compound.
To figure out why the introduction of silicon can facilitate the etching process, the adhesive energy between two detached layers implying the strength of the layer adhesion was investigated theoretically. The results implied that the adhesive
58 X.-H. Zha et al.
energy reduced significantly through silicon substitution of aluminum. To deeply understand this behavior, the atomic charges and bond lengths at the etching interfaces were studied, since the solid solution was determined to be ionic and the strength of an ionic bond was found proportional to the atomic charge and opposite to the bond length [32]. The weakening of the Hf-C bonds at the etching interface could be ascribed to the larger atomic charge of silicon (2.36) than that of aluminum (2.19). The shared carbon layer is bonded stronger with the aluminum layer after introducing silicon, and thus the adhesion of the neighboring etching interface is weakened.
The Hf3Al4C6 and Hf3[Al(Si)]4C6 powders were also synthesized by the PECS process. For the solid solution, the as-synthesized powders are mainly composed of Hf3[Al(Si)]4C6 besides a small amount of Hf2[Al(Si)]4C5 and rock salt-like cubic HfC secondary phase. After treatment with concentrated HF solution (35 wt%) at room temperature for about 60 hours, the precursor was partially converted to MXene. Meanwhile, the Hf2[Al(Si)]4C5 secondary phase converted into MXenes after the HF treatment as well. The as-synthesized Hf3[Al(Si)]4C6 phase exhibits a typical lamellar morphology (Fig. 4.4a). In contrast, delaminated few-layered thin flakes with large lateral size (2–5 μm) (Fig. 4.4b) are observed in the HFetched material after mild sonication and centrifugation. The corresponding EDS analysis of the flakes shows the presence of Hf, C, O, and F, but disappearance of the Al and Si signals. The obtained Hf/Al atomic ratio (3.0:1.3) from EDS analysis (from an area of about 2000 μm2) was used to quantify the fraction of unreacted precursor, and it was estimated that more than 65 at% of the Hf3[Al(Si)]4C6 has been transformed. Moreover, XPS results in the Al 2p region, Si 2p region, and C 1s region show significant decrease in the content of Al(Si)-C bonding (from 20.29% to 11.74%) after HF treatment, which suggests that the selective etching of Al(Si)-C layer from the primitive unit cell has occurred. Concomitantly, fitted XPS results in Hf 4f region and O1s region indicate the possible formation of Hf3C2 with mixed F, O, and OH surface termination. After sonication and centrifugation of the HF-treated powders, thin flakes with scrolled behavior can be observed (Fig. 4.4c), and corresponding EDS results confirm the presence of Hf, C, and O signals (Fig. 4.4f). The hexagonal symmetry in the basal plane was reserved (Fig. 4.4d), and the thickness of a monolayer sheet was estimated to be about 1.2 nm (Fig. 4.4e). It is interesting to note that the multilayered Hf3C2Tx materials are able to delaminate and form a stable colloidal solution in deionized water without pre-treatment with an additional intercalate agent. This behavior could be ascribed to the relatively lower adhesive energy in multilayer Hf3C2F2 compared to that of typical Ti3C2F2 MXene. From theoretical calculation, the adhesive energy in multilayer Hf3C2F2 is approximate to that in graphite [33], which is only one-quarter of that in multilayer Ti3C2F2.
The intrinsic physical properties of the as-synthesized Hf3C2Tx MXenes were further studied. From theoretical prediction, the functional groups T (T = O, F, OH) are all stabilized on the top sites of the middle hafnium atoms like in the Zr3C2T2 MXene. Similar to most MXenes [8], oxygen-terminated Hf3C2O2 presents smaller structural parameters and larger elastic constants compared to
4 Non-MAX Phase Precursors for MXenes 59
60 X.-H. Zha et al.
Hf3C2F2 and Hf3C2(OH)2. Its c11 value is predicted to be 417 GPa. Similar to Zr3C2T2 [22], both fluorine- and hydroxyl-terminated configurations are metallic, and the oxygen-functionalized one is a semimetal. Based on the Boltzmann transport theory [34], the predicted electrical conductivities σ xx/τ of the Hf3C2T2 MXenes were found in the order of 1020 −1 m−1 s−1. Due to the semimetal properties of Hf3C2O2, the electrical conductivity under various strains was investigated theoretically. Both biaxial and uniaxial strains are efficient in manipulating the magnitude of the Hf3C2O2 electrical conductivity. Moreover, the uniaxial strain could control the anisotropy of electrical conductivity [35]. As a consequence, Hf3C2O2 could be utilized in mechanical sensors.
The feasibility of using delaminated Hf3C2Tx (d-Hf3C2Tx) MXene flake-based materials as anodes in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) was further explored experimentally. Electrochemical measurements implied that the charge storage in d-Hf3C2Tx was due to the intercalation of Li+ and Na+ ions rather than a conversion reaction. It exhibited reversible volumetric capacities of 1567 mAh cm−3 and 504 mAh cm−3, respectively, for lithium- and sodium-ion batteries at a current density of 200 mA g−1 after 200 cycles (Fig. 4.5a). The performance of d-Hf3C2Tx MXene-based anode in LIBs is comparable to what was reported for Sn4+ ion decorated Ti3C2 nanocomposites (PVP-Sn(IV)@Ti3C2, 1375 mAh cm−3 after 50 cycles at 100 mA g−1) [54]. Moreover, benefiting from the improved structural/chemical stability of its interleaved architecture, the dHf3C2Tx material showed good rate performance in SIBs; the electrode had a stable charge/discharge cycle with no obvious capacity loss (312 mAh cm−3@1A g−1, 10 cycles) even at 1 A g−1 (Fig. 4.5b). These results suggest that d-Hf3C2Tx with 2D structure is a candidate anode material for metal-ion intercalation, especially for applications where size matters.
In this section, the synthesis of 2D Hf3C2Tx MXene and corresponding physical properties were reviewed, which details are presented in Ref. [23]. Based on the
4 Non-MAX Phase Precursors for MXenes 61
special configuration of bulk precursor with a carbon atomic layer shared by the MC and Al-C units, a solid solution approach was adopted to manipulate the interface adhesion to facilitate the selective etching process. Based on this technique, it is anticipated that many new 2D structures will be realized. Regarding the synthesized Hf3C2Tx MXene, it shows relatively high volumetric capacities in lithium- and sodium-ion batteries. In addition, the Hf3C2Tx MXene has abundant electrons that may be important for catalysis and electromagnetic interference shielding applications beyond energy storage.
Synthesis of ScCxOH from Selective Etching ScAl3C3
Additionally, 2D scandium carbide Sc2CT2 (T = O, F, OH) was predicted as the only MXene member showing semiconducting regardless of functional group [8, 36]. Special interest was devoted to synthesize the 2D scandium carbide. Since scandium is inclined to form ScAl3C3 rather than Al-containing MAX phase [17], the ternary ScAl3C3 compound was adopted as the precursor. However, it was found that ScAl3C3 was easily dissolved in HF acid and formed in ScFx because the scandium and fluorine showed strong affinity. Thus, an alternative aqueous organic base tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAOH) was adopted as etchant. Based on this procedure, we successfully obtained a new hydroxyl-terminated scandium carbide ScCxOH. We summarize the results here. For more details, please refer to Ref. [37].
The ScAl3C3 precursor was also synthesized by the PECS process. Its crystallites show typical plate-like morphology for layered materials. After treatment with aqueous TMAOH solution, most ScAl3C3 was converted to corresponding 2D structure. Sonication and centrifugation of the etched powders resulted in the separation of the flakes. Thin folded flexible flakes are obtained, in contrast to the relatively flat morphology with large in-plane stiffness typical of previously reported MXenes [1]. The measured value of the in-plane lattice parameter is approximately that of the original ScAl3C3 crystal, showing that the hexagonal crystal structure of the ScAl3C3 basal planes was inherited by the 2D sheets. According to the XPS measurement, the etched sample could be ScCx with a mixture of OH, Al(OH)4− surface groups and intercalated TMA+ ions. Monochromated STEMEELS was employed to evaluate the optical properties, and the valence EELS (VEELS) properties of the ScC sheet were acquired. The particle was determined to exhibit a direct bandgap of about 2.55 eV. Furthermore, as-synthesized few-layer ScC photodetecting device exhibits excellent photoresponse properties in the visible light region. Its responsivity and quantum efficiency are comparative with that of traditional pure GaN detector (0.148 A W−1, 51%) [38].
In this section, the synthesis of a 2D scandium carbide and corresponding physical properties is discussed. The 2D configuration is synthesized by selective etching of Al3C2 sublayers from the parent ScAl3C3 compound in aqueous organic base solution. This configuration is a semiconductor with an experimentally measured
62 X.-H. Zha et al.
direct bandgap of ~2.5 eV. In addition, a photodetecting device made from ScCxOH few layers exhibits excellent photoresponse properties in the visible-light region. This as-synthesized semiconductor has possible applications of 2D transitional metal carbides in optoelectronic and within photocatalytic chemistry.

sections.heading: The Existing (MC)n[Al(A)]mCm−1 Phases
sections.text:
According to the discussions above, the (MC)n[Al(A)]mCm−1 compounds could be potential precursors for MXenes and other 2D layered carbides. To facilitate the synthesis of more 2D layered carbides, the existing potential precursors (MC)n[Al(A)]mCm−1 are reviewed in this section. Experimental investigations have identified more than 30 (MC)n[Al(A)]mCm−1 members. Specifically, ThAl4C4 [39], Zr2Al3C4, Zr3Al3C5, Hf2Al3C4, Hf3Al3C5 [18], ScAl3C3 [40], U2Al3C4 [41], UAl3C3, and YbAl3C3 [42] have been reported many years ago, while LuAl3C3 [43], YAl3C3 [44], CeAl3C3, DyAl3C3, ErAl3C3, TmAl3C3 [45], ZrAl4C4 [46], ZrAl8C7 [47], Zr2Al4C5, Zr3Al4C6 [48], Zr2[Al(Si)]4C5 [49], Zr3[Al(Si)]4C6 [50], [(ZrY)]2Al4C5 [51], Zr2[Al(Ge)]4C5, Zr3[Al(Ge)]4C6 [52], Zr[Al(Si)]8C7, Zr[Al(Si)]4C4 [53], Hf2Al4C5, Hf3Al4C6 [54], and HfAl4C4 [55] were developed after 2006. All these existing members and their space groups are listed in Table 4.1. The crystal structure of these carbides can be described as an intergrowth structure of layers with NaCl-type M-C and Al4C3-like Al3C2/[Al(A)]4C3 sharing a carbon monolayer at their coupling boundaries [16]. The electronic characteristics and intrinsic properties of the M-C and Al-C slabs in (MC)n[Al(A)]mCm−1 crystal were comparable with those of the corresponding binary carbides MC and Al4C3, respectively. Generally, the MC layers are chemically stable, which is similar to those of the Mn+1Xn layers in MAX phases [16, 56, 57]. The Al4C3 is prone to hydrolysis in humid air or acidic media. Therefore, compared with M-C slabs, the Al-C units have relatively weaker bonding and higher chemical reactivity. In the past decade, many progress were toward developing synthesis methods for the layered (MC)n[Al(A)]mCm−1 compounds [16]. Several approaches were developed, including arc melting [18], solid state reaction [49], pulsed electric current sintering (PECS) [58], and reactive hot pressing [59].
Synthesis of Mo2CTx MXene from Selective Etching of Mo2Ga2C
As predicted by Khazaei et al., Mo2CTx may be a promising thermoelectric material [56]. Therefore, many efforts were devoted to synthesize this material. Although Mo2GaC had been synthesized as early as 1967 [60], challenges still exist by selective etching of this compound. In 2015, Hu et al. synthesized a new type of
4 Non-MAX Phase Precursors for MXenes 63
layered carbide Mo2Ga2C wherein two Ga layers instead of one are stacked between Mo2C layers [61]. The atomic structure of Mo2Ga2C and its stability had been well studied [26–28, 61]. In Hu’s work, they synthesized two forms for this compound: thin film and bulk. The thin film was grown by direct current magnetron sputtering of elemental targets on MgO(111) substrates, and the bulk state was synthesized by heating the mixture of Mo2C and Ga. The details can be referred to Ref. [62]. It was demonstrated that the Mo2Ga2C compound also belongs to the hexagonal lattice (space group is P63/mmc), with a and c lattice parameters of 3.05 and 18.19 Å, respectively. The EDX maps of the synthesized Mo2Ga2C compound are shown in Fig. 4.6a–f, wherein two Ga layers are located exactly on top of each other.
In the same year, Meshkian et al. adopted the Mo2Ga2C thin film as the precursor for the synthesis of Mo2C MXene [24]. By immerging the film in 50 wt% concentrated hydrofluoric acid solution for 3 hours at a temperature of 50 ◦C, the Ga layer was evidently etched out, and the Mo2CTx MXene was obtained eventually (Fig. 4.6). The retained Ga layer is caused by the difficulty of etching Ga from Mo2GaC that coexists with Mo2Ga2C. This is the first work on synthesis of MXene from the non-Al-containing layered carbides. Moreover, this is also the first report on the synthesis of Mo-containing MXene.
Later, Halim et al. also synthesized the Mo2CTx MXene through selective etching of Mo2Ga2C. Differently, they chose the bulk Mo2Ga2C as precursor and tested two different etchants, LiF + HCl and HF acid [25]. Based on the LiF + HCl solution, they produced less defective flakes. By testing the electrical transport property, they found that the Mo2CTx shows semiconductor-like behavior [25], in contrast to Ti3C2Tx which shows metallic [62]. Moreover, the Mo2CTx shows promising applications in supercapacitors and batteries. For electrodes in supercapacitors, a capacity as high as 700 F cm−3 is obtained in a 1 M sulfuric acid electrolyte and high capacity retention for at least 10,000 cycles at 10 A g−1. When acting as electrode materials for Li-ion battery, the free-standing films intercalated with ~8 wt% carbon nanotubes show stable reversible capacities of 250 and 76 mAh g−1, respectively, at 20 and 131 C cycling rates.
64 X.-H. Zha et al.
In this section, the synthesis of Mo2CTx from selective etching of non-Alcontaining layered carbide Mo2Ga2C was reviewed. The synthesized Mo2CTx shows semiconductor-like behavior and promising applications in supercapacitors and Li-ion batteries. This work generally opens a door to synthesize MXenes from selective etching of the Ga-containing layered carbides.
4 Non-MAX Phase Precursors for MXenes 65

sections.heading: Summary
sections.text: In summary, we had developed a new approach to synthesize MXenes by using layered compounds (MC)n[Al(A)]mCm−1 instead of MAX phases as precursors. Based on this type of precursors, forming solid solution was determined to be an efficient technique to manipulate the sublayer adhesion, which facilitated the selective extraction process. Based on this approach, two fascinating MXenes Zr3C2Tx and Hf3C2Tx were synthesized and found to show potential applications such as electrode materials, sensors, catalysts, and refractory coatings. Moreover, a new 2D hydroxyl-terminated scandium carbide was also developed. Based on the large family of (MC)n[Al(A)]mCm−1 compounds, our developed approach will further enrich MXene members. Moreover, the Mo2CTx had been successfully synthesized from the non-Al-containing layered carbide Mo2Ga2C. The non-MAX phase with double instead of single A-atomic layer as in MAX phases could also be candidate precursors for MXenes. We look forward to the synthesis of new 2D transition metal carbides with novel structure and properties in the near future.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Two-dimensional (2D) transition metal carbides, nitrides, and carbonitrides, commonly known as MXenes, have continually gained interest since the discovery of the first MXene in 2011, due to their tunable structures, wide variety of properties, and performance in an extensive set of applications. The material family is composed of approximately 20 experimentally produced MXenes, and many more are theoretically predicted.
MXenes have a general formula of Mn+1Xn, where M is an early transition metal (Ti, Nb, V, Mo, Ta, Cr, Hf, Zn, Sc, etc.), X represents carbon (C) and/or nitrogen (N), and n is from 1 to 3, representing the three common structures (M2X, M3X2, and M4X3). Recently, the family has grown to include more structures by design, including ordered and solid solutions of double-M MXenes (M′2M′′C2 and M′2M′′2C3) and ordered vacancies, such as Mo1.33C. After synthesis, MXenes reported so far have surface terminations, such as hydroxyl (OH), oxygen (O), and fluorine (F), rendering their surfaces hydrophilic and additionally making them easier to solution-process in aqueous or organic systems, deposit as thin or freestanding films, or collect as highly concentrated slurries or powders.
Since the first successful selective extraction of Al from Ti3AlC2 to produce Ti3C2, top-down synthesis methods have been the primary route used to produce MXenes. Here, a top-down method refers to the process where a bulk material or powder is reduced, made smaller, or part of the bulk structure is removed, leaving micro- to nano-sized particles. A few examples of top-down routes consist of lithography, polishing, and wet chemical etching. This chapter will overview

69

current top-down wet chemical etching methods used to synthesize MXenes, general processing and properties which should be expected after each synthesis route, an overview of current challenges, and a perspective for the future.
General Synthesis Approach for Top-Down Selective Etching of Al
Methods of producing (2D) materials vary across literature, but almost all require exfoliation from bulk layered materials which have strong in-plane bonding and weak out-of-plane bonding [1, 2]. A common example of this is exfoliation of graphite, where graphite must be sheared mechanically or expanded chemically to break the weak out-of-plane bonding and produce an atomically thin sheet of material, known as graphene [3]. The production of 2D materials, such as graphene, transition metal dichalcogenides, transition metal oxides, hexagonal boron nitride, etc., has been achieved mechanically by scotch tape, ball milling, shearing, etc. and chemically by ion intercalation or sonication/dispersion in solvent, polymer, or surfactant-assisted solutions [4]. Mechanical exfoliation, such as exfoliation of graphite into 2D graphene, has been applied on MAX phase layered precursors to try to synthesize MXenes but failed to break the metallic M–A bonds [4, 5]. Therefore, most of the synthesis procedures described to date use top-down or wet chemical etching to produce MXenes.
Top-down synthesis of MXene begins by etching the parent layered precursor (discussed in Chaps. 2, 3, and 4), which can be a MAX phase or non-MAX phase precursor (Fig. 5.1). The first MXene, titanium carbide (Ti3C2), was produced
5 Top-Down MXene Synthesis (Selective Etching) 71
through selective etching of Al from Ti3AlC2 (MAX) using hydrofluoric acid (HF) [6]. Since then, top-down synthesis routes using HF, or forming HF in situ using fluoride solutions, have been critical to producing many MXenes from the layered precursors [7]. Currently, most top-down synthesis methods for MXene still rely on fluoride-based etchants because of the selectivity to etch the A element; however, there have been reports of alternative synthesis methods using molten salts, alkaline solutions, and/or hydrothermal treatments, broadening the synthesis routes as well as resulting properties.
Regardless of the etchant, the surface of the material is not pristine and is often decorated with various concentrations of surface functionalities (Fig. 5.1, e.g., material shown with -OH termination). Fluorine (F), hydroxyl (OH), and oxygen (O) are the typical surface groups observed on any given MXene surface, and the concentration of each one has been shown to be dependent on the synthesis method [6, 8, 9]. Additionally, nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) measurements showed that instead of regions or areas that are monodisperse in termination, random distributions of surface terminations are more realistic [8]. The surfaces that are created as a result of selectively etching A elements have been theoretically predicted to determine many material properties, such as electronic band structure, optical absorption, and chemical reactivity [10–13].
To date, around 22 different MXenes have been synthesized and dozens have been predicted [11], making it one of the most rapidly evolving 2D material families [7, 11, 14, 15]. Table 5.1 summarizes the current synthesis methods for creating MXenes from Al-containing layered precursors, which can be categorized into five categories: (i) HF, (ii) HF-forming, (iii) HF-containing (mixed acid) etchants, (iv) molten-salt etching techniques, and (v) alkaline and/or hydrothermal treatments.

sections.heading: HF Etchants
sections.text:
Exposing a layered precursor (e.g., Ti3AlC2) to concentrated solutions of aqueous HF (50 wt%) was the first approach shown to weaken the M–A metallic bonds as well as retain the strength of the M–X bonds, leading to etching of the A layer (mostly Al) from different Mn+1AXn systems (M = Ti, Nb, Ta, V) [6]. Top-down selective etching utilizing fluorine-containing etchants has been proposed to involve the following reaction where the reaction of Ti3AlC2 with HF is used as an example:
Ti3AlC2 + 3HF = AlF3 + ( 3
2
) H2 + Ti3C2 (5.1)
During this reaction, the aluminum layers are removed in between individual Ti3C2 layers, resulting in the loss of metallic bonding between Ti and Al [47]. The exposure time in HF has varied in literature from a few hours to days and the etching temperature from room temperature (~ 22 ◦C) to higher temperatures,
72 K. Maleski and M. Alhabeb
5 Top-Down MXene Synthesis (Selective Etching) 73
such as ~ 50 ◦C [7]. For example, extraction of Al from Ti3AlC2 using HF showed that as low as 2 hours of exposure time was sufficient, as shown in Figure 5.2 [27]. Changing the concentration of HF from low (~3 wt% HF to 7 wt% HF) has also shown changes in the defect concentration of the materials produced, with higher numbers of defects present with increasing HF content in the etchant solution (also discussed in Chap. 7) [32]. In addition to the etching time, etchant concentration, and temperature, there are many layered precursors, each with different structures and compositions; therefore, the synthesis route to selectively etch Al may differ. In general, thinner Mn+1AXn lamellas (n = 1) require less exposure time to HF than the thicker counterparts (n = 2 or 3).
In addition to MXenes listed in Table 5.1, new MXene members (Hf3C2 and Mo1.33C) have been recently synthesized from Hf3(AlSi)4C6 and (Mo0.67Sc0.33)2AlC using HF [22, 43]. MXenes synthesized from selectively etching with HF acid, regardless of concentration, exhibit surfaces terminated with -F and -OH more than -O groups [24].

sections.heading: HF-Forming Etchants
sections.text:
Due to HF being extremely dangerous and harmful to the environment, alternatives were found to lessen the quantity of HF and make the reaction safer. HF can be formed via hydrolysis of bifluoride salts or via the reaction of a fluoride salt with
74 K. Maleski and M. Alhabeb
acid, and both routes have been used to prepare in situ HF etchants for selective etching of MAX phase precursors. Sodium bifluoride, potassium bifluoride, and ammonium bifluoride were used in the synthesis of Ti3C2 through selective etching of Al from Ti3AlC2 [37, 48]. Also, reacting fluoride salts such as lithium fluoride (LiF) with an acid, such as hydrochloric acid (HCl), have been used to synthesize Ti3C2 and Mo2C [30, 49].
When reacting LiF with HCl, the fluoride salt must act as the limiting reagent [14]. In comparison to using only HF as the etchant, MXene synthesized with HF-forming etchants exhibit larger interlayer spacing attributed to intercalation of cations of fluoride or bifluoride salts used to prepare the etchants. Although this route is preferred due to less time required to achieve delamination, MXene synthesized with this route often contains unetched MAX, and the yield is a major issue when it comes to scalability. In LiF/HCl etching routes, the amount or concentration of HF and LiCl produced as well as the excess HCl remaining is dependent on the molarity of both reactants. Therefore, the scalability of these methods is an issue considering the yield of exfoliated MXene will also contain a portion of unetched MAX [14, 30].
In 2014, Ghidiu et al. showed that in situ HF etchants using LiF/HCl resulted in processable Ti3C2 MXene due to the presence of an intercalant (Li+) in the etchant solution [30]. The presence of intercalants in both methods, HF etching and DMSO intercalation as well as LiF/HCl etching, facilitated exfoliation of Ti3C2 into single flakes after sonication [28, 30]. Due to sonication, the lateral size of the resultant flakes was on the nanoscale, ranging in size of a few hundred nanometers [28, 30]. Because the lateral size of exfoliated material is dependent on the starting grain size
5 Top-Down MXene Synthesis (Selective Etching) 75
of the parent MAX (usually 10–15 μm), producing, separating, and transferring a single flake with nanometer-size lateral dimensions makes studying properties of a single flake of MXene a challenge.
One approach to tackle this challenge was through optimization of the etching methods to make the flakes larger in lateral size (Fig. 5.3). This was accomplished through changing the concentration of exchanged cations since the intercalation process in the LiF/HCl method depends on the concentration of H+ exchanged with Li+ [14, 31]. Thus, instead of using 5 M LiF in 6 M HCl per mole of Ti3AlC2,
76 K. Maleski and M. Alhabeb
the improved method utilized 12 M LiF in 9 M HCl. The materials produced had an increase in lateral size (4–5 μm), and the delamination was achieved without sonication (Fig. 5.3) [14]. Optimizing the approach where sonication is optional was named minimally intensive layer delamination (MILD) [14, 31]. Another advantage of MILD method is the higher yield of exfoliated MXene (10–15%) rather than around 5% in the “clay” LiF/HCl method [30], as well as enabling the study of single-flake Ti3C2 properties [31, 32].

sections.heading: HF-Containing Etchants
sections.text: In addition to HF or in situ HF, etchants based on acid mixtures containing a lower concentration of HF (5–10 wt%) can be used. Etchants based on HF/HCl have been used to synthesize Mo2TiC2 and Mo2Ti2C3 from Mo2TiAlC2 and Mo2Ti2AlC3 MAX phases, respectively [42]. Intercalation of TBAOH into Mo2TiC2 and Mo2Ti2C3 MXenes, followed by manual shaking and washing of the intercalants, resulted in stable colloidal solutions of MXene [42]. Using the HF/HCl synthesis route has proven to be more controllable in terms of the etchant ingredients and quantity of HF used, making it advantageous compared to etching with HF alone.

sections.heading: Molten-Salt Etchants
sections.text: Aqueous acidic solutions, similar to those which have been used in the previous sections, have proven unsuccessful in etching nitride-based MAX phases. This was hypothesized to be because the calculated cohesion energies are lower for nitride MXenes than carbides and the formation energies of nitride MXenes from nitride-based MAX phase is higher than that of carbide MXene from carbide-based MAX phase [46]. In contrast to the methods mentioned above, nitride MXenes, specifically Ti4N3, have been produced through selective etching of Al from Ti4AlN3 by using molten salts, such as potassium fluoride (KF), lithium fluoride (LiF), and sodium fluoride (NaF) [46]. To etch, the molten salt and Ti4AlC3 mixture was heated to 550 ◦C in argon for 30 minutes, potentially supplying the reaction with more energy to overcome the differences in bonding between metals in a nitridebased MAX phase [46]. To remove residues and excess fluorides after etching, the powders were mixed with sulfuric acid (H2SO4) solutions and repeatedly washed to remove the compounds. Using molten salts to etch Si from Ti3SiC2 has been reported; however, the material after etching did not result in Ti3C2 MXene and was identified as nonstoichiometric Ti–C rock salt structures [50].

sections.heading: Alkaline and/or Hydrothermal Treatment
sections.text:
Alkaline etchants may be effective in etching Ti3AlC2 or other layered precursors due to the alkali’s strong binding ability with Al. In some cases, higher temperatures
5 Top-Down MXene Synthesis (Selective Etching) 77
or pressures are necessary to remove Al in alkaline environment and are used with hydrothermal treatment.
By pretreating the Ti3AlC2 powders in low-concentration (10–20 wt%) HF solution for 30 minutes, then immersing in tetramethylammonium hydroxide solution (TMAOH), Ti3C2 was formed [51]; however, this technique still relies on the exposure of HF and TMAOH has not been shown to directly selectively etch Al from Ti3AlC2. It is best to note that if the alkaline treatments did succeed in selective etching of Al from Ti3AlC2, it would result in the formation of aluminum oxide/hydroxide layers on the surface, instead of producing Ti3C2 alone, and would require an additional step to clean the surface and remove these compounds [51].
One of the first reports of synthesis by hydrothermal treatment used a mixture of Ti3AlC2 and ammonium fluoride (NH4F) in a sealed Teflon-lined autoclave while heating at 150 ◦C for 24 hours [52]. Through the combination of alkali and hydrothermal treatments, fluoride-free etchants have been proposed, such as using sodium hydroxide (NaOH) followed by H2SO4 hydrothermal treatment. In this case, the Al layers were only removed from the outer surface of Ti3AlC2 resulting in an incomplete etching [53]. More recently, Ti3C2 was reported to be synthesized through the alkali-assisted hydrothermal treatment of Ti3AlC2 in concentrated NaOH, where the resulting material is free of fluorine terminations [38]. In this treatment, also known as the Bayer process, concentrated NaOH solutions were used under elevated temperatures and pressures to readily attack Al layers in Ti3AlC2 through oxidation of Al into aluminum oxide/hydroxides followed by dissolution of the aluminum compounds into the alkali solution, leaving a Ti3C2 MXene terminated with only -OH and -O groups [38].

sections.heading: Selective Etching of Ga, Si, and Other A Elements
sections.text:
From the layered precursors used to perform top-down synthesis, most of the MXenes produced have been etched from Al-containing MAX or non-MAX phases [6, 7, 54]. This may be due to the lowest reduction potential of Al in comparison to all other A elements and thus the ability of HF-based etchants to weaken the M–A (A = Al) bonds in contrast to other A elements, such as Si, Ge, In, or Sn. This may also explain why Ti3AlC2 is the precursor of choice to synthesize Ti3C2, rather than Ti3SiC2 or Ti3GeC2, for example (Table 5.1).
The first MXene produced through the selective etching of a layered precursor which contained an A element other than Al was Mo2C from Mo2Ga2C, a nonMAX phase precursor (Table 5.2). Since the etching of Ga from Mo2Ga2C, HF etching of the A layer other than Al from Mn+1AXn systems has been a challenge [7]. This has been hypothesized to be because of differences in etching kinetics and dissolution of the A layer by HF [5]. For example, HF is known to etch and dissolve Al as well as SiO2 but not Si [57]. However, more recently, it was found that exposure of Ti3SiC2 to etchants consisting of HF/oxidant mixtures led to the etching of a non-Al layer from Mn+1AXn and Ti3C2 was synthesized (Fig. 5.4

Various oxidants such as hydrogen peroxide, ammonium persulfate, potassium permanganates, iron tetrachlorides, and nitric acid were mixed separately with HF, and all have shown selectivity to etching Si from Ti3SiC2 [56]. sections.heading: Large-Scale Production and Processing of MXenes
sections.text: After synthesis, the processing parameters implemented should vary depending on the synthesis method performed, the anticipated flake size or morphology, the media or solvent, as well as the desired properties and eventual application. Conventionally, delamination of the MXene multilayered powders must be considered in order to create two-dimensional MXene sheets which can be vacuum filtered to create free-standing films, spray-, spin-, or dip-coated to fabricate thin films, drop cast for single-flake measurements, or formulate into conductive ink compositions or polymer, metal, or ceramic composites. Delamination often occurs in MXene through a process of intercalation, or insertion of cations, organic molecules, or large organic bases [28, 30, 59, 60], followed by washing, optional sonication, and centrifugation to separate delaminated materials from those materials which stay as multilayered powders.

sections.heading: Exfoliation (Delamination) of MXene Single Flakes
sections.text: Layered precursors (e.g., Ti3C2 from Ti3AlC2 MAX phase) exhibit an expanded morphology as well as hydrophilic surfaces after exposure to HF. However, liquid exfoliation of MXene into single flakes has been achieved only after preintercalation of material with large organic molecules, such as dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), to weaken the interlayer interactions and separate flakes from one another [28]. The intercalation steps have been shown to be crucial in producing aqueous colloidal solutions of MXenes which can then be processed and fabricated into freestanding MXene films [28, 29]. In addition to this route, other methods have been shown to delaminate material without sonication such as with organic intercalants (e.g., tetraalkylammonium hydroxides) [14, 60]. Intercalation and delamination techniques will be discussed in Chaps. 10 and 11 and for simplicity will be mentioned here and developed more in later chapters.

sections.heading: Dispersion in Aqueous or Organic Media
sections.text:
In general, dispersions of MXene in aqueous and organic solutions can be realized after delamination [28, 61]. The surface charge of Ti3CN, V2C, and Ti3C2 has
80 K. Maleski and M. Alhabeb
been studied and displays negative zeta potentials over a wide range of pH values, suggesting the facile dispersion of these MXenes in neutral solutions [25, 60]. Ease in dispersibility allows for formulation of MXene with other nanomaterials or polymers by simple mixing, solvent exchange, or self-assembly [42, 62–64].
Additionally, Ti3C2 can be dispersed in a variety of organic solvents, preferring polar protic and aprotic solvents such as ethanol, propylene carbonate, and dimethylformamide (Fig. 5.5a, c) [61]. By measuring the absorbance per path length (A/l) of each dispersion, the relative concentrations were compared and showed that MXenes disperse best in solvents with similar Hildebrand solubility parameter (~27 MPa1/2), as shown by the Gaussian distribution in Fig. 5.5b. It is expected that the overall dispersibility will change with changes in surface chemistry or synthesis method.

sections.heading: Fabrication of Films
sections.text: Stable colloidal solutions or dispersions can be readily used to deposit MXenes (Fig. 5.6) by spray coating [65, 66], spin or dip coating [67], rolling [68], or vacuum filtration [14]. Rheological characterization paired with solution processability charts of aqueous Ti3C2 MXene dispersions showed low concentrations of Ti3C2 in water could be best for spray coating, and in comparison higher concentrations may be better suited for inkjet printing [69]. The ability to fabricate films, electrodes, inks, paints, etc. enabled the use of MXenes in a variety of applications, many of which are discussed in more detail in other chapters of this book.

sections.heading: Storage Conditions
sections.text:
Even regarding the hydrophilic nature and dispersibility in a wide range of media, MXenes have shown degradation in aqueous media over time. Depending on the MXene, it is possible that the degradation mechanisms may be different; however, in the presence of water, Ti3C2 MXene degrades to a cloudy-white solution of anatase titanium dioxide (TiO2) [70]. Degradation determines the lifetime of the material and the resulting properties; therefore, efforts focused on methods to control, suppress, or stop oxidation of the material are necessary.
Specifically, the environment where the solution is stored plays a critical role in its self-life. It was shown that material dispersed in deionized water, stored in air at ambient temperature, degraded faster than samples stored in argon-sealed vials at low temperature (~4 ◦C), which remained almost unchanged over the course of 28 days [71]. It is best to note that this process is dependent on concentration and higher-concentration solutions will degrade slower than their low-concentration
5 Top-Down MXene Synthesis (Selective Etching) 81
counterparts. Another way to mitigate or slow oxidation is to use organic solvents – keeping the material away from an aqueous environment [61]. Therefore, while the material degrades over time, there are strategies to overcome the fast degradation and keep material for longer periods of time (>1 month).
82 K. Maleski and M. Alhabeb

sections.heading: Scalability and Large-Scale Production
sections.text:
While research into synthesis and processing methods have advanced since the discovery of the first MXene in 2011, scalability and mass production efficiency will be necessary to move from research to industry-scale development and implementation. Graphene, a comparable 2D material, can be mass-produced in both large-scale growth or large-scale exfoliation; however, liquid exfoliation techniques require either organic solvent dispersions, surfactants, or polymer/protein stabilizers to achieve high concentrations [72–75]. In comparison, the synthesis of MXenes is scalable, and a single batch of ~100 g of Ti3C2 using laboratory pilot plants was achieved utilizing wet-selective etching and exfoliation techniques [14]. Relying on large-scale growth of MXene films has yet to be realized but would drastically advance the potential in MXene electronics, biomedicine, electromagnetic shielding, wireless communication, etc. and greatly improve large-scale production capabilities.
5 Top-Down MXene Synthesis (Selective Etching) 83

sections.heading: Summary and Vision
sections.text:
Two-dimensional transition metal carbides, nitrides, and carbonitrides synthesized since 2011 have largely relied on wet chemical etching to selectively remove A elements from the bulk layered precursors. From the top-down synthesis routes, various MXene compositions are available and new compositions are appearing rapidly. Even within the same MXene and layered precursor (e.g., Ti3C2 from Ti3AlC2), there are many ways to selectively etch the material, each resulting in slightly different surface terminations, properties, and target applications.
In general, the synthesis and processing can be tuned for each MXene to create material which is best for the job. For electronic applications, where less defects and large area flakes are necessary, less aggressive and harsh etchants are suggested, to produce free-standing films or thin films which are highly conductive (similar to metals). Less defective and large flakes have been used or theoretically predicted to be promising in optic, electronic, and electromagnetic applications (Chap. 7) such as transistors, transparent conductors, broadband and nonlinear saturable absorbers, photonic diodes, femtosecond lasers, terahertz detectors, and electromagnetic interference shielding, where conductivity and thin film uniformity play a vital role in the performance. In opposition, nanometer-scale flakes which are smaller in lateral size and exhibit more edges available for reactions or plasmonic activity will be applicable in applications such as catalysis, gas sensing, SERS substrates, light to heat materials, and biomedical photothermal therapy. The broad spectrum of applications of MXenes shows the diversity in possible properties (Fig. 5.7) [76].
In summary, material properties and promising applications are strongly dependent on synthesis method, morphology, structure, and composition of the MXene as well as the quantity and type of surface termination. Future investigations may include the effect of precursor on properties, synthesis of termination-free MXenes with pristine surfaces, the production and characterization of more carbonitride and nitride MXenes, and the optimization of top-down synthesis routes which utilize selective etching of layered precursors with non-Al A elements. Advances toward MXene materials with controllable and tunable properties has been realized through optimization of top-down synthesis methods over the course of the past 8 years; however, progress is inevitable, warranted, and essential to continue development of this large family of two-dimensional materials.
84 K. Maleski and M. Alhabeb

sections.heading: Bottom-Up Synthesis of 2D Transition Metal Carbides and Nitrides
sections.text: Chuan Xu, Long Chen, Zhibo Liu, Hui-Ming Cheng, and Wencai Ren

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
In Chap. 5, a top-down method is introduced for synthesizing a series of MXenes, the functionalized 2D transition metal carbides (TMCs) and nitrides (TMNs). This method is easy to scale up for mass production. However, the use of HF or LiF/HCl solution in this process makes the MXene surface terminated with various functional groups and introduces defects [1]. Moreover, the mechanical vibration or sonication would make the MXene smaller and introduce more defects. These chemical modification and mechanical damage of MXenes have hindered the studies on the intrinsic properties of 2D TMCs and TMNs. In addition, the structure and species of MXenes are limited by the mother 3D MAX phase materials. As summarized in Ref. [1], all the MXenes synthesized up to now have structures of M2X, M3X2, and M4X3. However, this method could not be used to synthesize MXenes with MX structure such as MoC, MoN, NbC, NbN, etc. These MX-structured materials are an important class of TMCs and TMNs with many intriguing properties, in which those with rock salt structure are mostly superconductors with high transition temperature [2] and those with simple hexagonal WC structure have been theoretically predicted and experimentally demonstrated to be topological semimetals [3–5]. Therefore, developing new synthesis methods is highly desired for improving the quality and expanding the family of 2D TMCs and TMNs.
Mechanical exfoliation [6] is the most reliable method for synthesizing highquality 2D materials from their 3D counterparts that have layered structure attracted with weak van der Waals force between the adjacent layers. Unfortunately, mechanical exfoliation is infeasible for the synthesis of 2D TMCs and TMNs because
