89
90 C. Xu et al.
both TMCs and TMNs are non-layered materials [2]. Alternatively, bottom-up synthesis method has been widely demonstrated to be an efficient way to synthesize a broad range of 2D materials including graphene, h-BN, and transition metal chalcogenides. Compared to top-down synthesis methods, bottom-up methods are more suitable for the synthesis of large-area high-quality 2D materials. In addition, these methods are very flexible and, for instance, can be used to directly grow heterostructures of 2D materials. More importantly, these methods can grow atomically thin non-layered materials. Recently, a variety of bottom-up methods have been developed to synthesize various 2D TMCs and TMNs [7–20], including chemical vapor deposition (CVD), template method, and plasma-enhanced pulsed laser deposition (PEPLD). This has greatly promoted the studies on the intrinsic structure and properties as well as technological applications of 2D TMCs and TMNs [7–10, 13–18, 20–23].
In this chapter, we will first introduce the three bottom-up synthesis methods of 2D TMCs (including their heterostructures with graphene) and 2D TMNs. Then, the microstructure of the samples synthesized by these methods will be discussed. Finally, their properties, in particular superconductivity, and applications including electrocatalysts, Li-ion batteries, and supercapacitors will be introduced.

sections.heading: Bottom-Up Synthesis Methods
sections.text:
Chemical Vapor Deposition: 2D TMCs and TMNs
In 2015, Xu et al. [7] first reported a CVD method to fabricate high-quality ultrathin 2D TMC crystals by using a bilayer metal foil substrate. Figure 6.1a shows the schematic of the CVD process of 2D Mo2C crystals and the atomic model of 2D Mo2C crystals with different thicknesses. An ultrathin Cu foil (10 μm thick) was first stacked on the top of a Mo foil as the growth substrate, and then the substrate was heated to above the melting point of copper (1085 ◦C) in hydrogen (H2), which enables the diffusion of Mo atoms to the liquid copper surface. Subsequently, a very low concentration methane (CH4) was introduced to provide carbon atoms by decomposition on Cu surface, which react with the Mo atoms to form 2D Mo2C crystals. Figure 6.1b shows the ultrathin 2D α-Mo2C crystals fabricated at 1090 ◦C for 5 min [7]. Most crystals have a lateral size of ~10 μm and a thickness of 3– 20 nm. The nucleation density, thickness, and lateral size of 2D α-Mo2C crystals can be controlled by changing the growth time and temperature. In addition, ultrathin αMo2C crystals can be transferred to other substrates, such as SiO2/Si substrates or transmission electron microscope (TEM) grids, by using a mild Cu etchant. The crystal was identified to be orthorhombic structure (α-Mo2C) by selective area electron diffraction (SAED). The energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mappings show the uniform chemical composition of the crystal (Fig. 6.1c–e). Furthermore, no defects are observed (Fig. 6.1f), indicating the high crystalline
6 Bottom-Up Synthesis of 2D Transition Metal Carbides and Nitrides 91
92 C. Xu et al.
quality. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) measurements indicate that the crystals have clean and smooth surface (Fig. 6.1g). Importantly, this CVD method is versatile and can be used to fabricate a broad class of high-quality 2D ultrathin TMC crystals with various structures. For example, high-quality 2D ultrathin hexagonal WC and cubic TaC crystals have also been fabricated by changing Mo foil to W and Ta foil (Fig. 6.1h, i), respectively.
Geng et al. [8] used the same method reported by Xu et al. [7] to fabricate 2D Mo2C crystals. A higher temperature (1100 ◦C), a thicker copper foil (at least 50 μm), and various CH4 concentrations (H2 200 sccm, CH4 0.1–0.4 sccm) were used in their work. They found that the Mo2C crystals have different shapes under different CH4 concentrations. For example, when the flow rate of CH4 was 0.1 sccm, the Mo2C crystals with fractal shape were fabricated. With increasing the flow rate of CH4, the crystal shape changes from fractal to hexagon (Fig. 6.1j). The hexagonal Mo2C crystal has a different crystalline structure from others (Fig. 6.1k). At CH4 flow rates of 0.3 sccm and 0.4 sccm, the dominant shapes are rectangle and pentagon, respectively. With increasing the thickness of copper foil, the Mo2C crystal became thinner. This is because a thicker copper layer prolongs the diffusion time of Mo, resulting in a less segregation on the liquid copper surface.
Based on Xu’s work, Wang et al. [9] fabricated ultrathin TaN with NH3 as nitrogen source and Cu foil/Ta foil as growth substrate at a temperature of 1077 ◦C, which is lower than the melting point of Cu. During CVD growth, the copper foil keeps solid state. Figure 6.1l shows low-magnification TEM images of TaN, and the inset shows the corresponding SAED pattern, which confirms that both of them are single crystals. Besides TaN crystals, ultrathin TaB crystals were also fabricated by using boron powder as B source. The reason why the ultrathin crystals can be fabricated at a temperature below the melting point of Cu was explained in this work. Using DFT calculations, they found that a very low excess energy of 0.03 eV is required for a Ta atom diffusing into a vacant Cu lattice site, which can be easily supplied thermally at a lower temperature (e.g., kBT ≈ 129 meV at 1356 K). Furthermore, they found that the Ta atoms would prefer to form clusters in Cu lattice rather than being uniformly distributed at a higher temperature. Therefore, at a lower temperature, the growth of these crystals can be controlled more easily than at a higher temperature.
Qi et al. [10] reported the growth of monatomic layer ReC crystal on Re (0001) substrates by CVD with C2H4 as carbon source under ultrahigh vacuum condition. They found that monolayer graphene was grown on Re (0001) at 903 K. When the grown graphene on Re (0001) was annealed at 953–1113 K, it began to decompose to carbon atoms, which were then dissolved in Re. Subsequently, during the cooling process, 2D ReC crystals with a periodic “flower-like” superstructure were formed on Re (0001) surface through carbon segregation from Re (Fig. 6.1m). Unfortunately, the 2D ReC crystals separated from the growth substrate were not obtained in this work.
6 Bottom-Up Synthesis of 2D Transition Metal Carbides and Nitrides 93
Chemical Vapor Deposition: Graphene/2D TMC

sections.heading: Heterostructures
sections.text:
As we know, CVD has been widely used to synthesize high-quality graphene film on copper foils [24]. Therefore, the CVD method shown above has been directly used or modified to synthesize graphene/2D TMC heterostructures [11–15]. Figure 6.2a shows a schematic diagram of one-step CVD process for the growth of vertical graphene (top)/2D α-Mo2C (bottom) heterostructures [11]. Compared to the synthesis process of 2D TMCs, a higher concentration of CH4 was used [11– 14]. Figure 6.2b, c, respectively, shows the optical image and Raman spectra of the graphene/2D α-Mo2C vertical heterostructure reported by Deng et al. [11]. The visible D band indicates the low quality of the graphene in the heterostructures. Similar graphene (top)/2D α-Mo2C (bottom) heterostructure was also synthesized by Qiao et al. with the same method [12]. They found that there is a twist angle of ~11◦ between graphene and 2D α-Mo2C (Fig. 6.2d) and suggested that the low quality of graphene is ascribed to the strong bonding between the Mo in 2D αMo2C and the C atoms in graphene. Different from the above two works, Geng et al. [14] reported the growth of 2D α-Mo2C (top)/graphene (bottom) heterostructures by one-step CVD. Figure 6.1e shows a supposed schematic for the growth of Mo2C flakes on graphene.
Xu et al. [13] developed a two-step CVD process to synthesize high-quality graphene (top)/2D α-Mo2C (bottom) vertical heterostructures. Figure 6.2f shows the schematic diagram of the two-step CVD growth process. In general, graphene was first grown on the top of the solid Cu/Mo substrate at 1070 ◦C. Subsequently, the temperature was increased to 1090 ◦C, and 2D α-Mo2C crystals were formed between graphene and the liquid Cu/Mo substrate under this condition. Figure 6.2g shows the graphene/2D α-Mo2C heterostructures on Cu/Mo substrate. These heterostructures can also be transferred very well to other substrates such as SiO2/Si (Fig. 6.2h). Same as the pure 2D α-Mo2C crystals [7], the 2D α-Mo2C crystals in the heterostructures have high quality (Fig. 6.2i). Figure 6.2j, k shows TEM image and the corresponding SAED pattern of a heterostructure of graphene with an octagonal 2D α-Mo2C crystal, respectively. It can be found that the Mo sublattices of 2D α-Mo2C and graphene show the same lattice orientation. Furthermore, the graphene in heterostructure shows a large upshift in both G and 2D peaks (Fig. 6.2l), and the upshift is non-uniform across the whole heterostructure (Fig. 6.2m–o). These results suggest that the graphene undergoes non-uniform compression in the heterostructure although it has a high quality (Fig. 6.2l).
2D in-plane WC-graphene (2D i-WC-G) heterostructure can also be synthesized by the one step CVD process. Zeng et al. [15] obtained 2D i-WC-G heterostructure at 980–1020 ◦C by using Ga droplet instead of Cu foil and CH4 as carbon source. Figure 6.2p shows the schematic growth process of 2D i-WC-G heterostructure. The formation of 2D i-WC-G heterostructure was supposed as the result of cosegregation of the WC and graphene. The coverages of 2D WC in 2D i-WC-G heterostructure can be controlled from 40% to 95%. Figure 6.2q shows a SEM image of 2D i-WC-G heterostructure with a high 2D WC coverage. 2D WC crystals have a thickness of ~1.36 nm and high quality, as shown in Fig. 6.2r, s.
94 C. Xu et al.

sections.heading: Template Method
sections.text:
2D transition metal oxides (TMOs) have been used as the template to synthesize 2D TMCs and TMNs by carbonizing or ammoniating the template [16–18]. Xiao et al. [16] reported salt-templated synthesis of 2D TMNs, which is based on the reported salt-templated synthesis of 2D TMOs. Figure 6.3a shows the schematic of synthesis of 2D MoN. First, the 2D hexagonal MoO3-coated NaCl (2D h-MoO3@NaCl) crystals were synthesized by annealing the Mo precursor@NaCl crystals under the protection of Ar atmosphere at 280 ◦C (Fig. 6.3a). Subsequently, 2D hMoO3@NaCl crystals were slowly ammoniated by NH3 at 650 ◦C to synthesize 2D MoN@NaCl powders. Finally, 2D MoN nanosheets (NSs) were obtained by removing NaCl with deionized water. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns show that the 2D MoN NSs have hexagonal structure with lattice constants a = b = 5.75 Å and c = 5.62 Å (Fig. 6.3b). They show a good dispersity in water (the inset in Fig. 6.3b), and the lateral size and thickness are several hundreds nanometers and 0.71 nm, respectively (Fig. 6.3c,d). 2D WN NSs and VN NSs were also synthesized by this method.
Joshi et al. [17] reported a two-step template method to synthesize 2D layered δMoN NSs (Fig. 6.3e). In step 1, they synthesized highly aligned 2D layered MoO3 NSs by a hot-filament CVD (HFCVD) process, in which a Mo wire was resistively heated close to its melting point in O2 and the obtained 2D layered MoO3 NSs were deposited on a cooler substrate. In step 2, 2D layered MoO3 NSs were ammoniated to obtain 2D δ-MoN NSs in NH3/Ar (flow rate ratio of 1:4) at 700 ◦C for 8 h. Figure 6.3f shows the MoO3 and δ-MoN samples on a fluorinated tin oxide (FTO)-coated glass substrate. It can be found that the color changed from bluish white to black after nitridation. The as-synthesized 2D δ-MoN NSs have layered structure (Fig. 6.3g), a lateral size of 20–30 μm, and a thickness of 5–40 nm.
Jia et al. [18] synthesized N-doped Mo2C (N-Mo2C) NSs by using MoO2 NSs as a template to react with dicyandiamide (C2H4N4). First, MoO2 NSs were synthesized through a chemical vapor reduction of commercial MoO3 powders in Ar/H2 (200 sccm, ratio of 9:1) at 900 ◦C for 60 min. Second, the N-Mo2C NSs were synthesized by calcining a C2H4N4 powders/MoO2 NSs (the weight ratio of 10:1) mixture at 450 ◦C for 2 h and then 700 ◦C for 2 h. The SEM images of MoO2 NSs and N-Mo2C NSs show similar morphology (Fig. 6.3h), which is a solid evidence of
Fig. 6.2 (continued) image (m) and the corresponding G (n) and 2D peak (o) position mapping of a graphene/hexagonal 2D α-Mo2C heterostructure. The scale bars are 5 μm. (p) Schematic cross-view of a Ga-W substrate for CVD growth of 2D i-WC-G heterostructure. (q) SEM image of the WC single crystals embedded in graphene. (r) AFM image of a 2D hexagonal WC crystal. (s) HRTEM image of 2D WC crystal. (Panels a–c are reprinted with permission from Ref. [11], Chinese Physical Society. Panel d is reprinted with permission from Ref. [12], American Physical Society. Panel e is reprinted with permission from Ref. [14], Wiley-VCH. Panels f– o are reprinted with permission from Ref. [13], American Chemical Society. Panels p– s are reprinted with permission from Ref. [15], Elsevier)
96 C. Xu et al.
template synthesis. The N-Mo2C NSs obtained have a thickness of ~1.0 nm, which is slightly smaller than the thickness (~1.1 nm) of the MoO2 template. It is ascribed to the different interplanar spacings of MoO2 NSs (0.241 nm) and N-Mo2C NSs (0.237 nm) (Fig. 6.3i). However, a number of nanopores were observed in N-Mo2C NSs, which maintain single crystalline nature with hexagonal structure (Fig. 6.3j–l).

sections.heading: Plasma-Enhanced Pulsed Laser Deposition
sections.text:
Zhang et al. [19, 20] reported a plasma-enhanced pulsed laser deposition (PEPLD) process to fabricate large-area high-quality 2D face-centered cubic (FCC)structured Mo2C crystal on sapphire (0001) substrate. The PEPLD system is a modified pulsed laser deposition system by equipping a high-voltage electrode for generating CH4 plasma at the CH4 inlet of the chamber. A Mo metal target was focused by a KrF laser of 248 nm for supplying Mo source. Figure 6.4a, b shows XRD patterns of the samples grown in ionized CH4 plasma and non-ionized CH4 at 700 ◦C, respectively [19]. They found there was no Mo2C deposited without
98 C. Xu et al.
ionized CH4, which demonstrates that ionized CH4 plasma plays a key role in the deposition of 2D FCC-structured Mo2C crystal (Fig. 6.4a, b) [19]. The 2D Mo2C film deposited by PEPLD shows a very smooth surface (Fig. 6.4c) [19]. The thickness can be tuned from 2 nm to 25 nm by changing parameters. Figure 6.4d shows a cross-sectional TEM image of a 14-nm-thick Mo2C film grown on the sapphire substrate [19]. The crystal quality degrades with the decrease of deposition temperature [20]. The Mo2C film grown at 700 ◦C is high-quality single crystal, as shown in Fig. 6.4e. The growth mechanism of the FCC-structured Mo2C was revealed by analyzing the interface between as-grown Mo2C thin film and sapphire substrate. They found that there is a parallel crystallographic orientation relationship between {111}Mo2C and {0006}sapphire and a little lattice mismatch of ~8.5% between {111}Mo2C and{0003}sapphire, which are favorable for forming a good lattice coherent interface between sapphire substrate and the Mo2C film (Fig. 6.4e, f). As a result, both the coherent orientation and small in-plane lattice mismatch between sapphire substrate and the Mo2C thin film serve as the driving forces for the formation of FCC-structured Mo2C.

sections.heading: Crystalline Structure
sections.text:
TMCs and TMNs are mainly composed of transition metal atom skeletons and polyhedron-interstitial carbon or nitrogen atoms. Bottom-up synthesized 2D TMCs and TMNs basically inherit the crystalline structures of their bulk counterparts. Ultrathin 2D Mo2C crystals have attracted much attention due to the novel material synthetic strategy and 2D superconductivity since the pioneer work by Xu et al. [7], and subsequently several bottom-up methods have been developed. So far, the asfabricated 2D Mo2C crystals show three crystalline structures including hexagonal (P63/mmc) [8, 14, 18, 21], orthorhombic (Pbcn) [7, 11–13, 21–23], and cubic (Fm3m) [19, 20] phases. Orthorhombic (α) and hexagonal (β) Mo2C crystals are common phases, and both consist of hexagonal close-packed (HCP) Mo atoms and interstitial carbon atoms which occupy half of the Mo octahedrons [21, 23]. Figure 6.5a shows the aberration-corrected bright field (BF)-STEM image of ultrathin αMo2C crystals, which clearly show the graphene-like Mo six rings and carbon atoms located in the centers of Mo six rings from the projected direction [23]. The projected structure of β phase is identical to α phase (Fig. 6.5b, c). However, the carbon atoms are orderly arranged in Mo octahedrons in α-Mo2C while randomly distributed in β-Mo2C. Therefore, the Mo sublattice of α-Mo2C slightly deviates from the strict hexagonal symmetry into an orthorhombic symmetry. Although the distortion of Mo HCP lattice in α-Mo2C is too small to be seen by the naked eyes, it can be identified from reciprocal space. Figure 6.5d shows the difference
6 Bottom-Up Synthesis of 2D Transition Metal Carbides and Nitrides 99
of electron diffraction (ED) between α- and β-Mo2C, and superstructure ED spots can be clearly seen in α phase [21].
It has been reported that α-Mo2C can be transformed from β-Mo2C during the cooling process, and the carbon atoms become ordered in this phase transition [25]. Liu et al. [21] found that electron beam irradiation (EBI) can induce α → β phase transition of 2D Mo2C crystals. Figure 6.5e shows HAADF-STEM image
100 C. Xu et al.
of an ultrathin α-Mo2C crystal, in which only the area I was subjected to largedose EBI. During EBI, carbon atoms migrate from zigzag configuration to random occupation, and the distorted HCP configuration of Mo atoms relaxes to rigorous HCP configuration. First-principle calculations show that carbon atom migration parallel to electron beam incident direction has minimal energy barrier. As a result, area I was transformed from α to β phase after EBI as shown in Fig. 6.5f. With the help of advanced aberration-corrected STEM, EBI provides a valid strategy to construct lateral junction of 2D superconducting α/β Mo2C with sharp interface [21], which provides a promising platform for studying vortex physics at the nanoscale and investigating the catalytic synergistic effects between α and β phases at the interface.
As shown above, Zhang et al. [20] synthesized Mo2C thin film with a FCC structure by PEPLD. In comparison to “ABAB”-stacked Mo atomic layers in αand β-Mo2C, FCC-structured Mo2C has “ABCABC”-stacked Mo atomic layers. All these three structures have almost identical interplanar spacing of closed-packed Mo atomic planes. However, the occupation of carbon atoms in FCC-Mo2C is unclear although the space group ( Fm3m ) and lattice parameter (a = 0.415 nm) are determined (Fig. 6.5g). Taking advantage of metal immiscibility route, Xu et al. [7] and Wang et al. [9] synthesized 2D TaC crystals with rock salt structure (Fig. 6.5h). Wang et al. [9] pointed out that the morphology of 2D TaC crystals suggests a pyramidal growth in the normal direction. In contrast to the AB-stacked metal atoms in α- and β-Mo2C, W atoms in the CVD-fabricated 2D WC crystals have AA-stacked pattern, and carbon atoms are located in the centers of tungsten trigonal prismatic interstices (Fig. 6.5i) [7, 15]. Recently, unique three-component fermions have been observed in the WC-structured crystals [4, 5]. Qi et al. [10] demonstrated the synthesis of ReC on Re substrate. Although the projected structure of ReC is the same as WC, carbon and Re atoms in ReC have the coplanar structure in 2D limit (Fig. 6.5j).
To date, two kinds of 2D TMNs, MoN and TaN, have been synthesized by bottom-up synthesis method. 2D MoN crystals derived from the ammoniation of MoO3 [16, 17] have hexagonal structure with space group P63mc. In this structure, Mo skeleton has “AA”-stacked pattern with some atomic columns slightly misaligned, and nitrogen atoms are located in Mo trigonal prismatic interstices, but the adjacent nitrogen atomic layers perpendicular to [0001] direction are not located in the projected coincident trigonal prisms (Fig. 6.5k). The as-obtained 2D TaN crystals were identified to have space group of P6/mmm with lattice parameters of a = b = 0.5196 nm and c = 0.2911 nm (Fig. 6.5l) [9].

sections.heading: Defect Structure
sections.text:
First-principle calculation shows that the interstitial carbon atoms are moved slightly off center in the octahedrons along the b-direction of the α-Mo2C lattice [23]. However, there are three equivalent off-center configurations of carbon atoms
6 Bottom-Up Synthesis of 2D Transition Metal Carbides and Nitrides 101
associated with the same HCP Mo atom sublattice [23]. If these equivalent carbon atom configurations exist simultaneously in the same Mo atom sublattice, topological α-Mo2C domains could form. Liu et al. [23] found that, except for rectangular and octagonal 2D α-Mo2C being single crystals, triangular, hexagonal, nonagonal, and dodecagonal crystals are composed of three or six domains with rotational-symmetry and well-defined line-shaped domain boundaries. For example, the hexagonal ultrathin α-Mo2C nanosheet is composed of sixfold rotationalsymmetric domains, in which the diagonal domains have the same carbon atom configuration as shown in Fig. 6.6a [23]. First-principle calculations indicate that the symmetric distribution of carbon atoms with respect to domain boundary has lower boundary energy (Fig. 6.6b) [23]. Since the off-center directions of carbon atoms in adjacent domains are different, the distorted directions of HCP Mo
102 C. Xu et al.
sublattice are different. Therefore, there is a small shear strain across the domain boundary (Fig. 6.6c, d) [23]. However, such domain boundary has a significant influence on the superconductivity, resulting in a broad resistive superconducting transition with two distinct transition processes due to the formation of localized phase-slip events in the boundary [23].
Intrinsically, Mo atoms should have “ABAB”-stacked configuration in β-Mo2C. However, Geng et al. [8] observed two types of Mo stacking order, i.e., AB and AA at the thinner edge of hexagonal-shaped β-Mo2C nanosheet (Fig. 6.6e), and suggested that the coexistence of multiple stacking is attributed to the incomplete growth of Mo2C at the edge and the similar formation energy for the two polytypes. Moreover, Geng et al. [14] also observed stacking fault in β-Mo2C nanosheet. As shown in Fig. 6.6f, additional Mo atoms appear in the centers of projected graphenelike Mo six rings. That is, there exists Mo atomic plane of local “C” layer besides “A” and “B” layers. Jia et al. [18] found that nitrogen atoms could replace carbon atoms in 2D β-Mo2C, forming N-doped β-Mo2C crystals, and the lattice parameter ratio a/b in β-Mo2C crystals decreases after N doping (Fig. 6.6g, h).

sections.heading: Properties and Applications
sections.text: TMCs and TMNs have many excellent properties of both metals and ceramics because of the coexistance of metallic and covalent bonds [2]. On the one hand, TMCs and TMNs have been widely used in jet engines, cutting tools, and protective coatings because of their high melting points, extreme hardness, and good wear resistance. On the other hand, they have unique electronic and magnetic properties, which render them superconductivity and excellent catalytic activity comparable to noble metals [26]. The high-quality 2D TMCs and TMNs provide a new platform for studying new physics and properties at the 2D limit and open up the possibilities for new applications.

sections.heading: Superconductivity
sections.text:
The transport properties of CVD-grown 2D α-Mo2C crystals were first investigated by Xu et al. [7]. Figure 6.7a shows the temperature dependence of the sheet resistance of a 7.5-nm-thick Mo2C crystal in different magnetic field strengths perpendicular to the crystal plane. At zero magnetic field, the resistance begins to decrease at 3.6 K and drops to zero at 2.76 K, indicating the onset of superconductivity. Figure 6.7b shows the magnetic field dependence of the sheet resistance for an 8.3-nm-thick Mo2C crystal. As the magnetic field is tilted toward the crystal plane (θ → 0), the transition to superconductivity shifts sharply to a higher field. Such strong anisotropy provides direct evidence of the 2D character of the superconductivity for ultrathin α-Mo2C crystals. The out-of-plane upper critical
6 Bottom-Up Synthesis of 2D Transition Metal Carbides and Nitrides 103
field Hc2,⊥ shows a linear behavior close to Tc (Fig. 6.7c), which is consistent with the standard linearized Ginzburg-Landau (GL) theory for superconductors. The extracted in-plane coherence length, ξGL(0)~22.0 ± 0.4 nm, is much larger
104 C. Xu et al.
than the extracted superconducting thickness, dSC ≈ 4.1 ± 0.1 nm. Moreover, the angular dependence of upper critical field, Hc2(θ ), can be well fitted by the Tinkham formula (Fig. 6.7d), and the current voltage (I − V) curves comply well with Berezinskii-Kosterlitz-Thouless (BKT) theory (Fig. 6.7e). All these results confirm the 2D nature of the superconductivity in ultrathin α-Mo2C crystals. Moreover, these crystals are clean system in terms of the much larger mean free path (~30–40 nm) than the coherence length. As shown in Fig. 6.7f, the superconductivity behavior strongly depends on the crystal thickness. A suppression of the superconducting transition is observed as the crystal goes thinner.
Wang et al. [22] found that the magnetoresistance (MR) of 2D α-Mo2C crystals exhibits well-resolved and pronounced fluctuations (Fig. 6.7g) and the fluctuations are reproducible and do not depend on the direction of the field sweep. Unlike the well-known Little-Parks (LP) effect, where oscillations are prominent in the vicinity of the superconducting transition, the resistance oscillations in the 2D αMo2C crystals occur only at low magnetic fields and low temperatures far below Tc. This abnormal phenomenon is explained by the triangle-shaped smooth terraces on the Mo2C crystal surface, whose geometrical area matches well with the observed loop area from MR oscillations and could act as an effective geometry enclosed by the screening currents. At temperatures lower than 2.6 K, the MR is negative and exhibits a nonmonotonic dependence on the magnetic field (Fig. 6.7h), which is contrary to a picture of weak localization. This result implies that amplitude fluctuations also play a crucial role in controlling Tc in ultrathin Mo2C crystals.
Xu et al. [13] studied the transport properties of the CVD-grown well-aligned and strongly coupled graphene/2D α-Mo2C crystal heterostructure. As shown in Fig. 6.7i, multiple voltage steps (marked by arrows) are observed in the intermediate current regime, undergoing a transition between the superconducting state and normal state. These voltage steps are producible and more pronounced and sharper at lower temperatures. In contrast, pure 2D α-Mo2C crystal samples exhibit a sharp superconducting transition, and no step-like feature is observed. Moreover, such multiple voltage steps have also not been observed in the stacked graphene/2D superconductor heterostructures or hybrids reported. The voltage steps can be understood in terms of the existence of strain-induced phase-slip lines, a 2D analogue of phase-slip centers. Superconductor-normal-superconductor junction devices were also constructed by using two closely located strongly coupled graphene/2D α-Mo2C crystal heterostructures with graphene as the weak link. A dissipationless supercurrent through the junction is clearly observed below the critical current Ic, which is a characteristic DC Josephson response due to the proximity effect (Fig. 6.7j). The high-quality graphene/2D α-Mo2C shows a high transparency of ~0.7–0.8 extracted by BTK theory. It can be seen that the critical current is periodically modulated by the magnetic field (Fig. 6.7k), exhibiting typical Fraunhofer-like diffraction pattern. Qiao et al. [12] also carried out spectroscopic measurements on graphene and 2D superconducting α-Mo2C heterostructure using scanning tunneling microscopy/spectroscopy (STM/STS). They found that Tc and Hc2(T) of the heterostructure could be tuned by simply varying the thickness of 2D α-Mo2C sheets. These results indicate that hybrid graphene-superconductor
6 Bottom-Up Synthesis of 2D Transition Metal Carbides and Nitrides 105
devices are attractive for fundamental investigations of rich phase diagram of superconducting transition and provide a facile route to tune the superconductivity in the 2D limit.

sections.heading: Electrocatalysts
sections.text:
Zeng et al. [15] investigated the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) performance of 2D i-WC-G heterostructures. As shown in Fig. 6.8a, the 2D i-WC-G sample with 70% coverage requires only ~120 mV to achieve a 10 mA cm−2 current density, and Tafel slope is as low as ~38 mV dec−1 (Fig. 6.8b), probably demonstrating
106 C. Xu et al.
a Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism. Moreover, the charge transfer resistance is only 2.26 at 250 mV (Fig. 6.8c), which affords faster charge transfer and promotes the HER kinetic process. The excellent performance of 2D i-WC-G heterostructures could be attributed to the synergetic effect between WC and graphene, where the electron conjugation across the 2D basal surface is more favorable than traditional configuration of stacked and aggregated heterostructure and exhibits fast interdomain electron transport (Fig. 6.8d). Geng et al. [14] studied the electrochemical HER activity of Mo2C crystals grown on graphene. Benefiting from the high crystallinity and electronic coupling to graphene, the HER performance is dramatically improved. As shown in Fig. 6.8e, the Mo2C/graphene electrode has a low overpotential value of 236 mV versus reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) for a current density of 10 mA cm−2 with an onset potential of 87 mV and Tafel slope of 73 mV dec−1, showing a more superior HER performance as compared to transition metal dichalcogenide-based 2D materials. It also exhibits high stability, where the polarization curve remains unchanged even after 1000 cycles (Fig. 6.8f). Jia et al. [18] investigated the HER performance of porous N-Mo2C NSs. Under the optimized condition, the samples show an onset potential of −48.3 mV, overpotential of 99 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 6.8g), and Tafel slope of 44.5 mV dec−1 (Fig. 6.8h). Moreover, the hydrogen production rate is 6.23 mmol mg−1 h−1, which is almost the same as the theoretical result (Fig. 6.8i), indicating that the Faradaic efficiency is nearly 100%. The excellent HER performance of N-Mo2C NSs is attributed to their 2D structure with large electrochemical area that facilitate the diffusion process, particular crystalline phase and high-proportioned C planes that expose more Mo active sites, and the synergistic manipulation of N doping with the electron density states that produce more active sites.

sections.heading: Li-Ion Batteries and Supercapacitors
sections.text:
Joshi et al. [17] demonstrated the Li-ion battery application of 2D MoN prepared by phase transformation from CVD-grown MoO3. After 200 cycles at C/20 rate, the capacity still remains around 310–320 mAh/g, while the Coulombic efficiency keeps above 99.4% (Fig. 6.9a). At fast cycling rate at 1 C, a steady discharge capacity of 180 mAh/g is obtained and shows no significant degradation even up to 100 cycles (inset of Figure 6.9a). The good cycling stability suggests that the Li+ are probably inserted at the interlayer spacing without reaction with the host lattice; thus no significant changes are involved. XRD patterns confirm that the crystal structure of MoN is kept well-defined after 200 cycles (Fig. 6.9b). Moreover, the Mo 3d X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectrum shows no significant shift (Fig. 6.9c), indicating that no conversion reaction is involved.
Recently, Xiao et al. [16] reported the use of 2D MoN NSs in supercapacitors. In 1 M H2SO4 electrolyte, the volumetric capacitance value reaches 928 F cm−3 at a sweep rate of 2 mV s−1 and maintains around 200 F cm−3 at an ultrahigh sweep rate of 20 V s−1 (Fig. 6.9d). The remarkable electrochemical performance can be
6 Bottom-Up Synthesis of 2D Transition Metal Carbides and Nitrides 107
attributed to their remarkably high conductivity and 2D morphology, which enables all active atoms of the MoN NSs exposed to the electrolyte and facilitates the electron transport in electrodes. EIS measurements reveal a typical capacitive behavior, and no apparent charge transfer resistance is observed (Fig. 6.9e). As shown in Fig. 6.9f, more than 95% of the initial volumetric capacitance is maintained after 25,000 cycles at a sweep rate of 100 mV s−1, indicating excellent stability. The solid-state supercapacitor fabricated by 2D MoN exhibits good flexibility (Fig. 6.9g) and could power a commercial red LED (Fig. 6.9h). The CV curves of the solid-state supercapacitor at different sweep rates show typical capacitive behavior (Fig. 6.9i). The largest power density is 1.5 W cm−3, and the largest energy density is about 2 mWh cm−3 which is comparable with a 4 V/500 μAh Li thin-film battery, better than the TiN-based solid-state supercapacitor, commercial AC-EC, and electrolytic capacitors (Fig. 6.9j).
108 C. Xu et al.

sections.heading: Summary and Outlook
sections.text:
In the past several years, several bottom-up methods, including CVD, PEPLD, and template method, have been developed for the synthesis of 2D TMCs and TMNs. The materials obtained have high crystalline quality, which are different from MXenes. Moreover, these methods also enable the synthesis of 2D TMCs and TMNs that could not be synthesized by top-down synthesis method, such as WC, TaC, TaN, MoN, and heterostructures. The high-quality samples allow deep studies on the intrinsic structure and properties of 2D TMCs and TMNs, in particular superconductivity. These materials also show great potential for various applications such as electrocatalysis, Li-ion batteries, and supercapacitors.
It is anticipated that the family of 2D TMCs and TMNs can be further enlarged by using the bottom-up synthesis methods. However, it is still challenging to synthesize large-area uniform films and atomically thin samples down to one unit cell thick. Furthermore, more efforts should be made to explore the properties and applications of such high-quality 2D TMCs and TMNs.

sections.heading: Effect of Synthesis Methods on the Structure and Defects of Two-Dimensional MXenes
Xiahan Sang, Michael Naguib, Mohamed Alhabeb, and Raymond R. Unocic
Introduction
sections.text:
Since the discovery of 2D transition metal carbides, nitrides, or carbonitride MXenes, methods have been developed to optimize and control their synthesis. Two-dimensional MXenes are generally synthesized through the selective etching of the parent MAX phase using etchants based on acidic fluoride solution [1, 2]. However, the specific etchant and etching parameters used can directly influence the structure and chemistry of the resultant MXene, which will ultimately affect the physicochemical properties. For example, the concentration and moiety of etchants [2, 3], etching temperature [4], and starting particle size of the MAX phase precursor [4, 5] have been shown to affect the required etching times and the processing of MXenes. Therefore, optimizing synthesis methods requires a deep understanding of how these parameters influence the micro- and atomic structure of the resulting MXenes. In this chapter, we review advances from recent literature on the influence of synthesis methods on the crystal structure [6], nanopores [7, 8], atomic defects

[9], and surface functional groups [10] and discuss how the structure and defects influence the properties of MXenes.

sections.heading: Influence of Synthesis Methods on the Crystal Structure of MXenes
sections.text:
An ideal etching process can completely remove the “A” element atoms without over-etching the 2D MXene flakes. The extraction of the “A” element leads to the formation of functional groups of various types and concentrations [10] and ion and water intercalation [11], each of which is accompanied with change of the clattice constant that can readily be measured by X-ray diffraction (XRD) [6, 10, 11]. Analysis of the lattice constant change can therefore reveal important information about the crystal structure, interlayer structure, and surface structure. A systematic study was performed on samples etched using 50 wt% hydrofluoric (HF) acid as a function of etching time and temperature [4]. As summarized in Table 7.1, longer etching times and higher etching temperatures lead to larger c-lattice constants. Lattice constant measurements are a convenient way to tell if sufficient etching has been conducted to ensure a high yield rate of 2D MXenes. Another study by Wang et al. [10] reported that the lattice constant of wet Ti3C2Tx MXene is significantly larger than dry Ti3C2Tx MXene, which is likely due to water intercalation from the complex interactions between water molecules, surface functional groups, and the HF solution. Water intercalation has been reported to increase the interlayer spacing of V2CTx, Nb2CTx [5], and Nb4C3Tx MXenes [12]. Due to the fact that the c-lattice constant is sensitive to many factors such as drying conditions, which are sometimes uncontrollable, conclusions should be carefully drawn from such studies.
The influence of water intercalation on the lattice constants is coupled with ion intercalation [11]. The d-spacing of dry K+-intercalated Ti3C2Tx MXene (11.5 Å) is
7 Effect of Synthesis Methods on the Structure and Defects. . . 113
larger than that of dry Mg2+-intercalated Ti3C2Tx MXene (10.1 Å). After hydration, the d-spacing of wet K+-intercalated Ti3C2Tx MXene (12.4 Å) is smaller than that of dry Mg2+-intercalated Ti3C2Tx MXene (14.6 Å) due to the formation of large Mg(H2O)6 clusters that separate adjacent layers [11].
The lattice constants can be easily obtained through conventional XRD analysis and are sensitive to the sample preparation methods employed, providing interlayer spacing information that can be used to understand the surface structure and intercalation mechanism [11]. The lattice constant is correlated to certain properties. For example, the Ti3C2Tx MXene sample etched with 10 wt% HF has a large clattice constant and also the highest Cr(VI) removal capacity, which is useful for reductive removal of other highly toxic, soluble, and strong oxidants [6]. Therefore, controlling the lattice constant using different synthesis methods can influence the functional properties of MXenes.

sections.heading: Influence of Synthesis Methods on Defects
sections.text:
Besides etching out the “A” atom layers (Al, Ga, etc.), the etchants can also attack the carbide layers from complex chemical reactions, leaving defects in the MXenes flakes. As a commonly observed type of defects in chemically etched MXene [7, 8], nanopores can influence ion transport properties for applications such as water desalination [13, 14]. Nanopores were initially observed at atomic resolution in Ta4C3Tx MXene after an HF (50 wt%) treatment for 72 hr. [7], where the average size of the reported nanopores was less than 3 nm and their formation was attributed to over-etching from using an etchant solution with a relatively high HF concentration. The influence of the synthesis method on the average nanopore size has been systematically investigated using Mo2CTx MXenes prepared using different etching times, intercalation methods, and sonication times (Fig. 7.1) [8]. The pore size increases from ∼10 nm to hundreds of nanometers as the etching time increases from 6 days to 16 days (Fig. 7.1a, b). Halim et al. [8] claimed that postetching treatment using TBAOH significantly increases the number of nanopores with a negligible influence on the pore size (Fig. 7.1c). Sonication after intercalation also increases the pore size but tends to destroy the flakes (Fig. 7.1d). Therefore, such experiments not only provide direct evidence of the existence of defects in MXenes from etching but also indicate that defects can be controlled by tuning critical parameters during synthesis.
It is interesting to investigate the influence of the synthesis method on the creation of smaller-scale defects: atomic defects such as vacancies and antisites. Atomic defects in 2D materials can directly influence the electronic structure, which in turn determines the electronic properties, optical properties, and magnetic properties [16–18]. Controlling the type and concentration of atomic defects in 2D materials to enhance physical properties through sample preparation and treatment has been extensively investigated for graphene and 2D transition metal dichalcogenides [19].
114 X. Sang et al.
To directly observe and quantitatively analyze atomic defects in 2D materials, aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) has been the method of choice as STEM offers sub-angstrom spatial resolution that is sufficient to resolve individual atoms in 2D materials [20]. The STEM images can easily be interpreted as the image intensity is proportional to the atomic number Z1.64 [19–21]. In STEM images, heavier atoms exhibit brighter contrast, while lighter atoms exhibit darker contrast. Due to the sensitivity of STEM images to the number and type of atoms, different atomic defects exhibit drastically different image contrast that can be used to determine their type and density.
The influence of the etchant concentration on atomic defect formation in monolayer Ti3C2Tx MXene has been investigated using atomic-resolution aberrationcorrected STEM [9]. As STEM images represent the projected atomic structure model, atomic defects are preferably characterized from monolayer flakes. Defects in multilayer flakes are more difficult to quantitatively analyze because the contrast of atomic defects becomes less obvious as more atoms overlap along the projection direction. To confirm the monolayer nature of the Ti3C2Tx MXene flakes prepared using the minimally intensive layer delamination (MILD) method (see Chap. 5 “Top-Down MXene Synthesis” for more detail) [2], multiple STEM images were acquired from different viewing directions to reveal the three-dimensional (3D) atomic structure. This is in principle similar to atomic-resolution tomography, which
7 Effect of Synthesis Methods on the Structure and Defects. . . 115
has been successfully used to reveal the 3D atomic structure of nanoparticles [22]. The STEM image acquired along the c axis (Fig. 7.2, β = 0) displays the hexagonal lattice of projected Ti atoms. Carbon atoms are not visible here due to their much lower atom number compared with Ti and overlapping with Ti atoms in this projection. For comparison, theoretical STEM images were simulated for Ti3C2Tx MXene from monolayer (SL), double layer with AA stacking, and double layer with AB stacking [23]. Along the zone axis, it is impossible to determine the layer number because the experimental STEM image matches well with all three simulated STEM images. The STEM image acquired along an orientation slightly off the c axis (Fig. 7.2, β = −189 mrad) shows a hollow-square pattern, which only matches the SL structure, while both double-layer AA and AB structures exhibit blurred contrast resulting from overlapping of the two layers. This unambiguously proves that the examined Ti3C2Tx MXene flake is SL, thereby providing the opportunity to directly observe atomic defects.
The most prevalent atomic defects in Ti3C2Tx MXene are Ti vacancies. Fig. 7.3a shows an experimental STEM image where the dark contrast indicated by the white arrow represents one missing Ti atom, i.e., a Ti vacancy, VTi. The dark contrast of VTi in the STEM image is confirmed by the theoretical STEM image simulated based on a Ti3C2Tx supercell created by removing one Ti atom from the system and optimized using density functional theory (DFT) (Fig. 7.3a). Similar Ti vacancies were observed previously using STEM [24]. The calculated VTi formation energies are 2.842 eV for the two surface Ti layers and 6.485 eV for the inner Ti layer. Therefore, the majority of VTi are expected to be found in the two surface Ti layers and the formation energy of the surface VTi should be dependent on the surface functional groups. As shown in Fig. 7.3c, the vacancy formation energies with all the functional groups are higher than the formation energy on a bare surface. It is very likely that the Ti vacancies are formed on the bare surfaces during HF
116 X. Sang et al.
etching before the surfaces are terminated by functional groups. Besides isolated Ti vacancies, Ti vacancy clusters are also commonly observed. Figure 7.3b shows a vacancy cluster consisting of 17 Ti vacancies and exhibiting a honeycomb structure. DFT indicates that the formation energy of a vacancy cluster is simply the sum of the formation energies of individual vacancies, suggesting that formation of such Ti vacancy cluster does not introduce an additional formation energy (Fig. 7.3d). Similar to a single Ti vacancy, Ti vacancy clusters should form during the etching process. This leads to the hypothesis that the concentration of Ti vacancies and vacancy clusters can be correlated with the etchant concentration, similar to the formation of nanopores.
To validate this hypothesis, atomic defects in monolayer Ti3C2Tx MXene samples prepared using the MILD method with different HF concentration, 2.7 wt%, 5.3 wt%, and 7.0 wt%, were systematically investigated. Characteristic STEM images acquired from the three different samples are shown in Fig. 7.4. At a low HF concentration (Fig. 7.4a), the atomic defects are mainly separated single Ti vacancies. Ti vacancy clusters are more commonly observed for medium
7 Effect of Synthesis Methods on the Structure and Defects. . . 117
(Fig. 7.4b) and high HF concentration (Fig. 7.4c). A statistical analysis of the defect concentration from tens of STEM images for each condition was performed. The average Ti vacancy concentration with standard deviation is plotted as a function of the HF concentration in Fig. 7.4d. It is obvious that the average defect concentration increases as the HF concentration increases. Moreover, vacancy clusters tend to form at higher HF concentration. This experiment indicates that the atomic defects in Ti3C2Tx MXene critically depend on the sample preparation method used and also confirm that the vacancies are formed during the etching process.
118 X. Sang et al.
Ti vacancies and vacancy clusters can modify the surface structure. As ab initio molecular dynamics simulations reveal [9], Ti vacancies in the surface can cause the adjacent Ti atoms in the middle layer to be exposed. Compared to Ti atoms that are blocked by the functional groups, the exposed Ti atoms can act as catalytic active sites. This is similar to the case of 2D TMDs, where atomic defects and edge defects are active sites for hydrogen evolution [25]. DFT calculations demonstrate that the Ti vacancies within the surfaces of Ti3C2Tx MXene do not compromise the excellent conductivity of Ti3C2Tx MXene (Fig. 7.5a) [9]. Rather, DFT simulations show that carbon vacancies in Ti2CTx can enhance electronic conductivity (Fig. 7.5b) [26]. More work needs to be performed to understand how atomic defects can influence other functional properties of Ti3C2Tx and other MXenes [27–29].
7 Effect of Synthesis Methods on the Structure and Defects. . . 119

sections.heading: Influence of Synthesis Method on Functional Groups
sections.text:
MXenes synthesized using the conventional top-down method through wet chemistry etching always terminate with functional groups such as –OH, –O, and –F. The functional groups in MXenes are important as they directly influence properties such as energy storage capacity [23], magnetism, band gap [30], and surface plasmon resonance [31, 32]. To better control the material properties, understanding the influence of sample preparation on type and concentration of surface functional groups is critical. Although diffraction methods have the advantage of obtaining averaged structural information from a large sample volume, XRD is not sensitive to light elements such as hydrogen and is difficult to quantitatively analyze –OH and hydrogen bonds. Moreover, due to the complexity and inhomogeneity of MXene phase crystal structures such as interlayer spacing and interlayer horizontal shifting after etching, a comprehensive structure model must be constructed to properly represent the MXene structure.
Neutron diffraction has been utilized to investigate the functional groups of Ti3C2Tx MXene using multilevel structural modeling [10]. Neutron diffraction has the advantage that H atoms are strong scatterers for neutrons, enabling better quantification of –OH functional groups. The multilevel structural modeling provides additional structural details of interest including stacking sequence/disorder, surface species identity, distribution, and interactions compared to conventional smallbox models. Structural analysis through neutron diffraction and pair distribution function (PDF) was performed on three samples (HF48, HF10, and HF48-NH4OH) prepared using different synthesis conditions. HF48 and HF10 were prepared by etching Ti3AlC2 powders in 48 wt% HF and 10 wt% HF solutions, respectively. As revealed in the previous section, a higher HF concentration leads to higher nanopore and atomic defect concentration. It is to be expected that other structural parameters could also be influenced by HF concentration. The HF48-NH4OH sample was prepared by soaking HF48 in an aqueous ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH) solution (28–30% NH3 basis) at room temperature.
PDFs can provide straightforward information about type and number of bonds in materials. PDFs of the three samples were obtained by a Fourier transform of the total scattering structure factor S(Q) up to a Qmax of 25 Å−1 collected using neutron diffraction on the NOMAD beamline at the Spallation Neutron Source, Oak Ridge National Laboratory (Fig. 7.6a). All three PDFs show similar positive and negative peaks but with different peak shapes. The first three peaks are a negative peak at 0.97 Å (O–H bond distance), a negative peak at 2.13 Å (Ti–C/O/F bond distance), and a positive peak at 3.04 Å (Ti–Ti and C–C in-plane distance). The peaks from HF10 are generally sharper and narrower than those from HF48 and HF48-NH4OH, suggesting that HF10 has a more ordered crystalline structure. Even for a very large bond distance (r > ∼45 Å), distinct peaks can easily be identified above the noise level from HF10 PDF, while the signal is more or less white noise at a large bond distance for HF48 and HF48-NH4OH. Thus, the MXene structure from the lower HF concentration has better long-range ordering from larger coherent
120 X. Sang et al.
lateral dimension of Ti3C2Tx sheets, a lower degree of interlayer stacking error, and fewer Ti defects, which is consistent with results presented in the previous section using atomic-resolution STEM imaging.
More details about the crystal structure of the three MXenes can be revealed using multilevel modeling to fit the neutron diffraction PDFs. The discussion is focused on the crystal structure difference between HF10 and HF48 since HF48 and HF48-NH4OH have nearly identical structures except for a slight difference in the c-lattice parameter. The average composition of HF10 and HF48 is Ti3C2[O0.13(1)(OH)1.04(6)F0.83(5)] and Ti3C2[O0.1(1)(OH)0.8(1)F1.1(2)], respectively.
7 Effect of Synthesis Methods on the Structure and Defects. . . 121
The concentration of –F functional groups is higher for HF48 possibly due to replacement of –OH by –F during etching. Moreover, HF10 has a more ordered stacking sequence than HF48. As represented in Fig. 7.6b and d, the relative shift between adjacent layers in HF10 is mainly (±1/3, ±2/3, z), which agrees with the ABAB stacking sequence predicted by DFT calculations [23]. The relative shifts between layers in HF48 are more randomly distributed. The difference in the stacking sequence further influences the interlayer spacing and bonding between them. For example, the ABAB stacking sequence by definition avoids the possibility that two functional groups are stacked on top of each other; HF10 has a smaller interlayer spacing compared to HF48, which has a random layer stacking shift and (on average) a larger repulsive force between function groups from two adjacent layers. Another possible explanation for the interlayer spacing could be from different levels of water intercalation for the two samples.
The HF concentration in the etchant can influence the distribution of surface functional groups and the stacking sequence between adjacent layers. The combined effect of surface functional groups and relative layer shifting controls the interlayer bonding that mainly results from van der Waals forces and hydrogen bonds. The strength of interlayer hydrogen bonds depends on the functional group types and distributions and orientation of –OH groups relative to the layer. The result provides valuable information on the development of synthesis methods to optimize selected surface terminations, controlled contact angle, and other functional properties.

sections.heading: Summary
sections.text:
Recently, our knowledge on the effects of synthesis method on the resultant structure and defects of MXenes have greatly advanced due to the utilization of a combination of characterization methods including XRD, atomic-resolution S/TEM, and neutron diffraction, with support from DFT calculations and MD simulations. Currently, structural details at length scales down to the atomic level can be correlated with the sample preparation method employed. However, there are great challenges before MXenes with desired crystal structures, defect levels, and functional groups can be accurately designed using optimized synthesis methods. This understanding is largely based on empirical data without accurate theoretical predictions. For example, due to the complex chemistries during etching, the concentration of atomic defects and surface functional groups of samples prepared using etchants of different HF concentration still cannot be accurately predicted using thermodynamics and kinetics. The formation mechanism of atomic defects and nanopores is still not clear and requires a more thorough understanding of the etching process, ideally from combined in situ experimental characterization and ab initio calculations. Also, aging and the influence of ambient conditions to the structure should be investigated with more detail [33]. Moreover, it would be very useful to have a clearer understanding at the atomic level of how defects, structure, and functional groups influence various functional properties of MXenes. It is important to extend
122 X. Sang et al.
such investigations to MXenes beyond Ti3C2Tx, as the MXene family has grown rapidly to include more than 25 different MXenes. Future characterization efforts require utilizing state-of-the-art instrumentations to obtain the highest possible temporal, energy, and spatial resolutions to better understand the atomic structure and the dynamic processes.
