sections.heading: Per O. Å. Persson
sections.text:
The MXene surfaces are inherently terminated with species that are foreign to the parent MAX phase. First-principle calculations have in numerous investigations shown the preference for termination of the bare MXene surface. The MXenes gain significant negative formation energy upon surface termination, which indicates the formation of strong bonds between the surface M atoms and the terminating species [1, 2]. Accordingly, the MXene chemical formula can be described as Mn+1XnTx, where T stands for surface terminating species and the subscript x indicates the coverage of T on the MXene surface. When x = 2, then for each surface M element atom, one terminating species is attached to the MXene surface.
The termination occurs during the very moment that the A layer is etched from the MAX phase. When the bonds originally connecting the MX slabs and the atomically thin A element layer are broken, new bonds are formed with the etchant species. While the etching process is strongly connected to the applied chemicals, the termination process was nicely demonstrated by theoretical means as shown in Fig. 8.1. The simulation shows how the etchant (here HF) interacts with a MAX phase edge (here Ti3AlC2), where particularly the A layer is targeted but additionally interacts with the adjacent M elements. In the process, HF dissociates such that F is attracted by the A and M elements. H is moderately attracted by these elements and prefers to form H2. With increasing HF concentration, the M-A bonds are eventually broken and AlF3 is formed. Hence, the A element is removed from the MAX phase, and the two-dimensional MXene starts to emerge. In the wake of the A element removal, the exposed M element surfaces are terminated by both H and F, though it is shown already in Fig. 8.1c that the preferred configuration is F-terminated surface, while H2 gas emerges as a by-product.
P. O. Å. Persson ( ) Electron Microscopy of Materials, Thin Film Physics Division, Linköping University, Linköping, Sweden e-mail: per.persson@liu.se
© Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2019 B. Anasori, Y. Gogotsi (eds.), 2D Metal Carbides and Nitrides (MXenes), https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-19026-2_8
125
126 P. O. Å. Persson
The presence of surface terminating species was identified already in the original MXene report wherein Ti3AlC2 was etched in 50% aqueous HF [3]. It was proposed that the surface terminations originated from the etching process according to the following simplified reactions:
Ti3AlC2 + 3HF = AlF3 + 3/2H2 + Ti3C2 (8.1)
Ti3C2 + 2H2O = Ti3C2(OH)2 + H2 (8.2)
Ti3C2 + 2HF = Ti3C2F2 + H2 (8.3)
Here, reaction (8.1) is required and is followed by reactions (8.2) and (8.3), in which the emerging MXene is terminated by species from the etchant. Based on a c-parameter obtained from XRD analysis and complementary DFT calculations, the best match was obtained for MXene sheets that were terminated by OH species. Accordingly, reaction (8.2) was deemed most probable, but additional F terminations according to reaction (8.3) could not be ruled out. Hence, the surface terminations were proposed to be OH and/or F. Following research has concluded that the termination chemistry is more complex and that surface terminations may additionally include O [1, 4, 5]. The explanation for the observed surface-bound O was proposed to occur as the surface-bound OH recombine into H2O and O by an equilibrium-driven reaction according to:
Ti3C2(OH)2 = Ti3C2O + H2O (8.4)
8 MXene Surface Chemistry 127
Particularly in vacuum, such as in most analytical equipment, the reduced water vapor pressure accelerates the process [6]. The implication of (8.4) is that one site is left with a termination vacancy or termination bare. In a vacuum environment, this can be sustained momentarily, depending on the vacuum conditions, but at ambient conditions the bare surface is likely to be oxidized immediately.
For identification and quantification of the terminating species, predominantly X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) has been implemented [3, 4, 7, 8]. XPS is an excellent tool for such studies since it can be used to determine the surface chemical compositions and the chemical states of the various species. Consequently, XPS enables identification and separation between terminating O and OH, as well as intercalated H2O and, e.g., TiOx particles remaining from the aqueous etching process.
A complementary method for probing the chemistry and the electronic structure of the surface-bound terminations is nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR). NMR has been used in the identification of the interactions of the terminating species and found a strong affinity for the OH terminations to bind to water [9]. NMR has also been used in the quantification of terminating species with the conclusion that O and F make up the majority of the terminating species, while OH occupy less than 5% of the available sites [10]. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) in the scanning electron microscope (SEM) and in the (scanning) transmission electron microscope ((S)TEM) has been used as a complementary method to identify and quantify O and F [11–13].
EDX is unable to distinguish between O and OH; hence both are integrated as O. Traditionally, EDX is not well suited to detect light elements which include inherent terminating species. In addition, the EDX signal is highly dependent on the experimental conditions and requires reliable conditions for accurate quantification. EDX on the other hand is highly applicable, e.g., for atomically resolved elemental mapping of the M elements [14].
Complementary to EDX, electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) in the (S)TEM has been used in quantification but also for site identification and the identification of the functionalizing species. It has been shown that the EELS fine structure is highly sensitive to the terminating species as well as the preferred sites, in both valence EELS and core loss EELS [6, 15–17].
Structural modeling including surface terminations has been successfully applied using atomic pair distribution functions (PDF) obtained through neutron scattering [13, 18]. Wang et al. used PDF to build a third-generation model of Ti3C2Tx MXene, including the periodicity of the bare MXene sheet and the random distribution of terminating species on the MXene surfaces. Furthermore, PDF experiments have provided significant insight of the inter-layer exchange and potential hydrogen bonds between the terminating species.
As a complement to spectroscopic methods, atomic resolution (S)TEM has been employed to observe individual terminating species [6, 17].
On the MXene surface, a number of configurations for low-symmetry sites for the terminating species are possible; see Fig. 8.2. Although Fig. 8.2 employs the M3X2 structure to illustrate the potential configurations, the corresponding situation
128 P. O. Å. Persson
can be applied to all Mn+1Xn structures. The configurations include the threefold coordinated Fcc and Hcp sites, as well as the Atop position above a surface M element and the Bridge position between two top surface M elements. All of these sites comprise energetically stable configurations as shown by theoretical means; however, structure optimization typically transforms Bridge and Atop into either Fcc or Hcp during relaxation [1, 19]. In addition to MXenes that are exclusively decorated with terminations in Fcc or Hcp configurations, the MXene theoretically allows for mixed configurations. Indeed, configurations with Hcpcoordinated species on one surface with Fcc-coordinated species on the other have additionally been investigated [20].
The most significant difference between the Hcp and Fcc sites comprises the distance to the nearest X element. In the Hcp site, the X element is directly below the terminating species, while for the Fcc site, three X elements are coordinated around the terminating species. The Fcc site has been predicted as the preferred site in numerous studies for both O, OH, and F terminations [1, 16, 20–25]. The reason for the Fcc site being the most favored was proposed to originate as a consequence of steric repulsion between the X element and the terminating species when positioned in the Hcp site [21]. However, some cases have been identified when the terminating species favors the vicinity of the X atom and hence also favors the Hcp site in order to gain more electrons [1, 21, 26, 27]. As a general prediction, the relative stability for each model (Fcc, Hcp, mixed) depends on the possible ionic state of the surface transition metal atoms. If the transition metals can assume an oxidation state that provide sufficient electrons to both the X element and the adsorbed terminating species, the Fcc configuration becomes the most stable. Otherwise, Hcp or mixed emerges as the most stable configuration [1]. The preference for the Fcc site may also be understood from the coordination number of the transition metal ion (M), which is often six. Hence, the surface M elements form octahedral building blocks (M-X3T3) with the underlying X-layer atoms and the terminating species T, with the M atom in the center of the octahedron. It has been observed through PDF analysis that the terminated Ti3C2 MXene shows a distortion in the structure, such that the distance between the surface M element and the underlying X layer is
8 MXene Surface Chemistry 129
different compared to the core M element layer and the adjacent X layers [13]. This was verified by a theoretical investigation, which concluded that the surface Ti 3d orbitals interact more strongly with the terminating species (O) 2p orbitals compared to the C 2p orbitals, resulting in a distortion of the octahedron [28].
Assuming that all Fcc sites are occupied by a termination group, then for each surface M element there is one terminating species. Consequently for Tx where x = 2 indicates saturation of the preferred surface sites. Yet, all other sites are available, such that if both Fcc and Hcp sites would be terminated, then x = 4. Most theoretical investigations assume x = 2, and even experimental investigations justify the elemental ratio between, e.g., O and F, according to this number. However, the occupancy of the MXene surface sites has been investigated, such that the binding energy vs. surface coverage was calculated for single-species systems on Ti2C [2]. It was assumed that the Fcc sites were first occupied; then additional species were placed in Hcp sites such that the surface was supersaturated. The binding energy does not change significantly with increasing occupancy of the Fcc sites, regardless of which species occupies the site. With increasing occupancy of the Hcp site, the binding energy per species increases significantly, though for all species the binding energy is still negative, even for complete saturation of both Fcc and Hcp sites. This however indicates that the system’s surface energy is minimized when all Fcc sites are occupied and Hcp sites are empty. In contrast to the common theoretical investigation, experimental quantifications predominantly report termination coverage with x < 2 [7, 10], but also x > 2 were reported [29]. Storage of MXenes at ambient conditions shows a slow and gradual oxidation that starts at the F-terminated sites, transforming the MXenes into metal oxyfluorides and causing a decrease in the amount of F terminations while increasing the number of O terminations on the MXene [7]. Particularly for systems that are oxidized to the point of ammorphization display x 2. Given the present experimental understanding, the level of saturation of the MXene surfaces by terminating species is not understood, and experiments with tailored surface composition are called for. Vice versa, while experimental investigations identify a mix of terminating species, only a few theoretical investigations have addressed the emerging properties from mixed terminations [30, 31].
The relative stability of the O, OH, and F (as well as H) terminating species has been addressed from both theoretical and experimental considerations. Based on Bader charge analysis and thermodynamic stability analysis, it was concluded that for Fcc site-saturated MXene surfaces, such that x = 2, the order of stability goes as Ti3C2O2 > Ti3C2F2 > Ti3C2OH2 > Ti3C2H2 [2, 28].
A recent temperature-programmed investigation combining (S)TEM and XPS identified the MXene surface as highly dynamical, as shown by the XPS results in Fig. 8.3. The XPS investigation revealed that F occupies only one site at any applied temperature throughout the experiment. However, O moves about on the surface, which can be seen as a reorganization of the O signal with temperature. At temperatures above 600 ◦C, F starts to desorb, and in the wake, O moves to occupy the abandoned site. This preferred site was identified by atomically resolved (S)TEM imaging as the Fcc site [29]. In the complementary TEM investigation,
130 P. O. Å. Persson
a few-layer Ti3C2Tx particle exhibited a clearly hexagonal appearance originating from the M3X2 structure, as expected, with the addition of a significantly disordered structure superimposed on the ordered Ti3C2. Upon heating the multilayer particle in vacuum, the disordered appearance was removed in favor of an ordered appearance in conjunction with the desorption of F from the MXene surface.
The experiment nicely describes a range of fundamentals; the preferred site for a functionalizing species is the theoretically predicted Fcc site. Furthermore, among the mixed terminations, F is the element that insists on occupying the preferred site over O. According to the increased water vapor pressure for vacuum conditions and at elevated temperatures, any OH contribution to the O signal was estimated as negligible. Also, little or no reduction of the O signal was observed during heating. Consequently, the surface-bound O displays a configuration with two alternative sites initially (with some redistribution with temperature) as identified by the O 1s signal. The experiment further identifies O to be the most stable terminating species, since it prevails as F desorbs. The preference for F to occupy the FCC site over O was suggested to occur as a consequence of the higher electronegativity. Finally, the experiment indicates that heating is a viable process route to deplete the MXene surfaces from F.
The disordered appearance, together with the two identified alternative sites for O, indicates that the position of O terminations on the surface is not necessarily well defined prior to F desorption. Indeed, diffusion of O on a Ti2C surface was investigated by theoretical means [19]. While diffusing from one Fcc site to the
8 MXene Surface Chemistry 131
next, an initial barrier of 0.53 eV has to be overcome in order to pass a Bridge site and into a Hcp site. However, from the Hcp site, crossing a Bridge and into the Fcc site, the barrier is approximately half (0.26 eV). With such negligible barriers, the diffusion between Hcp and Bridge sites is nearly barrierless. Also, during the diffusion process, the charge state of an O termination (again assuming x = 2) hardly changes from either sites (Fcc, −1.465 |e|; Bridge, −1.416 |e|; Hcp, −1.492 |e|). However, these conditions assume that the surface is exclusively terminated by O.
The dynamical properties of the terminations was observed by low-kV (S)TEM at ambient temperature on single- and double-sheet Ti3C2Tx MXene as shown in Fig. 8.4 [6]. The low-kV method promotes contrast from surface terminating species on 2D materials as shown here. From Fig. 8.4 it can be seen that the terminating species are organized in clusters that move about on the MXene surface. Using EELS, little or no F was observed on these sheets due to extended storage at ambient conditions; however, the clusters were identified as O-rich. Although some heating is applied to the MXene as a consequence of the interaction with the electron beam, the migration occurs already at low temperatures and underscores the facile migration of O surface terminations. From Fig. 8.4, it can also be observed that the O terminations are strongly attracted to single Ti adatoms that are scattered about the surface. The Ti adatoms presumably originate from defects in the MXene structure [6, 17]. Also the Ti adatoms are seen to organize themselves in clusters that
132 P. O. Å. Persson
attract a cloud of O terminations at ambient temperatures. At higher temperatures, interstitials have been observed to organize themselves into additional MX layers on Ti3C2Tx, during in situ heating and local e-beam heating in the STEM [32].
Such localized TiOx structures presumably destabilize the MXene. To verify this, a recent investigation into Nb2CTx was published, where the MXene was prepared such that >2/3 of the surface area was covered by adatoms immediately after etching (more than two adatoms per three M atoms); see Fig. 8.5b [33]. Though the immediate structure was highly organized, storage under high vacuum conditions initially depleted the surface from adatoms that were presumed to agglomerate and locally form NbOx clusters together with the migrating O terminations. These clusters served to locally destabilize and amorphize the MXene structure, leaving the adjacent MXene structure free from adatoms as shown in Fig. 8.5c. Upon exposure to ambient conditions, the structure was almost entirely amorphized as shown in Fig. 8.5d. These observations together identify O terminations as particularly attracted by surface adatoms and that the formed clusters become a nucleating point for degradation of the MXene structure.
Presently, MXenes exhibit a mix of terminations that is somewhat controlled. In order to correlate the MXene properties with the terminating species, it is essential to find means of tailoring the surface terminations. Additionally, to find unprecedented properties and new applications for MXenes, the inherent mix of terminations must be replaced with entirely new species. Accordingly, there has been some interest in tailoring the relative composition of the surface terminating species [9, 10, 15, 18, 28]. It is clear that the etchant constitutes the first and simplest choice toward tailored termination. Reducing the HF concentration during etching results in MXenes terminated by a reduced number of F terminations and a larger O/F ratio. NMR has also been used to investigate differences in terminations while changing the etchant. It was found that HF-synthesized MXenes contained approximately four times more F terminations compared to MXenes synthesized by a combination of LiF and HCl [10]. Further tailoring of the terminating species can also be achieved using post etching treatments such as by K+ ion intercalation. Using potassium hydroxide and potassium acetate in aqueous solutions, it was shown that the relative F termination content is reduced significantly as Ti-F bonds were suggested to become unstable at high pH [34]. A facile method for entirely avoiding terminations by F, and promoting O-containing species, is by alternatives to HF or LiF etching. A recent investigation employed a hydrothermal process to etch Ti3AlC2 at 270 ◦C in a 27.5 m NaOH solution. The results showed the removal of Al from Ti3AlC2 yielding only OH- and O-terminated multilayer Ti3C2Tx with a yield of 92 wt% [35].
While showing promise for tuning the terminating species and hence the MXene properties, available terminating species remain limited to those inherent to the etchant. Enyashin et al. proposed the replacement of the aqueous solution for alcohol or aqueous-alcohol solution and showed using density-functional tightbinding (DFTB), DFT, and MD calculations that methoxy-terminated MXenes can be stable. These findings suggest MXenes for catalytic applications such as in esterification processes [36].
8 MXene Surface Chemistry 133
Another approach for termination manipulation and for achieving terminations that are not inherent to the etchant is through a reduction process following the etching procedure. For example, removal of F terminations using a high-temperature vacuum annealing process has been investigated in a number of publications, such as shown in Fig. 8.3. However, temperatures exceeding ~750 ◦C typically initiate a phase transformation, where the 2D sheets transform into a 3D structure [29, 37].
Having removed F (and OH) at high temperatures and at high vacuum conditions, only O remains on the surface. Depending on the original coverage, some sites become available to new terminations that can be introduced, e.g., through gas
134 P. O. Å. Persson
phase. This allows, e.g., complete saturation of the MXene surfaces by O or introduction and adsorption of new species.
From a theoretical perspective, a number of new terminations have been investigated, including N- and Cl-functionalized MXenes [38, 39]. By investigating N-terminated Nb2C and Ta2C by first-principle calculations, Shao et al. found that these MXenes are not only stable but that they additionally exhibit direct bandgap semiconducting properties and ultrahigh carrier mobility equaling or exceeding that of graphene. Wang et al. also used a first-principle approach to investigate the electrochemical storage mechanism of Cl− ions onto MXenes. It was observed that Cl ion diffusion requires a much lower kinetic barrier for diffusion on the 2D surface than for the barrier connected to diffusion in bulk materials. This was expected to lead to a large reversible Cl capacity and high-rate capability.
While MXenes have been primarily investigated for applications in electrochemistry and for electronics, recently a number of theoretical works have investigated these materials for their properties in carbon capture, storage, and conversion [40, 41]. Morales-Garcia and Li have shown independently that the bare MXene surface can easily accommodate the CO2 molecule. Given the large surface area of MXenes, reaching 250–1000 m2 g−1, these materials can accommodate 2.34(W2C) -8.25(Ti2C) mol CO2 kg−1. These numbers are highly competitive to existing solutions for carbon capture, e.g., the zeolite I3X accommodates 3.96 mol CO2 kg−1.
Li further showed that the MXenes can catalyze a conversion of the captured CO2 to CH4 with a modest input of energy.
In summary, MXene surface terminations play an important role in the stability of the MXene structure and for the emerging properties. Currently, little is understood about the occupancy and on the dynamics of the terminations. It is clear that the terminations can be somewhat manipulated through the design of etching protocols and through post-processing. However, complete control is still lacking, and the currently measured termination composition may equally well depend on the preparation process as well as the interactions with ambient atmosphere as well as the experimental setup. The current research front is required to develop toward complete control of the surface terminations in order to tailor properties for specific applications, such as termination by non-inherent species.

sections.heading: Molecular Dynamics Simulations of MXenes: Ab Initio, Reactive, and Non-reactive Empirical Force Fields
Roghayyeh Lotfi, Dundar E. Yilmaz, Lukas Vlcek, and Adri van Duin
Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years two-dimensional materials have attracted tremendous attention due to their superior electronic, mechanical, chemical, and optical properties. MXene structures, which are among the latest additions to the 2-D materials, have been extensively studied because of their diverse applications from energy storage including electrode materials, lithium-ion batteries, and supercapacitors to water purification and catalysis [1]. Computational methods are powerful and useful techniques for developing and optimizing novel materials. Among different computational methods, molecular dynamics (MD) simulations can provide efficient, deep, detailed, and realistic understanding of physical and chemical basis of different materials and systems. MD solves the classical Newton’s equations of motion for the interacting many-particle system [2]. MD can be categorized into three different groups ab initio, reactive, and non-reactive empirical force fields. Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) methods use direct quantum calculations for calculating the forces between the particles in each MD iteration, while empirical force field-based methods (non-reactive and reactive) use a predefined mathematical expression (force field) to calculate the forces. The parameters of the force field are usually obtained from fitting to the quantum calculations or the experimental data.
Roghayyeh Lotfi and Dundar E. Yilmaz contributed equally with all other contributors.
R. Lotfi · D. E. Yilmaz · A. van Duin ( ) Department of Mechanical Engineering, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, USA e-mail: RUL12@PSU.EDU; duy42@psu.edu; acv13@engr.psu.edu
L. Vlcek University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN, USA
© Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2019 B. Anasori, Y. Gogotsi (eds.), 2D Metal Carbides and Nitrides (MXenes), https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-19026-2_9
137
138 R. Lotfi et al.
AIMD methods are typically more precise than empirical MD methods, but the computational cost of AIMD is much higher. On the other hand, non-reactive MD methods are limited to the systems without explicit chemical reactions, but their computational cost is much lower than AIMD. Reactive MD methods use the bond order concept in force fields to simulate the systems with chemical reactions, and their computational cost is between AIMD and non-reactive MD methods. All three categories of MD techniques have been used for simulating the MXene structures based on the complexity and the desired time scale of the simulations. Here, we have briefly introduced the MD simulation technique with ab initio, reactive, and nonreactive empirical force fields. Then we have reviewed the simulation of MXene structures with MD simulations in different applications such as energy storage and adsorption of ions and molecules, catalysis, exfoliation, and water purification.

sections.heading: Molecular Dynamics Simulations
sections.text:
MD simulations predict the time evolution of a system with interacting particles. The basic principle of any kind of simulation is to model the environment of the subject and calculate the observables based on the model. For atomistic simulations, the subject is ensemble of atoms and the environment is the interaction between them. The observables are calculated via modeling forces between particles and calculating the positions and velocities of them at each iteration of the simulation. One of the simplest models is Lennard-Jones (LJ) potential:

9 Molecular Dynamics Simulations of MXenes: Ab Initio, Reactive, and Non-. . . 139
Here t is the time step of the simulation. The continuous motion of atoms is approximated as discrete jumps in the time domain. Size of these jumps is often called MD time step. Observables of the system can be measured using velocities or positions of atoms.
Apart from errors caused by modeling the continuous motion as discrete jumps in Eq. 9.4, the total energy of the system (E) is conserved. Thus, the ensemble of such a system is the microcanonical, in which total energy, number of atoms, and volume (N, V, E) are conserved. Observables such as temperature and pressure should be controlled in order to simulate the system under the desired conditions. Controlling the pressure of the system can be achieved by simply adjusting the volume of the simulation box. The temperature of the system can be controlled by adding an external system as a heat bath to mimic the surrounding of a real system. This interaction can be modeled by scaling the velocities of particles. The basis of scaling is the fact that when an atom or particle collides with another particle, the result of this collision is a change in the velocity of the particle, v∗ = sv. The kinetic energy term regarding to the scaling factor s is introduced to construct the dynamical equation for s. The equations of motions for this extended system become:
ma = − 1 s2 ∇E − 2ṡ s v (9.5)
Thus, the temperature of the system can be controlled with scaling velocities of atoms in the system. In such a system temperature is constant along with number of particles and volume (N, V, T) as a canonical ensemble. This method first proposed by Nose in 1984 [3] and extended a year later by Hoover [4] and often called Nose– Hoover thermostat. Some other thermostats such as Berendsen [5] and Andersen [6] have also been developed.

sections.heading: The Empirical Force Fields and Bond Order Concept in Molecular Dynamics Simulations
sections.text:
Atomistic simulations utilize “force field” to determine the interatomic potentials and calculate the system energy. A force field is a set of mathematical expressions to relate the energy of a system to the coordinates of its atoms. It consists of functional forms of interatomic potential energies and a set of parameters. The parameters are usually obtained by fitting to the quantum chemistry calculations or the experimental data. The first force fields appeared in 1966 by Keating [7], who modeled the diamond structure using a bond stretching and bond angle term. Since then the goal of research in this area has changed to develop force fields applicable form more complicated systems. Good examples are MM, Dreiding, Universal (UFF), CHARMM, AMBER, GROMOS, OPLS, and COMPASS. More
140 R. Lotfi et al.
details about empirical force fields can be found in Ref. [8]. A typical expression for a force field includes the following terms for energy description:
Esystem = Ebond + Eangle + Etorsion + EvdWaals + ECoulomb
= kb(b − b0)2 + kv(θ − θ0)2 + Vn [1 + cos (nω − δ)] + 4εij [( σij rij )12 − (σijrij )6] + C qijrij
(9.6)
where the first three terms are related to the intramolecular interactions in the total energy (including bond stretching, angle bending, and dihedral torsion), and the last two terms are related to the intermolecular contribution in the total energy (van der Waals interactions, in this case a 12-6 Lennard-Jones potential, and the Coulombic interactions). In this equation, the terms which describe the geometry of the structure include the bond length, b, the valence angle, θ, the dihedral or torsion angle, ω, and the distance between atoms i and j, rij. The parameters include the bond force constant and equilibrium distance, kb and b0, respectively; the valence angle force constant and equilibrium angle, kv, and θ0; the dihedral angle force constant, multiplicity, and phase angle, Vn, n, and δ, the partial atomic charges, qi, the LJ well-depth, εij, minimum interaction radius, σij, and Coulomb’s constant, C [8].
However, such force fields are not sufficient to consider the changes in the connectivity of atoms during the bond breaking and formation, especially in chemical reactions. Thus, it is necessary to compute the bonds based on local geometry instead of having pre-defined bonds. This motivates the use of some terms in the force-field description, which are related to the connectivity of the atoms, leading to a reactive force field. Reactive force fields can be categorized into two groups. The first group is based on electron density such as the Finnis–Sinclair, embedded-atom method (EAM), modified EAM (MEAM), and Stillinger–Weber (SW). The second group is based on the integrated bond order terms such as Abell, Chelikowsky, Tersoff, REBO, COMB, and ReaxFF. More detailed information about reactive force fields can be found in the review paper [9]. To the best of our knowledge, simulation of MXene structures with reactive force fields has only been implemented with ReaxFF force field. Thus, ReaxFF technique has been introduced with more details in the next section.

sections.heading: ReaxFF Force Fields
sections.text:
ReaxFF is a bond order based reactive force field formalism which allows bond formation and bond breaking during molecular dynamics simulation [10, 11]. Bond order is empirically calculated from interatomic distances between all pairs of atoms and it is updated at each step. Consequently, a smooth transition between the non-bonded states and single, double, or triple bonded states would be possible. This approach leads to the simulation of chemical reactions with a comparable
9 Molecular Dynamics Simulations of MXenes: Ab Initio, Reactive, and Non-. . . 141
accuracy to quantum calculations but with much lower computational cost. Unlike in traditional force fields, in ReaxFF, each element is described by only one single atom type and the reaction site or connectivity information is not needed beforehand. Such transferability allows proper migration of atoms between phases during the molecular dynamics simulation. Bond order is calculated directly from interatomic distance using the empirical formula:

where BO is the bond order, rij is the distance between atoms i and j, and rO and pbo terms are equilibrium bond lengths and empirical parameters, respectively. This equation is continuous by transitions between σ , π , and ππ bonds, leading to a differentiable potential energy surface for calculating the interatomic forces. The total interaction energy in ReaxFF is described by the following energy contributions:
Esystem = Ebond + Eover + Eunder + Etor + Eval + Elp + Evdw + Ecoulombic (9.8)
The total energy of the system (Esystem) consists of bonded or covalent interactions (which are bond order dependent) and non-bonded interactions. Bond order-dependent terms include bond energy (Ebond), over-coordination (Eover), and under-coordination (Eunder). Energy penalty terms include torsion-angle energy (Etor), valance-angle energy (Eval), and lone pair energy (Elp). Non-bonded interactions include van der Waals (Evdw) and Coloumb energy (Ecoulomb). All connectivity energy terms, such as valance-angle and torsion-angle, are bond order dependent. In addition, non-bonded interactions such as van der Waals and Coulomb terms are taken into account for the entire system between each pair of atoms. Atomic charges are derived from an electronegativity equalization method (EEM) [12]. It should be noted that despite the previous bond order based reactive force fields (such as Tersoff and Brenner), a dynamic charge method is used in ReaxFF which changes the charge on the atoms based on their chemical environment. Furthermore, in comparison to the previous reactive potentials, a longer-ranged bond order is used in ReaxFF, leading to more precise transition states and reaction kinetics.

sections.heading: Modeling MXenes with Classical Non-reactive Force Fields
sections.text:
Many structural and thermodynamic aspects of MXenes and their interactions with solvents and electrolytes have been studied using simple non-reactive force fields. Despite their limitation to the investigation of processes without explicit chemical reactions, these models offer high computational efficiency for the simulations of large-scale systems and slow dynamics of electrode charging. Moreover, they are often optimized for a given set of thermodynamic conditions and may therefore reproduce specific properties more accurately than more general models. Although only a few models have been developed specifically for MXenes, a large variety of
9 Molecular Dynamics Simulations of MXenes: Ab Initio, Reactive, and Non-. . . 143
force fields are readily available from literature for most common fluid compounds. However, combining force fields from different sources and optimizing separately for the solid and fluid phases must be done with care and, ideally, be validated by comparison with density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The atomic interactions are typically defined through a combination of the non-bonded LennardJones (LJ) potential with point charge electrostatics, along with harmonic bonded terms such as in the popular force field sets of OPLS or UFF. For pure solids, simple many-body embedded atom models (EAMs) have been applied. Their availability along with computational efficiency makes simple force fields an ideal tool for the exploration of the configurational space, interpretation of scattering experiments, and testing hypotheses about possible interfacial and confined microstructures. Such exploratory simulations can be then followed by more expensive quantumchemical calculations to include more realistic description of electronic properties and chemical reactions.
Atomistic simulations have provided the first insights into the mechanical properties of individual MXene sheets, whose micrometer size poses a significant challenge for their direct experimental study. In the absence of existing optimized force fields for MXenes, Borysiuk et al. combined the EAM potential for Ti-Ti interactions with two- and three-body terms for Ti–C and C–C interactions to study a selected titanium carbide (Tin+1Cn) sheets [15, 16]. In close agreement with previously published DFT data [17], their investigation of Ti2C under tensile loading yielded Young’s modulus of ~1 TPa, which is about 50% lower than for graphene but three times higher than for MoS2. The simulations also indicate different modes of failure and fracturing as a function of the number of atomic layers [15]. The follow-up study of bending rigidity predicted the effective spring constant for Ti2C to be larger than for graphene but lower than MoS2, [16] while the bending rigidity of multilayer sheets Ti3C2 and Ti4C3 was higher than the other two single-layer materials.
Charging and discharging dynamics of [EMIM]+[PF6]− in Ti3C2(OH)2 MXene pores has been studied by Xu et al. using MD simulations [18]. In their setup, the positive and negative electrodes were represented by rigid immovable MXene plates situated in the same simulation box, and were gradually charged and discharged by scaling atomic charges during the course of the simulation. The authors observed that in the first stage of the charging process counter-ions compensating the electrode charge enter the pore and then, with a delay, co-ions leave the pore. The resulting fluctuations in the total number of ions confined in the slit pores during the charge–discharge cycles suggested that a volumetric response of the electrodes should be observed for a more realistic representation of the system with mobile MXene plates. In a follow-up study, Xu et al. investigated changes in interlayer spacing as a response to the positive and negative charging of Ti3C2T2 (T=O, OH, F) MXene in [EMIM]+[TFSI]− [19] with OPLS force field and MXene plates represented as rigid but movable bodies. In agreement with the trends observed in combined electrochemical and X-ray diffraction experiments [20, 21], they found volume expansion for negative polarization and contraction for positive polarization. At the atomic scale, the expansion was seen as the result of the cation intercalation,
whereas the contraction was mostly the result of ion exchange and, to smaller extent, cation de-intercalation.
The response of ion-intercalated MXenes to water has been investigated in a study combining scattering, electrochemical, and gravimetric experiments with classical and quantum chemical simulations [22]. The atomistic simulations have been used to identify the driving forces behind volumetric changes measured during hydration and dehydration cycles, such as the strong hysteresis of this process or large interlayer separations of Mg2+-intercalated MXenes at low hydration levels. The classical simulations suggested that in the confined environment the compact Mg(H2O)6 clusters can act as pillars with voids in-between (Fig. 9.1). In contrast, the weaker bonds between monovalent K+ ions and water molecules do not allow the formation of similarly stable clusters, which leads to smaller interlayer separations for K+-intercalated MXenes. However, since strong electrostatic forces exerted by the ionic charges will significantly polarize the conducting MXene plates, the simple force field cannot be expected to provide accurate answers about the strength of the interfacial interactions and assess reliably the metastability of the structures. To reduce this uncertainty, the structures generated in the classical simulations were used as input into DFT simulations, which confirmed that Mg(H2O)6 clusters are stable enough to.
MXenes have also been suggested as prospective molecular sieving membranes and studied by Ding et al. using MD simulations [23]. The authors calculated the flux and diffusion of small gas particles (H2, He, N2, O2, CO2, and CH4) through MXene with two different terminations, Ti3C2O2 and Ti3C2O2 and a constant pore gap of 3.5 Å. To capture the different response of MXene to the strong quadrupole moment of CO2 molecules the interactions of MXene atoms were described by a combination of the UFF force field with QEq charge equilibration [24, 25]. While they observed no significant effect of the surface termination on gas permeation, the simulations predicted large differences between the mobility of different gasses. In particular, gas particles with sizes smaller than the pore width (H2 He) diffused approximately 100 times faster than the remaining larger molecules. Even though no experiments measuring dynamics were performed to validate the model and its predictions, the good agreement between the simulated
9 Molecular Dynamics Simulations of MXenes: Ab Initio, Reactive, and Non-. . . 145
and experimental selectivities, including the high selectivity for CO2/H2 mixtures, attributed to the specific CO2 interactions, suggests that the simulations likely capture the correct trends in the dynamics as well.

sections.heading: Modeling MXenes with Reactive ReaxFF Force Field
sections.text:
As mentioned earlier, reactive molecular dynamics can model the chemical reactions and interactions during the simulation. Among them, ReaxFF has the advantage of predicting the transition states and reaction kinetics more precisely in comparison to other reactive force fields. MD simulations with ReaxFF have been used for studying the ion intercalation and water diffusion in MXene sheets as well as measuring the friction coefficient of these structures.
Due to hydrophilic nature of MXene surfaces and weak attraction between the layers, water molecules can intercalate in MXene structure easily. Osti et al. used X-ray and neutron scattering techniques to show that presence of potassium cations enhances the homogeneity and water stability in MXenes [26]. They also used ReaxFF molecular dynamics simulations, and they found that similar to the experiment, presence of potassium ions decreases the self-diffusion of water molecules and increases the stability of hydrated MXene. To consider the interaction of Ti3C2Tx layers intercalated with pure water and metal ions, they developed a new ReaxFF description from previously developed potentials for water and cations and for Ti/O/H interaction by adding new DFT data for Ti-C bond, C-Ti-C/O angles and the energy of condensed phases. To intercalate water molecules and metal ions in the interlayer spacing of MXene layers, Grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulation was carried out. During the MC simulations, water molecules had the capability to be randomly added into the system, removed, or moved. After each 20 successful GCMC iterations, subsequent MD simulation was performed for 10 ps under isobaric–isothermal condition (NPT) at 300 K and 0.1 MPa. The results indicated that the intercalated potassium ions decrease the diffusion coefficient of water in the ion-intercalated MXene by two orders of magnitude in comparison to the pristine MXene (Fig. 9.2). The reduction in water diffusion coefficient due to ion-induced effect indicates a higher stability of hydrated MXene.
In another work, Osti et al. studied the effects of intercalated metal ions (lithium, sodium, or potassium ions) on the vibrational states of water confined in Ti3C2Tx MXene structures using inelastic neutron scattering (INS) and MD simulations [27]. Such study is important for understanding the behavior of MXenes in different applications such as aqueous electrolytes and water purification. Using INS, the authors observed that water in pristine MXene is more disordered, while it is more ordered in intercalated MXene. They confirmed this result with ReaxFF MD simulation for a system of 1776 atoms at 300 K. The results indicated that by increase in ion size, the mobility of water molecules decreases. As shown in Fig. 9.3, Li+ ions position themselves between the MXene surface and water layers, while K+ (and almost Na+) ions sit along the water layer. Moreover, the results
146 R. Lotfi et al.
revealed that the order of diffusion coefficient of water in intercalated MXene is as following: Li+ > Na+ > K+ and all of these coefficients are about two orders of magnitude lower than that of bulk water. This means that the interference of Li+ ions with water molecules is lower than Na+ and K+ ions. Thus, the water molecules in the presence of Li+ ions are more disordered, whereas Na+ and K+ ions make the water molecules more ordered through higher resistance to the water motion. The radial distribution function (RDF) for water also confirmed that the order parameter of the water molecules is as following: Li+ < Na+ < K+.
Selective ion intercalation between MXene layers has the potential in development of charge selective membranes for water treatment applications. Thus, dynamical response of MXenes to intercalation of ions is crucial. Berdiyorov and Mahmoud used DFT, AIMD, and ReaxFF to investigate the effect of surface termination on the dynamical response of bilayer MXenes to intercalation of different ions (Fig. 9.4) [28]. They observed an increase and a decrease in the interlayer distance with intercalation of anions and cations, respectively. It decreased further with increasing charge of the cations by adding extra electrons to the MXene
layers. They conducted ReaxFF MD simulations using published parameters for Ti3C2(OH)2 MXene systems [26]. In this case, the system consists of bilayer MXene with 144 atoms and 14 water molecules. The temperature of the system was increased from 0 to 300 K with a rate of 3 K/ps with NPT ensemble. The simulation continued for 1 ns at 300 K with NVT ensemble. In the presence of water molecules, the distance between MXene layers averaged 7.62 Å without any ions. Adding two K+ ions between layers decreased the interlayer distance to 7.57 Å. This dynamic response originates from the charged nature of the material. These simulations confirmed selective intercalation of MXenes which is important for designing the membranes based on MXenes for water treatment applications.
Due to low friction coefficients between layers of similar two-dimensional materials, it is expected that Ti3C2 MXenes also have low friction coefficients. Zhang et al. calculated friction coefficients of Tin+1Cn MXenes (n = 1, 2, and 3) with and without surface termination, using DFT and ReaxFF MD simulations [29]. Stacking energies of multilayer structures were calculated. There are three highsymmetry stacking sequences for all three cases: the one with bottom oxygen atoms of the upper layer is at face-centered cubic positions with respect to bottom layer (Fig. 9.5c S1), one with the bottom oxygen atoms of the upper layer sits at the hexagonal close-packed positions of the bottom layer (Fig. 9.5d S2), and finally one with bottom oxygen atoms of the upper layer is at the top of oxygen atoms of bottom layer (Fig. 9.5e S3). The energetics of these stacking sequences sampled with DFT calculations by gradually shifting the top layer, while bottom layer was fixed.
For all cases, S1 is the minimum energy configuration for the stacking of layers. Type S2 is the local minima with slightly higher potential energy. The S3
148 R. Lotfi et al.
sequences are local maxima in the potential energy surfaces due to repulsive forces between oxygen atoms of top and bottom layers. To investigate the sliding of larger Tin+1CnO2 MXene (for n = 1, 2, and 3) bilayer systems, Zhang et al. carried out the MD simulations with ReaxFF potentials [29]. These systems contained 40,000– 70,000 atoms with simulation cell dimensions of 19 × 18 × 3 nm. Figure compares the energy change during the sliding calculated with DFT (Fig. 9.6a) and ReaxFF (Fig. 9.6b). ReaxFF calculations produced the same trend, albeit higher energies at S2.
Based on DFT and ReaxFF simulations, average friction coefficients were calculated between 0.24 and 0.26 for normal pressures below 1.2 GPa. They also considered the effect of Ti vacancies at the sublayer and terminal O vacancies at the surface in ReaxFF simulations. These defects increased the roughness of the structure and consequently the friction coefficient.

sections.heading: Modeling MXenes with Ab Initio Molecular Dynamics
sections.text:
Ab initio molecular dynamics can be named as the most precise and the most computationally expensive MD technique. In each MD iteration, the interatomic forces are calculated using electronic structure-based quantum techniques. AIMD method has been used in studying MXene structures in two different categories.
9 Molecular Dynamics Simulations of MXenes: Ab Initio, Reactive, and Non-. . . 149
In the first category, AIMD is used directly for finding the final structure and calculating some properties of the system. For example, adsorption of H2 molecules, uranyl, and Li and Na ions on MXene structure and exfoliation of MAX phases to MXene have been studied by this category of AIMD. Second group of AIMD simulations on MXene structures has used AIMD to confirm the stability of the system at finite temperatures. Some studies on MXenes such as adsorption of heavy metals, magnetic and metallic properties, Li intercalation, and photocatalytic water splitting have used AIMD to check the stability of the system at a specified temperature.
Hu et al. used DFT to find the hydrogen storage properties of the twodimensional (2D) Ti2C MXene [30]. They showed that depending on different adsorption sites, the hydrogen can be stored by three modes: chemisorption, physisorption, and Kubas-type. The authors used AIMD simulations to verify that the hydrogen molecules bonded by Kubas-type can be desorbed reversibly under ambient conditions. The simulations were performed at 300 and 400 K for 1.5 ps with a time step of 1.0 fs. The results indicated that at both temperatures of 300 and 400 K, all of physisorbed H2 molecules desorb from the surfaces, while all chemisorbed H2 molecules stay at the initial sites. H2 molecules bonded by Kubastype interaction revealed different behaviors at 300 and 400 K. At 300 K, only three H2 molecules departed, while at 400 K, almost half of the H2 molecules by Kubas-type interaction released from the surface (during the short simulation time of 1.5 ps). Thus, the AIMD simulations confirmed that Ti2C MXene structure is a reversible hydrogen storage material in the temperature range 300–400 K.
In a similar work, Hu et al. investigated the hydrogen storage capacity of 2D Sc2C MXene structure [31] and showed that similar to Ti2C MXene, three types of interaction including chemisorption, physisorption, and Kubas-type are observed
for hydrogen storage in Sc2C. To study the desorption behavior of hydrogen from Sc2C surface AIMD was performed at 273 and 400 K for 1.5 ps with a time step of 1.0 fs (Fig. 9.7). At temperature of 273 and 400 K, all the chemisorbed H atoms stay at the initial sites and all the H2 molecules stored by physisorption desorb from the surfaces. The Kubas type H2 molecules remained on their sites at 273 K, while almost all of them were released from the surface at 400 K. They concluded that Sc2C is a suitable reversible hydrogen storage media under ambient conditions.
Zhang et al. used DFT simulations to study the adsorption of uranyl ions on hydroxylated MXene Ti3C2(OH)2 in aqueous environments [32]. In order to investigate the solvated effect on the configuration of adsorbed uranyl on MXene structure, they performed AIMD simulations based on finite-temperature density functional theory (FT-DFT) at temperature of 298.5 K for 10 ps with time steps of 1.0 fs. The water molecules were added randomly to the optimized adsorption configuration. The pair correlation functions were obtained by averaging over the last 5-ps simulation (Fig. 9.8). The results indicated the aqua solution does not influence the configurations of water ligands of uranyl, verifying that the model without aqua solution used for the adsorption of uranyl on hydroxylated MXene is reliable.
In a similar work, Zhang et al. used DFT-based electronic structure simulations to study the adsorption of uranyl ions on hydroxylated V2C MXene structure [33]. They used AIMD simulations within the NVT canonical ensemble to find the stable surface morphology of hydroxylated V2C surfaces. The Nose–Hoover thermostat
9 Molecular Dynamics Simulations of MXenes: Ab Initio, Reactive, and Non-. . . 151
was used at T = 298 K for a run time of 10 ps with time steps of 1.0 fs. They added 56 H2O molecules on both sides of the V2C MXene to reach a density close to the real density of aqueous water (1 g/cm3). Figure 9.9 shows the AIMD snapshots of V2C MXene structure in water solution at 0, 1, and 8 ps. The results indicated that OH functional groups are located on top of the hollow sites between three neighboring C atoms. Moreover, the surface structures at 1 and 8 ps are almost similar, indicating that the surfaces of V2C MXene structure are covered rapidly with OH functional groups.
Chemical exfoliation of MAX phases to MXene layers often involves intercalation of reactants between layers. Sirvastava et al. used DFT calculations for
152 R. Lotfi et al.
understanding the exfoliation of MXene from bulk phase via HF solution [34]. In order to investigate the effects of HF concentration and temperature on the exfoliation process, AIMD simulations were performed at 300 K with a time step of 1 fs and the plane wave basis set cutoff of 350 eV at different concentrations of HF 1–18% (Fig. 9.10). At low concentration of HF, the F atom binds with Al and with concentration increase, AlF3 and H2 are formed (AlF3 by dark orange and cyan colors, and H2 by dark pink color). Moreover, the results indicated that higher temperature enhances the reaction rate.
In a similar work, the transformation of Nb4AlC3 MAX structure to Nb4C3 MXene was studied using AIMD method by Mishra et al. [35]. It has been showed that Nb-C bond is stronger than the Nb-Al bond [36]. This enables the insertion of guest atoms between the layers and breaking the Al bonds. Mishra et al. used AIMD technique to show chemical transformation of Nb4AlC3 MAX structure to Nb4C3 MXene by inserting Li atoms as guest atoms. The supercell contains 17 atoms (8 Nb, 6 C, Li, Al, F atoms). MD time step set to 1 fs. After increasing the temperature to 500 K the bonds started to dissociate at 200 fs of the simulation. This leads to the isolation of one pristine layer of MXene from the MAX phase. Snapshots from the simulation display the isolation process (Fig. 9.11).
They also increased the supercell to 3 × 1 × 1 to support the conclusion. In this case, Nb Li bond increased by 20% at 500 K in 20 ps. Later, temperature was increased to 650 K and N-Li bonds dissociated completely in 3 ps. These results clearly show isolation of MXene layers is possible by inserting LiF into the MAX phase.
Sun et al. systematically studied the adsorption of Li ions on MXenes [37]. In this study, the change in the structure was investigated as a function of Li concentration with first-principles calculations. V2C was selected as a representative MXene structure due to its capability of handling high charge–discharge rates and relative atomic weight of V with respect to other transition metals in MXene structures. AIMD simulations were also carried out to observe the structural transformations.
The simulation time was set to 2.0 ps with 1 fs MD time step and H1H2V2CO2Li2 was used as the initial structure. Here, first and second letters represent the adsorption sites for Li atoms and for O atoms, respectively. H1, H2, and T refer to adsorption sites on top of the C atom, on top of the surface metal atom, and on top of the sublayer metal atom, respectively. The temperature of the system was set at 800, 700, 600, and 500 K. At 700 and 800 K, migration of O atoms from H1 sites to T sites was observed. However, structural transformation was not observed below 650 K due to system size and simulation length. Same MD simulations were also carried out for Ta-MXene, which has the same crystal structure as V2CO2. For Ta2CO2 case, the structure transformation into corresponding H1T phase was observed at 650 K. The O atoms on the surface of V2CO2 shifted from H2 to T sites with adsorption of Li atoms. For the fully adsorbed first layer Li, H1TV2CO2Li2 is more energetically favorable with respect to H1 H2-V2CO2Li2 phase due to localized electrons and stronger bonds.
The predictive power of DFT along with AIMD simulations regularly used to design novel materials based on MXene structures. Meng et al. proposed Ti3C4, MXene-like material based on Ti3C2 MXene phase, for energy storage applications [38]. In this study, AIMD technique accompanied DFT calculations to investigate multilayer adsorption behavior of this proposed structure. After 10,000 MD steps at 800 K multilayer adsorption was only observed for Na ions and not for Li ions. For the case of Li ions, extra atoms more likely tend to form Li clusters (Fig. 9.11).
AIMD simulations are often used to support the static quantum calculations and show the fully relaxed system is stable at finite temperatures. It has been shown that MXene samples after full adsorption of heavy metal ions such as Pb and Cu
are thermally stable at 300 K with AIMD simulations [39]. In this work, Guo et al. used 3 × 3 supercell of saturated MXenes as starting configuration. The system was allowed to relax for 15 ps with an MD step of 3 fs. Ferro-magnetic M2N (M = Fe, Co, Ni) and half-metallic Cr2N MXenes were also shown to be thermally stable at room temperatures by using AIMD [40, 41].
As another energy storage application, Aierken et al. considered Li intercalation between Ti2CO2 MXene structure and graphene layer [42]. They performed AIMD simulations at 100 and 300 K for 6 ps and observed a stable structure of fully adsorbed Li layer between graphene and MXene layers. In a different study, AIMD simulations were conducted to investigate the surface structure of Ti3C2 MXene after etching with HF. Ti3C2 structure was immersed in HF solutions with different concentrations, and in all cases, the surfaces were rapidly covered with H, F, and OH functional groups during the AIMD simulations [43].
In a separate study, the possibility of Sc2C MXene structure as an anode material for battery applications was also explored with DFT and AIMD simulations [44]. Similar to the previous study, Lv et al. carried out AIMD simulations to show that two-dimensional Sc2C MXene structure is stable at 500 K.
There are other works which have used the ab initio molecular dynamics simulations as a proof of the system stability. For example, Si et al. predicted the quantum spin Hall (QSH) phase in Mo2M2C3O2 structures and by performing AIMD simulation with a Nose–Hoover thermostat at 300 K and a time step of 2 fs, the thermal stability of the structure was verified [45]. If after some simulation time, no significant structural deformation is observed, it can be concluded that the structure is thermally stable at room temperature. In another work, Ling et al. studied the effect of transition metal (TM: Fe, Co, and Ni) dopants on hydrogen production through water splitting over fully oxidized vanadium carbide MXenes (V2CO2) [46]. They confirmed the stability of TM-doped V2CO2 by performing AIMD simulation for 5 ps, with a time step of 2 fs. Guo et al. studied the efficiency of photocatalytic water splitting of 48 two-dimensional transition metal carbides,
9 Molecular Dynamics Simulations of MXenes: Ab Initio, Reactive, and Non-. . . 155
MXenes, and they found Zr2CO2 and Hf2CO2 structures as promising candidates for photocatalytic water splitting [47]. In order to investigate their stability in liquid water, AIMD simulations were performed at 300 K for 10 ps. The results indicated only slight vibration of atoms around their equilibrium positions suggesting that Zr2CO2 and Hf2CO2 would be stable in liquid water. Moreover, the normalized pair correlation functions g(r) of Zr2CO2 and Hf2CO2 confirmed the crystallinity of these structures under aqueous environment at around room temperature. He et al. introduced a new class of 2D magnetic materials, asymmetrically functionalized MXenes (Janus MXenes) such as Cr2CXX0 (X, X0 = H, F, Cl, Br, OH), which are fully compensated antiferromagnetic, and completely spin-polarized semiconductor [48]. They confirmed the thermal stability of the Cr2CFCl material by ab initio molecular dynamics simulations at 300 K.

sections.heading: Summary
sections.text: In this chapter, we reviewed the concept of MD simulation methods and their application in simulating MXene structures. We showed that MD simulations have been successfully used for simulating the MXene structures. Based on the system, different MD techniques including ab initio, reactive and non-reactive empirical force fields have been utilized to model these 2-D materials. A variety of MXene applications such as energy storage, adsorption, intercalation, catalysis, exfoliation, and photocatalytic water splitting have been modeled by MD simulations. In some cases, the results of simulations have been verified with the experiment. Continuing development on molecular dynamics techniques and computational facilities will further improve the usefulness and effectiveness of MD simulations in modeling the MXene structures in future.

sections.heading: Chemical and Electrochemical Intercalation of Ions and Molecules into MXenes
Michael Ghidiu, Michael Naguib, and Michel W. Barsoum
Introduction
sections.text:
Layered materials with weak bonds between the layers (van der Waals or hydrogen bonding) typically have space between the individual layers, where solvents and ions can move in and out in a process called intercalation. Such materials include clay minerals [1, 2], layered titanates [3], graphite and graphite oxide [4, 5], layered dichalcogenides [6], layered hydroxides, oxides [7, 8], etc. and have been well studied over the years.
MXenes as layered materials demonstrate intercalation of many species, including organic molecules and cations. The latter include metal cations or polyatomic cations such as organoammonium and can be intercalated chemically or electrochemically. Due to the young age of the field of MXenes research, the majority of this chapter focuses on Ti3C2, the most well-studied MXene. It is our expectation that the principles outlined here are general and will translate to other MXene compositions, though this remains to be pursued. The scope of this chapter is on ions and molecules that intercalate into layered MXene and their effects on structure and response. Discussion of applications involving intercalation is handled in other chapters.
