sections.heading: Organic Molecules
sections.text: MXenes can accommodate a wide variety of organic molecules (polymers are discussed in other chapters). As may be expected from the interaction of MXenes nanosheets with solvents [9], the solvent dielectric constant ε correlates with the ability of organic molecules to intercalate into the hydrophilic layered MXene, with molecules of high ε being preferred. Dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) and hydrazine monohydrate (HM) were some of the first to be intercalated. In general, the procedures for intercalating organic molecules involve simply immersing MXene into the desired solvent and allowing for the process to occur; the intercalation is generally spontaneous in ambient conditions.

sections.heading: Ions
sections.text: The preference for MXenes’ intercalation of cations over anions was demonstrated early on [10] and is similar to other layered intercalable materials, including clay minerals [1] and dichalcogenides [6]. Cations can be intercalated into MXenes either through chemical or electrochemical means and, like other materials, are subject to exchange for different cations. In clay minerals, close relatives in many aspects to MXenes, cations are a permanent fixture of the structure; they sit in the interlayer space and balance the inherent negative charges in the host sheets [1]. Such inherent negative charge has been suggested by studies of zeta potential of Ti3C2Tz, Ti3CNTz, and V2CTz (a strong function of pH, as shown in Fig. 10.1) [11, 12, 13]. In this chapter, we will use the nomenclature Ay-Mn + 1XnTz to designate a cation-intercalated structure, where A represents cations. Note here that Tz has been chosen instead of Tx to avoid confusion with the X-element (C/N) in MXene, though the literature currently includes both.

sections.heading: Chemical Route
sections.text:
The ionic composition of MXenes can be readily controlled through chemical reaction. To begin, ions must be introduced into the MXene structure. This was first accomplished by immersion of unintercalated MXene powders in solutions of various salts of the desired cations [10]. It was found that only salts of cations with base-forming anions, such as OH− and CH3COO−, would successfully introduce cations and other salts such as sulfates and chlorides had little to no effect of intercalating their corresponding cation. Further work showed that it was possible to introduce NH4+ during the etching process by using the cation of a bifluoride salt (NH4HF2); however, commercial bifluoride salts are not as readily available with a
diversity of cations as other salts [14]. Later work showed that chloride salts could indeed be used for cation intercalation, but that they needed to be present during the etching process, presumably while the MXene interlayers were expanded and exposed [15].
Due to salt solubilities in the etchant solution, highly soluble LiCl proved to be the best for this purpose. A mixture of 10% HF and 5 molar equivalents of LiCl yielded a highly ordered multilayered Li-Ti3C2Tz [15]. A typical XRD pattern is shown in Fig. 10.2, along with a theoretical pattern, showing a match for all peaks— this level of crystallinity is typically not seen in unintercalated MXene. Refining of this method with salts of other cations proved to be unnecessary (and difficult due to lower solubilities), as the Li-intercalated MXene can be transformed via ion exchange into other intercalated complexes, as discussed later.

sections.heading: Electrochemical Route
sections.text:
Electrochemical intercalation offers another method of controlling the ionic composition of MXenes. This was first realized in studies on Ti2CTz and Ti3C2Tz
164 M. Ghidiu et al.
as electrode material for Li-ion batteries using organic electrolyte and Li foils as counter electrodes [17]. Also, a variety of cations were inserted electrochemically, such as Li+, Na+, K+, NH4+, Mg2+, and Al3+ [10]. In general, this is accomplished by incorporating MXene as an electrode active material, choosing an electrolyte containing the desired cation, and applying a potential. In aqueous systems, care should be taken to not oxidize the MXene, by constraining the voltage window. Additionally, Cs+, Ba2+, Ca2+, tetramethyl-, tetraethyl-, and tetrabutylammonium have been electrochemically intercalated [18].

sections.heading: Cation Exchange and Available Cation Intercalants
sections.text:
MXenes are similar to other materials that contain cations as an integral part of their structure and are relatively held through weak interlayer electrostatic forces. Such materials include, for example, clay minerals, layered dichalcogenides, and layered titanates. An important property of these materials is ion exchange, or the ability for ions in the structure to be replaced by ions in a surrounding solution, simply by means of a concentration gradient. For the case of the most well-studied MXene Ti3C2Tz, starting with Li-Ti3C2Tz, a host of intercalated structures have been prepared via ion exchange. These are listed in Table 10.1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) evidence suggests that during exchange, Li+ is fully removed and replaced [15].
Organoammonium cations are of great interest due to their tailorability (the range of organic structures possible is quite large) and for the ability to introduce interesting moieties and nonpolar regions into the hydrophilic MXene interlayer space.
10 Chemical and Electrochemical Intercalation of Ions and Molecules into MXenes 165

sections.heading: Ion Densities in MXene Structures
sections.text:
Of great importance to applications involving intercalated cations is the density of ions per formula unit of the MXene host. Disregarding electrochemical intercalation for now, assuming a mechanism of permanent charge in the host structure to be balanced (like in clay minerals), or a finite number of sites of charge-holding groups, there is a natural upper limit to the number of ions that can be accepted into the structure (the total capacity of ions), and an equal or smaller number that may be readily removed and exchanged (the cation exchange capacity or CEC). Various methods exist in the literature of other materials for estimating the CEC [21]. Direct chemical analysis through methods such as energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and global elemental analysis has been used to quantify cations in the structure. The number of cations and the number of balancing charges ξ in the MXene structure are related simply by the valency of the cations (e.g. half as many divalent as monovalent cations are required to balance the same ξ ).
Reports to date [15, 19, 22] suggest that ξ for A-Ti3C2Tz ranges from 0.1 to 0.3, but the precision of those values is limited by either sample preparation uniformity or the analysis methods used. Muckley et al. report values for K+ at 0.14 per Ti3C2 and Mg2+ at 0.07, with H2O molecules per ion at 2 and 5, respectively, which are in decent agreement with earlier XPS analyses of 0.1–0.11 for Li+, Na+, and Rb+ [15]. For monovalent alkylammonium (AA) intercalants from Ref. [19], elemental analysis gives a value of ξ of 0.11, EDS analysis 0.12, and XPS 0.1–0.15. While the values are somewhat different, the consistency between analysis methods and samples gives evidence that the determined range of ξ is quite robust. These values are not constrained when ions are intercalated electrochemically, with the densities of cations then being generally proportional to current passed as cations enter the structure to balance the injected charge. The maximum number of intercalable cations (in a monolayer) is a function of the effective ionic radius [23], as shown theoretically for Ti3C2Tz in Fig. 10.3. These values can be sensitive to the surface composition of MXene [24].

sections.heading: Responses to Intercalation
sections.text: MXenes have a very wide structural response to cation intercalation. The main response is movement of the basal planes along the c direction and is highly sensitive to cation chemistry, spatial organization, and hydration. For simplicity’s sake, we will describe all c expansions here in terms of a single layer-to-layer spacing, or d002 in the case of P63/mmc symmetry. Understanding these driving forces is important in accurately determining what structural expansion to expect given varying conditions. Further responses include changes in mechanical properties, mobility of intercalated species, and electrical conductivity of the MXene.

sections.heading: Organic Molecules
sections.text:
Organic molecules of high dielectric constant interact best with MXenes. The general effect of intercalation of organic molecules is an expansion in d002. Two well-studied examples are dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) and hydrazine monohydrate (HM) [25]. Treatments with HM showed an expansion of d002 to 12.5 Å (from an initial value for Ti3C2Tz of 9.75 Å). Molecular dynamics (MD) modeling was used in conjunction with experimental quantification of organic molecules using XPS to show that the HM molecules can pack into a full monolayer. This demonstrates that intercalation is spontaneous to the point of expansion of the MXene nanosheets to accommodate a monolayer of intercalant, but the effect is limited by the energy barrier of further separating the sheets. Further, the composition of the host MXene may be affected. For example, studies have shown that adsorbed H2O loss and removal of –OH surface groups can occur due to HM intercalation [26].
DMSO intercalation into Ti3C2Tz [25] was shown to increase d002 to 17.5 Å. An additional effect was a dynamic increase in basal spacing—the intercalated DMSO drew in H2O molecules that further pushed d002 to 22.4 Å. It can also prepare the interlayer space in an expanded state to accept larger cationic species such as uranium ions [27]. Beyond the scope of this chapter, DMSO is also an important intercalant in the initial steps of delaminating and dispersing MXene nanosheets. This was later improved upon with solutions of tetrabutylammonium hydroxide by Naguib et al. [12].

sections.heading: Ions and H2O
sections.text:
Cations sitting in the interlayer space counterbalance negative charges of the MXene sheets, so that there is an attractive electrostatic force between the sheets and the
cations. Naturally, the magnitude of this force is sensitive to the cation radius and its valency. As a result, it has been shown that the degree of contraction, or expansion, of the distance between MXene sheets (relative to that of the unintercalated state) is generally proportional to the charge density of the intercalated cation, with, e.g. intercalated Mg2+ leading to a stronger contraction than K+ [15, 28, 29]. This effect can be complicated by the co-intercalation of H2O molecules as hydration shells of the cations, which is a dynamic effect sensitive to the relative humidity of the environment. This is demonstrated in Fig. 10.4 [15]. Here, Ti3C2Tz was chemically intercalated with different metal cations. Basal spacings as determined by XRD are shown with in-situ control of relative humidity. The bimodal distribution of spacings, with separation of ~2.5 Å (or the rough diameter of an H2O molecule) shows that there is a transition from monolayer- to bilayer-type intercalation. This terminology was first derived from the literature of clay minerals but is more accurately described simply as multiples of H2O molecular diameters. Recent work has shown that H2O seems to form around cations in pillars rather than in discreet layers and that amounts of H2O may be much lower than would be present in full layers [22]. The intercalated A-Ti3C2Tz samples in Fig. 10.4 are arranged in increasing ion hydration enthalpy, and it is clear that: 1) the trend of contraction with higher charge density persists and, 2) the relative humidity at which the monolayer–
168 M. Ghidiu et al.
bilayer transition occurs decreases with increasing cation hydration enthalpy. One of the most important realizations of these results is that d002 is dynamic, and thus the conditions in which it is measured should be carefully noted or, better yet, precisely controlled.
For MXenes intercalated with hydrated cations at equilibrium, the main forces at play are an electrostatic attraction between the negative MXene sheets and the positive cation, opposed by expansive pressure from H2O molecules being formed into hydration shells around the cations, which is affected by the cation hydration enthalpy (Fig. 10.5). It should be noted that the MXene surface terminations can affect the balance of these forces [30].
Ammonium-based cations result in more varied structural changes than do metal cations. This is due to their ability to contain larger organic groups that must arrange themselves in the constricted interlayer space. Like in other materials [2, 6], using AA cations, it was shown for Ti3C2Tz that d002 could be tuned over a wide range (between 14.6 Å and 38.2 Å) by changing the physical size of the intercalated cations, highlighted in Fig. 10.6 [19]. Further, varying of the chain length of AA cations leads to interesting phenomena: the constant basal spacing between C1 and C8 and the abrupt increase between C10 and C12 demonstrate that the interlayer space can remain porous at low chain lengths, but that longer-chained cations will eventually fill the space and force the MXene layers apart. This likely proceeds through a monolayer to quasi-bilayer transition of cation chains, with even further expansion caused by paraffin-type arrangements of long-chain cations [20]. This is similar to phenomena experienced in other layered materials [31, 32, 33].
It has been demonstrated that AA cations can be useful as spacing templates for insertion of permanent pillaring materials, as a method to improve electrochemical capacitance [20]. AA cations represent a very interesting avenue for future work
10 Chemical and Electrochemical Intercalation of Ions and Molecules into MXenes 169
due to their ability to contain functional moieties such as electrochemically active groups such as ferrocene or light-sensitive groups such as azobenzene, which have been exploited in clay minerals [34].
When cations are electrochemically intercalated, the number of cations contained in the interlayer is no longer constrained to an equilibrium value. Studies have shown that the cation valency, number of cations intercalated, and cation size/structure are all important factors in understanding the changes to d002. Two dominant and competing effects are the number of positive charges intercalated and the physical cation size. MXene layers have a higher electrostatic driving force to contract when more positive charges are present in the interlayer—this is seen strongly for Li+, Na+, Mg2+, Ca2+, and Ba2+ (shown in Fig. 10.7 as macroscopic height changes, related to changes in basal spacing, for various cations as they are electrochemically inserted into Ti3C2Tz) [10, 18]. The aforementioned cations tend to have a smaller ionic radius; cations of a larger physical size such as K+, Cs+, and the alkylammonium cations will still cause electrostatic attraction, but the limited volume in the MXene interlayer when packed with increasing amounts of these cations eventually causes an expansion of the MXene to accommodate them. The effect of valency on contraction is an extension of this idea, as more charge can
170 M. Ghidiu et al.
be contained in a smaller physical space. In the isolated case of Na+, bilayers of cations have been observed at high potential—in Fig. 10.7, Na+ is seemingly near a balance of the effects of charge vs. size, so it may be the case that it is easier to eventually fill all space in the monolayer and force an expansion of the MXene at high Na+ packing [35].

sections.heading: Mechanical Properties
sections.text:
Work with electrochemical insertion of Mg2+ ions into Ti3C2Tz showed that the presence of interlayer ions could have drastic effects on the mechanical properties of the host MXene [36]. As Mg2+ was inserted into the structure, Young’s modulus of the material was found to increase by about 300%. These intercalated samples showed distributions of Young’s moduli that could be due to the result of various sites for Mg2+ ions, and the spatial distributions had a high degree of heterogeneity. Pre-intercalation with K+ ions, followed by Mg2+, displayed a more uniform spatial response. While the ability to tune Young’s modulus was only demonstrated in depth for Mg2+, the intercalation of a range of alkali and alkaline earth cations has shown that mechanical deformations can be readily controlled [29].
10 Chemical and Electrochemical Intercalation of Ions and Molecules into MXenes 171

sections.heading: Changes in Mobility of H2O and Ions
sections.text:
The movement of H2O and ions within the MXene interlayers is sensitive to what is intercalated. Early reports showed that the permeation rates of ions were dependent on their charge and radius, with the rates of monovalent cations being much faster than those of their multivalent counterparts [28]. Within the monovalent cations, a general trend was observed that K+ moved more slowly through the MXene interlayer space than Na+ or Li+. In the same work, the flux of water across membranes was shown to decrease with increasing valency of cations present in solution. This was suggested to originate from higher-valency ions constricting the interlayers and is supported by theoretical work showing dynamic response of MXene basal spacing, as well as differences in energy barriers for ionic movement through MXenes [37]. More recent reports, using neutron techniques and MD to probe the movement of H2O in intercalated samples, suggest that the diffusion coefficients for H2O decrease on the order Li+ > Na+ > K+ [38]. This is in agreement with earlier observations that the ion permeation rates follow roughly the same trend. Interestingly, H2O in MXene without intercalated ions was found to behave more like bulk water in terms of diffusion, while ion intercalation lowered the diffusion coefficient by about two orders of magnitude. On a final note, these studies also suggested, through modeling, that the ions reside in different locations based on their chemistry—with Li+ closer to the MXene sheet faces and Na+ and K+ closer to the center of the interlayer space along with the H2O molecules (Fig. 10.8).
172 M. Ghidiu et al.

sections.heading: Changes in Electrical Conductivity
sections.text:
Because MXenes are inherently highly electrically conductive, changes to the conductivity are of great interest. Work on K- and Mg-Ti3C2Tz, into which H2O molecules intercalate as a function of the relative humidity in the environment, showed that the electrical resistivity of the MXene increases to R/R0 of 1.03–1.05 at the high end of relative humidity tested, about 80%; the response was also linear, leading to the MXene being a candidate for humidity sensing [22]. Further, the loss in mass, from deintercalating H2O upon decrease in relative humidity, was faster than the recovery of the electrical conductivity, leading to the conclusion that trapped H2O molecules that are more slowly removed from the structure can act as charge-depleting dopants, though after equilibration the resistivity increase was found to be reversible. Other reports on spin-coated films showed a fully reversible ~26-fold increase in film resistivity upon exposure to 80% relative humidity [39]. Adsorbed H2O clearly has a noticeable effect on the resistivity of MXene.
When Ti3C2Tz was intercalated with AA cations of the form [(CH3)3NCn H2n + 1]+ (variable alkyl chain length cations), the resistivity was found to generally increase with increasing chain length of cation [19]. This may be tied to the concomitant increase in d002. Because of the massive structural changes (with basal spacing increasing up to ~28 Å per interlayer), disruption of interparticle electrical contacts may also play a role.

sections.heading: Complexity of Intercalation in MXenes
sections.text:
A large question that still remains outstanding is where exactly the negative charge of MXene sheets originates or resides. This charge is required to balance cations considering they selectively intercalate. It is likely that –OH terminations on the MXene surfaces are deprotonated to form –O−, which may then electrostatically interact with cations. This has been invoked in work involving ion sequestration [13], and a mechanism of transformation between –OH/–O groups was invoked with Raman spectroscopic evidence as a reason for MXene’s high capacitance, with the deprotonation responsible for forming H3O+ cations [40]. Like in clay minerals, the negative charge balancing interlayer cations could also originate from within the MXene sheets rather than on surface groups, as has been demonstrated during electrochemical cycling [41].
Another complexity is the fact that MXene is a redox active material. Thus, species that are intended for intercalation into MXenes may undergo chemical changes upon intercalation or even from initial contact with MXene, before any intercalation. This was demonstrated recently, where it was shown that the process of intercalating urea into Ti3C2Tz resulted in decomposition of the urea, yielding instead an intercalation of NH4+ and evolution of CO2 [42]. While this may not be a general phenomenon, it is certainly something that must be taken into account in the design of intercalated MXenes.
10 Chemical and Electrochemical Intercalation of Ions and Molecules into MXenes 173

sections.heading: Summary
sections.text: MXenes show a high level of diversity in their ability to intercalate ions and molecules into the interlayer space. Insertion of organic molecules generally proceeds spontaneously but may be accompanied by reactions with active MXene sites. Ions can be inserted electrochemically or chemically and are exchangeable, like in clay minerals and many other intercalable layered materials. The intercalation of these species can have permanent effects on the MXene (expansion or contraction of the basal spacing, changes to mechanical properties, changes to mobility of intercalated species, and changes to conductivity), as well as endowing the MXene with dynamic responses such as structural sensitivity to changes in humidity via reversible H2O intercalation. There is, however, still much to be understood on the fundamental level—specifically, how charge is localized in ionic intercalation, the interactions with MXene surface moieties, potential reactions of intercalating molecules, and how intercalants enter and are arranged in between the MXene sheets.

sections.heading: Techniques for MXene Delamination into Single-Layer Flakes
sections.text: Armin VahidMohammadi, Emre Kayali, Jafar Orangi, and Majid Beidaghi

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
The advancement of methods for the controlled isolation of individual layers of layered materials has significantly contributed to the expansion of two-dimensional (2D) materials family. Arguably, the entire field of 2D materials was born in 2004 when single layers of graphene were exfoliated from graphite, and their electronic properties were studied [1]. The demonstration of such a high quality and stable free-standing atomic layers prepared the grounds for the extensive ongoing research on synthesis and characterization of 2D materials. Currently, the term “2D materials” refers to the atomically thin single/few-layer flakes (or sheets) of various materials with thicknesses ranging from 1 to less than 5 nm [2–5]. A single layer of a 2D material can consist of a single atomic layer (such as graphene, phosphorene, etc.) or a single crystalline layer with several atomic layers (such as transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), MXenes, etc.). Delamination (complete separation of individual layers from a layered structure) of single-layer flakes from layered materials has been achieved through a verity of methods including mechanical cleavage, chemical intercalation and exfoliation, and liquid exfoliation, to name a few [3, 4, 6]. Similarly, several techniques for the synthesis of single/fewlayer flakes of MXenes have been reported in the past few years. MXenes are a family of 2D transition metal carbides and nitrides with a general formula of Mn + 1XnTx, where M is a transition metal, X is carbon or nitrogen, n can be 1, 2, or 3, and Tx represents the surface terminations [5]. As it has been explained in Chap. 5, MXenes are produced by selective etching of A layer elements (i.e., Al) from a large group of layered ternary carbides and nitrides, called MAX

177
178 A. VahidMohammadi et al.
phases [5]. However, in most cases, the delamination of multilayered MXenes into single/few layer flakes requires additional steps after the selective etching process. Ti3C2Tx is the first discovered and the most studied MXene; therefore, this chapter will first focus on the delamination of Ti3C2Tx flakes before describing the recent efforts for delamination of other MXene compositions. We have intended to provide a general guideline for the synthesis of single/few-layer MXenes in this chapter.

sections.heading: Single/Few-Layer MXenes
sections.text:
Delaminated single-layer 2D materials often exhibit very different properties compared to their bulk layered counterparts. That is partly due to a significant increase in the surface area to volume ratio of the 2D flakes which can dramatically change the (electro)chemical and physical properties of the material [6, 7]. For example, unlike graphite or few-layer graphene, single-layer graphene sheets are zero-band gap semiconductors and show extraordinary high electron mobility at room temperature (RT) [2, 8]. However, these electronic properties rapidly change by increasing the number of layers in graphene sheets [1, 9, 10]. In the case of MXenes, it is also shown that delamination of multilayered MXene particles into single/few-layer flakes can significantly affect their properties. For example, delaminated MXene flakes have shown better electrochemical performances in different energy storage applications [11–16]. Therefore, it is crucial to successfully delaminate MXenes into single-layer flakes and harness their unique 2D properties. Mechanical cleavage or the so-called “scotch tape” technique has been used to isolate single-layer flakes of a variety of layered materials with strong in-plane bonds and weak van der Waals bonds between their layers [4]. Although this technique allows scientists to isolate single-layer 2D flakes and study their properties, its limited scalability prevents large-scale synthesis of 2D materials. Liquid exfoliation methods have also been widely applied to delaminate single-layer flakes of layered materials [6]. However, 2D MXenes cannot be directly produced through mechanical cleavage or direct liquid exfoliation of their parent MAX phases due to the nature of interlayer bonds in these ternary carbides. The MX layers of MAX phases are bonded with strong primary bonds (M—A bonds), which mostly have metallic character [5, 17, 18]. However, since the M—A bonds are more reactive than M—X bonds (with mixed ionic and covalent character), under certain conditions, the “A” atoms can be selectively removed in acidic environments. The readers are referred to Chap. 5 of this book for more details about this selective removal process. The resulting products of this process are usually multilayered particles of MXene (ML-MXene) and have a microstructure that resembles that of exfoliated graphite [5]. The separation of the individual single/few-layer flakes from the ML-MXene particles is not always straightforward. In many cases, the interactions between the layers in the ML-MXene are very strong. Moreover, for some MXenes the
11 Techniques for MXene Delamination into Single-Layer Flakes 179
current etching processes usually result in an incomplete etching and some residual strongly bonded A layer elements remain between the M-X layers, hindering their delamination using simple techniques. Therefore, to delaminate ML-MXenes into single/few-layer flakes, usually an additional step (usually a liquid-based delamination method) for expanding the interlayer space and weakening the interaction between layers is required. This is usually achieved by chemical intercalation of large organic/inorganic molecules between the MXene layers. In principle, intercalation of large molecules and ionic species results in an increased interlayer spacing and weakens the out-of-plane interactions between stacked MXene layers [7]. This is usually followed by a substantial swelling of the MXene powders due to co-intercalation of water molecules. The outcome of this intercalation process, if proper intercalants and process conditions are selected, is reduction of the energy barrier for delamination of MXenes [7]. As a result, subsequent agitation of dispersion of ML-MXenes (by ultrasonication or hand-shaking) could lead to delamination of single-/few-layer MXene flakes. The delamination process will be further discussed in this chapter in a case-by-case fashion as different MXenes require different delamination conditions. Figure 11.1 schematically shows different steps involved in the delamination of ML-MXenes into single-/few-layer flakes.
Ti3C2Tx is the most studied MXene in terms of synthesis, exfoliation, and delamination methods, as well as potential applications (note that Tx in the formula of MXene represents the functional groups that terminate the surface of the material). In the early reports on the synthesis of this material, the largescale delamination of single/few-layer Ti3C2Tx flakes was carried out by chemical intercalation of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) into ML-Ti3C2Tx powder produced by selective etching of Al from Ti3AlC2 in a concentrated hydrogen fluoride (HF) solution (50%) at room temperature [11, 16]. This intercalation process resulted in the expansion of layer spacing and a large increase (about 15.4 Å) in the c-lattice parameter (c-LP) of ML-Ti3C2Tx [11, 16]. Co-intercalation of water molecules has been mentioned as the reason for such large change in the c-LP upon DMSO intercalation [5].
The increase in the c-LP significantly weakens the interaction between M-X layers and the sonication of interlayer-expanded ML-Ti3C2Tx in water results in the delamination of single/few layer MXene flakes [11, 16]. As further explained in the next section, this two-step etching and delamination process (schematically illustrated in Fig. 11.1) has been successfully used for delamination of various other MXene compositions (by using a variety of intercalants). In 2014, Ghidiu et al. reported a facile and efficient one-step method for the synthesis of Ti3C2Tx [12]. In this method, instead of concentrated HF solutions, a solution of lithium fluoride (or other fluoride salts) and hydrochloric acid is used as the etchant. During the etching process, Al atoms are removed from Ti3AlC2, and the hydrated Li ions are simultaneously intercalated between the M-X layers, leading to their delamination into single/few-layer Ti3C2Tx flakes. This synthesis technique is schematically shown in Fig. 11.1. Later, it was shown that the synthesis conditions can be tuned to produce large-area and high-quality Ti3C2Tx single-layer flakes [19].
180 A. VahidMohammadi et al.
In the past few years, the two general MXene delamination methods have been applied to other MXene compositions as well. For many MXenes, the two-step process of etching and intercalation has been the only successful method of delamination. However, it has been found that specific conditions of the delamination process, such as the type of intercalant, are dependent on the etching method. Therefore, it is essential that we consider the etching process in our discussion of various delamination techniques.
11 Techniques for MXene Delamination into Single-Layer Flakes 181
Chemical Intercalation and Delamination of Ti3C2Tx into Single/Few-Layer Flakes
As mentioned earlier, chemical pre-intercalation of ML-MXene powder is an important requirement for the delamination of MXenes that are produced in concentrated HF solutions. The spontaneous chemical intercalation of a wide range of organic molecules and solvents such as ethanol, acetone, thiophene, formaldehyde, tetrahydrofuran, chloroform, hexane, toluene, hydrazine, dimethylformamide (DMF), DMSO, tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH), and urea into various multilayered MXenes have been previously demonstrated [11, 16, 20, 21]. The intercalated MXenes usually have large c-LPs and weak interlayer bonds [16]. For Ti3C2Tx, delamination of single-layer flakes by sonication of the dispersion of the intercalated ML-Ti3C2Tx has been demonstrated by several studies [11, 20– 22]. Table 11.1 summarizes various etching processes, intercalation conditions, and intercalant types that have been reported so far for successful delamination of MLTi3C2Tx into single or few-layer flakes.
It is worth noting that the direct sonication of HF-etched Ti3AlC2 powder at room temperature may yield a small amount of single/double-layer flakes among the produced ML-Ti3C2Tx particles, but the pre-intercalation is always required for the large-scale delamination of single-layer flakes [18, 20]. Utilizing the intercalation and sonication method for the delamination of Ti3C2Tx was first reported by Mashtalir et al. [16] where they intercalated ML-Ti3C2Tx particles with several organic compounds, such as DMSO and urea (increasing the c-LP of MXene to ~35 Å and ~25 Å, respectively) and subsequently delaminated the Ti3C2Tx flakes by a sonication process. In a typical process, ML-Ti3C2Tx powder (synthesized by etching Ti3AlC2 powder in 50% HF solutions) was dispersed and stirred in DMSO (in a 0.6 g to 10 mL ratio) at room temperature for 18 h. The powder was then washed several times to remove the residual DMSO and then was dispersed in water and sonicated for 4 h to achieve dispersions of single/few-layer Ti3C2Tx flakes [11, 16]. In our experience, shaking the DMSO intercalated Ti3C2Tx powders may also result in delamination of Ti3C2Tx into single-layer flakes, however, the delamination yield increases by using sonication instead of shaking.
The delamination of ML-MXene through pre-intercalation and sonication (technique 1 in Fig. 11.1) is not limited to materials synthesized by etching in HF solutions. However, MXenes produced by alternative etching methods may require different delamination conditions. There have been a few reports on the synthesis of Ti3C2Tx by etching the precursor MAX powders or thin films in solutions of ammonium hydrogen fluoride (NH4HF2) or ammonium fluoride [22–24, 26]. Although the materials obtained from this etching process can be grounded to produce some single-layer fragments [24], the direct delamination of Ti3C2Tx sheets through these methods has not been reported. During this etching process, NH4+ cations intercalate between the layers of the synthesized MXenes and increase their c-LP. However, the increased d-spacing does not lead to a complete delamination of the flakes and further intercalation and sonication processes are required [20]. The

delamination of ML-Ti3C2Tx has also been reported after the intercalation of aryl diazonium salts followed by shaking or sonication [27]. In the reported process, MLTi3C2Tx powders (synthesized by HF etching) were dispersed in a 5 wt% NaOH aqueous solution and the dispersion was stirred for 2 h to allow the intercalation of Na+ cations between MXene layers. Next, sulfanilic acid diazonium salt was mixed with the Na+-intercalated Ti3C2Tx powder at 0–5 ◦C for 4 h. Wang et al. reported that the expansion of interlayer spacing of the MXene due to the intercalation of aryl groups and the chemical interaction of phenylsulfonic groups with the negatively charged surface of the Ti3C2Tx result in the weakening of the interaction between Ti3C2Tx layers and enhances their delamination in water to form stable MXene dispersions [27].
Another delamination process for producing Ti3C2Tx flakes was reported by Xuan et al. [25]. They used tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAOH) to directly delaminate 2D flakes in a process that avoids excessive use of HF. In the suggested process, the Ti3AlC2 powder was first treated in a 10–20% HF solution for 30 minutes and then dispersed in a 25% aqueous solution of TMAOH. It was claimed that the short HF treatment is only for the removal of the oxide layer that usually exists on the surface of Ti3AlC2 particles, although slight removal of Al atoms from the structure is also possible [25]. However, the etching process mainly proceeds in the aqueous solution of TMAOH according to the reaction (11.1). The Al is removed from the MAX phase structure through the reaction with OH− while TMA+ cations intercalate between the Ti3C2Tx layers:
2Al + 2OH− + 6H2O → 2 [ Al(OH)4 ]− + 3H2 (11.1) As it can be seen from this reaction, the mechanism of etching and delamination in this technique is quite different from the previously explained methods. Nevertheless, shaking the dispersions of TMA+ intercalated MXene particles in water resulted in producing single-/double-layer flakes with thicknesses of around 1.6– 2.0 nm [25].
Single-Step Etching and Delamination of Ti3C2Tx and the Effects of Etching Parameters on the Size of the MXene Flakes
As briefly explained above, treatment of some MXenes in mixtures of fluoride salts and acids (e.g., HCl) may lead to the simultaneous synthesis (etching) and delamination of MXene flakes [12, 26]. This process (schematically shown as technique 2 in Fig. 11.1) was first reported by Ghidiu et al. [12]. In their proposed process, the single-step etching and delamination of Ti3C2Tx sheets was achieved by the treatment of the Ti3AlC2 in a solution of lithium fluoride (LiF) and hydrochloric acid (HCl). Due to the existence of fluoride ions and protons in the etching solution, the chemical reactions similar to those observed in the HF solutions result in the
184 A. VahidMohammadi et al.
selective removal of Al atoms from the MAX phase structure. Also, the concurrent intercalation of water molecules and hydrated Li+ cations between the MXene layers significantly increases the c-LP of Ti3C2Tx, leading to the delamination of individual layers. This process yields a MXene powder with a clay-like behavior which can be rolled into a few micron thick flexible films that are highly conductive (~1500 S/cm) when dried [12]. Highly concentrated and stable dispersions of single/few layer MXene flakes can be produced by sonication or hand-shaking of the Ti3C2Tx clay in water. The size of the flakes in the as-synthesized clay is reported to be between 0.5 and 1.5µm [12]. However, the MXene sheets tend to break into smaller sizes during the sonication of their dispersions [28, 29]. Therefore, the delaminated Ti3C2Tx sheets obtained in this method usually have sub-micrometer dimensions [12].
Since the introduction of the single-step etching and delamination, this method has largely replaced the HF etching processes for the synthesis of Ti3C2Tx. Therefore, it is worth to explain the details of this synthesis process further in this chapter. Usually, the process starts with preparation of an etchant by mixing 10 mL of 6 M HCl and 5 M equivalent LiF (0.66 g). The mixture should be stirred for at least 5 minutes to dissolve LiF. The etching process starts with a gradual addition of MAX phase powder (1 g of Ti3AlC2) to the etchant. This step is usually performed in an ice bath (over the course of 5–10 minutes) to prevent overheating of the solution due to the exothermic nature of the reaction between the MAX phase and the etchant. Etching is continued by continuous stirring of the mixture at 35 ◦C for 24 h, after which the mixture is poured into centrifuge tubes and diluted with deionized water for washing the exfoliated material. The etched powders are washed with the addition of deionized (DI) water and several steps of centrifugation. After each centrifugation, the supernatant should be decanted and the sediment should be dispersed in deionized water followed by shaking the centrifuge tube. This consecutive dilution and centrifuge process is usually repeated until the pH value of the supernatant is about 5–6. At this point, a clay-like MXene powder can be formed by filtering and drying the final sediment. To delaminate the sheets into individual layers, the clay-like MXene powder is usually dispersed in deionized water (~1 g to 200 mL) and probe sonicated for 1 h under flowing Argon. The resulting solution is centrifuged to remove any residual unreacted MAX phase or multilayered MXene particles. The supernatant collected at the last step is a stable dispersion of delaminated Ti3C2Tx with a dark green color [20].
In the salt and acid mixture etching/delamination technique, etching and postetching processing conditions can significantly affect the quality and dimensions of the produced Ti3C2Tx sheets. A few studies have shown that the molar ratios of LiF and HCl can affect the dimensions of the produced MXene flakes [19, 30, 31]. For example, by increasing the molar ratio of LiF to Ti3AlC2 from 5 to 7.5, and the molar ratio of HCl to Ti3AlC2 from 11.7 to 23.4, larger sheet sizes (up to 15µm) can be synthesized [19]. This is mainly due to the enhanced delamination of the flakes that can be achieved without the application of high power sonication, leading to preservation of the original size of the produced MXene flakes. Therefore, these modified synthesis processes enable applications or characterization methods
11 Techniques for MXene Delamination into Single-Layer Flakes 185
that require larger flake sizes [29, 30]. The adjustment of the composition of the etchant is the basis for a recently developed MXene synthesis process referred to as minimally intensive layer delamination (MILD) process. In this process, a simple shaking of the as-etched MXenes in water can produce flakes with large lateral dimensions and high qualities (Fig. 11.2). Recently, Alhabeb et al. reported
186 A. VahidMohammadi et al.
a comprehensive account of MXene synthesis using this method, which suggests that for MILD etching the concentration of LiF should be kept higher than a certain threshold [20]. They proposed an optimized MILD synthesis method where the concentrations of LiF and HCl in the etchant were increased to 12 and 9 M, respectively. It was observed that increasing the concentration of Li+ cations and H+ ions further facilitates the delamination; thus, MXene dispersions with higher concentrations (1–2 mg/mL) could be produced. Table 11.2 shows a comparison of different Ti3C2Tx synthesis methods based on the etching of MAX phase in the mixture of fluoride salts and HCl.
Another notable difference between the clay method (5 M LiF and 6 M HCl) and the MILD methods (both 7.5 M LiF/6 M HCl and 12 M LiF/9 M HCl) is the swelling of Ti3C2Tx sediment after washing. The swelling of the ML-Ti3C2Tx sediments is more pronounced and noticeable in the MILD processes. After washing, two different phases can be seen at the bottom of the centrifuge tubes; a grey sediment and a dark black slurry, as shown in Fig. 11.3. Characterization of both phases with XRD suggests that the grey sediment is likely to be a mixture of un-etched Ti3AlC2 and ML-Ti3C2Tx, and the dark black slurry is likely composed of single and few layers Ti3C2Tx flakes. The separation of the slurry from the grey sediment can be done with an additional centrifuge step, and the slurry can be used to obtain Ti3C2Tx flakes.
The MILD method for the synthesis and delamination of Ti3C2Tx involves the following experimental steps. At first, an etchant is prepared by adding 1 g (or 1.6 g in the optimized MILD process) of LiF to 20 mL of 6 M (or 9 M in the optimized MILD process) HCl solution. The mixture is stirred for 5 minutes using a Teflon coated magnetic bar. Then, 1 g of Ti3AlC2 powder is gradually added to the etchant in an ice bath over the course of 5 minutes. The reaction mixture is then removed from the ice bath and stirred in a 35 ◦C water bath for 24 h. The reaction products are washed with several centrifugations steps of 5 minutes at 3500 rpm followed by a gentle hand shaking of the products for less than one minute. After around five cycles of washing, a stable dark-green supernatant is obtained. At this point, the grey sediment and the black slurry shown in Fig. 11.3(b) can be separated by centrifuging the mixture at 3500 rpm for 2 minutes.
The average size and the quality of the Ti3C2Tx flakes can be controlled to some extent by adjusting the synthesis parameters. However, for all the reported synthesis methods the final produced MXenes have a large size distribution between a few nanometers to few microns. To produce MXene flakes with controlled average sizes and size distributions, post-synthesis methods such as sonication [29] and centrifugation [20, 32] can be applied to separate the flakes based on their size. For example, following up the previous reports [20, 29, 32, 33] and as we have recently shown in our laboratory [34], larger MXene flakes can be separated from the solution by high-speed centrifugation (Fig. 11.4a). Then, if smaller MXene flakes are required (e.g., to study the size-dependent property of MXenes), the large flakes can be uniformly broken to smaller ones by applying high power sonication to their dispersions in water (Fig. 11.4). However, during the sonication of MXene dispersions (either during the synthesis or post-synthesis treatments),

sections.heading: Delamination of Other MXenes into Single/Few-Layer Flakes
sections.text:
In contrast to Ti3C2Tx, information on the delamination of other MXenes into stable solutions containing single and/or few layers flakes is very limited in the literature. This is despite the fact that multilayered powders of a variety of MXenes have been experimentally produced and some have shown exceptional properties in various applications [14, 15, 35]. Some of the approaches that are already proven to be effective for delamination of Ti3C2Tx (discussed earlier in this chapter) have not been successful for delamination of other MXene compositions. This has prevented extended studies of the properties and applications of delaminated single/few layer flakes of MXenes other than Ti3C2Tx. So far, the most significant report on the largescale delamination of other MXenes is the work by Naguib et al. [36] in which they successfully delaminated MXenes, such as V2CTx and Ti3CNTx using an intercalation and agitation approach. The process is similar to the pre-intercalation and delamination process previously used for the delamination of Ti3C2Tx flakes (route 1 shown in Fig. 11.1). However, for delaminating V2CTx and Ti3CNTx large organic bases were used as the intercalants in the pre-intercalation step [36, 37]. It should be noted that the one-step etching and delamination technique used by a mixture of metal salts and acids has not been reported to be effective for the direct delamination of other MXenes (except for Ti2CTx and Mo2CTx) [35, 38– 40]. However, if the mixture etching method is effective in complete removal of the A layers from the MAX structure, similar to the MXenes etched with HF, post chemical intercalation might be used to fully delaminate the ML-MXene powders.
V2CTx and Ti3CNTx (representatives of M2X and M3X2 family of MXenes) were delaminated using immersion of the multilayered powders (etched in 48% HF for 92 h for V2CTx and 30% HF for 18 h for Ti3CNTx) in TBAOH, choline hydroxide, and n-butylamine in a ratio of 1 g MXene powder to 10 mL of intercalant solution for different time periods of 2, 4, and 21 h [36]. In this method, after washing and removal of excess TBAOH (or other intercalants) from the treated powders, both V2CTx and Ti3CNTx powders become swollen. By adding water and handshaking them, black colloidal solutions of single and few layers MXenes can be obtained. TBAOH treatment of 4 h was found to be the
190 A. VahidMohammadi et al.
optimal condition for successful delamination of V2CTx and Ti3CNTx [36]. For the swollen V2CTx, the (0002) peak in the XRD pattern shifted from 2θ of 8.9 to 4.56◦ corresponding to c-LP of 38.72 Å (9.4 Å increase in the d-spacing). Similar results were observed for the intercalated Ti3CNTx where the (0002) peak was shifted down from 8.26 to 4.5◦ corresponding to a c-LP of 39.2 Å and an 8.9 Å increase in the d-spacing. Figure 11.5 shows an AFM image of a single-layer V2CTx flake obtained from 4 h TBAOH treatment of the ML-V2CTx powder at room temperature. The delaminated V2CTx solution was produced by handshaking of the TBAOH intercalated powder in deionized water and centrifugation at 3500 rpm for 1 h.
Delamination of Ti2CTx and Mo2CTx have been reported through single-step etching method in a solution of LiF and HCl [35, 41, 42]. It was reported that Ti2AlC etched with a mixture of 6 M HCl and 1.1 g LiF for 36 h at 40 ◦C using 1 g of MAX phase powder in 30 mL of the etchant can be delaminated by sonication (1.5 h) and centrifugation (3500 rpm for 5 minutes) [41]. Lateral size and number of the layers of the delaminated Ti2CTx MXene solution produced by this technique have not been examined [41]. Besides, considering the duration of the centrifugation used in this process, there is a high probability that the produced solution consists of few-layer to many-layer flakes. Higher centrifugation times are needed to make sure the delaminated solutions only consist of single/few-layer flakes. It has been reported that ML-Mo2CTx powder prepared through HF etching (14 M HF in a 1 g powder to 40 mL acid ratio for 160 h at 55 ◦C) [42] can be delaminated by TBAOH intercalation (1 g powder to 10 mL 54–56% TBAOH solution ratio for 18 h). The delaminated Mo2CTx has also been prepared in LiF and HCl mixture etchant (12 M HCl with 3 M equivalent LiF [42] or 9 M HCl with 4 g LiF both at 35 ◦C for 72 h and in a 2 g powder to 20 mL etchant
11 Techniques for MXene Delamination into Single-Layer Flakes 191
ratio [35]) followed by several steps of washing, handshaking for 5 minutes (or 45 minutes sonication) [35], and centrifugation at 5000 rpm for 1 h (3500 rpm for 1 h) [35].
In general, the chemical pre-intercalation and sonication method seems to be a very effective method for delamination of all MXene compositions. Table 11.3 summarizes the delamination processes reported so far for a variety of MXene compositions. One problem associated with delaminated MXenes beyond Ti3C2Tx is their instability and fast oxidation in the water. For example, delaminated V2CTx flakes dispersed in water are reported to quickly degrade over a few hours when exposed to air in an open container [36, 37]. Therefore, for future characterization of these MXene flakes methods for proper storage of their dispersions and new techniques for their delamination should be developed.

sections.heading: Conclusion and Outlook
sections.text:
The knowledge and techniques for synthesizing single-/few-layer MXenes have been evolving since the discovery of these materials. Producing MXene flakes differs from synthesizing other 2D materials (i.e., graphene, MoS2, and h-BN) since the former usually requires an initial selective etching process to produce multilayered materials. As we discussed throughout this chapter, among different experimentally synthesized MXenes, the delamination techniques for Ti3C2Tx have been very well established in the literature. Dispersions of single-/few-layer Ti3C2Tx can be prepared in high concentrations and the dimensions of the flakes and their stability can be controlled. However, preparation of delaminated MXenes other than Ti3C2Tx is still challenging. Despite some reports on delamination of V2CTx and Mo2CTx that we summarized in this chapter, the knowledge about the properties of the delaminated flakes, the yield of delamination to single layers, and the scalability of delamination process is limited. Chemical intercalation techniques can be considered as an effective approach for delamination of MLMXenes that their selective exfoliation process does not directly result in single layer solutions. On the other hand, as we pointed out in this chapter, we believe that optimizing the salt/acid mixture etchants for MXene compositions other than Ti3C2Tx may lead to the development of concurrent etching/delamination processes. Therefore, we suggest that the future work in this area should focus on the systematic studies of the effect of the composition of etchant, as well as the etching conditions on the synthesis of single-/few-layer MXene flakes of various compositions.

sections.heading: MXene Films, Coatings, and Bulk Processing
Guo-Ming Weng, Marina Mariano, Jason Lipton, and André D. Taylor
sections.text:
A unique family of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal carbides and/or nitrides, MXene (Mn+1XnTx, where n = 1, 2, or 3, M is an early transition metal, X is C and/ or N, and T is a terminating group), was discovered in 2011 [1, 2]. In addition to their excellent mechanical properties (e.g., bending rigidities) [3], rich surface chemistries (e.g., hydrophilic [4] and hydrophobic [5]), and metallic conductivity [6, 7], this type of material offers particularly tunable transition metal chemistries [8] compared with other carbon-based conductive material (as shown in Table 12.1). More importantly, this material is produced by simply etching and exfoliating MAX phases, and this relatively simple technique may enable manufacturing-scale production [7]. Therefore, this material has been explored in various fields such as energy storage (e.g., batteries and supercapacitors), optics, electronics, catalysts, and medical applications. Recently, a variety of methods have been developed to process MXene into films or coatings for specific applications. This chapter 12 (i) introduces the basic principle of these typical methods for MXene films, coatings, and bulk processing and (ii) discusses the challenges and future direction of MXene processing.
