sections.heading: MXene Films
sections.text: Film formation is the conversion of a deposited film from a liquid or fluid form into a solid. Generally, the thickness of a film is in the range of a few atoms (<1 nm to 100 μm). Recently, various methods have been reported to process MXene flakes into MXene films. These films are commonly used for different applications such as energy storage, photo-electronics, and electromagnetic interference shielding after they are peeled off. In the following sections, we will introduce these methods in detail.

sections.heading: Vacuum-Assisted Filtration
sections.text:
Using vacuum-assisted filtration (VAF) to form a MXene film is a common method since it requires no complex apparatus [21, 22]. As shown in Fig. 12.1a, a uniform dispersion of MXene [24] is firstly prepared and filtered through a porous membrane with the suction filter device. Since filtration is intrinsically self-limiting, the
12 MXene Films, Coatings, and Bulk Processing 199
uniformity of the film on the filter membrane is therefore self-leveling [27]. In certain circumstances, van der Waals forces are involved for bringing the species together [28]. The next step is to peel off the deposited MXene film (Fig. 12.1b) from the filter paper where a 1.5-μm-thick MXene film can be obtained (Fig. 12.1c). We note that each filter parameter is significant (e.g., the type of filter paper, the vacuum pressure, the dispersion concentration, and the surfactant type). Among these, the solution concentration of the deposited material is the most important factor to adjust film properties such as thickness, opacity, rigidity, and conductivity [27]. The VAF technique can also be used to combine different materials into a film. For example, Zhao et al. demonstrated that MXene and CNTs can be combined by alternatively filtering two types of dispersions (e.g., Fig. 12.1a) through a filter paper, where sandwich-like and flexible MXene-MWCNT films (Fig. 12.1d–f) can be successfully obtained [24]. Other modified MXene films like MnOx-Ti3C2 film [26] can be obtained by three steps: (i) simple modification of the MXene dispersion with Mn(NO3)2, (ii) VAF, and (iii) heat treatment of the filtered film (Fig. 12.1g).
Recently, Zhao et al. [29] and Lukatskaya et al. [30] prepared new types of 3D macroporous MXene films (which consist of hollow MXene spheres) via VAF
200 G.-M. Weng et al.
(Fig. 12.2). We show the preparation procedure in Fig. 12.2a: (i) MXene flakes spontaneously wrap around the surface of PMMA spheres based on the interaction between their surface hydroxyl groups; (ii) VAF; (iii) thermal annealing of the MXene/PMMA films at 450 ◦C to remove PMMA and transformed into a 3D macroporous MXene film. This method can be generalized to various MXenes (Fig. 12.2b–d), e.g., Ti3C2Tx, V2CTx, and Mo2CTx, and the thickness of the film can be up to ~45 μm (Fig. 12.2f). Other post-treatments of the filtered MXene film, like hydrazine treatment, can lead to MXene foam films with extremely low density (Fig. 12.2e).
To further improve the flexibility and mechanical strength, polymer can be added as a filler of the MXene film [6, 22]. In Fig. 12.3, Ling et al. [22] firstly reported the fabrication of conductive, flexible, freestanding MXene-polymer films via VAF. A strong interaction between the polymer and MXene is key for successfully preparing the polymer-modified MXene dispersion before VAF, for instance, electrostatic absorbtion [22] between positively charged poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) (PDDA) and MXene negatively charged surface (Fig. 12.3a), and hydrogen bonding [31] between poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) and MXene (Fig. 12.3a). By introducing 10 and 60 wt% PVA into the MXene film, the tensile strength could be improved by 34% and 100%, respectively. As shown in Fig. 12.3b, c, the Ti3C2TxPVA film can support ~15,000 times its own weight, while ~4000 times for its Ti3C2Tx counterpart. Taken together, these research highlights demonstrate the level of versatility possible in creating MXene films via VAF.
12 MXene Films, Coatings, and Bulk Processing 201

sections.heading: Electrohydrodynamic Atomization
sections.text:
The electrohydrodynamic atomization (EHDA) technique, also referred to as electrospraying, is a non-vacuum process that is reasonably inexpensive for easy processing and requires less material [32, 33]. EHDA involves the flow of dispersion under the influence of an electric field at ambient temperature (Fig. 12.4a) [33]. Due to the applied electric field, the liquid forms a cone at the exit of the capillary, and from the cone apex, a jet evolves [33]. The jet breakup of a pendent droplet under the influence of an electric field has been explored by both Zeleny et al. and Taylor [34, 35]. Among all the atomization modes (e.g., micro-dripping, spindle, cone-jet, and multi-jet), the stable cone-jet atomization mode is the most important mode as near-monodispersed droplets of only a few micrometers in size are generated by this mode [36]. The stable cone-jet mode occurs when there is comparative equity in the electric field strength and surface tension of the flowing medium. The parameters that control the droplet size generated from atomization under the conejet mode include the applied voltage, the flow rate, and the physical properties of the liquid (e.g., density, viscosity, surface tension, relative permittivity, and electrical conductivity) [33]. Once the droplets are generated, the solvent evaporates very quickly because of its high surface area, and the film instantly forms [37]. Using EHDA to fabricate Ti3C2Tx film was firstly demonstrated by Ali et al. [32] with the setup shown in Fig. 12.4a. A uniform and pinhole-free surface morphology of these Ti3C2Tx films (100–400 nm) was observed (Fig. 12.4b). It was also demonstrated that the Ti3C2Tx films could be further improved by modifying the EHDA dispersion with other functional materials (e.g., graphene, CNTs, and metal oxide) with great potential for utilization in photo-electronics, energy storage, and sensing application [32].
202 G.-M. Weng et al.

sections.heading: Electrophoretic Deposition
sections.text:
Electrophoretic deposition (EPD) is a process in which an electric field is applied to a stable colloidal suspension in between two electrodes [38, 39]. As shown in Fig. 12.5a, two distinct processes are involved: (i) charged particles in the colloid move toward the electrode of opposite polarity to that of the particles’ surface charge (electrophoresis) and (ii) a solid deposit is formed by coagulation at the suspension-electrode interface (deposition) [38]. This technique can be used to prepare dense, void-free ceramic structures ranging from thin coatings to bulk layers
12 MXene Films, Coatings, and Bulk Processing 203
several centimeters thick [40]. EPD has been used for commercial-scale production of various ceramics [40–42] and making nanocomposite films of 2D materials [43, 44] because of the flexibility and scalability of the deposition apparatus (e.g., power sources and size/shape of the deposition electrodes and the cell, Fig. 12.5b), fast deposition rates, and the excellent microstructural control compared to other processing methods [38]. Collini et al. [38] successfully fabricated freestanding Ti3C2Tx films by EPD from both water-based (aqueous) and propylene carbonatebased (nonaqueous) colloidal Ti3C2Tx suspensions. It was found that increasing the deposition voltage led to the formation of pores and less-oriented structures in films made from aqueous suspensions (Fig. 12.5c), while the overall film morphology was quite insensitive in the case of the propylene carbonate depositions (Fig. 12.5d) [38]. At the optimal voltage of 5 volts, the samples fabricated in both cases showed very tightly stacked surface (Fig. 12.5e–f), and the kinetics of deposition can be modeled according to the following Eqs. (12.1) and (12.2) [40]:
ω(t) = ωo ( 1 − e−kt )
(12.1)
k = Af u V
(12.2)
where ω is the mass (mg), t is the deposition time (s), ωo is the total available dispersed mass in suspension (mg), k accounts for the current decrease due to the resistance of the forming deposit, A is the electrode surface area (m2), f is the efficiency of the process (f ≤ 1), u is the average velocity of the particles (m/s), and V is the volume of the suspension used (m3).
In addition to fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) electrodes [38], MXene films can be formed on various conductive substrates (e.g., nickel foam electrode) [45] to lead to versatile films for different applications. Therefore, EPD can be used as a fast and high-throughput method for making MXene films.

sections.heading: Dipping Layer-by-Layer Assembly
sections.text:
Layer-by-layer (LbL) assembly is the process of building a film by sequentially coating a substrate in polyelectrolytes of opposite charge [46]. Electrostatic attractions between polymers in solution cause a thin layer of material to deposit after each coating step. Additionally, if there are materials dispersed in the polyelectrolyte solutions, then the material will deposit in the polymer layer, forming a uniform composite. One method of LbL assembly is dip coating (dip-LbL), in which the substrate is coated by sequential dipping into the polyelectrolyte solutions (Fig. 12.6a, b). Dip-LbL has been widely utilized to make high-quality thin films [48–50] for a variety of applications. Due to the hydrophilicity [4] and large negative zeta potential [51] of MXenes, it is possible to form an aqueous dispersion of MXenes
204 G.-M. Weng et al.
in a polycationic solution, so that they may be used as a composite material in a multilayer thin film. A few points should be considered when using dip-LbL to prepare MXene films: (i) be sure the MXene dispersion in the polyelectrolyte solution is stable and uniform (e.g., in poly(sodium 4-styrene sulfonate) (PSS) and low-pH poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) solutions, Ti3C2 dispersions have shown to be unstable) and has (ii) sufficient drying time between dips to prevent irregular deposition of polyelectrolyte and (iii) proper gas drying near the bottom of the substrate to remove the droplet that forms due to gravity. Recently, Lipton et al. [52] successfully prepared several kinds of MXene-based LbL films. We illustrate an example of MXene-CNT composite film (Fig. 12.6c). The final MXene films (onto substrates like glass slide and silicon wafer) can be easily delaminated by immersing into hydrofluoric acid (HF) [49]. These films can then be characterized for its electronic, mechanical, and electromagnetic interference shielding properties. The flexibility of dip-LbL allows the use of many different combinations of materials in MXene composites.

sections.heading: Spin Spray Layer-by-Layer Assembly
sections.text:
In traditional dip-coating LbL, the film stays in contact with the polyelectrolyte solutions and rinsing fluids long enough to achieve a thermodynamic equilibrium at each stage [50, 53]. Taylor’s TMD group pioneered an automated spin spray layerby-layer (SSLbL) film assembly apparatus which employs sub-second spray times to produce LbL quality films with cycle times one order of magnitude shorter than those previously reported [47, 54]. As illustrated in Fig. 12.7a, the SSLbL involves alternately spraying polyelectrolyte solutions (i.e., positively charged and negatively charged polyelectrolytes) onto a rotating substrate (e.g., glass slide, Si wafer, or polyester film) such that electrostatic interactions and simultaneous drying results in tunable ultrathin films. The SSLbL approach is advantageous in comparison to dip
12 MXene Films, Coatings, and Bulk Processing 205
coating because the polyelectrolyte assembly is not limited by diffusion processes. Recently, Weng et al. [55] successfully prepared the LbL MXene-CNT composite films (Fig. 12.7b–d) using SSLbL assembly, and these LbL films showed high conductivity up to 130 S cm−1. To our best knowledge, this is the highest value achieved among LbL composite films to date. Moreover, these MXene-MWCNT films showed outstanding EMI shielding effectiveness. With this technique, various layer-by-layer MXene-based composite films can be developed and could lead to improved performance in mechanical strength, EMI shielding, and energy storage.

sections.heading: MXene Coatings
sections.text:
Solution-based processes such as spin, spray, and dip coatings allow surface coverage of MXene material combinations onto a wide variety of substrates. We note that these processes do not require electricity, as seen previously in EHDA and EPD (Sections “Electrohydrodynamic Atomization” and “Electrophoretic Deposition”), and rely more heavily on the chemical properties and interactions between the layering materials and the hosting substrate [56]. Typically MXene flakes are on the order of 1-nm-thick and several microns in the lateral size, depending on the delamination process [57–59]. Stable colloidal solutions of layered MXenes can be realized using appropriate solvents (described previously), and the resulting films can be obtained using nontoxic, low-cost, and solution-based processing [60]. In the next section, we will focus on using various coating techniques to obtain transparent conductive MXene thin films with good morphology that can be used as conductive electrodes for next-generation electronic devices [12, 57, 58, 61].
206 G.-M. Weng et al.

sections.heading: Spin Coating
sections.text:
Spin coating is the most known technique for producing thin films from liquid solutions. The basic working principle is depicted in Fig. 12.8a. Briefly, the desired material solution is made (colloidal or dissolved), and the substrate is wetted using the ink or droplet of the desired solution (step 1). The substrate is then rotated (step 2) and most of the solution flies off. The remaining solvent evaporates (step 3) leaving the desired molecules/material behind (step 4). Both the centripetal force and the surface tension help to obtain an even coverage of material forming a thin film [56]. In the case of the MXenes, the starting solution contains colloids of delaminated flakes (Fig. 12.8b). The thickness of the formed film can be easily controlled by changing the spin speed (Fig. 12.8c) and the concentration of the starting solution [12, 57, 62]. Such precise control allows for monitoring the amount of MXene flakes deposited on the substrates that leads to obtaining highly conductive and transparent films. A good representation of the films obtained using the Ti3C2Tx and Ti2CTx species of MXenes is summarized in Table 12.2. We also compared in this table the optoelectronic properties of other conductive 2D materials, such as reduced graphene oxide (rGO) and molybdenum disulfide (MoS2). Since the sheet resistance of thin conducting films is directly related to the transparency, a metric that enables one to quantify their quality is a figure of merit (FOM) of the ratio of the direct conductivity (σ dc) to the optical conductivity (σ oc). The higher this ratio (σ dc/σ oc), the better the film optoelectronic properties [66]. This FOM is related to both the sheet resistance (Rsh) and transparency (T) by the Eq. (12.3):
12 MXene Films, Coatings, and Bulk Processing 207
where μ0 is the vacuum permeability and ε0 is the vacuum permittivity. A comparison of optoelectronic properties of different 2D conductive materials is shown in Table 12.2. The spin-coated MXene films with high transparency (~80%) show ~5 times and ~50 times higher conductivity than rGO and MoS2, respectively. These promising results show that after only 3 years of their discovery, high conductive transparent electrodes have been fabricated; and in just 1 year, these FOM [57] have been doubled. As discussed in Chap. 25, grain boundaries of these delaminated MXene flakes play a significant role in forming a continuous network and lead to such high conductivity. It has been reported that the contact issue significantly limits the device performance of 2D electronics and requires a 2D material as electrodes to achieve ohmic contacts [67]. The highly conductive and transparent MXene films can be used as electrical contacts and reduce the contact resistance, to benefit the performance of short-channel field-effect transistors for 2D nanoelectronic devices [67] and open a path for future development for electronic applications. A more detailed discussion on transparent conductive MXene films can be found in Chap. 25 of this book.

sections.heading: Spray Coating
sections.text:
This technique relies also on the principle of self-aligning the molecules/materials while the solvent is being evaporated, nonetheless adding the benefit of independence on substrate morphology, i.e., large-scale coatings and flexible substrates. Using this process, Hantanasirisakul et al. were able to deposit thin film MXenes and take advantage of their unique combination of metallic conductivity and hydrophilicity with excellent mechanical properties [58]. Their process is shown in Fig. 12.9, where solutions containing delaminated films were sprayed onto substrates for producing the coatings. The thickness can be controlled by both the amount of solution sprayed and the initial concentration. The films obtained
208 G.-M. Weng et al.
with this technique optically resemble the ones used in spin coating. Transmissions can vary from 40% to 90% with a flat absorption in the visible range, which makes them suitable for display applications. Even though this process permits for large area coverage, the sheet resistance of the films remains a challenge [57, 58].
The importance of their method is the independence of substrate shape and size that allows for coating flexible substrates, such as polyester, and study of the bending parameters for deposited films. They described how the resulting films showed a remarkable electromechanical stability, upon a small bending radius where the sheet resistance only increased by about 15% and recovered back when removing the mechanical stress [58].

sections.heading: Mayer Rod Coating
sections.text:
There are other solution process techniques that allow for the deposition of thicker films (on the order of microns), for example, the Mayer rod coating technique [66], where ink of the desired material is spread over a large substrate by rolling a rod over it, as depicted in Fig. 12.10a. Kurra et al. used this technique to create thick MXene films for fabricating coplanar microsupercapacitors. The films created with this technique were paperlike, which allowed for laser patterning, and they were able to obtain microsupercapacitors with high areal capacitance and stable cyclic performance (Fig. 12.10b) [68]. They developed a protocol for fabricating coplanar devices with comparable energy densities with the state-of-the-art of paper-based capacitors.
12 MXene Films, Coatings, and Bulk Processing 209

sections.heading: Dip Coating
sections.text:
For completeness of this chapter, we will explain the dip coating method in the context of MXene film development. This technique is also well established for large area coverage, and a summary of the steps is depicted in Fig. 12.11a. Basically, the substrate is immersed into the desired solution (step 1), and it is slowly removed from it at a constant velocity (step 2). In the meniscus between the substrate and solution, the solvent slowly dries and the material packs by self-assembly (steps 3 and 4). Controlling the velocity and the solution concentration is important using this technique as this will have a direct impact on the film thicknesses (step 5) [69].
An interesting property of this method is the conformality that can be achieved. Ultrathin MXene flakes can keep the shape of a rough substrate and form a scaffold, as shown in Fig. 12.11b [61]. Here Anasori et al. demonstrated the possibility that their hollow structure can still be maintained while coating MXenes with carbon nanotubes (CNTs). The composites of MXenes-CNTs possess a high surface area contact which have potential applications in catalysis, water desalination, batteries etc. [4].
210 G.-M. Weng et al.

sections.heading: Bulk Processing of MXene
sections.text: A bulk process refers to the process of creating large numbers of similar products efficiently. Bulk processing of an advanced material requires significantly lower capital equipment costs, is suitable for large-area and flexible substrates, and benefits from higher throughput. The combination of more efficient materials usage and lower temperature processing [70], for example, solution-based processing (e.g., casting and printing) and roll-to-roll processing, makes this approach appealing. In this section, we will introduce some typical methods which could have significant potential for processing MXene in bulk.

sections.heading: Casting
sections.text:
The casting method is the best method for producing composite films on a large scale with high efficiency and low cost. As shown in Fig. 12.12, three steps are involved in the synthesis of MXene-polyacrylamide (PAM) nanocomposite films [71] which is used as a typical example: (i) homogeneous MXene-PAM solution should be obtained with water by mixing and sonication; (ii) the above mixed MXene-PAM solution was poured into a Teflon tray and quickly spread into an even layer at a certain thickness; and (iii) drying. The suitable polymers (should be water-soluble, hydrogen bond forming, and positively charged) can be easily processed into mixed solution and provide MXene with effective interaction, as discussed previously in section “Vacuum-Assisted Filtration”. Besides, Hao et al. [72] proposed an alternative way to achieve versatile MXene composite films via casting, in which Ti3C2Tx was firstly functionalized by grafting four types of moieties (i.e., —NH2, —COOR, —C6H6, and —C12H26) with the aid of organofunctional siloxanes. Here, polymer fillers are polyethylenimine (PEI) and
polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS), and the mixed solution was cast onto a support layer of polyacrylonitrile (PAN) ultrafiltration membrane. This research work led to four different Ti3C2Tx-based composite films with different solvent-resistant properties and nanofiltration performance.

sections.heading: Roll-to-Roll
sections.text:
Roll-to-roll, one of the dry manufacturing methods, is widely used for battery production lines [73] due to its significantly low capital equipment cost. As shown in Fig. 12.13, two steps were involved by Li et al. [74] in the roll-to-roll processing of Ti3C2Tx (MXene)-metallic lithium film [74]: first, available MXene nanosheets were rolled with lithium plate to make them elongated, and second, the elongated films are folded to increase the layer numbers. Typically, the hybrid films were folded to five times and rolled for six times. The as-prepared flexible films can be used as an artificial solid electrolyte interphase films for metallic lithium and lead to controlled growth of lithium dendrites in the nanoscaled gaps [74]. This method can be further generalized to fabricate graphene-metallic lithium films and boron nitride-metallic lithium films [74]. Currently, MXene-based electrodes for supercapacitors and batteries are mostly prepared in a slurry-cast way [75] like the preparation of that for lithium-ion batteries. Roll-to-roll could be an ideal way to directly process MXene on current collectors, thereby eliminating solvent and the evaporation process with it.
212 G.-M. Weng et al.

sections.heading: Compression Molding
sections.text:
Compression molding is a commonly used forming process for polymer, in which a plastic material is placed directly into a heated metal mold and then is softened by the heat and forced to conform to the shape of the mold as the mold closes. By using MXene-polymer mixed raw material, a large-scale and versatile MXenebased polymer composite can be easily obtained. Sun et al. reported the synthesis of MXene@polystyrene hybrid particle via electrostatic interaction and preparation of a bulk MXene@polystyrene sample with compression molding in which high pressure of 500 MPa was applied (Fig. 12.14) [76]. It is found that the compression molding at room temperature delivers a brittle MXene@polystyrene composite sample due to many gaps and voids that could not be removed. This is because the polystyrene microspheres are rigid when the molding temperature is below their glass transition temperature. To solve this issue, higher temperature like 130 ◦C could be used to enable viscoelastic deformation of the polystyrene during the compression molding. Depending on the application of the composite sample, moderate amounts of binder or lubricant additive (e.g., paraffin wax [77]) can be used to further reduce the pressing pressure and the operating temperature.
12 MXene Films, Coatings, and Bulk Processing 213

sections.heading: Patterning
sections.text:
An efficient and low-cost patterning method for MXene-based planar microsupercapacitors (MSCs), in which common laser printing is combined with VAF and physical sputtering, was recently reported by Hu et al. [78]. As illustrated in Fig. 12.15a, six steps are involved: [78] (i) a common laser printer for printing an interdigital circuit template designed with drawing software; (ii) paper substrate with the laser-printed template; (iii) vacuum-assisted deposition of fully delaminated fewlayered MXene flakes on the printed paper to fabricate the electroactive layer at the bottom; (iv) the bottom binder/conductive-additive-free electroactive layer based on few-layered Ti3C2Tx flakes; (v) magnetron sputtering of a top Au film that served as a current collector on the electroactive layer at the bottom; (vi) final lift-off to form the MXene-based planar MSCs. Compared with other patterning methods (e.g., conventional lithography [79], ink-jet printing [7], screen printing [7], and spray-coating with laser cutting [80]) for preparing coplanar interdigital MXene electrodes, this method allows fast deposition of fully delaminated few-layered MXene flakes on printing paper with tunable thickness as well as simultaneous ondemand patterning of them without the usage of any organic binders and conductive
214 G.-M. Weng et al.
additives, remarkably facilitating and accelerating the overall patterning process of MXenes to form thick coplanar interdigital electrodes for planar MSCs (Fig. 12.15b) [78].

sections.heading: Stamp Printing
sections.text:
Stamp printing is one of the flexible, scalable, reproducible, and cost-effective manufacturing methods for fabricating MXene-based electrodes. Nicolosi’s group recently reported a simple stamp printing [81] technique (comprised of 3D-printed stamps (Fig. 12.16a) and MXene-loaded inks (Fig. 12.16b)) which can be used to rapidly produce structures for MXene-based supercapacitors. This very simple deposition process involves coating the stamp with MXene ink and pressing it onto a substrate (e.g., paper, glass, and polyethylene terephthalate) subsequently (Fig. 12.16c) [81]. As shown in Fig. 12.16d, this approach promises high scalability potential, while simultaneously it stays flexible and adaptive to rapid changes [81, 82]. In Fig. 12.16e–f, Zhang et al. [82] demonstrated a scale-up production route by using cylindrical/pad stamps, and dozens of MXene-based MSCs could
12 MXene Films, Coatings, and Bulk Processing 215
be fabricated in seconds. In addition to optimizing the properties of MXene (i.e., composition, surface chemistry, and flake size), a better stamp design can be used to further achieve higher areal and volumetric capacitance, as well as higher rate handling of the solid-state MSCs [82].

sections.heading: Summary and Outlook
sections.text:
As we introduced in the above sections, multifunctional MXenes have been processed into films, coatings, and bulk products with various advanced methods. The choice of method for MXene processing depends on the specific application of interest, and each method has its pros and cons, as reviewed in this chapter. Among them, methods that involve solution-based (water as the solvent) and dry processing are more preferred since they are easy to handle and are scalable. Not surprisingly, most of the reviewed methods are mature and have also been applied to process CNTs, graphene, and other functional materials [27, 83]. However, each MXene processing method still needs to be perfected towards more efficient, lower-cost, reproducible, and higher-quality. In addition, new emerging processing technologies or methods such as 3D printing [13] and computer numerical control (CNC) deposition [84] could be used to precisely “engineer” MXene composite material in the near future. Compared with the other advanced materials (e.g., C60, CNT, and graphene), MXenes will undoubtedly open up more new opportunities by virtue of its particularly tunable surface chemistries and transition metal chemistries.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Since the discovery of the graphene, two-dimensional (2D) materials have gained momentum due to their unique physical, chemical, mechanical, electrochemical, and electronic properties [1]. Many 2D materials can be exfoliated into single atomic layers with large exposed surface areas which make them potential candidate for the next-generation flexible electronic, optoelectronic, and electrochemical devices [2, 3]. The family of 2D material is rich in compositions and offers a wide spectrum of properties (e.g., metals, semiconductors, and insulators) [4]. Recently, a variety of 2D materials have been explored including transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs), germanene, borophene, silicene, and black phosphene, among others [4]. 2D materials have been synthesized by a variety of methods, such as mechanical cleavage exfoliation, liquid-phase exfoliation, chemical/physical vapor deposition, wet chemistry, electrochemical metal ion intercalation and exfoliation, and many other methods [5].
In addition to unique properties of exfoliated 2D materials compared to their bulk counterpart, 2D geometry offers exceptional compatibility with the host materials which allow to manufacture 2D heterostructures with desired properties [6]. While 2D materials offer tremendous potential, scalability and reliable synthesis of 2D materials still pose a challenge [6]. It is worth noting that majority of the reported 2D heterostructures are inorganic in nature [3, 5], and less attention has been paid to the organic materials. Organic materials are abundant, metal-free, scalable, flexible, lightweight, and their properties can be tuned using established organic chemistry principles [7]. By knowing the target application, organic molecules

can be synthesized with tunable chemical, electronic, electrochemical, and optical properties [8]. A plethora of organic materials is available having potential for electrochemical energy storage (e.g., carbonyls), donor/acceptor organics for photovoltaics (e.g., dyes), and photosensitive (e.g., azo-molecules), electrochromic (e.g., conducting polymers [CPs]), biomedical (organic gels), and many more applications [9, 10].
From application standpoint, both organic and inorganic materials have pros and cons. Imagine an example of quinones for electrochemical energy storage applications. Theoretically, quinone molecules have high capacitance/capacity due to their highly reversible proton-coupled redox, yet they are insulator and dissolve into electrolyte during electrochemical operation; therefore, their performance deteriorates after a few hundred cycles [11]. On the other hand, if they are engineered on a conductive inorganic support, the issue of poor conductivity and solubility can be significantly reduced [12]. Consider another example of poorly conducting polystyrene for electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding [13]. Pristine polystyrene showed negligible EMI shielding effectiveness; however, when coupled with 7% carbon nanotubes, the EMI shielding effectiveness was increased to 18.2–19.3 dB over a frequency range of 8.2–12.4 GHz, which was attributed to the formation of conducting network in the polystyrene matrix [13]. These examples clearly motivate us to find the pathways to couple conductive inorganic materials with organics, which will provide a sheer number of combinations to achieve the desired properties in a device. Organic–inorganic hybrid materials have already shown a great promise for the purpose of manufacturing high-performance materials for a broad range of applications such as electrochemical energy conversion and storage, catalysis, water purification, drug delivery, electronics, photonics, textiles, and others [14]. Molecular-level combination of two best suited components in a hybrid material leads to new or sometimes exceptional sets of physical, chemical, mechanical, and electrochemical properties that makes them attractive for broad ranges of applications [15]. The desired properties of the resulting hybrid materials can further be altered by tuning the chemical compositions, molecular-level interactions/interfaces, morphologies, and shapes.
In 2011, a new family of 2D inorganic materials called MXene was discovered— now one of the fastest growing families in 2D materials world [16]. Since the discovery of the first MXene (titanium carbide, Ti3C2Tx), about 20 different MXenes have been synthesized, and dozens more are theoretically predicted [17]. MXenes are transition metal carbides, carbonitrides, and nitrides which are synthesized by selectively etching the A element layers from ternary transition metal carbides and/or nitrides with a general formula of Mn + 1AXn (M = an early transition metal, e.g., Ti, V, Mo, Sc, Zr, Hf, Nb, Ta, Cr, etc.; A = group 13 and 14 element; X = C/N; and n = 1, 2, or 3) [18, 19]. Wet chemical etching of A layer always yields surface terminations (e.g., —OH, —O, and/or —F); therefore, the general formula for the MXenes can be written as Mn + 1XnTx [20]. As opposed to other 2D materials, MXenes have a unique set of properties [21] such as metallic conductivity (∼6000–8000 S/cm), hydrophilicity, and structural diversity, enabling
13 MXene–Organic Hybrid Materials 223
their use in various applications such as supercapacitors, EMI shielding, batteries, sensors, water purification, catalysis, antibacterial films, transparent conductive electrodes, and many others [16].
MXene family is a rising star in the 2D material world. Since most of the “low-hanging MXene fruits” have already been reaped [16], it is now time to explore the MXene–organic hybrids. Indeed, the field of MXene–organic hybrids is quite new, yet it is expected that organic functionalization on MXenes can dramatically improve their performance due to synergistic contributions from each component of the hybrid. MXenes offer a unique platform to the organics because of their metallic conductivity and high aspect ratio [22]. Integration of MXenes with organic molecules and polymers is an attractive pathway to manufacture functional hybrid materials with tunable physical, chemical, electronic, mechanical, and electrochemical properties [23, 24]. The broad diversity of organic molecules and availability of over 20 different MXenes with different properties offer tremendous potential to expand the research horizons of MXene–organic hybrids. MXene–organic hybrids of desired morphologies, shapes, and properties can be synthesized by rationally selecting the MXene and organic component within a hybrid.

sections.heading: Synthesis of MXene–Organic Hybrids
sections.text:
Robust integration of organic molecules within 2D MXene sheets is the prime step toward synthesis of MXene–organic hybrids. Unlike synthesis of other 2D organic hybrids where many synthetic routes are available (e.g., wet chemical synthesis, epitaxial growth, chemical vapor deposition, spin-coating, etc.) [6], synthesis routes for MXene–organic hybrids are yet limited. The properties of the MXene–organic hybrids are largely governed by the nature of interactions between interacting moieties. These interactions can be van der Waals (vdW) or covalent interactions [25]. Unlike other 2D materials, MXenes offer unique chemical reactivity in aqueous media which can be effectively utilized to manufacture robust functional hybrid materials [24]. Synthesis of MXene–organic hybrids can be divided into three categories (Scheme 13.1): (1) oxidant-free polymerization of monomers into polymers, (2) self-assembly of organic molecules and polymers, and (3) covalent functionalization. In the following discussion, we have also included our computational results to explain the host–guest interaction mechanisms, charge transfer mechanisms, and propagation of monomers into polymers. The critical role of polarity in organic molecules/polymers is also discussed, which potentially will guide the design of new organic–inorganic hybrid materials with well-defined properties for a variety of applications.

Scheme 13.1 Various approaches for the synthesis of MXene–organic hybrid materials

sections.heading: Oxidant-Free Polymerization
sections.text:
The state-of-the-art synthesis of conducting polymer (CP) hybrids involves the addition of the monomer to the acidic solution of an oxidant in the presence of a host material where deposition of the CPs is needed (e.g., graphene, MoS2, etc.) [26, 27]. This process is called chemical oxidant polymerization [28]. While this synthesis process is in practice since the discovery of the CPs and widely explored by researchers around the world [29], it has several limitations when we want to use this method for the synthesis of organic–inorganic hybrid materials: (1) use of oxidants leads to uncontrolled polymerization, resulting in agglomerated CPs deposited on a host material. Consequently, the accessibility of ions and electrons to the bulk becomes slower; thus, maximum benefit of the hybrids remains unattainable. (2) Oxidants are hazardous agents in the synthesis and add extra cost to the synthesis. As opposed to other 2D materials [30], when we use titanium carbide (MXene) as a host material, both issues can be solved to a large extent [31]. For instance, titanium carbide offers metallic conductivity in slightly acidic aqueous media, and it can serve as an oxidant as well as offers conductive slit-shaped ion diffusion channels for rapid ionic and electronic transport [23]. In addition, its 2D morphology offers confined channels to CPs that will allow better control on polymerization process [23, 31]. The functional groups on MXene surface further serve as the interacting sites, enabling robust interaction between MXene and the CP monomers [25].
Let us discuss the synthesis of pyrrole on MXene surface [23]. Pyrrole is a five-membered ring and belongs to heterocyclic aromatic organic compounds with chemical formula C4H4NH [32]. Pyrrole can be polymerized into polypyrrole (PPy) using a variety of oxidants such as iron chloride, potassium permanganate, and others [32]. Figure 13.1a displays a schematic of synthesis of polypyrrole on MXene
13 MXene–Organic Hybrid Materials 225
by simple mixing of appropriate amounts of MXene with pyrrole. In a typical synthesis process, a solution of delaminated Ti3C2Tx (d-Ti3C2Tx) suspension of known concentration was mixed with pyrrole in two different mass to volume ratios, 2:1 and 1:1, of d-Ti3C2Tx/pyrrole to manufacture PPy–Ti3C2Tx hybrid. Vigorous stirring is usually needed to avoid agglomeration of the polypyrrole during polymerization process. After stirring, the thick black suspension was obtained that was vacuum filtered to obtain a brittle PPy–Ti3C2Tx hybrid film having thickness of ~13 μm and areal mass loading of 0.93 mg/cm2. The low-magnification crosssectional scanning electron microscope (SEM) image (Fig. 13.1b) shows that the hybrid film is composed of well-aligned stacked MXene sheets in which polypyrrole chains are likely confined.
The FTIR bands (Fig. 13.1c) in PPy–Ti3C2Tx hybrid film at 2116 and 1735 cm−1 are ascribed to C—N and carbonyl stretching, respectively. The bands at 1219 and 911 cm−1 are due to stretching vibrations of the doped polypyrrole chains. The
226 M. Boota
band at 838 cm−1 is ascribed to the C—H vibrations inside the pyrrole ring [33]. Raman bands (Fig. 13.1d) at 938, 1085, and 1261 cm−1 are associated with the formation of dications (bipolaron). The band at 985 cm−1 is ascribed to radical cation (polaron) structure within hybrid [34]. Raman bands at 616, 712, 1042, 1320, and 1590 cm−1 are assigned to the pyrrole ring torsion, C–H wagging, C– H deformation, C–C in-ring and inter-ring stretching, and C=C stretching of two oxidized structures, respectively [34, 35]. These results confirmed that pyrrole is polymerized on Ti3C2Tx MXene without using any oxidant.
Cross-sectional transmission electron microscope (TEM) image of the PPy– Ti3C2Tx hybrid film (Fig. 13.1e) showed that PPy chains are periodically aligned between MXene sheets. As opposed to conventional oxidant polymerization [26], MXene-induced polymerization produced hybrid film in which polymer chains were aligned instead of agglomerating. Here, MXene served as a hard template as well as a conductive substrate for the alignment and synthesis of the PPy chains. It was earlier reported that hydrogen bonding is the key interaction which assists alignment of the PPy chains. Generally, monomers of CPs incline toward random aggregation during polymerization; however, they tend to self-align if hydrogen bonding is present within interacting moieties of the hybrid [36, 37]. In the PPy–Ti3C2Tx hybrid, the hydrogen bonding-assisted alignment of PPy chains stems from the hydrogen bonding interaction between terminating oxygen or fluorine present on the Ti3C2Tx surface and N–H group of the pyrrole ring. In addition, ordered oligomer chains favored 2D growth of PPy within MXene sheets rather than randomly [29, 36]. Such ordered morphologies are highly desired where rapid ion and electron percolation is needed [38, 39]. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the pristine Ti3C2Tx and the PPy–Ti3C2Tx (1:2) exhibited identical XRD pattern in the range of 20–35◦; however, a clear downshift in the (0002) peak from ~6.4◦ to ~3.6◦ was noted for the hybrid film. This confirmed that PPy chains were intercalated between MXene layers and expanded the interlayer spacing from 13.8 to 24 Å (Fig. 13.1f). It is important to mention that pure PPy is amorphous and therefore shows a very broad diffraction peak at ~25◦, corresponding to the scattering from PPy chains [40].
Mostly, synthesis of CPs involves balanced mixing of a monomer and an oxidizing agent (e.g., K2Cr2O7, FeCl3, KMnO4, CuCl2, etc.) in an acidic media [41, 42]. However, it has been reported earlier that elements of halogen family can act as both oxidizing and chemical polymerization agents [43, 44]. For example, Kang et al. used halogens (e.g., iodine, bromine, and chlorine) for simultaneous oxidation and polymerization of pyrrole into PPy [43, 44]. The polymerization of pyrrole has also been reported via protonation of pyrrole [45]. Since Ti3C2Tx has an acidic character, its interaction with pyrrole resulted in protonated molecule, which then interacts with the unprotonated pyrrole to generate a dimer. The process continues to form longer PPy chains which become conductive via fluorine doping from MXene [41, 43, 44, 46]. The proposed mechanism for this polymerization is shown in Fig. 13.1g [32, 47]. MXene films are flexible [24]; however, PPy–Ti3C2Tx appeared brittle after polymerization. This further suggested the formation of low molecular weight PPy that hindered sliding of MXene sheets [24]. There are other possible
13 MXene–Organic Hybrid Materials 227
explanations; however, one theoretically supported mechanism of the spontaneous polymerization without the addition of any oxidant is discussed in the forthcoming section.
Mechanism of MXene Induced Self-Polymerization of CPs: A Case of PEDOT–Ti3C2Tx
With the help of the density functional theory (DFT) calculations, we tried to identify the mechanism of MXene-induced polymerization in the absence of oxidants [31]. We demonstrated this on a different monomer 3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene (EDOT) which serves as a backbone for the synthesis of a wide variety of π -conjugated polymers with tailored optical, electronic, and electrochemical properties [48]. Freestanding films of PEDOT–MXene were produced using a similar method that was used for the polymerization of pyrrole.
To experimentally confirm the MXene-induced polymerization of EDOT without an oxidant, we used Raman and FTIR spectroscopies. Raman spectra of pristine Ti3C2Tx, conventionally synthesized PEDOT, and the hybrid structure are shown in Fig. 13.2a. The PEDOT–MXene hybrid film exhibited a combined character of conventional PEDOT and Ti3C2Tx, confirming remarkable potential of MXene to polymerize monomers in the absence of oxidants. This is in sharp contrast to other 2D materials, where excessive amounts of oxidants are needed to initiate the polymerization which often leads to agglomeration on 2D sheets [30]. The bands at 1541 and 1451 cm−1 were ascribed to vibrations of thiophene ring, and C=C symmetric vibrations. It has been reported that 1451 cm−1 peak can be associated with the degree of oxidation in the PEDOT structure. Since the 1451 cm−1 peak appeared less intense compared to conventionally synthesized PEDOT, it was confirmed that EDOT is less oxidized using MXene compared to other strong oxidants, however sufficient enough to produce doped PEDOT chains [49, 50]. The bands at 1268, 1146, 998, 854, 713, 574, and 436 cm−1 are attributed to the C–C stretching, quinoid ring vibration, oxyethylene ring deformation, C–O bending vibrations, symmetric C–S–C deformation, and C–O–C bond deformation, respectively, confirming the polymerization of the doped PEDOT [51–53]. The Raman results clearly confirmed that EDOT interacted and polymerized on MXene surface [18]. FTIR spectroscopy (Fig. 13.2b) further corroborated the Raman results. The typical vibrations of the thiophene ring (C–S band) were observed at 990, 854, and 692 cm−1 [54]. The stretching vibrations of the C–O–C bond in the ethylene dioxy group were seen at 1149 and 1080 cm−1. The ones at 1643 and 1361 cm−1 were assigned to the C–C and C=C stretching vibrations of the thiophene ring [31]. Furthermore, the existence of the C=C stretching bands agrees to the conjugated network of the PEDOT, also endorsing doped (conductive) PEDOT [55, 56]. Both Raman and FTIR spectroscopic results confirmed that EDOT has been polymerized on/between the Ti3C2Tx layers. Once EDOT polymerization was confirmed by experimental means, further mechanism was supported by the DFT calculations [31].
228 M. Boota
As a first step, we determined the adsorption of the EDOT on the Ti3C2O2 in five different configurations (orientations: pI–III, parallel; vI–II, vertical). The following formula was used to determine the binding energies (BE) of EDOT on the surface of Ti3C2O2:
EBE = EMXene+EDOT − (EMXene + EEDOT) ,
where EBE is the total binding energy (BE), EMXene + EDOT is the total energy of EDOT adsorbed on the surface of Ti3C2O2, EMXene is the total energy of Ti3C2O2, and EEDOT is the total energy of the EDOT monomer. Based on the BE values, it became clear that EDOT preferably adsorb on MXene surface in parallel configuration, which was confirmed by the lowest BE values of the pI configuration (−1.02 eV). The fact that other configurations showing higher BE values confirmed that they are not preferred configurations for the EDOT adsorption during polymerization (Fig. 13.2c). Charge density of the most stable configuration (pI) was further calculated. It was found that the π electrons of EDOT were partially transferred to the Ti3C2O2 surface, while the rest were transferred to C-2p or O2p orbits (Fig. 13.2d) [31]. This electron exchange was further measured by using
13 MXene–Organic Hybrid Materials 229
Bader analysis [57], and we found that there were 0.34 electrons transferred from EDOT to Ti3C2O2. This electron transfer occurred due to higher Fermi energy level aligned to the vacuum energy level of EDOT at −4.31 eV compared to Ti3C2O2 at −6.24 eV (Fig. 13.2d).
The effect of charge transfer on EDOT polymerization on the surface of Ti3C2O2 was determined by calculating the energy cost for polymerization, while different electrons are lost from EDOT (Fig. 13.2e). The following relationship was used to calculate the average energy cost for polymerization (y):
y = (EPEDOT + 2nEH-nEEDOT) /n,
where EPEDOT, n, EEDOT, and EH parameters are the total energy of PEDOT with nx being electron loss, number of EDOT in one PEDOT unit, total energy with x electron loss, and total energy of H atoms, respectively. The fitted linear relationship between energy cost and electron loss is y = −7.19x + 4.93 (Fig. 13.2e). It can be seen that energy cost for polymerization was decreased with the electron loss from EDOT. In other words, the higher energy level leads to electron transfer from EDOT to MXenes, resulting in a facile polymerization of EDOT to PEDOT on MXene surface for formation of the Ti3C2Tx–PEDOT hybrid structure [31].
Based on our above discussion on facile in-situ polymerization, it can be concluded that two factors are needed to complete this polymerization using MXene’s local chemistry: (1) charge transfer must happen between the MXene and CP monomer, and (2) as the polymerization reaction proceeds, energy cost for polymerization ε decreases with the progress of charge loss from monomer e until the reaction barriers are conquered. Thus, two reaction pathways are possible as shown in Fig. 13.2f. In case of type I reaction pathway, electrons will transfer from the monomer to the substrate ( e) when the highest occupied molecular orbitals (HOMOs) of the monomer (EDOT) are higher than the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of the substrate (MXene). This potentially results in the polymerization if its energy cost decreases with electron transfer, just as EDOT on the MXene surface. For type II reaction pathway, the reverse may happen to complete the polymerization. For instance, polymerization reaction may also occur if its energy cost decreases with electrons transferring from the substrate (MXene) to the monomer (EDOT) (− e), since the HOMO of the substrate is higher than the LUMO of the monomer. Based on these rules, many MXene–polymer hybrids can be synthesized without using any oxidant for a broad range of applications.

sections.heading: Oxidant-Based Polymerization
sections.text:
There are few reports where oxidants were also used to polymerize the CP monomers on MXene surface. Zhongxing et al. [58] used ammonium persulfate to polymerize EDOT on MXene using 1,5-naphthalene disulfonic acid/H3PMo12O40 and 1,5-naphthalene disulfonic acid/anthraquinone-2-sulfonate (AQS) as dopants. Xiao et al. [59] prepared TiO2–Ti3C2Tx hybrid using hydrothermal method,
230 M. Boota
followed by in-situ polymerization of aniline on pre-synthesized TiO2–Ti3C2Tx hybrid using ammonium persulfate in acidic media. This yielded hierarchal PANI@TiO2–Ti3C2Tx ternary hybrid which was used for electrochemical energy storage applications. Yingying et al. [60] used the same approach as reported by Xiao et al. and polymerized aniline on MXene surface using ammonium persulfate as an oxidant. Yuan et al. [61] produced Ti3C2Tx–PPy hybrids using pyrrole as a monomer and ammonium persulfate as an oxidant in an acidic media. While there are reports on polymerizing CP monomers on MXene surface using oxidants, care should be taken since MXene solution tends to oxidize upon addition of the oxidants.

sections.heading: Self-Assembly of Organic Molecules and Polymers
sections.text:
Molecular self-assembly on 2D solids is an established approach to manufacture functional hybrid materials for a variety of applications [14]. Hybrid structures formed via self-assembly method are driven by the complex molecular interactions between organic functionalities and 2D solids [62]. These interactions are usually weak physical interactions, namely, as π–π stacking interactions, hydrogen bonding, and van der Waals interactions [63]. Molecular self-assembly of organics on 2D materials such as graphene, hexagonal boron nitride (hBN), and transition metal dichalcogenides can be different due to varying nature of chemistries [5]. Unlike other 2D materials, MXene flakes are hydrophilic and offer a highly negative zeta potential in the range of −30 to −80 mV [21]. These features facilitate the processing of MXene with organic molecules/polymers in aqueous media compared to other 2D materials where usually surfactants or other organic molecules are needed to stabilize the suspensions [64].
Ling et al. [24] pioneered manufacturing of first conductive, flexible, and freestanding MXene–polymer hybrid film. The hybrid films were made by simple mixing of Ti3C2Tx MXene with either a charged polydiallyldimethylammonium chloride (PDDA) or an electrically neutral polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) to produce Ti3C2Tx–polymer hybrids. The resulting suspensions were vacuum filtered through a polypropylene separator membrane to yield flexible hybrid films. The polymers were self-assembled between MXene layers due to high negative zeta potential and opposing charges on polymers especially on a cationic PDDA polymer. The fact that (0002) peaks shifted toward lower angles in XRD patterns of both hybrids suggested that polymer chains were intercalated between MXene sheets. It was shown that the thickness, conductivity, and flexibility of the hybrid films can be tuned in a range from hundreds of nanometers to tens of micrometers by simply altering the starting amount of the polymer within hybrid.
Using a similar concept, Hyosung et al. [65] recently produced MXene– polyelectrolyte hybrids using layer-by-layer (LbL) assembly method (Fig. 13.3a). They have used positively charged polyelectrolyte called poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) (PDAC) due to +18 mV zeta potential. As MXene offers highly
13 MXene–Organic Hybrid Materials 231
negative zeta potential, self-assembly of PDAC and MXene was expected. To accomplish this task, Ti3C2Tx MXene multilayers were first deposited by alternate immersion (Fig. 13.3b) or by spraying (Fig. 13.3c) of the Ti3C2Tx MXene and PDAC. As the number of MXene layers was increased, the color of the films became darker (Fig. 13.3b, c). Interestingly, when PDAC was removed from the coating process, and only Ti3C2Tx MXene film deposition was attempted, it did not work. This confirmed that electrostatic interactions between organic and Ti3C2Tx are needed for the robust MXene–organic hybrids. The structure and morphology of the hybrid films were examined by cross-sectional SEM of the hybrid film which showed nacre-like brick-and-mortar cross section, and moreover, surface was covered with the dense Ti3C2Tx nanosheets having a thickness of 378 ± 33 nm (for 40 layers). The ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectra exhibited broad absorption peaks at 770 nm which agrees to Ti3C2Tx sheets. As the number of the layers was increased, the absorption at 770 nm increased linearly, which is consistent with the linear increase in film thickness (Fig. 13.3 e–g). Given that the thickness of MXene
232 M. Boota
sheet is ~1 nm and that the thickness of the coated polymer is negligible, then each deposit step adsorbed ten layers of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets. The profilometry was used to measure the root-mean-square (RMS) roughness which appeared <40 nm (Fig. 13.1g). Using similar approach, many MXene–organic conductive coatings can be explored in the future. Zehang et al. [66] also used LbL method to produce freestanding, flexible, and conductive hybrid films composed of Ti3C2Tx (MXene), multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), and polycaprolactone (PCL) fiber networks. Initially, negatively charged MXene aqueous suspension was spray coated on oppositely charged MWCNT suspension on a polyethyleneimine-functionalized PCL film. This combination exhibited open network architecture since MWCNTs served as the spacer which prevented MXene sheet restacking, and highly porous nature of PCL assisted to enhance the surface area of the hybrid which is much needed for fluid transport through membranes.
While selecting a target polymer, another critical parameter to consider is the solubility of the polymer. It is important to mention that the solubility of the MXene and a target polymer in the same solvent is a crucial step to manufacture robust MXene–polymer hybrids. As MXenes have high negative zeta potential in neutral and basic solutions upon delamination, they give stable colloidal suspensions. Naguib et al. [67] investigated polyacrylamide (PAM) as a potential candidate for hybridization with MXene. PAM has many industrial applications such as in paper industry, wastewater treatment, and soil conditioner, among others. Since PAM potentially can form hydrogen bond as well as is a water-soluble polymer, it potentially can be a good candidate to hybridize with MXene. To prepare Ti3C2Tx– PAM hybrid, different mass ratios of Ti3C2Tx to PAM were mixed. The hybrid solution was then mixed to get the Ti3C2Tx–PAM hybrid films. Using XRD, it was noticed that the intensity of the Ti3C2Tx (0002) peak around 9◦ 2θ was reduced. This confirmed that Ti3C2Tx flakes are disordered or well dispersed in the PAM matrix, which is in contrast to previously reported MXene–PVA or PDDA systems. When 6 wt% of PAM was used as the initial mass, large quantities of PAM were intercalated between MXene layers, enabling their separation. When the PAM content was reduced, the intercalation of PAM appeared every 3–8 layers. This was not sufficient enough to delaminate multilayer Ti3C2Tx to nanosheets. Therefore, large amount of multilayer MXene was available in 31% hybrid film. From this analysis, it was concluded that intercalation of PAM between MXene layers is a multistaged process, like intercalation of organic compounds into graphite. Elisa et al. [68] electrospun a range of polymers, namely, poly(acrylic acid) (PAA), polyethylene oxide (PEO), PVA, and alginate/PEO with Ti3C2Tx MXene. While polymer content in these hybrid fibers was low (1% w/w), it significantly impacted the viscosity, conductivity, and crystallinity of the polymers.
While a variety of organic molecules and polymers were combined with the MXene, the interaction mechanism of polymers and MXene was not clear. We systematically investigated the interaction of conjugated polymers (polyfluorene derivatives [PFDs]) with layers of 2D Ti3C2Tx [69]. Three derivatives with polar, nonpolar, and charged nitrogen-containing functionalities were synthesized using Suzuki polycondensation reaction. We synthesized polyfluorene derivatives P1
13 MXene–Organic Hybrid Materials 233
[poly(9,9-dioctylfluorene), poly({9,9′-bis[3′′-(N,N-dimethylamino)propyl]-2,7fluorene}-alt-2,7-(9,9-dioctylfluorene))], P2 [poly({9,9′-bis[3′′-(N,N-dimethylamino)propyl]-2,7-fluorene}-alt-2,7-(9,9-dioctylfluorene))], and P3 [poly([2,7(9,9′-dioctyl)fluorene]-alt-{2,7-[9,9′-bis(5′′-trimethylammonium bromide)pentyl] fluorene})] with different lateral chain functionalities. These pre-synthesized polymers were combined with the Ti3C2Tx MXene to manufacture PFD–Ti3C2Tx hybrids (Fig. 13.4a).
When we compared the XRD patterns of all the hybrids, it became clear that intercalation of polymers between Ti3C2Tx MXene is end-group dependent. The largest downshift in c-lattice parameter (c-LP) was noticed for the P3@Ti3C2Tx, a nitrogen bearing charged polymer (7.23◦ for Ti3C2Tx to 5.34◦ for P3@Ti3C2Tx). The shift in the c-LP was associated with the end-group polarity. For instance, P1 neither had nitrogen end group nor the charged ends, so the change in the c-LP was lowest as opposed to P3. The cross-sectional SEM image of the P3@Ti3C2Tx (Fig. 13.4c, top left) displayed aligned Ti3C2Tx layers in which P3 is likely confined. TEM image (Fig. 13.4c, top right) of P3@Ti3C2Tx showed that P3 chains are confined and aligned between Ti3C2Tx layers. It was concluded that the self-assembly of this hybrid became possible because of electrostatic interactions
234 M. Boota
between positively charged lateral chain functionalities of P3 and negatively charged Ti3C2Tx MXene.
To further strengthen this argument, fluorescence microscopy images were taken on P2- (Fig. 13.4c, bottom left) and P3-containing (Fig. 13.4c, bottom right) hybrid films. The top view micrographs clearly show the existence of segregated fluorescent clusters (P2) on a black background (MXene) in P2@Ti3C2Tx; however, in P3@Ti3C2Tx, the fluorescent emission is diffused more homogenously on the entire MXene surface. FTIR spectra of the P3@Ti3C2Tx film (Fig. 13.4d) exhibited strong blue shifts from 1150 to 1550 cm−1. Importantly, the large shifts were associated with the cationic ends of the P3 polymer, confirming that the cationic end of the P3 polymer plays a decisive role in interaction with the Ti3C2Tx surface. Raman spectroscopy was conducted on all hybrids. It appeared that P3@Ti3C2Tx showed strong signatures of both Ti3C2Tx and P3, which displayed the presence of large amount of P3 between the layers or on the surface. All peaks of the P3@Ti3C2Tx were broadened (Fig. 13.4e), confirming P3 polymer interaction via the charged ends and confinement between the Ti3C2Tx MXene layers, consistent with earlier reports on polyaniline, polyamide, and other polymerclay hybrids [70–72]. Therefore, both FTIR and Raman spectra corroborated that the charged nitrogen-containing functionalities may be responsible for the interaction of polymers with Ti3C2Tx. A strong shift toward a lower binding energy (BE) in the Xray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of P3@Ti3C2Tx further confirmed the bonding of the nitrogen species to an electron donor (MXene). This study concluded that polar polymers with charged nitrogen-containing groups preferably interact with the Ti3C2Tx layers, as shown by an increase in interlayer spacing and large shifts in spectroscopic peaks (Fig. 13.4).

sections.heading: Covalent Functionalization
sections.text:
There are two synthesis methods reported so far which utilized covalent functionalization approach: (1) spontaneous functionalization of organics and (2) diazonium coupling. Hongbing et al. [73, 74] functionalized Ti3C2Tx using diazonium chemistry. First, multilayered Ti3C2Tx powder was mixed with sodium chloride to prepare pre-intercalated Ti3C2Tx. The solution was centrifuged, and sediment was washed with DI water to further functionalize it. The grafting of phenylsulfonic groups was achieved by mixing the sodium intercalated Ti3C2Tx suspensions with sulfanilic acid, hydrochloric acid, and sodium nitrite. The resulting mixture was washed with water, methanol, dimethylformamide, and acetone to eliminate salts, impurities, and loosely attached species. Our group has recently shown that amino acid such as glycine self-functionalize on Ti3C2Tx surface [25]. We first used DFT calculations to predict the most stable configuration of glycine on Ti3C2O2 MXene surface. It appeared that the glycine molecules were aligned in parallel to Ti3C2O2 (MXene) surface with largest BE of −0.75 eV. Shared electrons between Ti and N atoms suggested the formation of a Ti–N bond between glycine and Ti3C2O2,
13 MXene–Organic Hybrid Materials 235
which was also confirmed by the XPS analysis. We calculated interlayer spacing of glycine–Ti3C2Tx hybrid by XRD and found that hybrid film exhibited 1.22 Å larger spacing compared to pristine Ti3C2Tx MXene, which agreed with our theoretical predictions. This demonstration clearly suggests exploring more organic molecules which can covalently attached to MXene by simple mixing as opposed to other 2D materials where tedious synthesis protocols are needed for functionalization of organic molecules.

sections.heading: Applications of MXene–Organic Hybrids
sections.text:
MXene–organic hybrids offer a broad range of applications such as energy storage, catalysis, water purification, biomedical, conductive coatings, and EMI shielding, to name just a few (Fig. 13.5) [16]. We have summarized synthesis and applications of reported MXene–organic hybrid materials in Table 13.1.
Structural Hybrids Ling et al. [24] produced Ti3C2Tx–PVA and Ti3C2Tx–PDDA hybrid films which exhibited improved mechanical properties and prevented sheet restacking due to intercalated polymer chains. The strength of the Ti3C2Tx–PVA film reached up to 91 ± 10 MPa when PVA loading was 60 wt% in the hybrid film. Furthermore, a hollow cylinder made of 90 wt% Ti3C2Tx–PVA composition with 6 mm diameter and 10 mm height dimensions easily supported stress of ∼2.9 MPa.
