238 M. Boota
capacitance of Ti3C2Tx MXene (528 Fcm−3, 2 mVs−1, KOH electrolyte). Heng et al. [75] prepared Ti3C2Tx–ultrahigh molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE) hybrid by mixing modified Ti3C2Tx MXene solution with the UHMWPE. The mixture was then molded on a press vulcanizer which automatically controlled temperature, pressure, cooling, and spread out into a 150 × 150 × 4 mm3 squareshaped mold. The mixture was warmed up to 220 ◦C under 10 MPa, followed by cooling and cutting into different shapes for characterizations. Crystallinity, surface hardness, mechanical properties, creep resistance, and antifriction properties of the hybrid films appeared improved. Ti3C2Tx–PAM (polyacrylamide) hybrid was manufactured by simple mixing of PAM with Ti3C2Tx MXene, resulting in a very promising dispersion of MXene nanoflakes. Moreover, a high conductivity of 3.3 × 10−2 Sm−1 was achieved for 6 wt% (1.7 vol%) MXene-containing film [67].
Yong et al. [76] manufactured poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF)–Ti3C2Tx hybrids by solution blending and compression molding method. Regardless of the starting PVDF amount (1–5 wt%) used in the hybrid, the thermal conductivity of the hybrid appeared improved when compared to pristine Ti3C2Tx film. A maximum thermal conductivity of 0.363 W mK−1 was achieved when PVDF loading was 5 wt%, which is onefold higher compared to neat PVDF. Not only thermal properties, but 5 wt% hybrid also showed a storage modulus as high as ~7500 MPa that is 64% higher compared with that of pristine PVDF. Ziyin et al. [77] produced poly(ethylene oxide)(PEO)–Ti3C2Tx hybrid using solution blending method. Various compositions were prepared by changing the content of the Ti3C2Tx in the hybrid (0–5 wt%). Wide-angle XRD confirmed that crystalline structure of the PEO is not changed and Ti3C2Tx layers are exfoliated. By using non-isothermal and isothermal crystallization study, it was confirmed that with the addition of the Ti3C2Tx, crystallization rates first increased and then decreased. The fastest crystallization rates were noticed when 0.5 wt% Ti3C2Tx content was used in the hybrid. This observation was ascribed to the competition of the two phenomena named nucleation and confinement effect of the 2D filler. When Ti3C2Tx loading is lower, the filler enhances PEO crystallization because of heterogeneous nucleation, and when Ti3C2Tx loading is higher, the filler offers rigid confinement network, which reduces the crystallization. When Ti3C2Tx content was ~5 wt%, the crystallization of PEO was increased again due to lower confinement effect.
Riu et al. [78] investigated the thermal properties of the Ti3C2Tx–PVA hybrid by temperature-dependent Raman spectroscopy and polarized-laser power-dependent Raman spectroscopy. Their results showed that inclusion of PVA to MXene enhanced the thermal stability of Ti3C2Tx by reducing the thermal coefficient of the Eg1 mode from −0.06271 to −0.03357 cm−1 K−1. This was ascribed to the formation of the Ti–O bonds between Ti3C2Tx and PVA polymer, confirmed by the XPS results. In addition, the thermal conductivities of Ti3C2Tx–PVA hybrid and pristine Ti3C2Tx were found to be 47.6 and 55.8 W/(m−1K−1), respectively. Xinxin et al. [79] investigated the impact of MXene on crystallization and thermal
13 MXene–Organic Hybrid Materials 239
degradation kinetics linear low-density polyethylene (LLDPE). It appeared that the addition of only 2% of Ti3C2Tx MXene in the hybrid can accelerate the crystallization rate and thermal stability.
Filtration/Membranes/Coatings Runlin et al. [80] prepared the Ti3C2Tx–PES hybrid at 0.2 MPa on a polyethersulfone (PES) ultrafiltration membrane via a simple filtration method. When the Ti3C2Tx content was increased in the Ti3C2Tx–PES hybrid film, it showed high rejection to dyes and inorganic salts. Importantly, hybrid membranes exhibited good flux (115 Lm−2 h−1) and high rejection to Congo red dye (92.3% at 0.1 MPa). At flux above 432 Lm−2 h−1 (0.1 MPa), the hybrid film rejected inorganic salts below 23%, confirming the potential use of MXene-containing hybrid membranes in water treatment and dye desalination. Xiaoli et al. [81] prepared two different types of MXene–polymer hybrid membranes for solvent-resistant nanofiltration technology. They selected hydrophilic polyethyleneimine (PEI) and hydrophobic polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) to combine them with Ti3C2Tx MXene, where the former offers an excellent solvent resistance and good mechanical/chemical properties and later is promising for the organic solvents that mostly contain weak or nonpolar solvents. Six commonly used solvents, namely, ethanol, isopropanol, butanone, ethyl acetate, toluene, and n-heptane, were selected to assess solvent-resistant ability and nanofiltration performances of as-produced hybrid membranes. Large lateral size of Ti3C2Tx MXene provided interaction platform to the polymer chains, restricting the chain movement of the polymers. Consequently, hybrid films exhibited enhanced structural stability and solvent resistance. The hydroxyl groups present on Ti3C2Tx surface played a crucial role to transport alcohol molecules. In this way, PEIand PDMS-containing membranes showed 30% and 162% higher alcohol flux, respectively. PDMS-containing membrane showed better performance because weak interactions between PDMS and Ti3C2Tx permits more —OH groups to work as active sites for the alcohol molecules. When nanofiltration performance of both membranes was compared, it appeared that PEI-containing membrane is good for dealing with polar solvents and PDMS-containing membrane is good for the nonpolar solvents. Moreover, the Ti3C2Tx nanosheets effectively blocked the transfer of large-sized polyethylene glycol oligomers which helped to improve the rejection capability of both PEI- and PDMS-containing membranes. Lan et al. [82] modified the surface of the Ti3C2Tx nanosheets to prepare solvent-specific MXene-based membranes. Four different types of functional groups, namely, —COOR, —NH2, —C6H6, and —C12H26, were grafted onto pristine Ti3C2Tx with the aid of organofunctional siloxanes. The aim of this effort was to provide carrier sites and boost the molecular transport along the Ti3C2Tx surface. It turned out that functionalization of Ti3C2Tx–NH2, Ti3C2Tx–COOR, Ti3C2Tx–C6H6, and Ti3C2Tx–C12H26 led to major flux improvement ratio for isopropanol, ethyl acetate, toluene, and n-heptane, respectively. By embedding functionalized Ti3C2Tx MXene into PEI, PDMS improved the rejection ability of membranes by extending transport pathways of solute molecules. These results suggest that incorporation of
240 M. Boota
Ti3C2Tx MXene into PEI and PDMS polymers may be a universal strategy for the nanofiltration of the alcohol-based filtration processes.
Zhi et al. [83] produced hybrid of Ti3C2Tx with chitosan (CS) to fabricate Ti3C2Tx–CS membrane on porous polyacrylonitrile (PAN) substrate using spincoating process for solvent dehydration via pervaporation process. Three different types of organic solvents, ethanol, ethyl acetate, and dimethyl carbonate, were used to investigate the membrane dehydration performance. It appeared that combination of Ti3C2Tx MXene did not enhance the surface sorption; however, the presence of Ti3C2Tx MXene improved the permeation of water molecules throughout the membrane. Consequently, separation factor and flux of CS membrane were enhanced due to the presence of Ti3C2Tx MXene nanosheets. Particularly, Ti3C2Tx–CS membrane showed total flux of ~1.4–1.5 kgm−2 h−1 and separation factor of 1421, 4898, and 906 for dehydration of ethanol, ethyl acetate, and dimethyl carbonate at 50 ◦C, respectively [83]. This shows the potential of MXene to manufacture membranes for solvent dehydration.
Jiakui et al. [84] functionalized Ti3C2Tx MXene sulfonated polyelectrolyte brushes (Ti3C2Tx–SO3H) through a facile surface-initiated precipitationpolymerization. The functionalized MXene is then used to manufacture hybrid proton exchange membranes with basic CS and acidic sulfonated poly(ether ether ketone) (SPEEK) as polymer matrixes. It appeared that Ti3C2Tx–SO3H sheets provided efficient proton transport pathways and linked the conduction channels in polymer phase. Consequently, proton conduction in the hybrid membranes boosted under both hydrated condition and anhydrous condition. More importantly, the incorporation of only 10 wt% Ti3C2Tx–SO3H gave 144% and 66% improvement in proton conductivity to SPEEK membrane and CS membrane under hydrated condition, respectively. In addition, the mechanical and thermal properties of both membranes were improved.
Electromagnetic Interference (EMI) Shielding Hybrid materials are also attractive for EMI shielding applications [13]. While pristine Ti3C2Tx have shown extraordinary EMI shielding properties [85], search for the new hybrid materials with high conductivity and minimum amount of MXene is still ongoing [86]. For example, Faisal et al. [85] first reported nacre-like Ti3C2Tx–sodium alginate (SA) hybrid film (Ti3C2Tx–SA) which exhibited excellent EMI shielding performance. The thickness of the hybrid film was kept between 8 and 9 μm while studying different compositions of the hybrid. It appeared that EMI shielding efficiency increased with increasing the Ti3C2Tx loading and reached to a maximum of 57 dB for the 90 wt% Ti3C2Tx–SA composition. It was concluded that instead of reflection, absorption was the leading mechanism for EMI shielding in Ti3C2Tx–SA hybrids.
Renhui et al. [86] manufactured highly conductive Ti3C2Tx–polystyrene (PS) hybrid using electrostatic interaction principle (Fig. 13.6a). The positively charged PS spheres were prepared with cationic dimethylamino methacrylate methylchloride (DMC) as a stabilizer which exhibited zeta potential in the range of 33 (pH = 11.3) and 69 (pH = 2.7) mV (Fig. 13.6b). On the other hand, Ti3C2Tx synthesized in
13 MXene–Organic Hybrid Materials 241
their study showed zeta potential of −25 (pH = 3.0) to −54 mV (pH = 11.3). A simple mixing of two varying zeta potential materials led to the formation of robust hybrid via electrostatic interactions. The resultant hybrid showed low percolation threshold of 0.26 vol% and excellent conductivity of 1081 Sm−1. The EMI shielding performance of >54 dB was noted over the whole X-band with a maximum of 62 dB at the low Ti3C2Tx loading of 1.90 vol%. Not only had this but Ti3C2Tx– PS hybrid also exhibited improved storage modulus, 54% higher than those of pristine PS. Yuan et al. [61] produced Ti3C2Tx–PPy hybrid by oxidative chemical polymerization. It was noticed that 25 wt% Ti3C2Tx–PPy hybrids in a paraffin matrix demonstrated a minimum reflection loss of −49.2 dB and maximum effective absorption bandwidth of 5.7 GHz. The enhanced EMI performance was attributed to the conductive network, dipolar, and interfacial polarizations.
Energy Storage Polypyrrole (PPy) is known for its pseudocapacitance, flexibility, and intrinsic conductivity [87]. For the first time, we prepared [23] PPy–Ti3C2Tx hybrid in the absence of any oxidant which exhibited volumetric capacitance of ∼1000 Fcm−3 and high capacitance retention of 92% after 25,000 charge/discharge cycles. Chi et al. [31] produced PEDOT–Ti3C2Tx hybrids by oxidant-free polymerization of the EDOT on surface of Ti3C2Tx layers by simple mixing of the aqueous suspensions of EDOT and Ti3C2Tx MXene. The as-produced PEDOT–Ti3C2Tx hybrid showed a reversible capacity of ∼300 mAhg−1 with excellent capacity retention and rate performance, outperforming its pristine counterparts. In another study [25], we have shown that glycine molecules can covalently attach to Ti3C2Tx via Ti–N bonding, which also expanded the interlayer spacing of the Ti3C2Tx sheets.
242 M. Boota
Strong interactions between glycine molecules and expanded MXene layers gave an easier path for ion mobility, enabling high rate performance of the hybrid electrodes. At a scan rate of 10 mVs−1, the capacitance of the hybrid electrodes reached to 324 Fg−1 and lost 60% of capacitance after high rate of 1 Vs−1, twice the value of pristine Ti3C2Tx film. Not only high rate performance but the hybrid electrodes also showed excellent stability for more than 20,000 charge/discharge cycles. The improved capacitance, rate performance, and cycle life were ascribed to enhance interlayer spacing and stronger interaction between glycine molecules and Ti3C2Tx MXene (Fig. 13.7).
Minshen et al. [88] used PPy chains to intercalate between Ti3C2Tx sheets to improve the capacitance and cycling stability of the PPy [88]. The capacitance of the as-produced Ti3C2Tx–PPy improved from 150 (300) to 203 mFcm−2 (406 Fcm−3), and hybrid showed 100% capacitance retention after 20,000 charge/discharge cycles. This was ascribed to the fact that Ti3C2Tx prevented dense PPy stacking between/on the sheets; therefore, electrolyte infiltration was facile during charging/discharging. Another factor which contributed to boost the cycling stability was the strong bonding between PPy backbones and surface functional groups of Ti3C2Tx, resulting in improved conductivity and better stability of the hybrid during electrochemical operation. The hybrid was further tested in an ultrathin allsolid-state supercapacitor which exhibited an excellent capacitance of 35 mFcm−2, and stable electrochemical performance at any bending state, and during 10,000
13 MXene–Organic Hybrid Materials 243
charging/discharging cycles [88]. Hongbing et al. [73, 74] functionalized Ti3C2Tx MXene with phenylsulfonic groups derived from in-situ-generated diazonium ions by the corresponding amine. Aryl groups were attached to MXene sheets in the form of strong MXene-aryl (Ti–O–C) linkages. MXene sheets with grafted electroactive groups gave twice high capacitance compared to their pristine counterpart due to electroactive aryl groups. The hybrid electrodes also showed high capacitance retention of 91% after 10,000 charge/discharge cycles. This study clearly highlighted the importance of covalent functionalization MXenes with other electroactive organic molecules.
Yingying et al. [60] produced Ti3C2Tx–PANI hybrid via oxidative chemical polymerization. The as-produced hybrids were tested as a supercapacitor electrode in a three-electrode configuration. The electrolyte used was 1 M Na2SO4 and the tested voltage window was −0.8 V to −0.2 V versus Ag/AgCl. The hybrid electrodes showed a maximum capacitance of 164 Fg−1 at 2 mV/s and 96% capacitance retention after 3000 cycles. The improved performance was ascribed to the pseudocapacitive contributions of the PANI molecules. Leiqiang et al. [89] used a recently reported Mo1.33C MXene to prepare hybrids with commercially available PEDOT- or PSS-based solution. The Mo1.33C–PEDOT/PSS hybrid film was used to prepare flexible solid-state supercapacitor device which showed a maximum capacitance of 568 Fcm−3, an energy density of 33.2 mWhcm−3, and a power density of 19,470 mWcm−3. The Mo1.33C–PEDOT/PSS hybrid film electrodes exhibited high volumetric capacitance of 1310 Fcm−3 and remarkable rate performance and high cycle life. The enhanced electrochemical performance of the Mo1.33C–PEDOT/PSS hybrid film was attributed to the increased interlayer spacing (easier ion and electron mobility), high redox capacitance of CP, and electrode architecture. This strategy clearly provides an avenue to explore watersoluble CPs to manufacture CP–MXene hybrids for energy conversion and storage applications.
Xiao et al. [59] produced PANI@TiO2–Ti3C2Tx ternary hybrid using hydrothermal method via in situ polymerization process. The hierarchical hybrid showed high capacitance of 188.3 Fg−1 (10 mVs−1), which is twice higher than that of TiO2–Ti3C2Tx and 435.4 Fcm−2 at 0.5 A g−1 in KOH solution. Also, the hybrid showed good capacitance retention of 94% after 8000 charge/discharge cycles at 1 Ag−1. The improved performance was due to the hierarchical architecture and the synergistic impact of combining PANI nanoflakes within TiO2–Ti3C2Tx hybrid. Zhongxing et al. [58] prepared mono- and co-doped Ti3C2Tx–PEDOT hybrids by oxidative chemical polymerization. The fabricated hybrids showed lamellar microstructure, which facilitated the transport of ions and electrons to boost the capacitance. When Ti3C2Tx–PEDOT hybrid co-doped with 1,5-naphthalene disulfonic acid/H3PMo12O40 was compared with the one co-doped with 1,5-naphthalene disulfonic acid/anthraquinone-2-sulfonate (AQS), it became clear that the latter can provide higher capacitance due faradic contributions from the AQS.
Catalysis Li et al. [90] used Ti3C2Tx as a conductive support to deposit 2D metalorganic framework (MOF), namely, cobalt 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (CoBDC), via
244 M. Boota
an interdiffusion reaction-assisted process [90]. The idea was to utilize Ti3C2Tx MXene as a conductive support to improve the electron mobility to improve the catalytic activities of the hybrid. The resulting Ti3C2Tx–(CoBDC) hybrid was used in oxygen evolution reaction. It turned out that hybrid achieved a current density of 10 mAcm−2 (1.64 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode) and a Tafel slope of 48.2 mVdec−1 in 0.1 M KOH, outperforming state-of-the-art transition metal-based catalysts. This hybrid provided synergistic impact to boost the catalytic properties where CoBDC gave high surface area and hydrophilic Ti3C2Tx nanosheets provided rapid charge percolation across Ti3C2Tx − CoBDC interface, which overall eased the transport of aqueous electrolyte to majority of catalytically active sites. Asproduced hybrid electrodes were further used as an air electrode for a rechargeable zinc–air battery. The hybrid electrodes were able to power a light-emitting diode, confirming large potential of MXene-based hybrids in catalysis and air batteries. This study provided a starting point to the researches to hybridize a large family of MOFs with 2D MXenes.
Biomedical Applications Gongyuan et al. [91] produced modified Ti3C2Tx and tested them for tumor targeting photothermal/photodynamic/chemo-synergistic therapy. By taking advantage of negatively charged surface of Ti3C2Tx MXene, they hybridized doxorubicin (DOX) as the chemotherapy agent and hyaluronic acid as the active tumor targeting agent with Ti3C2Tx nanosheets through layer-by-layer adsorption. The resulting hybrid exhibited improved biocompatibility, stimuliresponsive drug release, tumor-specific accumulation, and excellent tumor ablation efficacy at a low dose (Ti3C2Tx at 2 mg kg−1 with DOX loaded at 1.6 mg kg−1) under a low power density of NIR laser (808 nm, 0.8 Wcm−2). This study pointed out the potential of the MXene for the biomedical applications and cancer therapy. Han et al. [92] combined Ti3C2Tx MXene with the soybean phospholipid (SP) and poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA) to study the impact of organic–inorganic hybrid as photothermal agent for cancer therapy. In another study, Han et al. [93] used Nb2C nanosheets to combine them with polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) to produce Nb2C − PVP for photothermal tumor eradication. After hybridization with PVP, the Nb2C − PVP suspension showed outstanding biocompatibility and physiological stability without obvious toxicity in vitro/in vivo.
Sensors Jing et al. [94] developed a unique strategy to graft vanadium carbide (V2C) MXene with poly(2-(dimethylamino)ethyl methacrylate) (PDMAEMA) brushes via self-initiated photografting and photopolymerization (SIPGP) method. Since PDMAEMA offers CO2 and temperature dual-responsive properties, this hybrid was used as a smart system for tuning the dispersion state, transmittance, and conductivity of V2C suspension. This report for the first time showed that V2C–PDMAEMA hybrid can experience hydrophobic–hydrophilic transitions in aqueous media. This demonstration opened the direction to manufacture smartresponsive MXene–polymer hybrids using other types of MXenes. Hyosung et al. [65] produced strain sensors to topographically sense objects or materials deformation using a patterned MXene multilayer-coated PET film (Fig. 13.8a) which deformed and bent when small objects passed through the scanner. As a
13 MXene–Organic Hybrid Materials 245
result, change in normalized resistance R/R0 occurred (Fig. 13.8a, b). The asmanufactured scanner even detected complex shapes such as T, A, M, and U letters (Fig. 13.8d, e). Next, MXene-coated PDMS was used to fabricate a soft human motion sensor which detected the angle of a bent index finger with little hysteresis (Fig. 13.8f, g). A large gauge factor (GF) of 11.5 (GF, the sensitivity to bending) was noticed when the bending angle was increased to 35◦; in comparison, most metalfoil gauges have a gauge factor of 2.0 (5% maximum strain) [65]. Nevertheless, MXene offers significant potential for organic hybrids in organic electronics and sensors.
246 M. Boota

sections.heading: Summary and Outlook
sections.text:
We have summarized the majority of the exciting work in which MXenes were combined with the organic molecules and polymers to manufacture MXene–organic hybrids. Unlike the majority of the 2D solids, MXenes offered unique properties of hydrophilicity, metallic conductivity, and structural diversity, enabling their use for numerous applications. We have also provided a fundamental understanding of interactions between MXenes and organics, including charge transfer-induced polymerizations, electrostatic self-assembly, and covalent interactions. Furthermore, we used computational results to identify host–guest interaction, charge transfer mechanisms, and propagation of monomers to polymers. We also explained the role of polarity in organic molecules/polymers which will guide the design of new organic–inorganic hybrid materials with well-defined properties for a variety of applications. Later, we have provided a detailed discussion on recent applications of MXene–organic hybrids for a broad range of applications and charted them in Table 13.1. We believe that the field of MXene–organic hybrids will progress swiftly in the coming years. While progress in this field is exciting, there are several challenges which need to be explored in detail:
1. MXenes offer reactive surface chemistry. It is necessary to find ways to control the surface chemistry of MXenes. Approaches to produce MXenes with uniform functional groups are critically needed. This will allow to rationally tune the MXene–organic interfaces/interactions. 2. Novel in-situ characterization techniques/methods are needed to understand the electron and ion transport mechanisms in a single molecule/MXene interfaces. 3. More diverse synthesis methods need to be explored for the synthesis of MXene– organic hybrids. It is necessary to develop strategies in which molecular selfassembly could be controlled at nanoscale. 4. Most of the reported studies have focused on the Ti3C2Tx MXene to combine them with organic molecules. Considering the diversity of MXene family, the combination of other MXene members with organics needs to be explored. 5. There is a large opportunity to further explore MXene–organic devices at molecular level. 6. More computational efforts are needed to guide the synthesis of MXene–organic hybrids in the future.

Mohammad Khazaei, Ahmad Ranjbar, Yunye Liang, and Seiji Yunoki
Introduction
sections.text:
MAX phases are a large family of solid layered transition metal carbides or nitrides with a hexagonal lattice (space group P 63/mmc) and the chemical formula Mn+1AXn, where “M” stands for an early transition metal (Sc, Ti, Zr, Hf, V, Nb, Ta, Cr, or Mo), “A” represents an element from the groups III–VI of the periodic table (Al, Ga, In, Tl, Si, Ge, Sn, Pb, P, As, Bi, S, or Te), “X” is carbon or nitrogen, and n = 1–4 [1–5]. Recently, the family of crystalline MAX phases has been expanded even further. For example, a set of ordered double transition metal MAX phases of M2M′AX2, M2M′2AX3 [6, 7], and (M2/3M′1/3)2AX2 has been synthesized [8, 9],

To the best of our knowledge, 82 different crystalline MAX phases have been experimentally fabricated [1, 3]. In addition to the crystalline MAX phases, various alloys of MAX phases with different mixtures of transition metals and/or X elements have also been synthesized. Theoretically, thousands of crystalline or alloy structures of MAX phases have been predicted to be stable [10–20].
Up to a few years ago, the applications of MAX phases were based solely on their interesting mechanical properties, rather than their electronic, magnetic, or optical properties. However, the possibility of exfoliation from MAX phases into two-dimensional (2D) transition metal carbides or nitrides, the so-called MXenes, has significantly broadened the range of potential applications of MAX phases [21, 22]. It has been repeatedly proved experimentally that by using the combination of acid treatment and sonication, the M−A bonds in some of the MAX phases can be broken, whereas the M−X bonds remain almost intact. After the exfoliation process, the A atoms are washed out from the MAX phase, and the remaining set of single or multilayers is MXene. The crystal structures of derived 2D MXenes, M2X, M3X2, M4X3, M5X4 M2M′X2, and M2M′2X3, are
14 Electronic Properties and Applications of MXenes from Ab Initio. . . 257
shown schematically in Fig. 14.2. So far, the single or multilayer 2D structures of Ti2C [22], Ti2N [23], V2C [24], Nb2C [24], Mo2C [25], Ti3C2 [21], Zr3C2 [26], Nb4C3, [27] Ta4C3 [22], and Ti4N3 [28] as well as TiNbC [22], (Ti0.5Nb0.5)2C [22], (V0.5Cr0.5)3C2 [22], Ti3CN [22], Mo2TiC2 [29], Mo2ScC2 [7], Cr2TiC2 [29], Mo2Ti2C3, [29] (Nb0.8Ti0.2)4C3 [30], and (Nb0.8Zr0.2)4C3 [30] have already been synthesized. The electronic properties of these 2D MXenes are different from those of their corresponding MAX phases. It is also shown theoretically that upon a particular surface functionalization, some of the MXenes turn into semiconductors [31]. In contrast to the limited applications of MAX phases as structural materials, many interesting electronic [31–37], optical [38], mechanical [39], magnetic [31, 40–44], thermoelectric [31, 32], photocatalytic [45], and many other applications [46, 47] have been theoretically proposed for 2D MXenes. Experimentally, MXenes have attracted a lot of attention in the materials science community for electronic transport [48–50], energy storage [51, 52], energy conversion [53–56], and development of novel hybrid nanocomposites [57, 58]. There are comprehensive reviews on the synthesis and application [59] and the current theoretical status [60] of MXenes in the literature.
It is now well accepted that the MAX phases are a great source for producing novel 2D systems. Considering the compositional varieties of the MAX phases, a large number of 2D MXenes with novel properties are expected to become available. Therefore, the important questions to be answered at this moment are the followoing: which of the MAX phases are promising candidates for successful exfoliation into 2D materials and what will be the electronic properties and applications of the derived MXenes? In the following, we address the above two main questions.

sections.heading: Computational Methods
sections.text:
Before discussing the properties and/or applications of MAX phases and MXenes, it is worth summarizing briefly the computational methods employed in the most
258 M. Khazaei et al.
recent theoretical studies. Among the different methods, density functional theory (DFT) has proved to be a reliable method of predicting various physical and chemical phenomena in atomic scale. Hence, DFT calculations are performed to examine many properties and applications of MAX phases and MXenes. However, it is known that the simple DFT method may fail to predict the values of band gap and van der Waals interaction and the properties of strongly correlated materials. For instance, the Perdew−Burke−Ernzerhof (PBE) version of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) for the exchange-correlation functional [61], which is most often used in this book chapter, underestimates the band gap. Because of the approximate nature of the DFT-based methods [62], this book chapter mainly focuses on the general trends expected in the physics and chemistry of MAX phases and MXenes, rather than emphasizing quantitatively the exact values of various properties. In the following, the DFT-PBE method is employed for the theoretical studies, unless otherwise stated.
Insight into Possibility of Exfoliation of MAX Phases into 2D MXenes
Here, we would like to address the question that which MAX phases are promising candidates for successful exfoliation into 2D MXenes. Theoretically, on the basis of analysis of tensile and shear stresses, the mechanical exfoliation of various M2AlC (M = Ti, Zr, Hf, V, Nb, Ta, Cr, Mo, and W) MAX phases into 2D M2C MXenes has been investigated [63]. There, it was found that by applying a large tensile strain, all the interlayer M−Al bonds can be broken, leading to separation between the M2C and Al layers [63]. However, the chemical exfoliation process is a very complicated dynamical process, which is very difficult to model and simulate with all the details. Nevertheless, we can still gain valuable insights by studying the bond strength and the exfoliation energy because MAX phases with weaker M−A bonds are expected to show promise for a successful exfoliation process. Moreover, we examine the effect of charge injection on the bond strength of the MAX phases for facilitating the exfoliation process.

sections.heading: Bond Strength
sections.text:
Currently, static calculations are considered as the only straightforward way to provide useful information on the possibility of exfoliation. In this regard, force constants, integrated crystal orbital Hamilton population (ICOHP), bond order, and exfoliation energies are important quantities that can provide quantitative measures of the bond strength and the ease of exfoliation [64]. In order to keep this book
14 Electronic Properties and Applications of MXenes from Ab Initio. . . 259
chapter short, the results of integrated crystal orbital Hamilton population (ICOHP) and bond order are not discussed here. They can be found in Ref. [64].
In order to evaluate the force constants of the bonds in the MAX phases, we perform a set of phonon calculations on the 82 experimentally observed crystalline MAX phases. The force constants are estimated from the phonon calculations [65]. A force constant can be calculated from the second derivative of the total energy with respect to the finite displacements of atoms i and j along the x, y, and z directions and is a 3×3 matrix, given as one of the output results of the phonon calculations. Because the trace of the force constant matrix is independent of the coordinate system, i.e., invariant under a coordinate rotation [66, 67], we consider the trace of the force constant matrix and refer to this scalar quantity as the force constant Fij between atoms i and j in the main text [67].
Here, M1 and M2 represent transition metals belonging to the first and second layers of transition metals close to the A element, and the X layer is sandwiched between the M1 and M2 layers (see Fig. 14.1). In the M2AX, M3AX2, M4AX3, and M5AX4 MAX phases, the transition metals of M1 and M2 are of the same type, whereas in the M2M′AX2 and M2M′2AX3 MAX phases, M1 and M2 are of different types. The results of the force constants for these bonds are summarized in Fig. 14.3. A general trend can be discerned: shorter bonds are stiffer. It is also observed that the force constants of the M1−X bonds are significantly larger than those of the other bonds. This indicates that the M1−X bonds are the strongest in the MAX phases, which is the main reason for the stability of these MAX phases and the resulting MXenes. Becasue the force constants of the M1−A bonds are smaller than
260 M. Khazaei et al.
those of the M1−X bonds, the M1−A bonds are weaker than the M1−X bonds. The X−X and A−A bonds are the weakest among all the bonds, as can be observed in Fig. 14.3 [64].
In order to examine which of the MAX phases are well suited for successful exfoliation into 2D MXenes, the total force constant FCA (the summation of all the force constants connected to the A element) is a very useful quantity. As a simple criterion, we can expect that MAX phases with a smaller FCA can be considered as promising candidates for the exfoliation process. In this respect, Ti2AlC, V2AlC, Ti3AlC2, Zr3AlC2, Ti4AlN3, Nb4AlC3, Mo2TiAlC2, Cr2TiAlC2, Mo2ScAlC2, and Mo2Ti2AlC3 are the MAX phases that have already been exfoliated into Ti2C, V2C, Ti3C2, Zr3C2, Ti4N3, Nb4C3, Mo2TiC2, Cr2TiC2, Mo2ScC2, and Mo2Ti2C3, respectively. All these compounds contain Al in the MAX phases. Our analysis indicates that the minimum (maximum) FCA is for Zr3AlC2 (V2AlC). Therefore, we expect that by using appropriate acids in the experiments, it might be possible to break bonds as strong as the V−Al bond. On the basis of this criterion, we can screen our data for compounds with an FCA less than 21.855 eV/Å2 [64].
The exfoliation process can be said to be successful experimentally only if the obtained 2D MXenes are structurally perfect. This requires the M1−M2 and M1−X bonds to be stronger than the M1−A and A−A bonds. Otherwise, during the exfoliation process, other bonds may also be broken in addition to the M1−A bonds. In such a case, either the MXenes would not be formed at all or they would be formed with many M and X defects. Because the M1−X bonds are strongest in the MAX phases, we calculate the total force constant FCX (the summation of all force constants connected to the X element) for the MAX phases experimentally exfoliated into MXenes. We find that the maximum (minimum) FCX is obtained for V2AlC (Zr3AlC2). Therefore, in order to successfully synthesize MXenes, FCX should at least be as large as that for Zr3AlC2 (40.511 eV/Å2). On the basis of this criterion, we rescreen the results of FCX in all the MAX phases [64].
As described above, chemical exfoliation is a complicated dynamical process involving subtle details. Hence, it is extremely difficult to simulate such processes computationally. However, calculation of the static exfoliation energy would help us screen MAX phases for successful exfoliation into 2D MXenes. Here, we evaluate the exfoliation energy EExfoliation for the 82 different MAX phases. The static exfoliation energy EExfoliation of a bulk MAX phase into 2D MXenes is calculated through EExfoliation = −[Etot(MAX phase) − 2 Etot(MXene) − 2 Etot(A)]/(4S), where Etot(MAX phase), Etot(MXene), and Etot(A) denote the total energies of the bulk MAX phase, 2D MXene, and A element, respectively [64]. Here, S = √3a2/2 is the surface area, and a is the lattice parameter of the MAX phase. Exfoliating a MAX phase, each unit cell of the MAX phase generates two MXene layers with four surfaces in all. This explains why the exfoliation energy is divided by 4 in the above formula.
From our exfoliation energy analysis, it is seen that among the MAX phases experimentally exfoliated into MXenes, Zr3AlC2 (V2AlC2) shows the lowest (largest) EExfoliation (eV/area), 0.131 (0.205) eV/Å2. Therefore, we expect that the MAX phases with an exfoliation energy lower than 0.205 eV/Å2 have a better
14 Electronic Properties and Applications of MXenes from Ab Initio. . . 261
chance of being exfoliated into MXenes. Figure 14.4 shows a plot of the total force constant FCA for the A atoms versus the exfoliation energy. It is clear that the total force constant FCA is strongly correlated with the exfoliation energy: the MAX phases with smaller FCA have a lower exfoliation energy [64].
Combining all the above bond analyses, we can finally conclude that the best candidates among MAX phases for successful exfoliation into 2D MXenes are those MAX phases with small total force constants of the A atoms, large total force constants of the M and X atoms, and a low exfoliation energy. We predict that in addition to the 10 MAX phases that have already been exfoliated experimentally, the following 37 MAX phases are promising candidates for the successful exfoliation. Because the exfoliation energy is more directly related to the chemical exfoliation process than to the other two criteria, we prioritize this criterion to sort these 37 promising candidates from the smallest to the largest exfoliation energies [64]. Therefore, in the following list, we predict that the first (last) MAX phase is the most (least) promising candidate for successful exfoliation: (1) Ti2CdC, (2) Zr2AlC, (3) Ti3AuC2, (4) Ti5AlC4, (5) Zr2InC, (6) Hf2AlC, (7) Ti2GaC, (8) Ti4GaC3, (9) Hf2InC, (10) Nb5AlC4, (11) Hf2TlC, (12) Ti2InC, (13) Ti2TlC, (14) Nb2GaC, (15) Hf2PbC, (16) Ta5AlC4, (17) Ti3SiC2, (18) Ti4SiC3, (19) Ti3GeC2, (20) Nb2InC, (21) Ti2GeC, (22) Ti4GeC3, (23) Hf2SnC, (24) Mo2GaC, (25) Ti2SiC, (26) Ta2GaC, (27) Cr2GaN, (28) Ti3IrC2, (29) V2GaC, (30) Ti2InN, (31) Ta2AlC2, (32) Ti2PbC, (33) Ta2AlC, (34) Cr2GaC, (35) V4AlC3, (36) V3AlC2, and (37) Ti2SnC [64].

sections.heading: Charge Effect on Bond Strength
sections.text:
In order to investigate the effects of electron (hole) injection to the MAX phases, here we add (remove) 2, 3, 4, and 5 electrons per unit cell to (from) M2AX, M3AX2, M4AX3, and M5AX4, respectively, by changing the total number of
262 M. Khazaei et al.
valence electrons. The number of injected charges is chosen such that the number of injected charges per atom in all the studied MAX phases is the same. We employ Bader charge analysis [68–70] to estimate the number of electrons on each atom in the neutral and charged MAX phases.
We have investigated the relative number of electrons or holes received by the M, A, and X atoms in the charged MAX phases with respect to the neutral phases. Interestingly, in both positively and negatively charged MAX phases, most of the charges are received by the transition metals [64]. That suggests that the states close to the Fermi energy must be transition-metal-centered. In order to explore this observation, we calculate the electronic structure of the charged and neutral MAX phases. Typical results for the projected density of states (PDOS) for charged and neutral Zr2TlC and Hf2SC are shown in Fig. 14.5. It is found that in all the neutral MAX phases, the states near the Fermi energy are dominated by d orbitals of the transition metals, as anticipated already [64]. Hence, the electrons or holes injected into the MAX phases are mainly received by the transition metals. Among Zr2TlC and Hf2SC, Hf atoms in Hf2SC receive a larger number of electrons or holes as compared with Zr atoms in Zr2TlC. This is because in Hf2SC the states below and above the Fermi energy are almost wholly contributed by the d orbitals of Hf, whereas in the case of Zr2TlC, in addition to the d orbitals of Zr, there is a contribution from the d orbitals of Tl near the Fermi energy [64].
In addition, we have also investigated the effect of charge injection on the bonds. It is found that in the positively (negatively) charged MAX phases, the bond lengths of both M1−A and M1−X bonds decrease (increase). Injecting electrons (holes) increases (decreases) the number of electrons on the M, A, or X atoms, which results in a longer (shorter) bond length [64]. Interestingly, the impact of the charge injection on the M1−A bonds is generally more significant than that on the M1−X bonds. When the transition metals receive a sufficient amount of electrons, the M1−A bonds expand and may break completely. Indeed, we find that in negatively charged Cr2GeC, V2GeC, Ti3SnC2, V4AlC3, and Cr2TiAlC2, the M1−A bond length increase is so large that the A atoms are completely detached from the transition metals [64].
14 Electronic Properties and Applications of MXenes from Ab Initio. . . 263
In order to understand clearly the effect of charge injection on the structural properties, thicker MAX phases such as Ti5AlC4 and Nb5AlC4 are preferable to thinner phases. This is because the thinner MAX phases become unstable with only a few injected electrons [64]. Although Ti5AlC4 and Nb5AlC4 have not been synthesized as phase-pure ternary compounds yet, their solid solutions (Ti0.5Nb0.5)5AlC4 already exist experimentally [71]. Figure 14.6 summarizes the results for the bond lengths and the corresponding force constants and the lattice constants, when 1–5 electrons or holes per unit cell are injected into Ti5AlC4. As shown in Fig. 14.6a, upon the electron (hole) injection, all bond lengths tend to increase (decrease), and the change in bond length is larger when the amount of injected charge is larger. It is also clearly observed that the Ti1−Al bond is most sensitive to the charge injection. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 14.6b, the force constants increase (decrease) with the hole (electron) injection. This occurs because the positive charge injected on either of the atoms in the bond would increase the electronegativity and decrease the bond length, thus increasing the ionic contribution to the force constant [64]. Note also in Fig. 14.6b that after injecting a certain amount of electrons, the force constant of the Ti1−Al bond becomes very small. This implies that if a larger amount of electrons is injected, the A atom (i.e., Al) becomes detached from the transition metal Ti.
We also investigate in Fig. 14.6c the effect of charge injection on the a and c lattice parameters of Ti5AlC4. As expected, the strongest effect occurs in the c lattice constant because the Ti1−Al bonds are oriented almost parallel to the c axis. In particular, the electron injection induces a large swelling along the c axis in Ti5AlC4 and also in other MAX phases in general. This implies that the exfoliation process becomes easier for the negatively charged MAX phases than for the neutral case because the M1−A bonds become longer and weaker upon receiving electrons [64]. The exfoliation of charged MAX phases might be achieved experimentally through charge-controlled electrochemical swelling techniques [72–82]. Volume swelling can also be produced using irradiation methods by controlling the density of intrinsic point defects [83].

sections.heading: 2D MXenes
sections.text:
As was explained before, 2D MXenes are experimentally obtained when the A element is washed out from the MAX phases upon applying an appropriate acid solution such as HF [21, 22]. In the previous section, we have shown that this might be possible because in some MAX phases, the bonding between elements A and M is weaker than that between elements M and X. Experimentally it has been suggested that the outer layers are often saturated with F, O, and/or OH groups when HF acid solutions are used to eliminate the A element [84–88]. The process of exfoliating Ti3AlC2 into Ti3C2 has been theoretically studied in the presence of water and HF acid using ab initio molecular dynamics simulations [89, 90]. There, it is shown that the spontaneous dissociation of HF and subsequent termination with H
264 M. Khazaei et al.
or F at the edge of the Ti atoms weakens the Al−M bonding, consequently opening the interlayer gap. The further insertion of HF is facilitated through the interlayer gap. This leads to the formation of AlF3 and H2, which eventually emerge from of the MAX phase. After these processes, the fluorinated MXene is left behind [89, 90].

sections.heading: Structural and Mechanical Properties
sections.text:
The model structures for 2D MXene systems can be constructed by removing the A element from the bulk MAX phases. Because the MAX phases have hexagonal lattices, their derived 2D MXene systems are also found in hexagonal lattices. As schematically shown in Fig. 14.2a, in 2D MXene the X layers are sandwiched

between two M transition metal layers. Becasue the coordination number of a transition metal ion is often six, it is natural to assume that the transition metals in MXenes form six chemical bonds with the neighboring X atoms and the attached chemical groups on the surfaces, resulting in the formation of M2XF2, M2X(OH)2, and M2XO2 [31]. In more detail, on the surfaces of M2X, two types of hollow sites exist: hollow sites (A) under which there is no X atom between the transition metal layers and hollow sites (B) under which there is an X atom, as indicated in Fig. 14.7a. Therefore, depending on the relative positions of the termination groups attached to the transition metal atoms, at least four different configurations are possible for the chemical termination of the MXenes. Model 1: two functional groups are located on top of the two transition metals. Model 2: two functional groups are located on top of hollow sites A. Model 3: one of the functional groups is located on top of a hollow site A, and the other functional group is located on top of a hollow site B. Model 4: the two functional groups are located on top of hollow sites B. The model structures of 2 and 4 are shown in Fig. 14.7b, c, respectively.
The electronic structure of MXenes is significantly affected by the chosen model structure. Therefore, the above four model structures should be considered for each type of functional group with fully relaxed atomic positions to determine the most stable structure. As a general trend in functionalized MXenes, model 1 is energetically less stable than the other three models, and in many cases it is transformed to one of the models 2–4 during structural optimization. It is also found that the relative structural stabilities of models 2–4 depend mainly on the possible ionic state(s) of the transition metals on the surfaces [31]. If the transition metals can provide sufficient electrons to both X and the attached functional groups, model 2 becomes the most stable configuration [31]. Otherwise, either model 3 or model 4 becomes a more stable configuration [31]. In other words, the chemical groups choose their locations on the surface such that the bonding states of M−X

In order to consider the stability of the functionalized MXene sheets in the experiments, we have calculated their formation energies. The formation energies of the functionalized MXenes are defined as Hf = Etot(M2XTn)-Etot(M2X)(n/2)Etot(T2)-n μ where M2X represents the pristine MXenes without functionalization and T= F, OH, or O groups. n is the number of chemical groups in the supercell. Etot(M2X) and Etot(M2XTn) stand for the total energies of the pristine and functionalized MXenes, respectively. Depending on the functionalization type, Etot(T2) is the total energy of F2, O2+H2, or O2. μ = μ-(1/2)Etot(T2), where μ is the chemical potential of the attached chemical group, which can vary as a function of pressure and temperature [92].
The results of the formation energy calculations at μ = 0.0 eV are presented in Table 14.1. From Table 14.1, it can be seen that all the formation energies are large negative values. This indicates the formation of strong bonds between the transition metals and the attached groups, which results in the development of MXene systems with a particular surface functionalization. As seen in Table 14.1, the values of the formation energies for an MXene system functionalized with F, OH, or O are different. To explain the relative stability (formation energy) of an MXene functionalized with F, OH, or O, it is necessary to know the details of effect of the octahedral crystal field created by carbon and the chemical groups on the d orbitals of the transition metal. For example, in a recent study on Ti3C2T2 (T = O, F, OH, and H), it has been shown that due to the generated crystal field, the 3d orbitals of surface Ti atoms split in such a way that they exhibit pseudogaps whose widths predict a stability order Ti3C2O2 > Ti3C2F2 > Ti3C2(OH)2 > Ti3C2H2 > Ti3C2 [93].
In the above formation energy calculations, we assumed that the surfaces of MXenes are fully functionalized/terminated by the attached groups, but there is a
question regarding whether the formations of such systems are thermodynamically favorable with respect to the lower functionalization. In order to investigate the thermodynamic feasibility of formation of such systems, we have examined the formation energies of Ti2C systems at different oxygen concentrations and chemical potentials. We have selected Ti2C becasue its monolayer has been experimentally produced and it is a representative of MXene systems with interesting electronic and thermoelectric properties, as will be shown later. In this regard, we have constructed a 2×2 model of Ti2C, containing eight Ti and four carbon atoms, and functionalized both its side surfaces with 1 (lowest concentration) to 8 (highest concentration) oxygen atoms in a super cell. For each oxygen concentration, there are many different possibilities. We have considered more than 100 different structures of Ti8C4(O2) n2 systems, n = 1–8. The formation energies of each oxygen concentration are plotted in Fig. 14.8 as a function of the chemical potential in the range −6.0 to 0.0 eV. As shown in Fig. 14.8, in a very wide range of the chemical potentials between −4.0 and 0.0 eV, the structure with full oxygen coverage (with eight oxygen atoms) is thermodynamically the most favorable configuration in comparison to other configurations with lower oxygen concentrations. Because the chemical potential is estimated to vary from 0 to −0.8 in the temperature range 230–750 K [92], the full termination is the most stable configuration under such this condition [31]. The above thermodynamic analysis has been examined in other systems too [94]. In all cases, it has been shown that MXenes with full surface functionalizion are thermodynamically more favorable than those with less surface functionalizion [31, 94].
Moreover, we have also calculated the phonon spectra of the fully terminated Ti2C with oxygen atoms. It is observed that all phonon frequencies are positive, signifying that this system is in its equilibrium state. In recent studies, phonon frequency analyses have been performed on almost all members of MXene family with full surface functionalization [31, 34, 36, 95, 96]. It is observed many of them obtain completely positive phonon frequencies. Therefore, various fully
268 M. Khazaei et al.
functionalized MXenes can be realized experimentally under appropriate conditions although there are still some challenges.

sections.heading: Electronic Properties
sections.text: Similar to the MAX phases, the pristine MXenes are all metallic. However, upon surface functionalization, some of them become semiconducting. As will be discussed below, theoretical investigations have shown that the MXenes can be divided into two categories, topologically trivial [31] and nontrivial [33, 34, 97– 99] metal/semimetal or semiconductor, depending on the strength of the relativistic spin-orbit coupling (SOC) in these systems.

sections.heading: Topologically Trivial Metals and Semiconductors
sections.text:
Although most of the functionalized MXenes are metallic, Sc2CT2 (T= F, OH, and O), Ti2CO2, Zr2CO2, and Hf2CO2 become semiconducting with the surface functionalization. The energy gaps are estimated to be 1.03, 0.45, and 1.8 eV for Sc2CT2 with T= F, OH, and O, respectively; 0.24 eV for Ti2CO2; 0.88 eV for Zr2CO2; and 1.0 eV for Hf2CO2 within the GGA [31]. The band structure calculations reveal that Sc2C(OH)2 has a direct band gap and the other semiconductors have indirect band gaps. Becasue Ti, Zr, and Hf are in the same group in the periodic table with the same number of electrons in the outermost partially filled atomic orbital shell ([Ar]3d24s2, [Kr]4d25s2, and [Xe]4f145d26s2), the corresponding MXene systems exhibit similar metallic to semiconducting behavior upon the same type of functionalization. It is also predicted that both F and OH groups similarly affect the electronic structure of a pristine MXene system [31]. This is because each F or OH group is capable of receiving only one electron from the surfaces. By the same token, the O group differs from the F and OH groups because it requires two electrons from the surfaces to be stabilized [31].
In order to understand why some of the MXenes become semiconducting, the electronic structures of MXenes with and without the surface functionalizations have been systematically studied [31]. The calculations show that pristine M2X (X = C or N) systems are all metallic with the Fermi energy located at the d bands of transition metals. In most MXenes, the p bands of carbon/nitrogen X appear below the d bands separated by a small band gap. With the F, OH, or O functionalization, new bands are generated below the Fermi energy, resulting from F or O p orbitals hybridized with M d orbitals. Sc2CT2 (T = F, OH, or O), Ti2CO2, Zr2CO2, and Hf2CO2 become semiconducting because the functionalization shifts the Fermi energy to the center of the gap between the M d bands and the X p bands. As examples, Fig. 14.9 shows the PDOS and projected band structures for Ti2C, Ti2CF2, and Ti2CO2. It has also been shown that the band gap of Ti2CO2
14 Electronic Properties and Applications of MXenes from Ab Initio. . . 269
and Sc2CO2 can be significantly varied by applying either a strain [100, 101] or an external electric field [102, 103].
Recently experimenters have realized a set of MAX phases with in-plane ordered double transition metals with a chemical formula of (M2/3M′1/3)2AlC (M = Mo or V; M′ = Sc, Y, or Zr) [9, 104]. Our calculations indicated that oxygen-terminated (Mo2/3Y1/3)2C and (Mo2/3Sc1/3)2C MXenes are semiconducting with indirect band gaps of 0.45 and 0.04 eV, respectively [105]. The origin of these band gaps may be attributed to the splitting of Mo d orbital-dominated bands. In functionalized MXenes, the transition metals are surrounded by carbon atoms and the attached chemical groups (F, OH, or O). Such a local environment splits the d bands into subbands [93]. More precisely, the states near the Fermi energy can be assigned as t2g bands hybridized with C, F, or O p orbitals via the dpπ coupling. In the case of (Mo2/3Y1/3)2CO2 and (Mo2/3Sc1/3)2CO2, the t2g bands further split due to the low symmetry structure, resulting in finite band gaps.

sections.heading: Topologically Nontrivial Semimetals and Semiconductors
sections.text:
Because many MXenes contain heavy 4d and 5d transition metals, the relativistic SOC affects the electronic structures significantly. As shown in Fig. 14.10, without considering the SOC, M2CO2 (M = Mo, W), M2M′C2O2 (M = Mo, W; M′ = Ti, Zr, W), and Ti3N2F2 are semiconducting with a zero energy gap (semimetallic) because the topmost valence band and the lowest conduction band touch only at the point, around which the valence and conduction bands are both parabolic. The projected band structure calculations reveal that the bands near the Femi energy originate from the d orbitals of the transition metals M and M′. Upon considering the SOC, the degeneracy of the topmost valence band and the lowest conduction band at the Fermi energy is lifted, and the band gap is open at the point (see lower panels in Fig. 14.10). Consequently, M2CO2, M2M′C2O2, and Ti3N2F2 turn
270 M. Khazaei et al.
into semiconductors with indirect band gaps [33, 34, 37]. The induced band gap is larger as the SOC is larger [34]. It is found that the band gaps can be as large as 0.194 eV (0.472 eV) for W2CO2 and 0.285 (0.401 eV) for W2HfC2O2 within the GGA (hybrid functional HSE06) [33, 34, 37]. The band gap of Ti3N2F2 is approximately 0.02 eV [37].
The SOC lifts the degeneracy of the bands at the point by inducing a finite gap. The nature of these bands around the Fermi energy can be characterized by the Z2 topological invariant. Because M2CO2, M2M′C2O2, and Ti3N2F2 MXenes have inversion symmetry, the Z2 topological invariant can be simply calculated from the parity of the valence band wave functions at the time reversal invariant momentum
14 Electronic Properties and Applications of MXenes from Ab Initio. . . 271
(TRIM) points of the Brillouin zone [106, 107]. For the hexagonal structure, the TRIM points are located at , k1 = (0, 0); M1, k2 = (0, 0.5); M2, k3 = (0.5, 0); and M3, k4 = (0.5, 0.5); and therefore the Z2 index ν (= 0, 1) is evaluated by (−1)ν = 4i=1δ(ki ), where δ(ki ) = Nn=1ηn(ki), ηn(ki) (= ±1) is the parity of the nth valence band at TRIM ki and N is the number of occupied valence bands [106, 107]. The trivial and nontrivial topological phases are identified with ν = 0 and 1, respectively. The parity analysis of the occupied bands at the TRIM points reveals that ν = 1 for all the systems discussed here, M2CO2 (M = Mo, W), M2M′C2O2 (M = Mo, W; M′ = Ti, Zr, Hf), and Ti3NF2 [33, 34, 37].
One of the remarkable characteristics of the topological insulators is the presence of an odd number of topologically protected conducting edge states that cross the Fermi energy. The 2D topological insulators display intriguing conducting edge states in which electrons with opposite spins propagate in the opposite directions and thus they are robust against nonmagnetic impurities and disorders [108–111]. In order to further confirm the nontrivial band topology, we also calculate the electronic band structures for the zigzag nanoribbon structures of W2CO2, W2HfC2O2, and Ti3N2F2 with symmetric edges of 80 Å width. Figure 14.11 shows the results of the electronic band structures, which clearly demonstrate that the edge bands cross the Fermi energy odd times along the ̄-X̄ points for both systems.
The origin of the topological insulating behavior found in the M2CO2, M2M′C2O2, and Ti3NF2 MXenes is almost the same. As shown in Fig. 14.10, the SOC is essential to open a finite band gap but does not induce the band inversion that is necessary to change the band topology, implying that the band inversion has already occurred in the M2CO2, M2M′C2O2, and Ti3NF2 MXenes before introducing the SOC. This is thus different from most topological insulators for which the SOC is required to induce the band inversion [112–116], although some exceptions have been reported [111, 117–119].
272 M. Khazaei et al.
To understand the band structures in greater details, as an example, we investigate the evolution of the band structures for W2HfC2O2 without the SOC as the lattice constant is uniformly expanded from the optimized constant. Note that the structure is not optimized when the lattice constant is expanded because this makes it much easier to analyze the evolution of the band structures. As shown in Fig. 14.12, the band structures around the Fermi energy are qualitatively the same until the lattice constant is expanded slightly below 20% (1.2a0), where the topmost valence band and the lowest conduction band remain in contact (i.e., degenerate) at the point, and they are essentially composed of the dxy and dx2−y2 orbitals of W and Hf. However, when the lattice constant is expanded more than ∼20%, the band gap opens, and the band characteristics around the Fermi energy change qualitatively at the point, where the topmost valence band is composed of the d3z2−r2 orbital, whereas the lowest conduction bands are doubly degenerate and consist of dxy and dx2−y2 orbitals. More interestingly, we find that band inversion occurs at the point concomitantly when the band gap opens. We should note that neither the band inversion nor the gap closing occurs at other momenta except for the point.
The evolution of the electronic bands at the point is summarized schematically in Fig. 14.13. When the lattice constant is very large ( 1.2a0, where a0 is the optimized lattice constant) and the SOC is absent, W2HfC2O2 is a trivial band insulator in which the two topmost valence bands are made of bonding and nonbonding states of d3z2−r2 orbitals with even and odd parities, respectively, while the lowest conduction bands are doubly degenerate and formed by a bonding state of dxy /dx2−y2 orbitals with even parity. As the lattice constant is reduced, the hybridization between neighboring d orbitals increases. As a result, the bonding state of the doubly degenerate dxy /dx2−y2 orbitals shifts downward below the Fermi energy, while the nonbonding state of the d3z2−r2 orbital moves above the Fermi energy. Because these two states have opposite parities, this is precisely when band inversion occurs. Note that the Fermi energy remains exactly at the doubly degenerate dxy /dx2−y2 states once the band inversion occurs, and therefore the
system remains semimetallic. However, as soon as the SOC is introduced, the doubly degeneracy is lifted, and the system becomes a nontrivial insulator. The role of the SOC is thus to induce a finite band gap but not band inversion, which has similarly been observed in ZrTe5 [120], square-octagonal WS2 [121], and MX (M = Zr, Hf; X = Cl, Br, I) [117]. It should be emphasized once again that the band inversion occurs in these topologically nontrivial MXenes mostly among d orbitals (more precisely, dz and dxy/dx2−y2 orbitals) of the transition metals [33, 34], not involving s and p orbitals as in the previously known or predicted topological insulators [108–111].
We have also studied the electronic structures of M2M′2C3O2 (M = Mo, W; M′ = Ti, Zr, Hf), i.e., MXenes with four transition metal layers. From the band structures and the Z2 index calculations, we find that the M2M′2C3O2 MXenes are nontrivial topological semimetals. The orbital characteristics of the bands near the Fermi energy around the point are very similar to those in the M2M′2C2O2 systems. Because of the local D3d hexagonal symmetry, the touching valence and conduction bands at the point are mainly dominated by the dxy and dx2−y2 orbitals of M and M′. In Mo2Hf2C3O2 and W2Hf2C3O2, band inversion is induced by the SOC at the point between the W-dxy/dx2−y2 and W-d3z2−r2 bands, while in the other M2M′2C3O2 (M = Mo, W; M′ = Ti, Zr) MXenes, the SOC only induces the band gap at the point but band inversion occurs due to the hybridization of the neighboring orbitals, similar to the M2M′C2O2 systems.

sections.heading: Work Function Properties
sections.text:
Various metallic substrates of transition metal carbides and nitrides provide the high stability, high melting point, and relatively low work function that have increasingly attracted attention as suitable field emitters. Considering the properties of the
274 M. Khazaei et al.
MXenes, members of this family can be good candidates as materials with a low work function for the following two reasons. First, the MXenes offer tunability of the work function with an appropriate choice of the transition metal as well as the X element, usually carbon or nitrogen. Second, during the synthesis of MXenes, their surfaces are functionalized naturally, which changes the electrostatic potential near the surfaces and affects the electronic structures, especially giving rise to the shift of the Fermi level. These two features have significant effects on the work function [36].
The work function is defined as the energy difference between the Fermi energy and the vacuum level (the electrostatic potential away from the surface). From the work function calculations of M2C and M10C9 (M = Sc, Ti, Zr, Hf, V, Nb, Ta) as well as M′2N and M′10N9 (M′ = Ti, Zr, and Hf) functionalized with F, OH, and O, it is found that the work functions of the bare and functionalized MXenes with F, OH, and O are distributed in the ranges 3.3–4.8, 3.1–5.8, 1.6–2.8, and 3.3– 6.7 eV, respectively [36]. It is also shown that work functions always decrease upon functionalization with OH. This is in remarkable contrast with the systems functionalized with F or O, in which the work functions increase or decrease depending on the type of transition metal. Interestingly, M2C(OH)2, M10C9(OH)2, M′2N(OH)2, and M′10N9(OH)2 all exhibit ultralow work functions, as compared with work functions of the corresponding bare and the functionalized MXenes with F and O [36]. The thickness dependences of the work function for Tin+1Cn (n = 1– 9) functionalized with F, OH, and O have been systematically studied, and it has been shown that, regardless of the thickness, a family of Tin+1Cn(OH)2 exhibits an ultralow work function [36].
By using the Poisson equation, it can be shown that the electrostatic potential away from the surface can be related to the surface dipole moment, and thus, the work function [122] = −e/ 0 P = −180.95 P with = − 0 and P = p−p0. Here, e (C) is the charge of an electron, 0 (CV−1 Å−1) is the vacuum permittivity, and 0( ) and p0 (p) are the work function and the surface dipole moment without (with) functionalization, respectively. As seen from Fig. 14.14, the work function properties of MXenes can be well explained by the surface dipole moments because the change in the work function ( ) upon functionalization is linearly correlated with the change in the surface dipole moment ( P ). The positive (negative) value of corresponds to the increase (decrease) in the work function when the surface is functionalized. This indicates that MXenes also follow the above rule, whereas correlates with P almost linearly with a slope of −170.012 VÅ [36].
In general, three main factors control the surface dipole moment upon deposition of any element: (i) the redistribution of electron charge between the surface and the adsorbates, (ii) the surface relaxation caused by the adsorbates, and (iii) the polarity of the adsorbates [36, 122]. By decomposing the P into the above three contributions, we can explain the work function properties of MXenes seen in Fig. 14.14 [36]. Further analysis on the MXenes indicates that the work function of the F and O functionalized MXenes is controlled by two factors, i.e., the dipole moment induced by the charge transfer between F/O and the substrate and the change in the total surface dipole moment caused by the surface relaxation upon
14 Electronic Properties and Applications of MXenes from Ab Initio. . . 275
functionalization. Besides these two factors, the intrinsic dipole moment of the OH group plays the most important role in determining the total dipole moment, which consequently explains the ultralow work function found in the OH-terminated MXenes [36].

sections.heading: Surface State Properties
sections.text:
A careful examination of the projected band structures of the OH-terminated MXenes has revealed that some of the states around the point, near and above the Fermi energy, do not constitute any of the composed elements [35]. As examples, the projected band structures of Sc2C(OH)2 and Hf2C(OH)2 are shown in Fig. 14.15. These states mainly distribute in the vacuum region outside the hydrogen atoms, and, more interestingly, they have nearly free electron (NFE) characteristics with parabolic energy dispersions with respect to the crystal wave vector [35].
The electron localization function (ELF) analysis [123] in Fig. 14.16 shows clearly that there exists a uniform floating electron gas above the hydrogen atoms in MXenes such as Hfn+1Cn(OH)2 (n = 1, 2, and 3) with partially occupied NFE states. It has been shown that Ti2C(OH)2, Zr2C(OH)2, Zr2N(OH)2, Hf2N(OH)2,
276 M. Khazaei et al.
Nb2C(OH)2, and Ta2C(OH)2 also possess partially occupied NFE states [35]. The lowest energy NFE states in Sc2C(OH)2, Ti2N(OH)2, and V2C(OH)2 are unoccupied and located above the Fermi energy but at a much lower energy than those of the graphene, graphane, BN, and MoS2 (see Fig. 14.15). Therefore, these unoccupied NFE states in OH-terminated MXenes should be accessible more easily than those in other known 2D systems [35].
Like the OH-terminated MXenes, the F- and O-terminated MXenes also exhibit the NFE states. However, the NFE states in the F- and O-terminated MXenes are located at much higher energies. For example, as shown in Fig. 14.15, the lowest energy NFE states of Hf2CF2 and Hf2CO2 appear around 3 and 5 eV above the Fermi energy, respectively. This already implies that the NFE states of the F- and O-terminated MXenes are not suitable for application purposes. The NFE states can
14 Electronic Properties and Applications of MXenes from Ab Initio. . . 277
be only formed in the spatial regions away beyond the surfaces toward the vacuum in the electrostatic potential wells. In this regard, the shallow potential tails in the OH-terminated MXenes are found near the Fermi level (due to positively charged hydrogen atoms at the surfaces [35]), while the shallow potential tails in the F- and O-terminated systems are located far above the Fermi level. Hence, the NFE states of the OH-terminated MXenes are generally found near the Fermi level, while those in F- and O-terminated MXenes appear at higher energies [35]. As shown in Fig. 14.16, the presence of the NFE states and the location relative to the Fermi energy do not depend significantly on the thickness of the MXenes. This is because the thickness of the MXenes cannot essentially change the nature of the surface charges; i.e., the surface of the OH-terminated (F- and O-terminated) MXenes remains positively (negatively) charged, independent of the thickness.
Electron transport properties of MXenes with partially occupied NFE states have also been studied [35]. The calculations can show the signature of the NFE states in electron conduction [35]. The electron transport properties of MXenes, which possess NFE states, are important because these states are located above the MXene surfaces (see Fig. 14.17) and can conduct electrons through the nearly free channels without being significantly scattered by the surface vibrations at finite temperatures. The transmission analysis indeed clearly shows that the NFE states
278 M. Khazaei et al.
can act as both hole and electron channels at low bias voltages, thus making them suitable for applications in low-power nanoelectronic devices [35]. It is noteworthy that the partially occupied NFE states near the Fermi energy are sensitive to the conditions and indeed they disappear by applying large compressive or tensile strains; adsorbing molecules such as O2, N2, and CO; or hetrostructuring the MXenes with graphene, BN, or graphane [35]. It has also been proposed that due to their localized states that appear above the hydrogen atoms, the OH-terminated MXenes may offer potential application for Pb and heavy metal purification for environmental remediation [124, 125].

sections.heading: Thermoelectric Properties
sections.text:
Owing to their intrinsic ceramic nature, MXenes may be suitable as thermoelectric materials for energy conversion applications at high temperatures. The performance of thermoelectric material is quantified through the dimensionless figure of merit ZT given as S2σT/K , where S, σ , T , and K (= kl + ke) are the Seebeck coefficient, electrical conductivity, temperature, and thermal conductivity with both lattice (kl) and electronic (ke) contributions, respectively. In general, ZT can be maximized when the power factor (S2σ ) is maximized and the thermal conductivity is simultaneously minimized. The thermal conductivity can be minimized efficiently by enhancing the phonon scattering in the presence of edges, interfaces, grain boundaries, and embedded nanostructures [126]. However, maximizing S2σ is not straightforward because both S and σ are strongly coupled to the electronic structure of the system and usually behave inversely: a material that has a high Seebeck coefficient has a poor electrical conductivity and vice versa. Therefore, a trade-off between the Seebeck coefficient and the electrical conductivity at a particular p- or n-type carrier concentration is required so as to maximize the power factor. Here, the thermoelectric transport properties, the Seebeck coefficient (S),
14 Electronic Properties and Applications of MXenes from Ab Initio. . . 279
the electron conductivity (σ ), and the power factor (S2σ ), were computed within the Boltzmann theory [127] and the constant relaxation time (τ ) approximation. Within this approximation, the Seebeck coefficient becomes τ -independent without any other adjustable parameter, but the electrical conductivities and thus the power factors are obtained with respect to τ . On the basis of this approximation, the electrical conductivity and Seebeck coefficient tensors of a material can be written as

N indicates the number of k points sampled. In the formulations v(i,k) (α = x, y, z) is the αth component of the group velocity of the carriers (=1/h̄∇ i,k). The above formulations have already been implemented in BoltzTraP code.
On the basis of Boltzmann theory and first-principles electronic structure calculations, the power factor S2σ of monolayer and multilayer M2C (M = Sc, Ti, V, Zr, Nb, Mo, Hf, Ta) and M2N (M = Ti, Zr, Hf) MXenes functionalized with F, OH, and O groups has already been explored [32]. It has been shown that the metallic (semiconducting) MXenes are poor (good) thermoelectric materials [32]. For example, as shown in Fig. 14.18 for Nb2CF2, the metallic MXenes exhibit excellent electrical conductivity but a very poor Seebeck coefficient, consequently having a very poor power factor. On the other hand, the semiconducting MXenes exhibit relatively poor electric conductivity, but an excellent Seebeck coefficient, resulting in a relatively good power factor. Among the semiconducting MXenes, Mo2CF2 (see Fig. 14.18) exhibit superior power factor over other MXenes, and thus it is a potential thermoelectric material in the MXene family [32]. The exceptionally superior thermoelectric property of Mo2CF2 is attributed to the peculiar band structure near the band edge, where flat and dispersive bands are merged. This type of band shapes allows for a large Seebeck coefficient and simultaneously a good electrical conductivity at low carrier concentrations [128–130].
The effect of a band gap on enhancement of the Seebeck coefficient can be understood through its formula [131–133]. The Seebeck coefficient is proportional to ν
σ , where σ is the electrical conductivity and ν is the ( -μ) weighted by the average value of the squared band velocities of electrons multiplied by the DOS and the derivative of the Fermi function (f( )) with respect to the energy (df( )/d ). The ( -μ)df( )/d has opposite signs in the energy regions above and below the chemical potential [32]. Thus, it can be easily understood that S tends to be large once the DOS and band velocities at above and below the chemical potential exhibit a large
14 Electronic Properties and Applications of MXenes from Ab Initio. . . 281
contrast [134, 135]. Accordingly, if the chemical potential is located in the energy region where the DOS and band velocities change smoothly, the Seebeck coefficient would be small due to the cancellation of the positive and negative contributions. This is the reason why Nb2CF2 with a smooth DOS near the original Fermi level exhibits a negligible Seebeck coefficient (Fig. 14.18). In semiconducting materials, as the chemical potential moves toward the band edges, the difference between the number of states above and below the chemical potential increases, which results in an increase in S. For this reason, the semiconducting MXenes such as Mo2CF2 exhibit large Seebeck coefficients near the band edges (Fig. 14.18).
The thermal conductivity of various MXenes, e.g., M2CO2 (M = Ti, Zr, Hf) [136, 137], Sc2CT2 (T = F, O, OH) [138, 139], and Mo2C [140], has also been studied by taking into account both phonon and electron contributions. These MXenes are all semiconducting except for pristine Mo2C which is metallic. The thermal conductivity is in general anisotropic along the armchair and zigzag directions [137]. Among M2CO2 (M = Ti, Zr, Hf), Ti2CO2 and Hf2CO2 exhibit the lowest and highest lattice thermal conductivities, respectively, in the temperature range 300–700 K. Consequently, Ti2CO2 achieves a higher figure of merit ZT for thermoelectric application (ZT= 0.45 for 14.0 × 1020 cm−3 n-doping and ZT= 0.27 for 1.7 × 1020 cm−3 p-doping [136]) because of the low thermal conductivity and the high carrier mobility [136, 137]. The room temperature thermal conductivity of Hf2CO2 is 62.12–131.2 (27.63–53.03) Wm−1K−1 along the armchair (zigzag) flake length of 1–100 μm [137]. Among Sc2CT2 (T= F, O, OH), Sc2C(OH)2 is predicted to be a candidate for thermoelectric application at elevated temperatures higher than 300 K due to a relatively good Seebeck coefficient, high electrical conductivity, and very low lattice thermal conductivity [138]. At room temperature, the thermal conductivity of Sc2C(OH)2 along the armchair (zigzag) direction can be as large as 123–245 (78.5–148) Wm−1K−1 when the flake length increases from 1 to 50 μm [139]. The room temperature thermal conductivity of Mo2C is also evaluated to be 48.4 (64.7) Wm−1K−1 for the armchair (zigzag) flake length of 100 μm [140]. From the calculations it is predicted that maximum ZT of MXenes will be less than 1.1 [141].

sections.heading: Summary
sections.text:
There has been an emerging interest in synthesis and exploring the potential properties and applications of two-dimensional (2D) nanosheets other than graphene. Recently, it has been proved experimentally that MAX phases with layered structures can be exfoliated into 2D systems, so-called the MXenes. Thus, MAX phase family with various composition elemental possibility preserves a great source for novel 2D systems. Considering diverse properties and applications, MXenes serve as suitable materials for interdisciplinary research and collaboration between academia and industry.
282 M. Khazaei et al.
Here, we have provided an insight into the exfoliation possibility of various crystalline MAX phases into 2D MXenes by examining the strength of bonds through force constant calculations and static exfoliation energy. It was shown that many of MAX phases can be exfoliated into 2D MXenes. Also we have shown that charge injection could affect the possibility of exfoliation significantly. Then, the structural and electronic properties of MXenes have been studied. We have shown that upon an appropriate surface functionalization, some of the MXenes turn into semiconducting from the original metallic. The physics behind topologically trivial or nontrivial behavior of metallic or semiconducting MXenes have been discussed in detail. Moreover, by considering the surface dipole moments, it was exhibited how the surface functionalization of MXenes could affect their work function and consequently their surface states. Finally, as an example of applications of MXenes, using the Boltzmann theory and first-principles electronic structure calculations, we explored the thermoelectric properties of MXenes. We have shown that semiconducting MXenes obtain a superior thermofactor to metallic ones. We hope that this chapter could provide a broad insight into the physics behind various structural and electronic properties of MAX phases and MXenes.
