sections.heading: Nathan C. Frey, Christopher C. Price, Arkamita Bandyopadhyay, Hemant Kumar, and Vivek B. Shenoy
Structural and Chemical Degrees of Freedom
sections.text:
While there have been significant research efforts into the properties of 2D semiconductors and optoelectronic materials, 2D magnetic materials are relatively unexplored. Two-dimensional magnetic materials are desirable for their potential applications in quantum computation, logic and memory operations, spintronics, and any electronic device that relies on manipulation of the spin degree of freedom of carriers [1–3]. The search for intrinsic 2D magnetism is also motivated by interest in understanding the fundamental physics of spin processes and phase transitions in two dimensions. However, most experimentally realized 2D materials thus far are intrinsically nonmagnetic. In fact, long-range magnetic ordering is prohibited in two-dimensional systems with continuous spin symmetry at finite temperatures, according to the Mermin-Wagner theorem [4]. The search for practically useful magnetic 2D materials must, therefore, focus on systems with magnetic anisotropy that can be reliably produced and that are robust to oxidation and thermal fluctuations.
MXenes hold great promise for achieving intrinsic 2D magnetism because of their available chemical and structural diversity. Over 70 different MXenes have been proposed theoretically [5], and millions of solid solutions are possible with various M-X systems. Of these, a few have already been synthesized, and some MXenes have been predicted to be intrinsically magnetic. The choice of M (transition metal) atom provides freedom in the number of d-electrons in the system, which may be strongly spin-polarized depending on the transition metal coordination environment. Transition metal nitrides in particular, which contain an
N. C. Frey · C. C. Price · A. Bandyopadhyay · H. Kumar · V. B. Shenoy ( ) Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA e-mail: vshenoy@seas.upenn.edu
© Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2019 B. Anasori, Y. Gogotsi (eds.), 2D Metal Carbides and Nitrides (MXenes), https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-19026-2_15
291
extra electron compared to transition metal carbides, are expected to have robust ferromagnetic ground states due to the excess density of states (DOS) at the Fermi level [6]. Furthermore, surface functionalization via F, OH, or O groups provides an additional degree of chemical freedom that may be used to tune the magnetic ground state.
Beyond the diversity of choices in M, X, and T atoms, MXenes also allow for ordered double transition metal structures with the general formula M2M’nXn+1Tx (n = 1–2) and a variable number of layers (n = 1–3) in single transition metal systems. Careful design of such MXene systems has yielded structures that are predicted to have magnetic ground states without any doping, defect, or strain engineering, suggesting the possibility that they may be synthesized in a crystalline state [7]. A fraction of the diversity of predicted magnetic and transport behavior in MXenes is illustrated in Fig. 15.1.
Before discussing the variety of magnetic properties and strategies for tuning these properties in MXenes, we first briefly introduce a general framework [7, 8] for understanding and predicting magnetism in MXene monolayers. While unsaturated p-orbitals in graphene with point defects [9] and zigzag edges in transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) [10] result in ferromagnetism in 2D systems, controlling the magnetic response in a predictable manner remains a challenge. In contrast, the magnetic ordering in many MXenes is intrinsic to the chemical and structural composition of pristine structures. In MXenes, transition metal atom d-orbitals lie between bonding (σ ) and antibonding (σ ∗) states from the M-X and M-T bonds. Assuming nominal oxidation of all constituent atoms, the bonding states are filled while the antibonding states are unfilled. Therefore, only electrons in the nonbonding d-orbitals contribute to the magnetic behavior.
The octahedral crystal field imposed on the transition metal atoms from its nearest neighbors further splits the nonbonding d-orbitals into low energy dxy, dyz, and dxz (t2g) states and high energy dx2- y2 and dz2 (eg) states. A schematic of this alignment of the states near the Fermi level is shown in Fig. 15.2. The available

number of electrons then determines the filling of the d-bands and gives rise to a wide variety of possible magnetic behavior. This picture is complicated somewhat by the coupling between transition metal cations that is mediated by the nonmagnetic X and T anions. Based on symmetry considerations and the occupancies of overlapping orbitals, the semi-empirical Goodenough-Kanamori rules have been used to rationalize the effects of double-exchange and superexchange in MXenes [8]. In general, the calculated DOS of O-terminated magnetic MXenes show broad peaks, indicating delocalized electrons with itinerant character, which stabilize ferromagnetic (FM) ordering via a double-exchange interaction. Electrons are more localized in F-terminated MXenes, leading to a weaker double-exchange interaction and a more dominant antiferromagnetic (AFM) superexchange interaction that favors AFM ordering. The interplay of these interactions is not trivial and may lead to unexpected magnetic ground states.

sections.heading: Predictions of Ground State Magnetic Ordering
sections.text:
Khazaei et al. first predicted ground state ferromagnetic order in pristine Cr2C and Cr2N MXenes [11]. Ferromagnetic ground states are of particular interest due to the potential applications in spintronics and coupling to other 2D systems that may allow for probing novel phenomena. While the covalent M-X and M-T bonds are in general quite strong and lead to nonmagnetic ground states, various studies have reported intrinsic magnetism in both bare and functionalized MXenes beyond Cr2C and Cr2N. Bare Ti2C and Ti2N also exhibit intrinsic ferromagnetism [12].
Because of the surface functionalization that is inevitably introduced during the synthesis of MXenes, it is desirable to identify systems that retain a magnetic ground state after surface termination. Especially considering that other candidate 2D magnetic materials are vulnerable to oxidation, it is beneficial to find magnetic MXenes that are robust to oxidation and suitable for potential device applications. The single transition metal Ti2NO2 and Cr2NO2 are ferromagnetic [8, 13], as well as the ordered double transition metal Cr2VC2T2 (T = OH, F, O) [14], Hf2MnC2O2,
294 N. C. Frey et al.
and Hf2VC2O2 [7]. To date, the Mn2NTx and Ti2MnC2Tx MXenes have been shown to exhibit robust ferromagnetism regardless of surface functionalization [7, 8]. These systems, with high predicted Curie temperatures and strong spinpolarization with high magnetic moments (greater than 3 μB/unit cell), are therefore more robust than materials that rely on induced magnetism [15]. Additionally, these ferromagnetic MXenes exhibit a range of transport behavior including metallicity, half-metallicity, semi-metallicity, and semi-conductivity.
There have been comparatively more reports of antiferromagnetism in MXenes. In contrast to FM ordering, AFM ordering results in a zero net magnetization that makes the spin degree of freedom difficult to control or use in devices. Recently, experimental developments in AFM spintronics [17] and topological AFM spintronics [18] have changed the historical view of antiferromagnetic systems as a theoretical curiosity and intensified interest in the search for robust 2D AFM systems. To this end, multiple models for AFM ordering in MXenes have been proposed. In general, there are two considered AFM spin configurations in MXenes, which have transition metal atoms arranged in a bilayer triangular lattice: (1) intralayer FM coupling and interlayer AFM coupling and (2) intralayer AFM coupling and interlayer FM coupling. These arrangements are referred to as AFM1 and AFM2, respectively, in Fig. 15.3. Note that these spin configurations are only models for AFM order, and complications arise when considering the spin frustration inherent in the triangular sublattice. V2C [12], V2CTx (T = F, OH) [19], Cr2CTx (T = F, Cl, OH, H) [16], Cr2N, and Cr2NTx (T = OH, F) [13] have all been predicted to be antiferromagnetic in the ground state. Among the ordered double transition metal MXenes, Cr2TiC2Tx (T = F, OH) [14], Hf2MnC2Tx (T = F, OH), and Hf2VC2Tx (T = F, OH) [7] exhibit AFM ordering.
A new class of so-called “Janus” MXenes, which break symmetry via asymmetric surface functionalization, demonstrate both intrinsic FM and AFM ordering. Of particular interest in these systems is the possibility to tune the magnetic and transport behavior by the chemically different top and bottom layer functionalization, which creates a mismatch in the M atom d-states. Members of the Janus Cr2CTT’ (T, T’ = H, F, Cl, Br, OH) family are predicted to exhibit bipolar antiferromagnetic semiconductor behavior with high Neel temperatures [20] and switching to a half-metallic antiferromagnet state under a gate voltage [21]. Asymmetrically functionalized O-Ti2C-Li monolayers show half-metallic
15 Predicted Magnetic Properties of MXenes 295
ferromagnetism by inducing substantial differences in the valence states of the Ti layers [22]. With mixed surface termination, Mn2NOxF2−x (x = 0.5, 1, or 1.5) is a robust Ising ferromagnet, while Cr2COxF2−x, Ti2COxF2−x, and V2COxF2−x exhibit antiferromagnetic ordering [23]. Applied electric fields stabilize ferromagnetism in Mn2NOxF2−x, leading to enhanced Curie temperatures, and enable switching from AFM to FM ordering in Cr2COxF2−x [23].
The essential ingredient for stabilizing nanoscale magnetism in MXenes (and enabling practical device applications) is magnetic anisotropy. Spin-orbit coupling and covalent bonds provide anisotropy in 2D materials by symmetry breaking, resulting in energetically favorable orientations for magnetic moments. Recent work has provided a simple and effective method for using calculated magnetic anisotropy values to more accurately predict Curie temperatures in 2D materials [24, 25]. Spin-orbit coupling is increased in MXenes by increasing the mass of the M atom, while highly directional (anisotropic) covalent bonds are formed by O surface functionalization. Thus, MXenes like Mn2NO2 are engineered to exhibit strong magnetic anisotropy and intrinsic, out-of-plane Ising ferromagnetism [26]. The magnetic anisotropy can be tuned through further changes in the M and T atoms to achieve in-plane XY and isotropic Heisenberg magnetism [26]. This tunability is shown schematically in Fig. 15.4.

sections.heading: Tuning Magnetic Order via Strain and Defects
sections.text:
Strain or impurity induced magnetism in MXenes opens new possibilities in the regime of microscopic understanding of magnetism in these systems. Often doping or defects induce local magnetic centers in low dimensional systems, whereas strain engineering leads to overall displacement of the atoms from their equilibrium positions, and as a result, electronic rearrangement may lead to magnetic phase changes in the system.
A recent study focusing on strain-induced magnetism, using density functional theory calculations, elucidated the effect of biaxial symmetric mechanical strains
on M2C (M = Hf, Nb, Sc, Ta, Ti, V, Zr) MXenes (shown in Fig. 15.5). Without the application of strain, only Ti2C and Zr2C exhibit an appreciable magnetic moment of 1.92 and 1.25 μB/unit cell, respectively. Increase in tensile strain induces magnetism in all the other nonmagnetic MXene sheets and leads to nonmagnetic to ferromagnetic phase transitions. Hf2C, exhibiting an overall 0.0 μB/unit cell magnetic moment in its strain-free form, shows the most drastic change, with an induced magnetic moment of 1.5 μB/unit cell, achieved at a strain of 1.80%. The magnetic properties of strained Hf2C are attributed to the band shift mainly involving Hf(5d) states [27]. Another study predicts an AFM1 to FM phase transformation in a V2C MXene system upon application of biaxial strain and an overall magnetic moment of 1.0 μB/unit cell [12]. MXene systems can maintain their structure with even 9.5% biaxial strain [28], thus these methods can be applied to reliably tune the magnetic properties of MXenes.
Doping nonmetal atoms (B, Si, etc.) in the X layer or doping transition metal atoms in the M layer also leads to interesting magnetic behavior. Nonmetal doping can generate magnetic moments up to 1.0 μB/unit cell in MXenes [29]. Doping Ti, V, Cr, or Mn atoms into Sc2CT2 systems modifies the magnetic nature of the system, e.g., Ti- and V-doped Sc2CT2 systems are nonmagnetic or weakly magnetic in nature, whereas late transition metal Cr and Mn doping atoms can induce a 2.1 μB/unit cell magnetic moment because of an electron redistribution in the system [30].
Recently, Sang et al. experimentally confirmed the presence of atomic defects in MXene layers [31], and these defects can also alter the magnetic properties of MXenes. In the case of Ti2XT2 systems (X = C/N, T = O, F, OH), X-vacancies (VX) lead to magnetization of the MXene layers, with an exception of VC in Ti2CO2. This happens because of the dangling bonds near the defect sites and the electronic redistribution which leads to a local magnetic moment that can be as high as 2.19 μB/unit cell with an FM to NM stabilization energy of 70 meV/supercell [32]. This has been confirmed by the electron density gain in the nonbonding eg levels of MXene systems with VC [33].
15 Predicted Magnetic Properties of MXenes 297

sections.heading: Applications: Spintronics and Quantum Computing
sections.text:
The field of spintronics began with the discovery of the giant magnetoresistance effect (GMR) in thin-layer magnetic heterostructures, where two ferromagnetic layers sandwiched a thin conducting paramagnetic separator. Alignment or antialignment of the spins in the two ferromagnetic layers produces a difference in resistance due to spin-polarization dependent scattering of conducting electrons [1]. The implications of selectively transmitting electrons with specific spins and measuring the magnetic state of a system without applying a field enable potential storage and transmission of information using the spin degree of freedom. While GMR is currently implemented in read heads of magnetic hard disks and non-volatile magnetic random-access memories, materials research is ongoing to develop the necessary components for a full spintronic technology platform. Naturally, these hypothetical devices will only be useful if they can be reliably synthesized below the ten-nanometer length scale of current silicon devices. This requirement emphasizes the unique potential of the 2D MXene structure for realizing accessible magnetic properties on the appropriate length scale. This effort is driven by the demand for smaller and faster information transmission and storage, which faces the physical material limits of conventional silicon-based electronics and the reliance on Coulombic charge transport. Utilizing spin currents has the potential to reduce the power consumption of information flow, as spins can preserve information while transporting through metals, and reduction of spurious magnetic fields that arise from the flow of charged particles [34]. Particularly in topologically insulating phases, these properties can be realized with dissipationless surface states that conduct a net spin current but zero charge current, due to spin-momentum locking in chiral edge states. Figure 15.6 shows a schematic of a spintronic transistor using ferromagnetic domains overlaid on a 2D topological insulator which enables
298 N. C. Frey et al.
control over the flow of spin current without inducing net Coulombic charge current [35]. Other ingredients for material spintronics, such as significant spd orbital hybridization and spin-orbit coupling are achievable in MXenes [26, 36]. Furthermore, the initial ability to both solution process and vapor deposit MXenes is consistent with the long-term goal of designing a cost-effective, scalable spintronics platform [37].
Achieving scalable quantum computation requires a materials platform that can manipulate information through distinct quantum states. The number of operations required to compute “hard” computational problems scales exponentially with regard to the number of operations required as a function of the number of inputs, making these problems intractable using traditional on/off bits for all but the simplest of cases. Quantum computation, using qubits instead of traditional bits, can take advantage of the combinatorics of quantum superposition to enable an equivalent exponential scaling of the number of possible operations, rendering these previously hard problems tractable. One proposed method of constructing coherent, stable qubit systems is realization of Majorana zero-mode quasiparticles by layering a superconducting phase on top of a topological insulator. Although quantum computation is being investigated from several different perspectives, topological protection is highly desired for applicational use since it enables error correction by non-Abelian braiding and protection from mechanical perturbations at the hardware level [38]. The challenge is realizing these exotic quasiparticle statistics on a materials platform that is both robust at room temperature and allows selective spin transport between the two phases. Two-dimensional ferromagnets, which in low dimensions are limited to those systems with magnetic anisotropy, are particularly useful due to their inherent long-range spin correlation and sensitivity to spin currents [39]. Akin to the spintronic transistor in Fig. 15.5, patterned heterostructures of topological, ferromagnetic, and superconducting phases will be required to excite and control Majorana modes, invoking the familiar materials science problem of interfacial electronic properties. A diverse family of materials such as MXenes possessing long-range electronic and spin correlation as well as inherently smooth planar interfaces is ideal for exploring the physical building blocks necessary for quantum computation.

sections.heading: Challenges and Future Directions
sections.text:
Predictions thus far indicate that MXenes are promising candidates for 2D magnetic materials capable of operating in ambient conditions; possessing intrinsic and tunable magnetic ordering, strong magnetic anisotropy, and robustness to oxidation and thermal disorder. Despite the recent progress in predicting the magnetic properties of MXenes, many interesting challenges and unexplored opportunities remain. Perhaps chief among these is the synthesis and characterization of systems that are predicted to be magnetic, although recent success in the demonstration of paramagnetism in Ti3C2 [40] and the synthesis of the Ti4N3Tx nitride MXene and 2D sheets of transition metal nitrides are a promising start [41, 42]. Beyond the
15 Predicted Magnetic Properties of MXenes 299
theoretical studies undertaken to date, there is potential for materials engineering via the proximity effect, which would take advantage of interesting quantum effects that are induced when 2D materials are made into heterostructures. By layering magnetic MXenes or coupling magnetic MXenes to systems with large spin-orbit coupling, a nearly unlimited range of novel devices and applications may be realized.

sections.heading: Electronic and Mechanical Properties of MXenes Derived from Single-Flake Measurements
Introduction: Learning from Research on Other 2D Materials
sections.text:
Two-dimensional materials attract great attention due to the breadth of physical properties that they offer and their potential for a variety of applications. Active exploration of 2D materials started after the isolation of individual monolayer flakes of graphene [1–3], and now the still growing family of 2D materials includes hexagonal boron nitride, phosphorene, silicene, and transition metal chalcogenides among many others [4–6].
Graphene flakes were first isolated from graphite crystals using an adhesive tape by micromechanical exfoliation [1, 2]. Although this method is time- and labor-consuming and the resulting flakes are relatively small, they are of very high structural quality and were historically used for measuring most of the fundamental physical properties of graphene. Such measurements performed on individual flakes revealed that graphene possesses a number of unique characteristics, including ultrahigh charge carrier mobilities of over 2 × 105 cm2/ V · s [7, 8], high Young’s modulus (~1 TPa) [9, 10] and optical transparency (~97.7%) [11], and excellent thermal conductivity of up to 5300 W/m · K [12]. These properties make graphene promising for a variety of applications ranging from electronics and energy storage to separation and mechanically reinforced composites [13, 14].
While the micromechanical exfoliation is ideal for the preparation of individual graphene crystals for research needs [15] and it is still used in laboratories worldwide more than a decade after its original introduction, this method cannot be scaled up to produce bulk quantities of graphene for commercial applications. Therefore, a great deal of research was focused on the development of large-scale

approaches for graphene preparation [13, 14]. In addition to many other important synthetic advancements, these efforts produced new methods for graphene growth on metal substrates by chemical vapor deposition (CVD) [16–20] and revitalized interest in graphene oxide (GO), a solution-processable material produced by oxidation of graphite in harsh acid media and known since mid-nineteenth century [21].
GO is often viewed as a low-cost and scalable alternative to pristine graphene for large-scale applications [22]. GO can be synthesized by several methods, including five major synthetic approaches developed by Brodie [21], Staudenmaier [23], Hofmann [24], Hummers [25], and Tour [26], as well as their multiple variations. For example, in the Hummers method, which was originally introduced in 1958 and remains a commonly used procedure for the GO synthesis, graphite powder is treated with a solution of potassium permanganate (KMnO4) and sodium nitrate (NaNO3) in concentrated sulfuric acid [25]. Although GO sheets could reach hundreds of μm in lateral size [27] due to functionalization with oxygen-containing moieties they are highly soluble in water and other solvents [28]. Unlike pristine graphene, GO could be conveniently processed into bulk structures, such as coatings [29–31] or a free-standing ‘graphene oxide paper’ [32], or blended with various polymers for their mechanical reinforcement [14, 33]. However, because of the chemical treatment in harsh oxidative conditions, some properties of GO are inferior to those of graphene. Because of the high degree of oxidation the as-synthesized material is an electrical insulator, although the conductivity can be partially restored via chemical reduction of GO to reduced GO (rGO) [34–37]. Extensive oxidation also results in the degradation of mechanical characteristics of graphene.
Because of the great potential of GO for large-scale applications [22], it was important to determine its fundamental physical properties and understand how they compare to those of graphene. However, when the measurements (electronic, mechanical, optical, etc.) are performed on a bulk assembly of multiple sheets in the form of a large-scale film or a structural composite, the results are inevitably affected by the interfaces between the flakes and thus do not necessarily provide an accurate representation of GO/rGO’s properties. Therefore, shortly after the characterization of individual flakes of mechanically exfoliated graphene, similar experiments were performed on individual sheets of GO and rGO [34, 35, 38]. While GO/rGO sheets are originally produced in solution, they can be conveniently deposited on a substrate of choice by drop-casting or spin-coating, and then individual rGO flakes can be used for device fabrication [34, 35]. Electrical measurements of such devices revealed that similar to graphene, rGO can exhibit an ambipolar electrical field effect, although the room field-effect mobilities of holes (2–200 cm2/ V · s) and electrons (0.5–30 cm2/ V · s) are several orders of magnitude lower than in graphene [34]. Likewise, GO/rGO flakes can be deposited on substrates with microscopic holes and thus form nanomembranes, which could be used for nanoindentation experiments [38]. The measurements showed that despite some degradation of the integrity of the graphene lattice during the oxidation [39], the Young’s modulus of GO monolayers is still considerably high (>200 GPa) [38, 40] which is about onefifth of the Young’s modulus of pristine graphene [9, 10].
16 Electronic and Mechanical Properties of MXenes Derived from Single-. . . 303
The single-flake measurements were important to determine the place of GO and rGO in the hierarchy of graphene-based materials. Because of its low charge carrier mobilities, rGO is not suitable for high-speed electronic applications, but is very promising for applications, such as conductive thin films and coatings [29–31], separation and filtration [41], gas sensing [42, 43], and mechanically reinforced composite materials [14, 33], for which bulk quantities of an easily processable material are required.
Among the latest additions to the family of 2D materials are MXenes, a large class of 2D transition metal carbides, carbonitrides, and nitrides with a general formula Mn + 1XnTx, where M stands for a transition metal, such as Ti, Zr, V, Nb, Ta, Cr, Mo, and Sc, X is carbon and/or nitrogen, Tx denotes surface functionalities, such as fluorine, oxygen, and hydroxyl groups, and n = 1, 2, or 3 [44, 45]. MXenes are produced from layered ternary metal carbides/nitrides, called MAX phases, by selective chemical extraction of interleaving layers of an “A” element (group IIIA and IVA elements, e.g., Al). Fluoride-containing acidic solutions, such as HF [45, 46], NH4HF2 [47], or LiF-HCl [48], are used for the A-element (typically, Al) extraction, which results in mixed oxygen- and fluorinecontaining surface terminations. More than 25 different MXenes have been already experimentally demonstrated, and many others have been studied theoretically [49, 50]. Some examples of widely studied MXenes include Ti3C2Tx [46], Ti2CTx [51], Nb2CTx [52], Nb4C3Tx [52], V2CTx [53], and Mo2TiC2Tx [54]. Figure 16.1 summarizes MXene materials that have been experimentally demonstrated, as well as theoretically predicted so far [50].
The exploration of many 2D materials followed the footsteps of graphene, starting with micromechanical exfoliation of individual high-quality crystals [55], which was followed by intrinsic property measurements and development of largescale synthetic approaches for various applications. However, the path of MXenes was different, because from the very beginning they were produced by a solution process in large quantities [46] enabling bulk application tests. Soon after their experimental demonstration, MXenes were shown to be promising for a variety of energy storage applications, including Li-ion [45], Li–S [56], Na-ion batteries [57], and supercapacitors [48]. However, while bulk applications of MXenes are rapidly developing, their intrinsic physical property characterization through single-flake measurements remains a largely unexplored area of research, and scarce examples of such studies, which will be reviewed here, focused only on Ti-based MXene materials, Ti2CTx [58] and Ti3C2Tx [59–62]. Yet, such studies are very important for the field, because they not only provide insights into fundamental properties of MXenes and elucidate their potential for the aforementioned and emerging applications, but also enable comparison of different MXene materials with each other.
Electrical conductivity of MXenes is a very important parameter for a variety of applications, such as energy storage [50], transparent conductive films [63, 64], electromagnetic interference shielding [65], gas [66, 67] and strain sensors [68]. So, a considerable number of papers reported results of electrical measurements, which are summarized in Table 16.1. However, most of these measurements were
304 A. Lipatov and A. Sinitskii
performed on bulk MXene structures, including filtered, spin-casted or sprayed films, pressed discs, and particles. These structures vary in thickness, preparation, and postprocessing methods, so the resulting conductivities often show a large spread in values even for the same material. These results clearly illustrate that the conductivity of a bulk assembly of MXene sheets strongly depends on the preparation method, which dictates the stacking of individual MXene sheets and the interflake resistances, underscoring the importance of single-flake measurements for revealing the intrinsic properties of various MXene materials and their comparison with each other.
In the following sections, we provide detailed examples of electrical and mechanical characterization of the monolayers of the most studied MXene material to date, Ti3C2Tx. Ti3C2Tx is the first discovered [46] and the most widely studied MXene material to date [50]. It shows higher electrical conductivity than solutionprocessed graphene [59], outstanding electrochemical properties [82], and great promise for various applications ranging from energy storage [50] to electromagnetic interference shielding [65]. After examples of the Ti3C2Tx measurements, we discuss the importance of similar single-flake measurements on other members of the rapidly growing MXene family.

Electrical Measurements of Monolayer Ti3C2Tx Flakes
For the electrical measurements of MXene flakes, some ideas and approaches can be borrowed from research on GO/rGO, with which MXenes have a number of similarities. Both kinds of materials are prepared in acid solutions and share a number of properties, such as relatively low cost, scalable production, large (μm scale) size of flakes, and solubility in conventional solvents due to the surface functionalization. Similar to previous works on rGO [34, 35], a colloidal solution of Ti3C2Tx can be simply drop-casted onto a Si/SiO2 substrate, and after the solvent drying, individual MXene flake can be identified by optical microscopy and used for device fabrication. Monolayer flakes of Ti3C2Tx are well visible on silicon substrates covered with a 300-nm-thick layer of SiO2, which are routinely used in graphene research [15], although the highest optical contrast was found for SiO2 thicknesses of about 220 nm [61].
Figure 16.2a shows the schematic illustration of the simplest device that could be used to probe MXene’s electronic properties. It is a field-effect transistor (FET), in which a MXene flake bridges source (S) and drain (D) electrodes, while a conductive highly p-doped Si can be used as a bottom gate (G) electrode. Figure 16.2b illustrates the device fabrication process, showing a representative Ti3C2Tx flake before and after the preparation of a FET. It is important to point out that since MXenes degrade in the presence of water and oxygen [83–85], in order to achieve the highest electrical conductivity of a device, it is imperative to minimize the exposure of flakes to humid air [50].
308 A. Lipatov and A. Sinitskii
FET devices shown in Fig. 16.2a, b can be employed for a variety of experiments that include (a) probing of electronic properties of MXenes, (b) evaluation and comparison of the efficiencies of synthetic procedures for MXenes, and (c) study of MXenes’ environmental stability. In the following sections, we provide examples of these experiments.

sections.heading: Electronic Properties of Ti3C2Tx
sections.text:
Figure 16.2c demonstrates a representative drain–source current (IDS) – drain– source voltage (VDS) dependence recorded for a FET device based on a Ti3C2Tx monolayer (Fig. 16.2a, b), which shows a linear Ohmic behavior. Control experiments utilizing four-probe devices showed that the contact resistance does not play a significant role in transport measurements [60]. The average resistivity at gate voltage (VG) = 0 was shown to be 2310 ± 570 /sq., which is comparable to the sheet resistivity of graphene [86]. Since the thickness of the Ti3C2Tx flake is 1 nm [48, 87], the calculated single-flake resistivity is 2.31 ± 0.57 μ m and conductivity is 4600 ± 1100 S/cm [59].
It is important to put these data into context and compare transport properties of Ti3C2Tx in different forms. Resistivity measurements conducted on the Ti3C2Tx material from the same batch but in a form of filtered paper revealed resistivity of 15.8 ± 1.3 μ m [59]. The difference between bulk and monolayer flake resistivities may be explained by the contribution of the contact resistance at the interfaces between individual MXene flakes, i.e. the resistance perpendicular to the basal plane. The difference between the resistivities of an individual monolayer Ti3C2Tx flake and a film is within one order of magnitude, which is surprisingly small. In graphite, a stack of 2D sheets of graphene, the resistances perpendicular and parallel to the basal plane differ by three orders of magnitude [88]. In the study of Ti3C2Tx particles [76], the reported resistance anisotropy was also of about one order of magnitude. Moreover, the ratio strongly depends on the mechanical load (stretching or compressing) perpendicular to the basal plane, and comparable in- and out-ofplane resistances can be achieved when Ti3C2Tx layers were pressed to each other [76]. Overall, these results demonstrate a very good interflake conductance through the surface functional groups.
Transport measurements of monolayer flakes and bulk films even of the same material cannot be compared directly due to the presence of ions and water molecules in the interlayer spacings and the variability of stacking in multilayer particles. Furthermore, a pseudonegative compressibility in Ti3C2Tx clay samples was recently demonstrated [89]. When a mixture of MXene particles and water is quasi-hydrostatically compressed in a diamond anvil cell, Ti3C2Tx MXene expands along its crystallographic c direction, and this expansion persists after the pressure is released. Water molecules forcefully inserted between MXene layers remain trapped and affect transport properties of a bulk material. Thus, it is not surprising that the first conductivity measurements of MXene pressed pellets revealed orders of
16 Electronic and Mechanical Properties of MXenes Derived from Single-. . . 309
magnitude higher resistivity [51] than later observed for freestanding flakes [59, 60], see Table 16.1.
The application of an external electric field via the gate electrode changes the conductivity of a flake. As can be seen from Fig. 16.2d, IDS increases with VG, indicating that electrons are major charge carriers. The average Ti3C2Tx fieldeffect electron mobility (μFE) was found to be 2.6 ± 0.7 cm2/ V · s [59]. The distribution of the mobility values for MXene devices is rather narrow compared to other solution-processed 2D materials, such as monolayer rGO sheets [34] and nanoribbons [90], suggesting the structural uniformity of Ti3C2Tx flakes. While at room temperature the mobility is constant at the gate voltages ranging from −60 to 60 V, at temperatures below 200 K, it was shown to be VG dependent [60]. For a Ti3C2Tx device reported by Miranda et al., at VG > 18 V, the mobility was found to be 0.8 cm2/ V · s, while at VG < 18 V it abruptly changed to a lower value of μFE = 0.2 cm2/ V · s; this effect was associated with the multivalley band structure of Ti3C2Tx [60].
Miranda et al. also measured temperature dependence of the electrical conductivity of MXene flakes [60]. Figure 16.2e shows that the IDS–VDS curves obtained at 300 K and 2.5 K are qualitatively similar, although the currents are slightly smaller at the lower temperature. The inset in Fig. 16.2e shows the temperature dependence of the measured sheet resistances at VDS = 0.5 V. The resistance decreases with temperature reaching a minimum at about 250 K and then increases with further decrease in temperature, likely due to the contact resistance effects [60].

sections.heading: Comparison of Synthetic Approaches for MXenes
sections.text:
Electrical measurements of MXenes can also be used to compare efficiencies of different synthetic methods for preparing high-quality MXene materials. The methods for MXenes’ preparation are rapidly evolving, and a number of variations have been already reported for the synthesis of Ti3C2Tx [91]. Similarly to how charge carrier mobility became one of the metrics of graphene’s quality and is often reported to compare a certain method for graphene synthesis with other known approaches, electrical conductivities of individual MXene flakes can be used to compare efficiencies of the corresponding synthetic procedures.
In the following example, the electrical measurements of MXene flakes clearly differentiate between two methods for the synthesis of Ti3C2Tx (Fig. 16.3a). In one procedure (Route 1), which was originally reported by Ghudiu et al. [48], Ti3C2Tx was synthesized by immersing Ti3AlC2 powder into a LiF-HCl solution maintaining the molar ratio of LiF to MAX equal to 5:1. Previous studies have shown that this method primarily yields monolayer flakes [48]. In the modified procedure (Route 2), the molar ratio of LiF to MAX was increased to 7.5:1 to provide the excess of Li+ ions for intercalation, and the HCl to LiF ratio was doubled to facilitate etching of aluminum [59]. Other aspects of the original procedure remained identical, except
310 A. Lipatov and A. Sinitskii
no sonication was needed to delaminate Ti3C2Tx particles that were produced using Route 2 [59].
Microscopic characterization demonstrates drastic difference in the quality of Ti3C2Tx flakes produced by Routes 1 and 2 (Fig. 16.3b–g). As can be seen from scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and atomic force microscopy (AFM) images, the majority of the flakes produced by Route 1 are 200–500 nm in diameter (Fig. 16.1b), and despite their small size, some of the flakes are not completely exfoliated (Fig. 16.1c). Further characterization of the Route 1 Ti3C2Tx flakes by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) shows uneven edges decorated with tiny dark particles
16 Electronic and Mechanical Properties of MXenes Derived from Single-. . . 311
(Fig. 16.1d), which are likely composed of titanium dioxide [83]. TEM images also show that Ti3C2Tx flakes produced by Route 1 exhibit numerous pin holes (Fig. 16.1d). In contrast, Route 2 MXene flakes are substantially larger (4–15 μm in size; Fig. 16.1e) and well exfoliated, as can be seen from the AFM image in Fig. 16.1f, which shows that all Ti3C2Tx flakes are monolayers. While the nominal thickness of a Ti3C2Tx flake is about 1 nm, the increased AFM height (≈2.7 nm in Fig. 16.1f) is associated with the presence of surface adsorbates, such as water molecules, that are trapped under the Ti3C2Tx flake; similar effects have been previously reported for other 2D materials as well [55, 92–94]. AFM measurements of MXene flakes’ thickness will be discussed more in detail in section “Mechanical measurements of Ti3C2Tx flakes”. TEM analysis of Ti3C2Tx produced by Route 2 shows that the flakes have well-defined and clean edges and are visually hole-free (Fig. 16.1g). From this side-by-side comparison, it is clear that the modified synthesis procedure (Route 2) yields Ti3C2Tx flakes of visibly higher quality and larger size compared to the flakes produced using Route 1 [59]. This improvement could be attributed to the change in the composition of the etching solution, which facilitates both etching of aluminum and intercalation of lithium. As a result, multilayer Ti3C2Tx flakes can be delaminated to monolayer flakes by a manual shake, with no need for sonication that shreds flakes into smaller pieces [59].
Importantly, the microscopic characterization of the Ti3C2Tx flakes produced by Routes 1 and 2 (Fig. 16.3) correlates well with the results of electrical measurements. The metallic conductivity of the Route 2 Ti3C2Tx flakes is illustrated by Fig. 16.2a–d. However, similar devices produced from the Route 1 Ti3C2Tx flakes were not conductive [59]. These results demonstrate that electrical measurements can be used to compare quality of MXene flakes produced by different methods, and also that a thorough optimization of a synthetic procedure is important for manufacturing high-quality and environmentally stable flakes for electronic applications [59].

sections.heading: Environmental Stability and Oxidation Kinetics of Ti3C2Tx Monolayers
sections.text:
Another possible use of electrical measurements of individual flakes of MXenes is to study their environmental stability and oxidation kinetics. It was demonstrated that monolayer MXene flakes cannot sustain prolonged exposure to oxygen in presence of water [83] or at high temperature [84]. For instance, when a colloidal MXene solution in water is exposed to air, Ti3C2Tx flakes are completely oxidized within several days. This results in the solution’s color change from translucent black/brown to cloudy white, with a white precipitate of titania accumulating at the bottom of a vial. The following example shows that the kinetics of the environmental degradation of an individual Ti3C2Tx flake can be studied in situ by measuring the change of FET’s conductivity in air as a function of time [59]. Device measurements have been previously used to study kinetics of other reactions involving 2D materials, such as diazonium functionalization of graphene [95].
312 A. Lipatov and A. Sinitskii
Figure 16.4a shows the drain–source current in a Ti3C2Tx FET (Fig. 16.2a) that was measured every 10 sec while the device was exposed to air at room temperature and a relative humidity ~50% [59]. Black points at time (t) < 0 correspond to the readings in vacuum before the device was exposed to air. The readings are stable in vacuum but once the device is exposed to humid air, the IDS started to decrease (see red data points in Fig. 16.4), indicating degradation of a MXene flake. However, the IDS decreased by only 18.5% in the span of 70 h, suggesting that high-quality
16 Electronic and Mechanical Properties of MXenes Derived from Single-. . . 313
Ti3C2Tx flakes (Route 2) are reasonably stable in air even at a monolayer thickness [59]. The device conductivity change upon exposure to air suggests the potential of MXenes for sensing applications, which have been demonstrated in recent studies [66, 67]. Previously, a number of gas sensors have been fabricated using other 2D materials, such as graphene, rGO, and transition metal chalcogenides; which benefit from high surface-to-volume ratios and tunable electronic properties [42, 43, 97–101]. The remarkable chemical and structural diversity of MXenes and their rich surface chemistry [44, 102] make MXene devices very promising for sensing applications.
Although there have not been any detailed sensors studies of individual MXene flakes yet, some recent studies discussed tunable electronic properties of Ti3C2Tx films [66, 67]. While Fig. 16.4a shows the current decay in a Ti3C2Tx single-flake device exposed to air [59], Fig. 16.4b demonstrates a similar experiment performed on a Ti3C2Tx drop-casted film [96]. The figure compares the oxidation rates of a freshly prepared film and the film that was kept in Ar for 6 days prior to exposure to ambient. The apparent current decay rate was ~3 times higher for the freshly made sample compared to an Ar-dried film, indicating that the residual water molecules trapped between the flakes are detrimental for the stability of MXene films. These findings provide means to put the oxidation process under control or conversely utilize it to manufacture MXene–TiO2 composites [96].
It is interesting to note that the current decays in a vacuum-dried monolayer Ti3C2Tx exposed to air (Fig. 16.4a) much slower than in an Ar-dried Ti3C2Tx film (Fig. 16.4b). For example, after 25 h of measurements in air the conductivity of a monolayer flake decreased by 8.8% (Fig. 16.4a), while for a film it dropped by 62% (Fig. 16.4b). These observations are consistent with the established importance of residual water for MXene’s degradation, as it should be considerably easier to dry a monolayer flake than a thick film, from which water molecules intercalated between Ti3C2Tx sheets are difficult to remove due to the strong hydrogen bonding with the surface functional groups. Thus, these observations suggest that monolayer flakes could benefit from the improved environmental stability compared to bulk assemblies of MXene sheets.
While oxidation of MXenes is detrimental to their electrical conductivity, it could be purposefully used to engineer new functional properties. Figure 16.4c shows a reversible modulation of current measured in a Ti3C2Tx film under a UV light irradiation [96]. Since the pristine Ti3C2Tx MXene is metallic, the authors propose that the photoresponse is associated with the presence of TiO2 nanoparticles, which formed in Ti3C2Tx films due to oxidation (Fig. 16.4d), and the UV light induces electron transitions from the valence band or defect levels to the conduction band in TiO2 nanocrystals [96]. The slow decay of the photocurrent observed in Fig. 16.4c can be useful for applications in photoresistors and sensors with memory effect. The decay is very sensitive to the atmosphere: inert gases like argon and hydrogen do not affect the photocurrent relaxation after the UV excitation of a Ti3C2Tx-TiO2 composite film (Fig. 16.4e). However, oxygen, humid air, and water vapor significantly accelerate the photocurrent decay (Fig. 16.4f), with water species showing the most pronounced effect [96]. The conductivity photoresponse
314 A. Lipatov and A. Sinitskii
is reversible, opening possibilities for application of Ti3C2Tx-TiO2 thin films in optoelectronic and environmental sensing.
High electrical conductivity and 2D nature of Ti3C2Tx MXenes could be beneficial for gas sensing applications. Unlike pristine graphene, which is chemically inert and does not have any surface functionalities that could serve as binding sites for gas analytes, MXenes have a benefit of an extensive surface functionalization with chemically diverse moieties (see Fig. 16.4g). Kim et al. demonstrated that gas sensors made of Ti3C2Tx MXene with -OH and -F groups exhibit a very low detection limit of 50–100 ppb for volatile organic compounds at room temperature; see Fig. 16.4g for a gas response to different concentrations of acetone [66]. Gas analytes like acetone, ethanol, ammonia, and propanol at 100 ppb concentration produce high sensor responses of 0.97, 1.7, 0.8, and 0.88%, respectively, while the responses for NO2, SO2, and CO2 are significantly lower (Fig. 16.4h) [66]. These results suggest that Ti3C2Tx sensors have higher responses toward gases capable of hydrogen bonding and that the terminal –OH groups play an important role in the detection of the analytes. Interestingly, unlike 2D semiconductor-based sensors, the Ti3C2Tx sensors display a positive change of resistance for both oxidizing and reducing gases. An important advantage of metallic Ti3C2Tx devices for sensing is high currents and low noise in electrical measurements. Figure 16.4i shows a comparison of electrical noise measurements for different 2D channel materials in the inert N2 atmosphere. Calculated noise levels are approximately 1.5, 1.0, 0.02, and 0.005% for black phosphorus, MoS2, rGO, and Ti3C2Tx, respectively. As a result, Ti3C2Tx sensors exhibit signal-to-noise ratios that are two orders of magnitude higher than that of other 2D materials [66].
Mechanical Measurements of Ti3C2Tx Flakes
Single-flake measurements were paramount for the determination of the mechanical properties of 2D materials. Because of its Young’s modulus of about 1 TPa [10], graphene is widely regarded as the strongest material known, which makes it relevant for applications in structural composites, protective coatings, fibers, etc. [13, 14, 33]. The elastic moduli of mechanically exfoliated and CVD-grown transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), such as MoS2 and WS2, have also been measured and found to be about one third of that of graphene [103–105]. Among other 2D materials, only hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) showed mechanical characteristics approaching graphene [106]. However, it should be recognized that many of the record properties of graphene have been measured on small samples prepared by micromechanical exfoliation, a method relevant for fundamental studies, but not large-scale structural applications. Another limitation of pristine graphene is its poor solubility in conventional solvents, which complicates its processability and miscibility with other materials, such as polymers, for the preparation of composites.
In search of other 2D crystals with promising elastic characteristics, it is natural to consider transition metal carbides (TMCs) which exhibit exceptional bulk
16 Electronic and Mechanical Properties of MXenes Derived from Single-. . . 315
mechanical properties [107] and are now available in 2D form as MXenes. Several theoretical studies are available on mechanical properties of MXenes [108–112], predicting them to be stiffer than their MAX phase precursors [113] and bulk TMCs [107]. MXene paper and composites have been tested [75], but their properties are determined by weak interfaces.
Recently, we reported mechanical measurements of the elastic modulus and breaking strength of monolayer and bilayer Ti3C2Tx MXene flakes by the AFM indentation [62]. MXene flakes with lateral sizes up to 10 μm were synthesized by in situ HF etching of aluminum from Ti3AlC2, as described in Refs. [59, 91] (Route 2). These flakes can be deposited on a Si/SiO2 substrate with prefabricated 300- nm-deep microwells to produce very clean, tautly stretched Ti3C2Tx membranes (Fig. 16.5a). According to the AFM results, the MXene membranes are stretched across the openings and adhere to the well walls because of the attractive interaction between MXene flakes and SiO2 (see the AFM height profile in Fig. 16.5b). The step height at the edge of the flake shown in Fig. 16.5a is about 3.0 nm (Fig. 16.5c), which includes trapped water molecules between the flake and the substrate. This flake folds at its edge, which adds a layer with the thickness of 1.6 nm in noncontact AFM mode (Fig. 16.5c). While the procedure that we used for the synthesis of Ti3C2Tx provides monolayer flakes at high yields, we also found several suspended bilayer (2L) structures, which consisted of two monolayer flakes overlapping over a well.
Since the thickness of Ti3C2Tx monolayers is an important parameter for the analysis of the results of nanoindentation experiments, it is necessary to comment on the limitations of AFM for determination of thicknesses of monolayers of 2D materials. For example, while the nominal thickness of graphene is 0.335 nm, in various experiments the AFM measurements of monolayer graphene flakes produced thickness values in the range from 0.4 to 1.7 nm, as summarized in Ref. 114. This inaccuracy could be affected by a number of factors that include the AFM imaging mode (tapping, contact, etc.), tip–surface interactions, presence of various surface adsorbates, and trapped interfacial molecules, among others. Therefore, nominal rather than AFM-measured thicknesses were used in other works on mechanical indentation of 2D materials for calculations of mechanical characteristics [10, 103]. Here, likewise, AFM produced a largely overestimated thickness value of 1.6 nm, and for the Young’s modulus calculation, we instead used the thickness of a Ti3C2Tx monolayer of 0.98 nm, which was determined by atomically resolved TEM and supported by theoretical calculations [47, 87]. It should be pointed out that high-resolution TEM is a preferred method for the determination of the thickness of a Ti3C2Tx monolayer compared to X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. When Ti3C2Tx is produced in a bulk form, XRD could be used to determine the interlayer spacing between the MXene sheets; this spacing can vary considerably depending on the amount and chemical nature of species intercalated between the sheets [48]. However, in a monolayer Ti3C2Tx membrane there are no interlayer spacings with intercalated species, and similarly to AFM, the XRD measurements may overestimate the nominal thickness of a MXene monolayer.
316 A. Lipatov and A. Sinitskii
The scheme of the nanoindentation experiment is shown in Fig. 16.5d. The AFM tip was positioned over the center of a membrane and slowly moved downward, providing a controlled stretching of a MXene flake. Two to four cycles of loading and unloading were performed on the same MXene flake with an incremental loading increase of 50 nN (see the corresponding curves in Fig. 16.5e). The
16 Electronic and Mechanical Properties of MXenes Derived from Single-. . . 317
extension and retraction curves within each loading cycle as well as the curves for different loads retrace each other, indicating high elasticity of MXene flakes and that no flake detachment occurs during the measurements. The fracture of the 2L Ti3C2Tx membrane shown in Fig. 16.5e occurred at a load force of about 200 nN and a deflection of 38 nm. Even at the maximum deflection, the center of the membrane is far from the bottom of the well that is ≈300 nm deep. The AFM tip punctures the membrane leaving a small hole as seen in the top inset in Fig. 16.5e.
Figure 16.5f also shows representative force–deflection curves for 1L and 2L Ti3C2Tx membranes. Analysis of the force–deflection dependences using Poisson’s ratio of Ti3C2Tx, v = 0.227 [115], yielded for 1L MXene the E2D elasticity values ranging from 278 to 393 N/m with the average of 326 ± 29 N/m, while for 2L Ti3C2Tx flakes the E2D elasticity values ranged from 632 to 683 N/m with the average of 655 ± 19 N/m (Fig. 16.5g). Both 1L and 2L Ti3C2Tx membranes showed very narrow distributions of the experimental E2D values. The average E2D for 2L Ti3C2Tx membranes is exactly twice that determined for monolayer MXene flakes, suggesting a strong interaction between layers that is likely associated with the hydrogen bonding between the Ti3C2Tx surface groups. Similar effects were observed for overlapping GO membranes [38] and multilayer h-BN flakes [106], where a strong interaction between layers was caused by either hydrogen bonding or interlayer B–N interaction, respectively. In contrast, multilayer graphene exhibits lower E2D than expected from multiplying monolayer E2D by the number of layers due to weaker interlayer interaction and therefore a greater tendency of layers to slide relative to each other upon indentation [10, 106].
Suspended MXene membranes can be deformed elastically up to a certain stress when mechanical failure occurs. The fracture forces for monolayer MXene membranes ranged from 50 to 102 nN with an average value of Ff = 77 ± 15 nN. As shown in the inset in Fig. 16.5e, the fracture occurred in the center of a membrane where the stress was applied by the AFM tip.
Considering that graphene is a benchmark 2D material, it is interesting to compare the force–deflection curves for suspended Ti3C2Tx and graphene monolayers (Fig. 16.5h). The elasticity of graphene determined in work [62] was found to be 341 ± 28 N/m, which is very close to the previously reported values of 340 ± 50 N/m [10].
The effective Young’s modulus EYoung and breaking strength σmax can be calculated from E2D and σ 2Dmax, respectively, by dividing them by the membrane’s thickness. As we explained previously, for the Young’s modulus calculation, we used the nominal thickness of a Ti3C2Tx monolayer of 0.98 nm, which was obtained from high-resolution TEM analysis and theoretical calculations [47, 87]; the same approach was utilized in other works on indentation of 2D materials [10, 103]. The effective Young’s modulus for MXene membrane is 333 ± 30 GPa and the breaking strength is 17.3 ± 1.6 GPa (taking the average tip radius of 7 nm). It is interesting to note that according to the molecular dynamics simulations, Ti3C2 has a Young’s modulus of 502 GPa [109]. As expected, the experimentally determined value for Ti3C2Tx of 333 ± 30 GPa is lower because of surface functionalization and presence of defects. However, the difference in the Young’s moduli of the “ideal” Ti3C2 and
318 A. Lipatov and A. Sinitskii
the experimentally realized Ti3C2Tx is not as dramatic as in the case of graphene and GO (1050 GPa versus 210 GPa). This could be rationalized by the fact that surface functionalization has a stronger effect on the mechanical properties of oneatom-thick monolayer graphene compared to thicker Ti3C2Tx flakes.
Comparison of EYoung values for 1L Ti3C2Tx MXene and monolayers of other benchmark 2D materials is presented in Fig. 16.5i. At 330 ± 30 GPa, the effective Young’s modulus of Ti3C2Tx MXene exceeds the previously reported mean values for GO, rGO, and MoS2 that were produced in similar nanoindentation experiments [38, 40, 103], but is lower than those of h-BN and graphene [10, 106]. While the values for graphene, h-BN, and MoS2 were reported for defect-free flakes, the Ti3C2Tx MXene flakes tested here are solution processed. There is a potential to develop methods to synthesize Ti3C2Tx flakes of higher quality to reach a larger Young’s modulus closer to the theoretical value. Additionally, Ti3C2Tx is just one of more than twenty synthesized MXenes, and MXenes with a different number of atomic layers or a different transition metal may have higher elasticity. This study suggests great potential of MXenes for structural composites, protective coatings, nanoresonators, membranes, textiles, and other applications that require bulk quantities of solution-processable materials with exceptional mechanical properties.

sections.heading: Summary and Future Outlook
sections.text:
We reviewed recent experimental results on electrical and mechanical characterization of MXenes. First, we summarized the electrical measurements of bulk MXene assemblies and demonstrated that the results strongly depend not only on the MXene’s chemical composition and structure, but also on the form of assembly (a pressed disc, a filtered, spin-casted or sprayed film, a particle, etc.), as well as preparation and postprocessing methods and measurement conditions, which dictate the stacking and interflake resistances of individual MXene sheets. These results show the importance of single-flake measurements for revealing the intrinsic properties of various MXene materials and their comparison with each other.
Single-flake measurements have been imperative for revealing intrinsic physical properties of various 2D materials, starting with graphene. Importantly, they have been successfully applied to not only micromechanically exfoliated crystals but also solution-synthesized 2D materials, such as rGO, with which MXenes share many similarities. We discussed recent efforts on single-flake measurements of MXenes, which so far have been primarily focused on Ti3C2Tx.
Electrical measurements of individual Ti3C2Tx monolayers showed their high conductivity of 4600 ± 1100 S/cm, which is higher than previously reported for solution-processed graphene-based materials, and field-effect electron mobility of 2.6 ± 0.7 cm2/ V · s. These measurements were further proved to be useful for comparing the efficiencies of different synthetic methods for preparing high-quality
16 Electronic and Mechanical Properties of MXenes Derived from Single-. . . 319
MXene materials and investigating the environmental stability and kinetics of oxidation of Ti3C2Tx flakes in humid air. Interestingly, the data suggest that highquality monolayer Ti3C2Tx flakes benefit from the improved environmental stability compared to bulk assemblies of MXene sheets as they could be more efficiently dried from water, which promotes the air oxidation of Ti3C2Tx.
Mechanical measurements of Ti3C2Tx monolayers revealed their high Young’s modulus of 330 ± 30 GPa, which is currently the highest value measured in nanoindentation experiments of solution-processed 2D materials. These results demonstrate great potential of Ti3C2Tx for applications in mechanically reinforced composites, protective coatings, and nanoresonators.
These examples demonstrate the importance of single-flake physical measurements, which will expand our understanding of MXenes and broaden the already impressive range of their potential applications. They should encourage thorough single-flake measurements of other members of the very broad family of MXene materials. Also, as the methods for MXene synthesis will advance, the researchers should get access to MXene flakes with well-controlled surface functionalization, and for such samples single-flake measurements will be crucial to determine the effects of specific functional groups on MXene’s properties. In particular, it would be interesting to compare electrical and mechanical properties of Ti3C2Tx with different surface moieties and, ultimately, without functionalization. For example, in the extensively discussed Ti3C2Tx monolayers a considerable fraction of the nominal thickness of 0.98 nm is occupied by the surface functionalities [87], such as –F and –OH, and thinner flakes of pristine Ti3C2 are expected to have a Young’s modulus approaching the theoretically predicted value of 502 GPa [109]. Monolayer MXene samples without surface functionalization may become available through advancements in solution chemistries or development of CVD methods, which have been recently demonstrated to yield few-layered samples of Mo2C and may be eventually extended to thinner crystals and other transition metal carbides [116].

sections.heading: Krishnakali Chaudhuri, Zhuoxian Wang, Mohamed Alhabeb, Kathleen Maleski, Yury Gogotsi, Vladimir Shalaev, and Alexandra Boltasseva
Optical Properties of 2D Materials
sections.text:
Ever since the discovery of graphene in 2004 [1], the family of two-dimensional (2D) materials has grown steadily. Beyond graphene, transition metal dichalcogenides, commonly known as TMDs or TMDCs (such as MoS2, WS2, WSe2, MoTe2, etc.) [2], and phosphorene or black phosphorus [3] are particularly notable. Each of these materials exhibits unique characteristics that are reflected in their unusual mechanical, electronic, and optical properties. In a single- to few-layer form, they support distinctly strong light-matter interactions, which can be used as a tool to probe unusual physical processes in such condensed matter systems [4]. Many 2D materials and their heterostructures are excellent candidates for low power, electrically switchable electronic [5], and optical devices [6]. In addition, they provide an excellent platform to enhance light-matter interactions through effective integration with nanophotonic structures and inherent polaritonic resonances [6].
Graphene contains a single layer of SP2-hybridized carbon atoms arranged in a plane in a honeycomb lattice structure. Each “C” atom contains an extra electron in the pz orbital. The orbitals of adjacent atoms overlap and interact giving rise to bonding and antibonding states and the corresponding π-bands in graphene [7]. This results in the linear energy-momentum relation experienced by electrons in graphene. Thus, they behave as massless Dirac fermions [7, 8], leading to a variety

M. Alhabeb · K. Maleski · Y. Gogotsi Department of Materials Science and Engineering and A.J. Drexel Nanomaterials Institute, Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA, USA
© Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2019 B. Anasori, Y. Gogotsi (eds.), 2D Metal Carbides and Nitrides (MXenes), https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-19026-2_17
327
328 K. Chaudhuri et al.
of interesting transport and optical phenomena [4, 9]. Linearly dispersive Dirac electrons can interact with a broad bandwidth of photon energies [10] strengthening the potential of the material for many optical applications. The Pauli blocking principle leads to a strong saturable absorption [11] and a strong luminescence that can be created and modulated externally [12, 13]. The transmittance of graphene is a function of its fine-structure constant [14], which makes it naturally visible [15] although it is only a fraction of a nanometer thick.
Monolayer transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDC) consist of a single layer of transition metal atoms placed with a layer of chalcogen atoms on either side, placed in a trigonal prismatic structure. Bulk TMDs are indirect bandgap semiconductors, while the monolayers exhibit a direct bandgap lying in the near-infrared (IR) and visible spectral regions. In addition to a broken in-plane inversion symmetry [16], TMDs exhibit tightly bound room temperature-stable excitons [17–19] and spinand valley-selective electronic and optical properties [16, 20]. Broken inversion symmetry allows strong nonlinear optical processes such as second harmonic generation (SHG), third harmonic generation (THG), and saturable absorption to exist within the body of ultrathin layers of TMDs [21–23]. Planar photonic and plasmonics are coupled to the strong excitonic systems to realize unique exciton polaritons [24], ultrathin gain material for lasing [25], and even single-photon emitters [26].
More recently, black phosphorus (BP) was reintroduced to the optics and electronics community as an anisotropic 2D material [3, 27]. The layer-dependent direct bandgap of BP ranges from 0.3 eV in bulk to 1.5 eV in monolayer form. This bandgap falls in between the gapless graphene and large gap TMDs establishing it as an excellent material platform for near- and mid-IR optics and optoelectronics. Unlike graphene, it has an orthorhombic crystal structure consisting of puckered layers of phosphorus atoms [28]. This also exhibits an anisotropic electronic and optical response with respect to the armchair and zigzag direction of the lattice. The structural anisotropy extends itself to unique anisotropic excitons, electron mobility, optical absorption, thermal conductivity, and plasmons [29–33]. The bandgap, the exciton binding energies, optical absorption spectrum, and linear polarization energy window can be tuned widely by changing the number of layers in a stack of BP. In addition, likewise to other 2D materials, BP exhibits strong saturable absorption-type nonlinearity [34–36].
MXenes are a relatively new addition to this exciting class of 2D materials which have drawn a great amount of interest due to their tunable properties and wide range of applications [37]. Although discovered 7 years ago, synthesis and isolation of single- to few-layer flakes of MXene are extensively studied and are shown to be scalable, tunable, and processable into variety of solvents in comparison to other extensively studied 2D materials [38] (also see Chap. 5). More than 60 MXene compositions have been predicted with over 20 experimentally synthesized, making them among the fastest growing and the most diverse 2D materials [39]. MXenes with high electrical conductivity [39] have been explored explored in a variety of applications including transparent electrodes [40], metal ion batteries [41], supercapacitors [42–44], and electromagnetic interference shielding [45, 46].
17 Optical Properties of MXenes 329
Utilizing the optical properties of MXenes, other applications such as effective light to heat conversion [47], saturable absorption for mode-locked lasing [48], surfaceenhance Raman scattering (SERS) [49, 50], plasmonic broadband absorber [51], and photonic diodes [52] have also been demonstrated. However, the most studied MXene, titanium carbide, Ti3C2Tx, has been the material of choice for most of all these studies and optical properties of other MXenes are yet to be investigated.
In this chapter, we will overview the theoretical and experimental approaches to study optical properties of MXenes, and discuss some of the optical device demonstrations based on MXenes.

sections.heading: Theoretical Predictions of Electronic and Optical Properties of MXenes
sections.text:
In the last decade, a number of groups have focused on the understanding of the physical behaviors of MXenes with the intention integrating them into nanoscale devices [53]. In particular, MXene compounds with Tin + 1Xn (X = C, N and n = 1, 2) were studied extensively in both theory and experiments to understand and predict the characteristics with changing elements, lattice structures, and surface functionalization groups (fluorinated or hydroxylated derivatives). Optical response of materials is intricately related to its structural as well as electronic properties, e.g., band-to-band electronic transitions result in enhanced optical absorption at certain frequencies. Theoretical framework can provide a complete understanding of such potential mechanisms behind material optical response and can also predict behavior of other similar systems. This is particularly useful for the rapidly growing family of synthesized MXenes.
H. Lashgari et al. have used density functional theory formulation to calculate the density of states (DOS) and band structures, which is used to predict respective optical behavior of single MXene sheet [54]. Electronic properties confirm the metallic nature of most Tin + 1Xn MXenes with their valence and conduction bands overlapping with the Fermi level. The 3D orbital of the Ti in Tin + 1Xn MXenes contributes largely to the metallicity near the Fermi level.
H. Lashgari et al. made use of the full-potential linearized augmented plane wave (FP-LAPW) method [55] and random phase approximation (RPA) formalism [56] to calculate the optical response (complex dielectric function (ε), reflection, absorption, and electron energy loss function) of the two-dimensional Tin + 1Xn MXene compounds such as Ti2C, Ti2N, Ti3C2, and Ti3N2. The imaginary part of the dielectric function, Im ε, is calculated as

Monolayers of Tin + 1Xn (X = C, N and n = 1, 2) contain a hexagonal space group symmetry with three atoms for Ti2X and five for Ti3X2. Due to this symmetry, under the excitation of an electric field parallel (E||x) and perpendicular (E||z) to the c-axis, the complex dielectric function (ε) tensor has only three nonzero components εxx(ω) = εyy(ω) and εzz(ω). Figure 17.1a plots the corresponding dielectric tensors. The peaks in the Im ε has direct contributions from the different inter- and intraband electronic transitions. The real part of the ε, Re ε, is then obtained using the the Kramers-Kronig relations [57, 58], shown in Fig. 17.1a- inset. With the knowledge of the frequency-dependent complex dielectric function, other important optical parameters such as the reflection and absorption can be calculated. The absorption spectrum (A) is proportional to the total contribution of interband transitions from filled valence band states to empty conduction band levels (Fig. 17.1b).
17 Optical Properties of MXenes 331
The outermost transition metal atoms of a single layer of MXene were experimentally found to be passivated by functional groups, such as –F, -O, and –OH, due to the synthesis processes as described in Chap. 5. Recent studies have shown that the surface functionalization can largely affect both structural and electronic properties of MXenes [59–61]. It has also been demonstrated that specific attributes of the MXene properties (electron transport, capacitance, etc.) can be tailored by tuning the surface functional groups. A recent work by G. Berdiyorov discussed the effect of the functionalization on the optical properties of Ti3C2T2 MXene, where “T” represents a surface functional group (either –F, -O, or –OH), using computational methods [62]. Here, the susceptibility tensor χ (ω) of the MXene monolayer system is calculated using the well-known Kubo-Greenwood formula [63], often used to calculate electronic conductivity in materials. The frequencydependent complex dielectric properties of the material system are derived from the electric susceptibility as ε (ω) = Re ε + Im ε = 1 + χ (ω).
Real and imaginary parts of the frequency-dependent dielectric functions were calculated and compared for the experimentally shown functional groups, Ti3C2F2, Ti3C2(OH)2, Ti3C2O2, and pristine Ti3C2 in Fig. 17.2a, c. Considerable variation in the dielectric functions is noted with the variation of the functional groups and spectral range of interest. Using the dielectric functions, the frequency-dependent refractive index, n, and extinction coefficient, k, and absorption spectra have been calculated for Ti3C2T2 (shown in Fig. 17.2b, d). Significant differences between functional groups were observed in the absorption spectra, particularly in the lower photon energy regime, showing the importance of how the surface groups impact eventual properties. The peaks observed agree well with the various inter- and intraband transitions obtained through density functional theory (DFT) predictions reported previously [54, 60].
