sections.heading: MXenes for Plasmonics: Theory and Experiments
sections.text:
MXenes initially were evaluated largely for energy storage applications owing to their 2D structure and ion intercalation properties. However, the growing family of materials is gaining significant attention from the optics and optoelectronics community as well due to their high metallic conductivity [64] and large transmissivity [65] in single- to a few-layer form. This has led to the exploration of MXene-based transparent electrodes [40, 65], photothermal therapy (PTT) [66, 67], and effective electromagnetic interference shielding [45]. More recently, other interesting attributes such as plasmonic properties [51, 64] and large nonlinearities [48, 68] have been observed and implemented in various experimental devices.
Here, we will be focusing largely on the most well-studied MXene, Ti3C2. It shows high metallic conductivity, down to a single monolayer, and has been investigated for bulk and surface plasmons. Plasmons are collective electron oscillations formed of light-matter interaction [69]. Surface plasmons (SP) are electron oscillations that exist at a metal-dielectric interface at the surface of the metal, whereas bulk plasmons (BP) can form deeper within the body of a free carrier containing system [70].
In early investigations of plasmons in Ti3C2 MXene, theoretical and experimental measurements of the electron energy loss function were used. Following the formalism discussed in section 4.2.2, H. Lashgari et al. calculated the electron energy loss function for a single layer of pristine Ti3C2 MXene as in Fig. 17.3a [54]. The interaction of a fast moving electron through a solid may experience an energy loss through mechanisms such as band transitions (inter- and intra-) or excitation of plasmons. The contribution of such interactions can be identified by utilizing electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS). V. Mauchamp et al. experimentally
17 Optical Properties of MXenes 333
measured the high-resolution electron energy loss spectra (HREELS) in the energy range of 0.2–30 eV along with an ab initio theoretical framework to demonstrate detectable SPs in nanoscale MXene systems [71]. Results from their calculations are summarized in Fig. 17.3b. Electron energy loss spectra (EELS) was obtained for Ti3C2T2 MXene, with nanoscale multilayered sheets with thickness ranging from 5 nm to 45 nm. The EELS spectra were compared both experimentally and theoretically. In calculations, the surface functionalization (“T”) is assumed to be either exclusively −OH or −F; however, it should be noted that −OH, −O, and −F terminations can be present on the surface of the material as hydrofluoric etching techniques were used. Strong SP modes are observed at very low energy (less than 10 eV) range.
As the thickness of multilayered MXene is decreased, reduction in the BP strength is observed, while the intensity of the SP increases significantly (Fig. 17.3b). At low thicknesses, contribution of the surface terms in the total cross section increases, enhancing the SP intensity as shown in Fig. 17.3b (right). The bulk plasmon appears at a much higher energy at which the contribution of the surface terms becomes negligible. In addition, the BP energy (or peak position) is independent of the thickness and the number of MXene layers in a stack as shown in Fig. 17.3b (left). This can be explained by weak interlayer coupling that exists between neighboring layers in a few-layer-thick multilayer Ti3C2T2 stack. In contrast to other 2D materials, such as graphene, h-BN, or TMDs, with increasing layer thickness, electronic band structure and valence band electron densities are modified, resulting in considerable spectral shifts in the BP energy (peak position) [72].
Experiments reveal the dominance of SP contribution over the BP counterpart for Ti3C2T2 thicknesses up to 45 nm or approximately 45 single-layer sheets of Ti3C2
334 K. Chaudhuri et al.
(assuming each Ti3C2T2 layer is ~1 nm). This observation is in contrast to other plasmonic metals, such as aluminum or gold, where the SP vanishes for thicknesses greater than 30 nm, suggesting metallic Ti3C2 exhibits different optical properties in comparison to aluminum or gold [73, 74]. The small value of the SP damping factor (extracted from the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the Gaussian peak fitted to the SP peak in Fig. 17.4a, c), weak interlayer coupling, and lower probability of low-energy SP decay into higher-energy interband transition channels lead to a reduction in bulk plasmon excitation probability and, in turn, a SP dominance in the Ti3C2T2 system (Fig. 17.4b). Thus, SP resonances in MXene can be tuned by altering the electronic structure while controlling the thickness. Electronic band structure of Ti3C2T2 MXene can be modified by the surface functionalization groups “T” added during the synthesis process. Changing the functionalization from –OH to –F, the peak of the interband transition can be frequency shifted, allowing existence of higher-energy SPs.
Another study has revealed that the strongly metallic and plasmonic behavior is retained in Ti3C2Tx MXene thin films as well, in contrast to measuring on multilayered stacks of MXene. The films are made of overlapping arrangements of individual single-layer sheets [64]. The experimentally retrieved complex dielectric functions have shown a dielectric to metallic crossover (Re ε falls below 0) at a wavelength of ~1130 nm for MXene films of varying thicknesses (Fig. 17.5a). This further corroborates earlier findings that surface plasmon polaritons (SPP) can be excited in the multilayered MXene at near- to mid- IR frequencies.
More recently, MXene films of much higher thickness (~400 nm) have been used as building blocks of plasmonic metamaterial devices. The spectral dependence of the real and imaginary parts of the dielectric function (ε) were measured (using a variable angle spectroscopic ellipsometer) for the spin-coated Ti3C2Tx films. A dielectric to metallic crossover at ~1.07 μm indicates plasmonic behavior at near-
17 Optical Properties of MXenes 335
and mid-IR for MXene film thicknesses up to 400 nm [51]. Using a Drude-Lorentz model, optical parameters are extracted (shown in Fig. 17.5b). Optical properties of the thicker MXene films are qualitatively similar to the previously discussed thinner MXene films [64]. Large Im ε or optical losses in the films are attributed in parts to the intrinsic absorption due to interband transitions (at ~5.36 eV (0.23 μm) and ~1.54 eV (0.8 μm)) [54] and to losses stemming from surface roughness and bulk disorder-related scattering of carriers.

sections.heading: Metamaterial Absorber, Mode-Locked Laser, PTT, and Others
sections.text:
So far, there are a handful of experimental demonstrations of optics devices with MXenes. The notable ones include a plasmonic absorber with nanostructured MXenes, mode-locked laser using MXene saturable absorber, and surface-enhanced Raman scattering substrates using MXene sheets.
Plasmonic resonances in nanostructured Ti3C2Tx MXene have been used to create a simple and easy-to-fabricate metamaterial absorber device [75]. Large absorption over a broad bandwidth (~1.55 μm), covering a significant portion of visible to near-IR spectral window, was obtained by utilizing both the large intrinsic optical absorption and the scattering enhancement of plasmonic resonances of nanostructured Ti3C2Tx at longer wavelengths. Optical scattering characteristics of the Ti3C2Tx nanostructures are evaluated using full-wave three-dimensional (3D) finite element method (FEM) simulations. The optical parameters (transmission, T, and reflection, R) as a function of the wavelength are calculated for Ti3C2Tx MXene
336 K. Chaudhuri et al.
disk/pillar arrays on a glass substrate with varying diameters and thicknesses (Fig. 17.6a). Signature of strong localized surface plasmon (LSP) resonance is observed at ~1.26 μm wavelength for disk diameter (d) of 450 nm, thickness (t) of 400 nm, and periodic spacing (P) of 600 nm (shown in cross-sectional electric field maps in Fig. 17.6c). MXene resonators have dielectric like optical properties at higher energies and exhibit signs of weak photonic resonance modes at certain conditions as well. Deeper into near-IR, beyond ~1.8 μm, Ti3C2Tx MXene is more Drude-type metallic and reflects most of the incident photons.
Losses inherent to the multilayered Ti3C2Tx and existence of LSP resonances in nanostructures make Ti3C2 a suitable candidate for an absorber metamaterial. The absorption (A = 1-T-R) characteristic of a large area array of Ti3C2Tx nanodisks is simulated and plotted as a function of the incident excitation wavelength (λ) in Fig. 17.6b. Structural parameters were optimized to obtain maximum absorption efficiency and bandwidth. An array of Ti3C2Tx disks with d = 450 nm, P = 600 nm, and t = 400 nm sitting on a glass substrate absorbs ~85% of the incident light across 0.4–1.4 μm bandwidth (blue curve in Fig. 17.6b). Absorption in the visible and very near-IR is reported to be originating largely from the inter- and intraband
17 Optical Properties of MXenes 337
transitions of electrons [54, 71]. At longer wavelengths, plasmonic resonance aids increased the scattering cross section. Together, these two phenomena create a high absorption efficiency over a large spectral window. The absorption in the patterned disk array shows significant improvement (~2.5 times at ~1.5 μm) when compared to an unpatterned film of similar thickness (Fig. 17.6b).
Combining MXene with other conventional/well-known plasmonic material components to improve and augment performance has also been explored. An addition of a thin mirror (Au) and dielectric spacer layer (Al2O3) underneath the MXene disk array further enhanced the absorber performance (green curve in Fig. 17.6b). The schematic of a unit cell is shown in Fig. 17.6d (left). The geometrical configuration supported a gap surface plasmon (GSP) resonance that created a strong field confinement in the alumina (Al2O3) spacer layer (crosssectional electric field map in Fig. 17.6d (right)) (at λ ~1.85 μm in this structure) [76]. This mode is formed when a resonator is placed close to metal surface but separated by a nanoscale gap (in a practical scenario, a dielectric spacer layer) [77]. Interaction of SPs on the two adjacent dielectric-metal interfaces and efficient reflection from the ends of the finite dimension resonator on the top surface results into this resonance [78]. This GSP mode attribute can be tuned by the optical properties and thickness of the spacer dielectric, as well as the properties of the top MXene resonator. Optimizing the extended parameter space of this layered hybrid geometry, >90% absorption for incident radiation bandwidth of ~1.55 μm (green curve in Fig. 17.6b) is obtained.
Optical scattering parameters, e.g., reflection (R) and transmission (T) spectra of the fabricated Ti3C2Tx MXene-based absorber devices, are experimentally measured at different incident angles (20 ◦ –80 ◦ ) and both orthogonal polarizations (TM and TE) (Fig. 17.7a–d). Greater than 80% absorption (A) (calculated as A = 1- T-R) efficiency over 0.4 μm to 1.3 μm is observed for the Ti3C2Tx disk array on glass (blue curve in Fig. 17.7c). For the hybrid design (Fig. 17.6d), similar large absorption (~85%–90%) is obtained, but in addition, the bandwidth is stretched further to ~1.55 μm (green curve in Fig. 17.7c). As compared to an unpatterned MXene film, significant enhancement of absorption throughout the entire bandwidth of operation is demonstrated experimentally. A good qualitative agreement between the experimentally measured curves (~2 times improvement in absorption in the Ti3C2Tx disk array on Au/alumina over an unpatterned film of similar thickness (t) at λ ~ 1.6 μm) with the ones obtained through simulation (Fig. 17.6b) is apparent. The angular dependence of the absorption spectra was recorded for both orthogonal polarizations. The measured absorption spectra for both TE- and TM-polarized excitation match almost perfectly for low incident angles (< ~40◦) as shown in Fig. 17.7d. Large absorption efficiency over the entire bandwidth of interest was maintained for incident angles ranging from 0 ◦ to 65 ◦ in case of TE-polarized incident light (shown in Fig. 17.7e) [51]. In addition to the plasmonic resonances, another significant optical property of 2D MXenes is their large nonlinearities which enable applications in laser science. Controllable optical nonlinearities in different types of materials have led to many interesting phenomena such as second harmonic generation, Kerr
338 K. Chaudhuri et al.
effect, optical rectification, four-wave mixing, saturable absorption, etc [79]. Many of these play crucial roles in the development of ultracompact, high-power, and ultrafast femtosecond pulsed laser sources. Femtosecond lasers are of critical importance in field such as advanced micromachining, molecular, chemical, and optical spectroscopy techniques, as well as in information processing. In the past few decades, the development of ultrafast lasers has had tremendous impact on industry and research alike.
Saturable absorber is one of the key building block of lasers generating highpower, ultranarrow pulses using Q-switching and/or mode-locking methods. In saturable absorbers, the light absorption is modulated with the intensity of the impinged light as α(I) = α0
(1+I/Is) , where α0 is the linear absorption coefficient, I is the incident intensity and Is is the saturation intensity (defined as the incident intensity at which the absorption coefficient is half of the linear absorption coefficient
17 Optical Properties of MXenes 339
α0/2. Maximum modulation of absorption coefficient at a specific wavelength of incident radiation for a saturable absorber is termed as the modulation depth. Several 2D materials display outstanding saturable absorption behavior, e.g., increased modulation depth and fast recovery time, and can be beneficial for mode-locking, Q-switching, and pulse shaping in ultracompact lasers.
Recently, researchers have reported strong saturable absorption behavior in 2D MXenes as well. This was first reported for Ti3CNTx MXene by Y. Jhon et al. (schematic of molecular structure of Ti3CNTx is shown in Fig. 17.8a) [48]. A mode-locked femtosecond fiber-based ring cavity laser was implemented, with a Ti3CNTx MXene stack as a saturable absorber. The generated pulse widths are comparable to the best reported TMD-based saturable absorbers in lasers [48] (Fig. 17.8b). Ti3C2Tx MXene has also been studied for its broadband, nonlinear optical response in the near-IR regime (between 800 and 1800 nm), measured using Zscan measurement technique by X. Jiang et al. (Fig. 17.8c) [68]. The maximum nonlinear coefficient is found to be on the order of 10−21 m2/V2, comparable
340 K. Chaudhuri et al.
or even exceeding in magnitude to the values reported for other 2D materials. The calculated effective nonlinear optical absorption coefficient of Ti3C2Tx is two orders of magnitude higher than MoS2 and black phosphorus, indicating an efficient optical switching ability. Peak saturation intensity is extracted to be at a few tens of GW/cm2 for the near-IR spectral range. High-intensity illumination-induced nonlinear refractive index for Ti3C2Tx MXene, measured using an open aperture Z-scan, is also comparable in magnitude (~ −1020 m2/W for the near-IR spectral window) to previous reports on graphene (Fig. 17.8d). When implemented in a fiber-based cavity, the Ti3C2Tx MXene- based saturable absorber generates modelocked, ultrashort (159 fs) duration pulses. The fundamental origin and thickness dependence of the saturable absorption behavior of Ti3C2Tx MXene are further studied by Y. Dong et al. [52]. Open aperture Z-scan measurements on MXene films of varying thickness (5–100 nm) revealed thickness dependence of the modulation depth. This arises from the plasmon-induced increase in absorption at incident energies above the dielectric to metallic crossover frequency after which the free carrier oscillation becomes more favorable. A maximum modulation depth of 50% is measured at incident intensity of 70 mJ/cm2 for a 67-nm-thick Ti3C2Tx MXene, indicating a higher damage threshold than other 2D materials. A Ti3C2Tx MXenebased photonic diode that achieves nonreciprocal transmission of nanosecond laser pulses is demonstrated [52].
Apart from strong plasmonic resonances and nonlinear behavior, MXenes also exhibit a large optical transparency window and strong surface sensitive optical characters. Large transmission coefficient of few-layer stacks of metallic MXenes is promising for applications as transparent electrode materials [40, 65]. The ability to dynamically modulate the transmittance of MXene films by chemical intercalation method enables adaptive device designs [65]. On the other hand, the surface plays a crucial role in determining optical properties (including characteristics of surface plasmons) of 2D MXene (see also section “Theoretical Predictions of Electronic and Optical Properties of MXenes”) making them utile for sensing applications. This has led to demonstration of effective surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) substrates based on MXene sheets either in pristine or in specially synthesized nanoparticle-hybridized form [49, 50].
Recently, MXenes have been identified for their efficient and tailorable photothermal conversion property and as potential candidates for biomedical applications of photothermal therapy or PTT. In the past, many inorganic substances including plasmonic nanoparticles [80], carbon-based nanomaterials [81], and other 2D materials graphene [82], MoS2 [83], WS2 [84], etc. have been investigated as novel photothermal agents for cancer therapy. And recently, MXene ceramics (such as Ti3C2, Ta4C3, and Nb2C) have demonstrated extraordinarily high efficiency of converting light to heat energy in ultrathin 2D nanosheets [66, 67, 85]. Large absorption of electromagnetic energy in the NIR bio window I (750–1000 nm) and II (1000–1350 nm) causing local hyperthermia can be utilized in vivo and in vitro that can lead to thermal ablation of affected tumor tissue. As an added benefit, MXenes can be synthesized and surface modified to be photothermally stable as well as stable and nontoxic in physiological environment containing many bodily fluids [67, 85].
17 Optical Properties of MXenes 341

sections.heading: Conclusions and Outlook
sections.text:
This chapter provides an overview of the recent advances in the field of 2D MXenes for optics and nanophotonics. The unique optical properties of MXenes have enabled fascinating applications such as ultrafast laser pulse generation, broadband absorber, and SERS. We have placed emphasis on the plasmonic properties of Ti3C2Tx MXenes which enables plasmonic device designs in the near-IR. Although demonstrations of new device concepts have shown the potential of 2D MXenes for optical applications, many challenges remain to be overcome and new opportunities should be explored.
One of the main challenges for nanophotonic and plasmonic applications of MXenes is to develop a solid understanding of the optical properties of MXenes, especially the dielectric functions of single- to few-layer MXenes. Even though there have been reports on the band diagrams and the optical properties of monolayer MXenes through density functional theory (DFT) simulations [54, 60, 62], the results are yet to be verified by experimental measurements. This requires fabrication of uniform single- to few-layer MXene films on a large area. Improvements in the optical stability of MXenes flakes, especially for colloidal solutions and single- to few-layer films, are another great challenge. It has been shown that the environmental and chemical stability of single MXene flakes is dependent on the synthesis and processing method, where the overall stability of single flakes in air can be improved from hours to several days [39, 86]. Nevertheless, highly stabilized MXene flakes in longer time periods will provide more reliable device performance.
The recent reports on the large nonlinear response and plasmonic behavior of Ti3C2Tx MXene films bring with it further exciting opportunities to explore other members of the MXene family. Even though large nonlinear optical response of MXene films has been observed in a broad wavelength range with z-scan experiments [68], the time dynamics and source of the nonlinearity haven’t been studied yet. Carrying out pump-probe experiments could provide us a deep understanding of the nonlinear process in MXene films [87]. Second, in addition to ultrafast laser pulse generation, MXenes could improve the figures of merit of another important type of laser source, random lasers. It has been theoretically predicted that the exotic optical response of 2D materials could offer new avenues to control random lasers due to the extraordinarily low threshold for saturable absorption [88]. The colloidal solution of single- to few-layer MXene serves as a perfect candidate for the experimental demonstration due to its ease of fabrication [89]. And lastly, due to the larger carrier density, Ti3C2Tx MXene shows plasmonic behavior in the nearIR. This provides the material platform for abundant plasmonic device designs in addition to perfect metamaterial absorber. Overall, considering the multifaceted nature of MXene family and their highly electronic/optical tunability, MXenes have a great potential to be used in nonlinear photonics, optoelectronics, and plasmonics.
342 K. Chaudhuri et al.

sections.heading: Electrode Materials
sections.text:
Electrochemical capacitors, also known as supercapacitors (SCs), are energy storage devices which store energy through (I) electrosorption of charge carrier ions on porous carbon electrode surface – termed as electrical double layer capacitors (EDCLs), as illustrated in Fig. 18.1a, b – and (II) electrode surface or near surface redox reaction/intercalation, termed as pseudocapacitive charge storage, as presented in Fig. 18.1c, d, respectively. Typically, SC electrodes are characterized by rectangular cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves (Fig. 18.1e) and linear galvanostatic charge-discharge plots (Fig. 18.1g), which are different from battery materials that are known to have sharp redox peaks in their CVs and obvious plateaus in their charge-discharge plots, as presented in Fig. 18.1f, h, respectively [1].
Performance of SCs is characterized by their energy (W, Joules, but usually expressed in Watt hours) and power (P, Watts). For EDCLs, the energy is given by the equation:
W = 1 2 × 3600C × V 2 (18.1)

This set of equations is only applicable to systems that show linear chargedischarge and rectangular cyclic voltammetry (CV) electrochemical signatures, i.e., when the charge Q (A.s) changes linearly with the potential. Most commonly, the discharged energy is obtained by integrating the potential V (in V) and the current I (in A) during the discharge time t (h) (Eq. 18.3):
W = ∫ V (t)I (t)dt (18.3)
And the power is the product of the voltage multiplied by the current (Eq. 18.4):

18 MXenes for Supercapacitor Application 351
The energy and power values are usually normalized by the weight or volume of the device, or the electrode (it is very important to distinguish between those), to obtain energy and power densities.
Thanks to the highly reversible and fast process of ion electrosorption, EDLCs can deliver high power densities (5–20 kW/kg) with long life spans (>10 years), but EDLCs are limited by energy density (1–10 Wh/kg) when compared to batteries (≈250 Wh/kg). Porous carbon electrodes with high specific surface area (SSA) in the range of 1000–2000 m2 g−1, such as activated carbons, are the materials of choice for EDLCs; these carbons can achieve capacitances up to 150–200 F g−1 and 50–100 F cm−3 in aqueous or nonaqueous electrolytes, respectively. By introducing fast, surface-confined redox reactions, pseudocapacitive materials can provide higher energy density, but this is generally achieved at the expense of the cyclability. Conventional pseudocapacitive materials include – but are not limited to – MnO2, RuO2, and Nb2O5, with capacitance values beyond 500 F g−1. However, they are limited either by the high cost, toxicity, poor conductivity, or electrochemical stability of the materials. Therefore, developing novel electrode materials with superior electrical conductivity, high specific surface area (SSA), and/or involving fast redox reaction/intercalation, combined with attractive costs of production that are free of environmental constraints, are needed.

sections.heading: Electrolytes
sections.text:
Beside active materials, the electrolyte is another key component of supercapacitor devices. Typically, electrolytes are categorized into (i) aqueous electrolytes, (ii) nonaqueous electrolytes, and (iii) ionic liquid electrolytes. Aqueous electrolytes – using water as the solvent – are characterized by high ion mobility (up to 100 mS/cm for concentrated acid or base), low viscosity, and low cost; however, the main drawback is the limited electrochemical stability of water which results in a narrow operational potential window of 1.23 V (from thermodynamics). Although some kinetic overvoltage can push this value to 1.5 V, Eq. (18.1) shows that a limited voltage window will translate into a low energy density at the device level. In contrast, nonaqueous or organic electrolytes mainly use acetonitrile (ACN) or propylene carbonate (PC) as solvents. Despite having lower ion mobility, higher viscosity and cost compared to aqueous electrolytes, larger voltage windows up to 3 V can be achieved, which make organic electrolytes very competitive for practical applications. Room-temperature ionic liquids (RTILs) are solvent-free electrolytes that are made up of salts that are liquids at room temperature, thanks to their high melting points [6]. RTIL electrolytes can achieve high electrochemical and chemical stability, thanks to the absence of any solvents, resulting in large voltage stability windows (>3 V). However, the relative high viscosity limits the ionic conductivity, as well as low temperature operation since most of RTILs solidify around 0 ◦C. Beyond the conventional electrolytes listed, novel electrolytes such as “solid-statelike” organic electrolytes based on polymers, gels, or ionogels [7–9], redox active
352 Z. Lin and P. Simon
electrolytes [10–13], and “water in salt” [14–16] electrolytes have been developed. More electrolytes with large voltages and operational temperature ranges, nontoxic, that are less expensive should be explored (Table 18.1).
The excellent electrical conductivity up to 6500 S/m [17] and their twodimensional structure which enables fast ion transport and high surface accessibility to electrolyte ions make MXenes promising electrode materials for supercapacitor and battery applications. In the following chapter, highlights of MXene-based supercapacitors and the charge storage mechanisms behind the superior performance will be discussed.

sections.heading: MXene-Based Supercapacitor Operating in Aqueous Electrolyte
sections.text:
In 2013, Gogotsi et al. [18] reported the possibility for Ti3C2Tx (Tx stands for the presence of =F, –OH, and =O surface groups) MXene electrodes to reversibly intercalate a large variety of cations (Fig. 18.2a), including Na+, K+, NH4+, Mg2+, and Al3+. Capacitance beyond 440 F cm−3 (130 F g−1) could be achieved, thus challenging the best performance reported for carbon-based SC electrodes in similar electrolytes. The voltammograms in various alkaline and neutral electrolytes show a typical capacitive-like electrochemical signature, that is symmetric, rectangular-shaped CVs without pronounced redox peaks (Fig. 18.2b). Electrochemical quartz-crystal admittance (EQCA) measurements combined with in situ electronic conductance and electrochemical impedance analysis confirm a capacitive-like behavior over a wide range of charging rate in various neutral or alkaline electrolytes, especially when interlayer gaps are filled with ions and water molecules [19]. The fast deformation of partially exfoliated Ti3C2Tx MXene upon ion intercalation/de-intercalation was also observed.
Further studies in acidic electrolytes reported even higher capacitance. As an example, Ti3C2Tx MXene “clay” electrode could achieve up to 900 F cm−3 (245 F g−1) in 1 M H2SO4 without significant degradation after 10,000 charge/discharge cycles [21] (Fig. 18.2c). Such a high capacitance cannot be explained by the sole contribution of the electrical double layer (EDL) since the specific surface area (SSA) of these materials is limited to tens of m2 g−1; as a result,
18 MXenes for Supercapacitor Application 353
pseudocapacitive contribution from the core Ti3C2 was suspected to be involved. The presence of a pseudocapacitive contribution was later confirmed by in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements which showed that high capacitance in H2SO4 electrolyte mainly originates from the pseudocapacitive contribution of Ti atoms. X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) measurements evidenced a change in the titanium oxidation state during charge/discharge experiments [22]. An in situ Raman spectroscopy study further revealed that the change of oxidation state of titanium was associated with the presence of hydroniums ions (H3O+) in H2SO4 electrolyte that can reversibly bond/debond with oxygen-containing groups present at MXene surfaces, as shown in Fig. 18.3 [23]. The lower capacitance reported in neutral and alkaline electrolytes was then associated with the absence of hydronium ions. Recently, density functional theory (DFT) calculations using ion solvation model and constant-potential Gibbs free energy analysis were used to get further understanding of the surface redox process occurring in Ti3C2Tx in 1 M H2SO4 electrolyte [24]. These calculations proposed a charge storage mechanism based on the following reaction:
Ti3C2O q 2 + 2H+ (aq) → Ti3C2O2−2x(OH)q ′ 2x + 2 (1 − x) H+ (aq)
where x is the surface hydrogen coverage (ranging from 0 to 1) and q is the net charge on the electrode. The DFT calculations further confirm the mainly capacitance contribution originates from redox reaction.
Although high capacitance could be achieved in aqueous electrolytes with MXene electrodes, the limited potential range offered by aqueous electrolytes (<1 V) thus results in low energy. In a recent work, the MXene operation potential window could be increased from 0.55 V to 1 V in H2SO4 electrolytes, thanks to the use of glassy carbon or graphite current collectors [25]. This improvement
354 Z. Lin and P. Simon
was ascribed to the kinetic overpotential for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) on these current collector shifts the redox reaction toward negative potentials. The combination of an enhanced pseudocapacitive contribution at a negative potential range together with the use of MXene electrodes pre-intercalated with electrolyte, ultrahigh volumetric capacitance up to 1500 F cm−3 (370 F g−1) could be achieved, reaching the previously unmatched volumetric performance of RuO2. In addition to the superior capacitance and enlarged potential window, ultrahigh rate performance (210 F g−1 at 10 V s−1) was obtained as well by designing MXene electrodes with tailored macroporous architecture, which surpasses the best performance reported for pseudocapacitive or capacitive electrode materials [25]. This study highlights the great potential of MXene as supercapacitor electrode materials in aqueous electrolytes, and sheds light on the possibility of tailoring the structure of MXene electrodes to further improve their electrochemical performance.

sections.heading: Effect of MXene Surface Chemistry
sections.text:
Another key factor that drives the electrochemical performance of MXene electrodes is the surface terminations that are introduced during the chemical etching process. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments have confirmed the presence of =O, =F, and –OH terminations on MXenes’ surfaces [26, 27]. Firstprinciple density functional theory (DFT) calculations have predicted there is a significant effect of the presence of these surface groups on the electrical and
electrochemical properties of MXenes [17, 28, 29]. The influence of the surface chemistry of Ti3C2Tx on the electrochemical behavior in acidic electrolyte was investigated by Dall’Agnese et al. [30]. By replacing fluorine surface terminations with oxygen-containing functional groups using a chemical treatment in alkaline electrolytes, a fourfold increase in the capacitance could be achieved in sulfuric acid electrolyte. The origin of this improved performance lies in the decrease of the concentration of redox inactive =F groups together with the increase of =O terminations that can reversible bond/debond with hydronium ions in H2SO4 electrolyte [21, 23]. Further studies using 1H and 19F nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) experiments have identified and quantified the surface terminations of Ti3C2Tx MXene etched either from LiF-HCl or HF solution [31]. MXene samples prepared in LiF-HCl show the highest O- terminations content, as presented in Fig. 18.4; this explains the higher capacitance of LiF-HCl prepared MXene in H2SO4 electrolyte [21], in agreement with previous studies [23]. Tuning the surface chemistry by hydrazine intercalation into 2D Ti3C2Tx MXene was also reported to decrease the amount of fluorine, –OH surface groups, and intercalated water and result in consequent improvement of the specific capacitance. In summary, =F and – OH surface groups have a negative impact on the capacitance, while = O contributes to the capacitance of MXene in acidic electrolytes through a pseudocapacitive mechanism.
Other strategies have been investigated to fine-tune the surface chemistry, such as annealing under Argon atmosphere or under vacuum, or by doping with heteroatoms (N). Thermal treatments can be used to control the surface chemistry since, at high temperatures, O atoms will occupy the sites that are mostly occupied by F atoms at room temperature [32]. As an example, K+ intercalation and removal of surface groups by annealing at 673 K under Ar resulted in significantly higher capacitance compared to pristine MXene [33]. Nitrogen-doped Ti3C2Tx MXene electrodes prepared by MXene annealing in ammonia or polymeric carbon nitride were able to deliver higher capacitances (up to 327 F g−1 at 1 A g−1 in 6 M KOH
356 Z. Lin and P. Simon
electrolyte) compared to untreated samples (230 F g−1), thanks to the tuning of surface chemistry and structure as well [34, 35]. In addition to the surface chemistry, atomic defects like the presence of Ti vacancies – controlled by the etchant concentration during MXene synthesis – can influence the surface morphology and surface groups, but do not strongly affect the metallic conductivity [36]. A Mo1.33C MXene containing di-vacancies ordering could achieve 65% higher volumetric capacitance (up to 1100 F cm−3) compared to untreated Mo2C; this was explained by the increase of electrochemically active sites, but without direct evidence. As a result, more work is needed to answer some of these fundamental questions [37].

sections.heading: MXene Electrodes Operating in Nonaqueous Electrolytes
sections.text:
Moving from aqueous to nonaqueous electrolytes allows for increasing the operating potential window, thanks to the absence of water electrolysis reactions. As a result, MXene electrodes have been extensively characterized in organic electrolytes to further increase their energy density (see Eq. 18.1). Dall’Agnese et al. [38] first characterized MXene/carbon nanotube (MXene/CNT) composite electrodes in 1 M EMI-TFSI1 in acetonitrile and obtained a potential window of 1.8 V together with a capacitance of 80 F g−1 (245 F cm−3). CNTs were used here to limit restacking of the MXene flakes which currently happens for most two-dimensional materials, which results in decreased accessibility of large ions such as EMI+/TFSI− to the interspace between MXene flakes. By using pre-intercalated MXene films with neat EMI-TFSI ionic liquid, Lin et al. [39] demonstrated the possibility of using MXene electrodes in neat ionic liquid electrolytes. A cell voltage of 3 V was achieved together with a capacitance of 75 F g−1 as well as decent power performance, such as presented in Fig. 18.5a. In situ XRD measurements indicated the reversible intercalation/de-intercalation of EMI+ cations at the negative electrode during charge/discharge, while exchange of cations and anions was assumed to occur at the positive electrode [40] (Fig. 18.5b). The volumetric changes of MXenes in contact with different ionic liquids and swelling/contraction during cycling were also observed by complementing electrochemical dilatometry with in situ XRD measurements [41]. The study demonstrated high strains increase with negative polarization while much lower strains are observed during positive polarization, which is explained by a higher population of cations intercalating at negative potentials and less cations de-intercalating or swapping of cations and anions at positive potentials. Such a charge storage mechanism has further been investigated by a molecular dynamic simulation study and the same conclusions were reached: only cation intercalation at negative potentials was observed, while ion exchange occurs at positive potentials in EMI-TFSI ionic liquid electrolyte [42]. These studies first suggest the important effect of MXene layer distance for especially large
1Ethyl-methyl-imidazole, tri-fluoro-sulfonyl-imide
18 MXenes for Supercapacitor Application 357
ions intercalation. However, these results also highlight the key issue of MXene as electrode material in nonaqueous electrolytes, which is the limited capacitance these materials can achieve in nonaqueous electrolytes (around 80–100 F g−1), which is three to four times less than in acidic electrolytes. This points out the key role of water molecules, protons, and hydronium ions which are now known to be needed to activate the redox pseudocapacitance on the transition metal [43]. In aprotic, nonaqueous electrolytes, most of the capacitance is assumed to come from the double layer charging with no – or minor – charge transfer on the transition metal atoms of MXenes. Because of these limitations, only few examples of MXene-based supercapacitor using nonaqueous electrolytes have been proposed, while MXenebased batteries or metal ion capacitors [44] which use nonaqueous electrolytes as well have been extensively studied, which will be detailed in other chapters in this book.
As a result, one of the main challenges in MXene – if not the main one – will be in the next years to find strategies to unlock the redox activity of the transition metal to combine both high capacitance and high cell voltage. If successful, such an approach could lead to a major breakthrough in the supercapacitor industry.

sections.heading: MXene-Based Composite Electrodes
sections.text:
Many MXene-based composite electrodes have been investigated, aiming at increasing electrochemical or mechanical performance [38, 45–54]. For instance, graphene or CNTs were added to Ti3C2Tx MXene to avoid the restacking issue of the 2D flakes, which was successful for increasing electrical conductivity, mechanical robustness, and electrolyte ion accessibility to MXene surface [38, 53, 55–57]. Free-standing and flexible sandwich-like MXene/carbon nanotube (CNT) paper was reported with high volumetric capacitances in 1 M MgSO4 aqueous electrolyte [55].
The same route was followed to enhance the accessibility of MXene surface to large size cations and anions, especially for organic electrolytes or even ionic liquid electrolytes [38]. Also, polypyrrole (PPy) was used as well to produce PPy/Ti3C2Tx MXene composite electrode, as shown in Fig. 18.6. Pyrrole was in situ polymerized and confined between Ti3C2Tx layers, resulting in high volumetric capacitance and excellent cyclability due to the improved electronic conductivity and better ion transport pathways [50, 54]. Metal oxides including TiO2 [58, 59], ZnO [60], MnO2 [61, 62], Nb2O5 [63], and MoO3 [64] have also been used to synthesize MXene-based composite electrodes [53, 61]. For instance, ε-MnO2 nanocrystalline whiskers were directly chemically synthesized on MXene nanosheet surface to make nanocomposite electrodes for preparing high capacitance, aqueous-based supercapacitors.

sections.heading: MXene-Based Supercapacitor Devices: Hybrid, All-Solid-State, and Micro-supercapacitors
sections.text:
Although MXenes exhibit great potential as supercapacitor electrodes, especially in acidic electrolytes where extremely high volumetric as well as gravimetric capacitance have been reported, practical applications of symmetric MXene-based supercapacitor devices are limited by their narrow voltage ranges. This is partially due to water electrolysis, but the low oxidation potential of MXenes is a major factor. For instance, oxidation of Ti3C2Tx MXene in 3 M H2SO4 electrolyte starts at about −0.1 V (vs. Hg/Hg2SO4) [25]. Therefore, MXenes can be used as a negative electrode in hybrid devices, in combination with a positive electrode operating in a potential range located beyond −0.1 V vs. Hg/Hg2SO4. Generally, a hybrid supercapacitor combines a capacitive activated carbon electrode together with a
18 MXenes for Supercapacitor Application 359
faradic (pseudocapacitive or battery-like) electrode. Such a cell design comes with an increase in capacity and cell voltage compared to symmetric carbon devices resulting in improved energy density versus EDLCs. Apart from activated carbon, various materials such as rGO [65], annealed-MXene-nickel oxide [66], RuO2 [67], and carbon nanofiber films [68], have been investigated as positive electrodes together with MXene [69]. Kim et al. [66] prepared a composite electrode based on NiO-grown derived-TiO2/C-Ti3C2Tx MXene nanocomposite (Ni-dMXNC) with a volumetric capacity of 60.7 mA h g−1 at 1 A g−1, which demonstrates a voltage window of 1.8 V when combined with a Ti3C2Tx MXene negative electrode. Recently, RuO2 was proposed as a positive electrode because of its high conductivity, large proton-induced pseudocapacitance, and high overpotential for oxygen evolution in acidic media. Working with a Ti3C2Tx MXene negative electrode coated onto a carbon fiber current collector [25, 67], the prepared hybrid device can operate within a voltage window of 1.5 V, which is about two times wider than the operating voltage window of symmetric MXene supercapacitors, with a capacitance of 93 F g−1 (Fig. 18.7). It’s believed that more hybrid supercapacitor systems with various positive electrodes including capacitive electrodes and battery electrodes will be investigated to further boost up the energy density and/or power density. Here also, the successful development of highly capacitive MXene electrodes operating in nonaqueous electrolyte would be a major breakthrough. Interestingly, recent results have shown the possibility for MXene electrodes to achieve high capacitance in Liion containing non-aqueous electrolytes and this gives strong hope for the successful development of this technology [70].
In order to meet the demands for safer energy storage systems to power portable or wearable electronic devices and flexible displays, all-solid-state supercapacitors and micro-supercapacitors are currently being developed [71]. Taking advantage of the high gravimetric and volumetric capacitance along with metallic
360 Z. Lin and P. Simon
conductivity, MXene-based electrodes have been assembled into all-solid-state micro-supercapacitors (MSCs) for on-chip energy storage [51, 69, 72–76]. As shown in Fig. 18.8, an all-MXene solid-state MSC was fabricated by spray-coating a first thin layer of Ti3C2Tx onto a glass substrate as the current collector, followed by the coating of a second electroactive Ti3C2Tx film. Laser scribing was then used to prepare an interdigitated supercapacitor cell which was further soaked with a PVA/H2SO4 gel electrolyte. This device could deliver an areal capacitance of 28 mF cm−2 that is five times improvement compared to advanced porous carbon-based symmetric MSCs (0.1–6 mF cm−2) [72]. Recently, Zhang and co-workers reported a 2D Ti3C2Tx MXene viscous ink which can be stamped into flexible, coplanar MSCs [76]. Different stamp shapes were prepared by a 3D-printing process, coated with MXene ink and then firmly pressed onto paper substrates. Moreover, dozens of stamped MSCs can be fabricated in seconds through such a facile, low-cost, but elegant stamping strategy. Despite the progress achieved, more attention should be paid to MXene-based MSCs to further boost energy and power performance.
18 MXenes for Supercapacitor Application 361

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: So far, MXenes have been mainly investigated in aqueous electrolytes, where the capacitance achieved outperforms most of the carbon-based materials and pseudocapacitive materials. For instance, values as high as 1500 F cm−3 and 370 F g−1 were achieved for a Ti3C2 MXene electrode in acidic electrolyte, due to the fast and reversible redox reactions involving protons/hydronium ions. Although various in situ techniques like X-ray diffraction/adsorption, electrochemical quartz crystal microbalance (EQCM) in gravimetric and dissipative modes or NMR combined with MD and DFT modeling have been used to explore the charge storage mechanism of MXene electrodes in aqueous electrolytes, more efforts are still needed to provide a full picture of the charge storage mechanism. With the purpose of boosting the energy density, few efforts are trying to move from aqueous to nonaqueous electrolytes which offer higher operating voltage. All these efforts are still to this day unsatisfactory due to the low volumetric and gravimetric capacitance achieved by MXene in these proton-free electrolytes, where there is an absence of redox pseudocapacitive behavior as well as the limited surface accessibility to the large ions. To further improve the electrochemical performance, strategies such as surface chemistry modification, 3D porous structures, or composite MXene electrode designs have been developed to either introduce a redox contribution or improve surface accessibility to ions. Special interest should go toward unlocking the redox activity of the MXene transition metal in nonaqueous electrolytes to combine both high capacitance and high cell voltage. The successful development of these approaches would provide guidance for developing the next generation of MXene-based supercapacitors.

sections.heading: Demand for Advanced Batteries
sections.text:
A crucial requirement of sustainable power grids is a wide distribution of electrochemical energy storage devices in a power grid, which balances uneven energy demands and intermittent power generated from renewable sources, improving our energy control and operational efficiency. Thus, we must develop high-performance electrochemical energy storage devices such as batteries [1].
Lithium-ion batteries are used mainly for portable electronics because these batteries have relatively high gravimetric/volumetric energy densities (200–250 Wh/kg and 500–600 Wh/L, respectively). However, these batteries do not have satisfactory energy densities for larger applications such as electric vehicles. Because the energy density of a battery depends partly on its electrode materials, a major challenge in battery research is to find electrode materials with better specific capacity, operating potential, rate capability, and cycle stability. Recently, MXenes have attracted attention as potential lithium-ion battery electrodes (section “Application to Lithium-Ion Batteries”), because their layered structure enables reversible Li+ (de)intercalation, while their compositional versatility enables optimization of electrochemical properties [2].
Another important requirement for advanced grid-scale batteries is elemental abundance and low cost. Because lithium is distributed poorly across the world, making it expensive, we must develop batteries that consist of more-abundant elements. For example, sodium is abundant, so sodium-ion batteries are a promising candidate to replace lithium-ion batteries. Thus, much effort has been devoted to researching sodium-ion battery electrodes [3]. Several research groups have

In this chapter, after describing the electrochemical properties of MXenes (section “Charge Storage in MXene”), we will summarize recent progress in their applications to batteries.

sections.heading: Charge Storage in MXene
sections.text:
Before summarizing the battery applications of MXenes, let us first consider the charge storage mechanism of MXene [4]. Figure 19.1 illustrates the charge storage of stacked MXene and delaminated single-layer MXene electrodes. For both cases, the specific capacitance (C) of the MXene electrode is defined as C = Q
(ϕcc−ϕb) , where (ϕcc − ϕb) is the change of the inner potential difference between a current collector (ϕcc) and a bulk electrolyte (ϕb), and Q is the stored charge per unit weight of the electrode. (ϕcc − ϕb) is equivalent to the voltage change of an electrochemical cell when a reference electrode is used.
ϕcc − ϕb is expanded by the inner potential differences as
ϕcc − ϕb = ( ϕcc − ϕeE ) + ( ϕe E − ϕiE ) + ( ϕi E − ϕb ) .
The equilibrium condition of the electron electrochemical potential μe between the current collector and the electrode material (MXene) applies to give
μcce = μEe ,
19 MXenes for Batteries 369
which leads to
μe cc–Fϕcc = μeE–FϕeE.
The equilibrium condition of the ion electrochemical potential μi between the electrode and electrolyte also applies to give
μi E = μib,
which leads to
μi E + FϕiE = μib + Fϕb.
Thus,
ϕcc − ϕb = μ cc e − μEe

( ϕEe − ϕEi ) + μ b i − μEi

Because μcce and μ b i are constant regardless of the state-of-charge of the electrode,
(ϕCC − ϕb) is expressed as
(ϕcc − ϕb) = ( ϕEe − ϕEi ) − ( μEe + μEi ) F .
If, as is true for aqueous electrolytes, the density of states of the electrode is much larger than the number of stored electrons, then μEe is almost constant during charging and discharging, so μEe = 0. Also, if the electrode has much more cation storage sites than stored cations, then μEi will be almost constant during charging and discharging, giving μEi = 0. Thus, (ϕcc − ϕb) = ( ϕEe − ϕEi ) applies for small Q, and the electrode will behave as an electric double-layer (EDL) capacitor. Hydrated-ion intercalation into the interlayer space was confirmed using the electrochemical quartz crystal microbalance (EQCM) method [5]. The specific capacitance (C) for non-delaminated multilayer MXene (Fig. 19.1a) is C = εrε0A
b−a , where εr is the dielectric constant between the MXene wall and ion, ε0 is the vacuum permittivity, A is the specific surface area of the MXene walls, 2b is the separation of the MXene walls, and a is the ionic radius [6]. Indeed, Ti2CTx and Ti3C2Tx with aqueous electrolytes exhibit rectangular cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves (Fig. 19.2a, c), typical of EDL electrodes. Note that, when the EDL is formed, the stored electrons occupy originally unoccupied electronic states, reducing the MXene.
Conversely, when the electrode is charged/discharged with nonaqueous electrolytes, desolvated ions are intercalated to induce orbital hybridization with surface termination groups (charge transfer). The charge transfer strongly screens the electric field between the electron and the cation, which reduces the contribution of (ϕeE − ϕiE) to the capacitance. More importantly, because the organic electrolytes
370 M. Okubo and A. Yamada
have a wide potential window, many electrons and cations are stored during charging, and μeE and μiE change significantly due to band filling and inter-cation interaction. These effects presumably distort the CV curves for Ti2CTx and Ti3C2Tx with nonaqueous electrolytes, as shown in Fig. 19.2b, d This is the situation where the MXene electrode behaves as a pseudocapacitor (or redox capacitor). For the limiting case where the electric field in the electrode is completely screened by sufficient charge transfer and the inner potential is uniform (ϕeE = ϕiE), the applied potential difference is described only by the change in the chemical potentials of electron and ion as an ion-intercalation or ion-adsorption reaction. Desolvated-ion intercalation into the interlayer space has been demonstrated for Na+ using TEM and NMR [7, 8].
When an electrode consists of delaminated single-layer MXenes, the structural changes should only slightly change μeE and μiE, and a band-filling effect, intercation interaction, and MXene-cation interaction could dominate the capacitance.
19 MXenes for Batteries 371

sections.heading: Application to Lithium-Ion Batteries
sections.text:
MXene was first used as a negative electrode material for lithium-ion batteries by Naguib et al. in 2012 [9]. The electrochemical properties of non-delaminated Ti2CTx synthesized by hydrofluoric acid (HF) treatment were evaluated in 1 M LiPF6/ethylene carbonate (EC)-diethyl carbonate (DEC). As shown in Fig. 19.3, after a large irreversible capacity in the first charge (an initial coulombic efficiency of 45%), Ti2CTx delivers a specific capacity of 150–200 mAh/g at a C/10 rate (~20 mA/g) with good capacity retention. The sloping potential profile between 0 and 2.0 V vs. Li/Li+ is typical of capacitor electrodes, although Li+ (de)intercalation occurs upon (dis)charge. The same group, led by Gogotsi and Barsoum, also reported the electrochemical properties of non-delaminated Nb2CTx and V2CTx in a nonaqueous Li+ electrolyte [10]. Despite the different transition metals, both MXenes showed specific capacities of 210–220 mAh/g with sloping potential profiles, similar to those observed for Ti2CTx. However, the reaction voltage of V2CTx was slightly higher than that of Ti2CTx, presumably because band filling affected μeE: the 3d orbital energy of V in V2CTx should be lower than that of Ti in Ti2CTx. Table 19.1 summarizes the applications of MXenes to Li-ion batteries [11–20]. Most non-delaminated MXene electrodes have relatively low initial coulombic efficiency (60–70%), presumably because the large surface area of the partially delaminated structure causes deteriorative side reactions such as electrolyte decomposition and surface reaction.
Most non-delaminated MXenes exhibit a charge/discharge reaction of 1.0–2.0 Li+ per the formula unit (Table 19.1). These capacities are less than expected for the one-electron capacity per transition metal in the formula unit. Similar capacity increases have been achieved by delaminating Nb2CTx and Mo2CTx [18, 20]. For both cases, the specific capacity including the additional capacity of carbon nanotube (CNT) increases to 400 mAh/g. However, though the delamination increases the specific capacity, the increased surface area produces a larger irreversible capacity in the initial charge, worsening the coulombic efficiency (ca. 45–55%) (Fig. 19.4).
The functionalization of MXene has further increased the specific capacity of MXene electrodes. For example, anchoring the “Sn4+ nanocomplex” (most likely amorphous SnO2) on the surface of non-delaminated Ti3C2Tx accumulates additional capacity of the conversion reaction of SnO2, delivering a specific capacity of 1500 mAh/g at 100 mA/g [16]. Similarly, cobalt-ion intercalated V2CTx exhibits a large capacity of 1117 mAh/g [21]. However, the initial coulombic efficiency decreases after functionalization due to the well-known irreversibility of conversion reactions.

sections.heading: Application to Sodium-Ion Batteries
sections.text:
The electrochemical properties of MXene in sodium-ion cells were reported by Xie et al. in 2014 [22]. Non-delaminated Ti3C2Tx synthesized by HF treatment was evaluated as the electrode material in a 1 M NaClO4/EC-PC electrolyte; after an initial irreversible charge capacity (coulombic efficiency of 50%), Ti3C2Tx delivers a specific capacity of 100 mAh/g at 100 mA/g with sloping charge/discharge potential profiles. More detailed analyses of the electrochemical reaction of nondelaminated Ti3C2Tx revealed the following: (1) initial sodiation expands the
interlayer distance by 3.0 Å; (2) Na+ is reversibly intercalated/deintercalated during charge/discharge; (3) the interlayer distance does not change after the initial expansion [7]. Similar behavior has been reported for non-delaminated Ti2CTx, though it has a larger specific capacity of 180 mAh/g at 20 mA/g (Fig. 19.5) [23]. It is most likely that the co-intercalation of both Na+ and solvent molecules occurs, expanding the interlayer distance during initial sodiation, which improves the ability of Na+ to access the interlayer space [7]. Indeed, the non-delaminated Ti3C2Tx electrode can deliver a high specific capacity of 70 mAh/g even at a high specific current of 500 mA/g [7]. Table 19.2 summarizes the applications of MXenes to sodium-ion batteries [7, 8, 22–29]. For example, V2CTx and Hf3C2Tx, other non-delaminated MXenes were reported to give specific capacities of 80 mAh/g at 10 mA/g and 800 mAh/g at 50 mA/g, respectively. As summarized in Table 19.2, except for an exceptionally large capacity for Hf3C2Tx, non-delaminated MXenes usually deliver 100–200 mAh/g with an initial coulombic efficiency of 40–65%.
Non-delaminated MXenes in nonaqueous Na+ electrolytes usually have smaller specific capacities than nonaqueous Li+ electrolytes: non-delaminated MXenes generally exhibit a reaction of <1.0 Na+ per formula unit. Because μeE is the same for lithiation and sodiation, this capacity difference should result from the difference in μiE such as from inter-cation coulombic or MXene-cation interaction. Presumably, the interlayer space of MXene cannot accommodate large Na+ efficiently. Indeed, delaminated and functionalized MXenes show higher sodiation capacity. For example, 3D macroporous electrodes consisting of delaminated MXenes (Ti3C2Tx, V2CTx, and Mo2CTx) were fabricated using a poly(methyl methacrylate) spherical template [27]. After annealing at 450 ◦C, they delivered specific capacities of 330–370 mAh/g at 50 mA/g, much larger than reported for non-delaminated MXenes. The specific capacity of delaminated Ti3C2Tx also increased to 500 mAh/g by combining it with the conversion-reaction capacity of Sb2O3 [28].

sections.heading: Application to Other Batteries
sections.text:
Some other groups have studied the application of MXene to other batteries. For example, Gogotsi et al. theoretically predicted the electrode performance of MXenes (Ti2CTx, V2CTx, Nb2CTx, and Ti3C2Tx) with K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, and Al3+ [18]. For MXenes with Tx = −O2, the MXene electrodes were predicted to deliver specific capacities of 200–300 mAh/g by monovalent cation adsorption (Fig. 19.6) [22]. Note that the predicted capacity decreases as the ionic radius of the monovalent cation increases. Indeed, the charge/discharge experiments confirmed that the specific capacity of Ti3C2Tx decreases in the order of Li+, Na+, and K+ [31].
MXene electrodes have been predicted to deliver much larger capacities by adsorption of divalent and trivalent cations (Mg2+, Ca2+, and Al3+) than by adsorption of monovalent cations. For example, a V2CO2 electrode was predicted to deliver a specific capacity of 530 mAh/g by Al3+ adsorption (Fig. 19.6). However, non-delaminated V2CTx in an Al3+ ionic liquid electrolyte delivered a reversible capacity of less than 150 mAh/g [32]. Though delamination improved the capacity to 200 mAh/g, the measured capacity was much smaller than the predicted value. Similarly, the intercalation of a cetyltrimethylammonium cation into Ti3C2Tx enables Mg2+ storage of 90 mAh/g at 50 mA/g, much smaller than the predicted value of 420 mAh/g [33].
19 MXenes for Batteries 377

sections.heading: Summary
sections.text:
Many research groups have demonstrated that MXenes are attractive electrode materials for various electrochemical energy storage devices such as lithiumion batteries and sodium-ion batteries, because non-delaminated MXenes have large interlayer space for ion storage (high energy) as well as high electronic conductivity (high power). In particular, using nonaqueous electrolytes, with their large electrochemical windows, allows for MXene electrodes with large capacity. Furthermore, delaminating MXene nanosheets significantly increases their specific capacity by enlarging their reactive surface area.
However, due to the exfoliated nanosheet morphology even for non-delaminated MXenes, all MXenes (non-delaminated and delaminated) show large irreversible capacity in the initial cycle, leading to poor initial coulombic efficiency, generally less than 60%. One promising approach to improve their initial coulombic efficiency is to control the surface states of the MXenes. For example, heat treatment of Ti3C2Tx appears to modify its surface state and improve its initial coulombic efficiency from 45% to 57% (with nonaqueous Li+ electrolytes) [34]. Alternatively, suppressing the excess formation of a solid-electrolyte interphase by optimizing the electrode-electrolyte system should also improve their initial coulombic efficiency.
Another important issue is the electronic conductivity of MXenes. Though many reports claim that MXenes have high electronic conductivity, MXene electrodes are usually prepared with conducting carbon additives to improve their conductivity (Tables 19.1 and 19.2). For high-power applications, we must find a way to develop highly conductive MXenes, such as by doping with aliovalent or hetero atoms.

sections.heading: MXene Materials as Electrodes for Lithium-Sulfur Batteries
Xiao Liang and Linda F. Nazar
Introduction
sections.text:
A clean energy revolution is underway that includes harnessing renewable energy sources such as wind and solar and beginning a switch to electric vehicles, in an effort to curb CO2 emissions and mitigate urban air pollution. Effectively integrating renewable energy sources calls for electrochemical energy storage devices that embrace low cost and high energy density as well as long cycle life. The market has been – and continues to be – dominated by Li-ion batteries that use lithium transition metal oxides to store electrical energy by a process known as intercalation chemistry. While the latter fundamentally limits their electron storage capacity and hence energy density [1], the cost and availability of some of those metals, such as cobalt, are also a rising concern. Exploration of new electrochemistries that go “beyond lithium-ion” to boost energy density and reduce cost is rapidly gaining momentum. In this pursuit, lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries that couple sulfurpositive electrodes (or “cathodes”) with lithium-negative electrodes (or “anodes”) are considered particularly promising candidates. The Li-S battery has received enormous attention in the past decade, due to the high theoretical specific energy (Wh kg−1) and earth abundance of sulfur, which is coupled with a high-energy density Li metal anode in the cell [2–5]. Instead of intercalation chemistry, these batteries rely on conversion chemistry, as summarized by the reaction below, that

yields a high theoretical capacity of 1675 mAh g−1 at about 2.1 V and hence an energy density approaching 2500 Wh kg−1:
