This theoretical energy density is not realized in practice, however. The redox chemistry proceeds through lithium polysulfide (LiPS) intermediates consisting of Li2Sx chains, reaching the end member, Li2S where x = y = 1 (Fig. 20.1a) [6]. Fundamental challenges facing Li-S batteries originate from the dissolution of these highly mobile lithium polysulfides in the electrolyte, the intrinsic insulating properties of the redox end members (elemental sulfur/lithium sulfides), the volume changes at the cathode on cycling, and the need for passivating membranes at the lithium anode to inhibit dendrite formation. In particular, the soluble polysulfide species create a “polysulfide shuttle” in the cell (Fig. 20.1b), which decreases the sulfur utilization and Coulombic efficiency, while the insolubility of Li2S and/or Li2S2 results in the precipitation of passivating solids on both the cathode and anode [7]. Moreover, it is now widely realized that high areal sulfur loading in the cathode is essential for Li-S technology to gain a foothold in the marketplace [8, 9]. In such cells, the challenges listed above are greatly amplified due to the difficulties in creating a continuous electron/Li+ pathway in thick cathodes and protecting the anodes from LiPS corrosion and dendrite formation at high current rates.
Infiltrating molten sulfur into porous electronically conductive carbon materials to form the cathode was the standard approach in the early years [5, 10–12],
20 MXene Materials as Electrodes for Lithium-Sulfur Batteries 383
resulting in interconnected conducting networks and physical entrapment of the LiPSs. However, simple entrapment was found insufficient to prevent diffusion and shuttling of LiPSs over long-term cycling. Interfacial phenomena – strong chemical interaction between the host materials and the dissolved LiPSs – are essential to suppress LiPS diffusion and thus achieve a long cell life time [6]. This was demonstrated by employing a variety of sulfur host matrices such as reduced graphene oxides (rGO) [13], nitrogen-doped carbon [14], metal oxides [15, 16], and chalcogenides [17, 18] and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [19] to accomplish the task. The key factor of these host materials lies in their ability to bind sulfide or lithium ions in the LiPS molecules, providing affinity for LiPSs. However, many do not fulfill properties that are also critical to cathode design, such as sufficient mechanical stability to maintain electrode integrity over long-term cycling and high electronic conductivity which is especially necessary for electron transport in thick, high areal loading electrodes.
Here, MXenes can provide a vital role. Delaminated MXenes are capable of high electronic conductivity and exhibit rich surface properties [20], which synergistically improves the electron transport properties of the sulfur electrode and provides chemical interactions with LiPSs. Another advantageous aspect is their denser structure compared to most “fluffy” carbonaceous materials, which benefits the volumetric energy density of the battery. The goal of this chapter is to provide a brief overview of the recent development of MXenes for Li-S batteries, from material aspects on tuning the physical and electrochemical properties of the sulfur cathode, to their performance in prototype cells. Different mechanisms of chemical interactions with polysulfides are summarized. Finally, a perspective of MXenes and their composites for future advances toward practical Li-S cells is provided.

sections.heading: Material Aspects of MXenes for Li-S Batteries
sections.text:
MXenes are an exciting family of early transition metal carbides or carbonitrides first reported by Gogotsi et al. in 2011 [21]. They are produced by selective etching (in aqueous hydrofluoric acid, HF) of the A element from the MAX phases [22], named because of their composition Mn+1AXn, where M is an early transition metal, A is a group IIIA or IVA element, X is C and/or N, and n = 1–3 [23]. Delamination of the sheets is affected via solvation by donor solvents [24]. The sheet surface is terminated with groups such as hydroxyl, oxygen, or fluorine, which impart hydrophilicity to the surfaces (denoted as Mn+1XnTx, where T represents the surface termination). These surface properties are one reason why MXenes have found application in Li-S cells. As mentioned above, a recent techno-economic analysis suggests that Li-S cathodes with areal sulfur loadings of >7 mg cm−2 (and low electrolyte volume) are necessary for the batteries to find practical applications in transportation [8]. The poor sulfur utilization in thick electrodes (with high areal loading) is due to the significant differences in the mass transport and spatial distribution of polysulfides throughout the electrode. This leads to limited diffusion
384 X. Liang and L. F. Nazar
pathways, kinetics, and electrolyte uptake to support high current densities [6]. The advantages of the physical and chemical properties of MXenes in potentially overcoming these problems are discussed in this section.

sections.heading: Mechanical Properties
sections.text:
The elemental sulfur in Li-S batteries changes its state from a solid phase to a solution phase when the battery is partially discharged (i.e., partially dissolved LiPSs in the electrolyte), and then precipitates as solid Li2S/Li2S2 at the fully discharged state [6]. The reverse occurs on charge. Moreover, sulfur exhibits a large volume expansion (~80%) upon conversion to Li2S [15]. These phase transformations pose big challenges to maintaining the structural integrity of the electrode. Thus, one requirement for a robust sulfur host is mechanical strength (Fig. 20.2a). Benefiting from a strong covalent M-X bond, MXenes show remarkable flexibility, good tensile, and compressive strengths [26]. A cylinder with walls made of a 5-μm-thick Ti3C2Tx paper can support ~4000 times its own weight. It can be further strengthened by creating a Ti3C2Tx composite with 10 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) to hold ~15,000 times its own weight (Fig. 20.2b) [25]. Theoretical calculations predict that M2X MXenes are stiffer and stronger than their M3X2 and M4X3 analogues [27, 28]. These properties can help ensure that the sulfur electrode forms a flexible structure without collapse during charge/discharge.
20 MXene Materials as Electrodes for Lithium-Sulfur Batteries 385

sections.heading: Electrical Conductivity and Density
sections.text: MXenes represent a class of host materials with very high electrical conductivity. Theoretical studies have shown that the electronic properties of different MXenes range from metallic to semiconducting [29]. The electrical conductivity of MXenes depends on the composition, the defects, and the surface termination. MXenes derived from heavier M elements such as molybdenum are predicted to be semiconductors, while titanium-based MXenes are metallic [30]. The conductivity of Ti3C2Tx ranges from 1000 to 4600 S cm−1, for example, depending on the defect concentration [31]. These values exceed those of other solution-processed materials including graphene, making MXenes viable conductive hosts. Furthermore, sulfurMXene cathode materials have much higher tap density than carbon materials at the same weight fraction of sulfur loading [20], thus in principle leading to better volumetric energy density.

sections.heading: Interactions with Sulfur
sections.text: MXenes are attractive candidates as a sulfur/polysulfide/sulfide anchor due to their rich surface chemistry that can be used to facilitate intimate electrical contact to the insulating sulfur. While the sulfur S8 ring is nonpolar, MXenes are polar due to the asymmetric chemical environments of the metal atoms. This apparent incompatibility is overcome by formation of metal-sulfur bonds during the molten sulfur infiltration process (155 ◦ C) [32]. In the sulfur-Ti2C MXene composite, there is evidence that the terminal Ti-OH groups on the surface are replaced with TiS groups, inducing a switch in the nature of the MXene phases from hydrophilic to Sulfophilic. Ti-S moieties on the surface were detected by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Fig. 20.3a) [32]. In a separate study, density functional theory calculations showed that there is charge transfer of 0.26 e− between sulfur and the oxygen-terminated Ti2C substrate (Ti2CO2), which is indicative of a chemical interaction between sulfur and the MXene host [34]. Moreover, the band structure and density of states (DOS) diagram illustrate that LiPS adsorption does not change the bandgap of the MXene (Fig. 20.3b) [33, 35].

sections.heading: Interfacial Properties
sections.text:
Several studies have tried to understand the fundamental chemistry between the sulfur species and Ti-based MXenes by considering the pristine surface or with various different termination groups. Different modes of interaction have been proposed based on both computational and experimental studies.
386 X. Liang and L. F. Nazar
Computational studies based on first-principles calculations have provided valuable metrics regarding the theoretical strength of the interaction based on binding energies at an atomic scale. The binding energy is defined as the energy difference of the relaxed host/LiPSs system versus the sum of the isolated host and LiPS. A computational screening of O-terminated MXenes (Ti2CO2 and Ti3C2O2) revealed that the negatively charged oxygen terminal atoms interact with the positively charged Li+ ions in the LiPS species, giving rise to moderate binding energies in the range of 1–2 eV (Fig. 20.4a) [34]. Therefore, the chemical interaction of these soluble LiPS intermediates with the Ti2CO2 monolayer was mainly ascribed to the electrostatic attraction between the Li ions of the LiPS species and the Ti2CO2 monolayer. Chung et al. reported that Ti2CO2 suppresses the polysulfide shuttle in a different manner [35, 36]. By calculating the average charge of the sulfur atoms in LiPSs, they found that high-order LiPSs such as Li2S8 and Li2S6 tend to oxidize to elemental sulfur due to significantly weakened Li-S bonds by the strong Li-O interaction, while medium-order LiPSs such as Li2S4 maintain their original molecular configuration via sole Li-O interactions with the MXene substrate (Fig. 20.4b). For fluorine-terminated MXenes, the high-order LiPSs are adsorbed parallel to the substrate and the medium-order LiPSs are anchored vertical to the substrate
20 MXene Materials as Electrodes for Lithium-Sulfur Batteries 387
via Li-F interactions [33, 35]. However, the binding energy of the Li-F interaction is weak and was not observed in an experimental XPS study [37].
Calculations suggest that hydroxyl-terminated MXenes tend to bind with LiPS via sulfur atom interactions (this premise assumes that the hydroxyl groups have not been consumed by reaction with elemental sulfur in forming the original composite) [32, 33, 37]. Given that the H atom in hydroxyl groups can shield the repulsive forces between the negatively charged S and O atoms, the hydroxyl-terminated MXenes demonstrate higher binding energies with LiPSs than that of O- and Fterminated MXenes, based on theory [33]. For example, the binding energy of Li2S4-Ti2C(OH)2 is about 3.4 eV [33, 37], while Li2S4-Ti2CO2 is 1.9 eV [34]. Calculations also show that the binding energy between LiPSs and the electrolyte solvent (i.e., a mixture of 1,3-dioxolane/dimethoxyethane) is much weaker than that of the OH-terminated MXenes, suggesting that LiPSs preferentially adsorb on the MXene surface instead of being dissolved in the electrolyte [33, 35]. This understanding of the interaction between hydroxyl-terminated MXenes with LiPSs suggests that the H-S bond is the main interaction (Fig. 20.5a) [33]. That finding was supported by the dissociation energy difference of the –OH group (6.06 eV) and H atom (2.92 eV) from the MXene surface and hydroxyl group, respectively. The reasoning suggests the H atom of the hydroxyl group tends to partly dissociate, contributing to interaction with LiPSs via the H-S bond.
A different view of the OH-terminated MXene interaction with LiPSs is supported by a combination of computational and experimental observations [37]. It was reported that LiPSs act as soft Lewis bases owing to the lone electron pairs of the sulfur atoms [38]. Therefore Lewis acid-type MXene host materials (free of terminal groups) are able to interact strongly with LiPSs via Ti-S coordination (Fig. 20.5b) [32]. More recent studies have elucidated the formation of Ti-S bonds, the decrease of terminal hydroxyl groups on the surface, as well as formation of a significant amount of thiosulfate-polythionate species on the MXene surface after contact with LiPS [37]. The formation of thiosulfate-polythionate species indicates a redox reaction between hydroxyl groups and LiPSs, similar to the cleavage of
388 X. Liang and L. F. Nazar
hydroxyl groups on graphene oxide by contact with LiPSs [16]. Once a terminal group vacancy is formed on the MXene surface (i.e., a hydroxyl vacancy), LiPSs could readily bond to the defect site via a Ti-S Lewis acid-base interaction with very high binding energy [37]. The interaction of hydroxyl-terminated MXene and LiPSs can therefore be described in a two-step process (Fig. 20.5c): The hydroxyl terminal groups on MXene first undergo redox with polysulfides to form surface thiosulfate groups, followed by the Wackenroder reaction [16] that exposes the Ti atoms. Second, the exposed and metastable Ti atoms readily accept additional polysulfides in the electrolyte and form Ti-S bonds by Lewis acid-base interactions.
20 MXene Materials as Electrodes for Lithium-Sulfur Batteries 389

sections.heading: Progress of MXenes in Li-S Batteries
sections.text: The exploration for new sulfur host materials was extended to MXenes due to their good mechanical strength, electrical conductivity, and chemical interaction with LiPSs, as described above. There are several examples of application of MXenes and their composites as cathodes for Li-S batteries, encompassing both sulfur host materials, and interlayers between the cathode and the separator to improve sulfur utilization. Moreover, MXenes also show lithiophilic properties which could facilitate lithium nucleation and efficiently suppress dendrite formation for lithium metal anodes, which are necessary components of a Li-S battery on the negative side.

sections.heading: Sulfur Hosts
sections.text:
Liang et al. first reported the use of 2D conductive MXene nanosheets as cathode hosts to improve Li-S battery performance [32]. A fully delaminated MXene phase, Ti2C, combined metallic conductivity with a 2D surface abundant with Lewis acid Ti sites and hydroxyl groups. A strong Lewis acid-based interaction of the lithium polysulfides with the surface was demonstrated by metal-sulfur (TiS) binding at the interface [32, 37]. Meanwhile, the hydroxyl terminal groups undergo a redox reaction with LiPSs to form thiosulfate on the MXene surface, by which a thiosulfate-polythionate conversion is triggered as described above, that also contributes to suppressing the polysulfide shuttle [32, 37]. The adsorbed polysulfides are converted into Li2S to form nucleation sites on the surface, inducing further epitaxial deposition on the existing Li2S nuclei. Both mitigated diffusion of LiPSs and abundant Li2S nucleation sites act to control Li2S deposition on discharge, thereby improving electrochemical properties. The 70 wt% S/Ti2C composite exhibited excellent cycling performance with a specific capacity close to 1200 mAh g−1 at a C/5 current rate and capacity retention of 80% over 400 cycles at a C/2 current rate. Zhao et al. also reported the use of exfoliated MXene Ti3C2 (nondelaminated) composites as a sulfur host, which showed a high initial discharge capacity of 1290 mAh g−1 and excellent capacity retention of 970 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles [39].
Although delaminated multilayer MXene sheets are expected to have a high surface area, the restacking of the nanosheets due to van der Waals forces upon removal of the delaminating solvent significantly limits the accessibility of LiPSs or Li+ ions, hindering the full utilization of their surface properties [40]. To prevent restacking of the delaminated MXene nanosheets, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) were introduced as spacers to create an interwoven MXene nanosheet/carbon-nanotube architecture (Fig. 20.6a, b) [37]. Ti2C, Ti3C2, and Ti3CN were examined in this study. The presence of CNTs between the nanosheets not only better exposes the MXene surfaces for polysulfide anchoring but further facilitates electron transport
390 X. Liang and L. F. Nazar
between the nanosheets, which is essential for Li-S batteries with high sulfur loading. Consequently, an initial discharge capacity of 1240 mAh g−1 was obtained, and a capacity of 450 mAh g−1 at a moderate sulfur loading of 1.5 mg cm−2 was retained after 1200 cycles, corresponding to a decay rate of merely 0.043% per cycle. Moreover, a stable capacity of 910 mAh g−1 was delivered when the practical sulfur loading was increased up to 5.5 mg cm−2 (Fig. 20.6c). The good performance of the high loading electrodes emphasizes the importance of the high conductivity, high surface area, and the effective polysulfide chemical absorptivity of the MXene host material.
The same strategy of using spacers to create more active surface of MXenes was expanded to other functional materials such as mesoporous carbon [41] and reduced graphene oxide (rGO) [42, 43], as shown in Fig. 20.7. Mesoporous carbon with a robust porous structure provides sufficient space for loading sulfur and effectively cushions the volumetric expansion of sulfur cathodes [41], while rGO also contributes to polysulfide adsorption via its active surface groups [42]. 3D conductive architectures were constructed with the Ti3C2 MXene phase uniformly distributed in these functional spacer matrices. High surface area was achieved for the composites, owing to the inhibited restacking of the MXene layers. Moreover, these 3D architectures also provide physical confinement for LiPSs due to their unique pore
20 MXene Materials as Electrodes for Lithium-Sulfur Batteries 391
structures. The Ti3C2@Meso-C/S cathodes with 73 wt% sulfur achieved a high initial capacity of 1225 mAh g−1 and reversible capacity of 705 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles at a C/2 current rate, respectively [41]. Similarly, Ti3C2/rGO/S with 70 wt% sulfur content exhibited a high initial capacity of 1145 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C and a capacity retention of 880 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles [42].
These studies shed light on designing new functional MXene-based composites for Li-S batteries. The key factor is to preserve the uniform dispersion of MXene sheets in the spacer phases (i.e., to prevent them from being restacked) while maintaining the excellent conductivity, mechanical robustness, and rich surface properties of the MXene phases. There are many MXene composites being widely used beyond the Li-S battery arena, such as MXene-polymers [25, 44], MXeneoxides [45] and sulfides [46], and MXene-C3N4 composite [47], which could also show promise for high sulfur loading Li-S batteries by optimizing the electrode architecture.
The doping of MXene phases can provide more polysulfide adsorption sites. Wang et al. synthesized crumpled nitrogen-doped MXene nanosheets with large specific surface areas and a porous structure by thermal annealing of negatively charged metallic Ti3C2Tx MXene flakes and positively charged melamine (Fig. 20.8) [48]. The introduction of nitrogen into the MXene nanosheets effectively
392 X. Liang and L. F. Nazar
improved the electronic conductivity, the affinity, and the binding energy of the polar titanium atoms with elemental sulfur and polar polysulfides via strong Lewis acid-base interactions. Enhancement of the electrochemical properties and chemical adsorption capability was observed. Meanwhile, the large specific surface area and porous crumpled structure improved the physical absorptivity and the capability to accommodate high sulfur loading and volume expansion. Consequently, the nitrogen-doped MXene nanosheet-sulfur cathodes demonstrate a high reversible capacity of 1144 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C rate, a high level of capacity retention of 950 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles and extended cycling stability (610 mAh g−1 at 2 C after 1000 cycles; 590 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles with a 5.1 mg cm−2 sulfur loading).
20 MXene Materials as Electrodes for Lithium-Sulfur Batteries 393

sections.heading: Interlayers on a Separator
sections.text:
Inserting a conductive interlayer between the cathode and the separator is another effective strategy to enhance sulfur utilization, which was first demonstrated by the Manthiram group [49]. It is believed that the freestanding carbon interlayer functions to confine lithium polysulfides to the sulfur cathode side and also works as a secondary current collector to improve active material utilization. To avoid sacrificing the energy density of the battery, it may even be more desirable to modify the separator with a thin layer of conductive material such as a MXene. The ultrathin two-dimensional structure also facilitates the formation of freestanding membranes by simple filtration. Benefiting from these advantages, MXenes were deposited on the side of the separator facing the sulfur electrode to form a conformal coating layer on a separator without obvious pores or gaps (Fig. 20.9) [50, 51]. The thin MXene layer immobilizes soluble polysulfide from the cathode region of the cell via both physisorption and chemisorption and also improves the reaction kinetics by decreasing the charge transfer resistance. Lin et al. reported a Ti3C2 nanosheetcovered glass fiber composite separator prepared by a simple vacuum filtration process [50]. Using this approach, a Li-S cathode containing commercial bulk sulfur delivered an initial discharge capacity of 820 mAh g−1. Good rate capability was achieved over 100 cycles: 720 mAh g−1 at a current density of 0.5 A g−1 and 590 mAh g−1 at a current density of 1.5 A g−1, respectively. Song et al. proposed a Ti3C2Tx nanosheet-coated commercial “Celgard” membrane to improve the performance of Li-S batteries [51]. The thickness of the Ti3C2Tx coating layer was only 520 nm with a loading mass of 0.1 mg cm−3. A simple sulfur/carbon black composite cathode exhibited a high initial capacity of 1050, 850, and 745 mAh g−1 at 0.2, 0.5, and 1C rates, respectively. The cells also showed very good long-term cycling performance with a high Columbic efficiency of almost 100% and a very small capacity decay of 0.062% per cycle at 0.5 C.
394 X. Liang and L. F. Nazar

sections.heading: Host for Li Deposition
sections.text:
While MXenes are promising hosts for the positive electrode of the Li-S battery, they have also been employed to inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites at the negative Li electrode in the cell due to their lithiophilic properties [52]. Dendrite formation is especially a challenge for high-sulfur-loaded batteries at high current densities [6]. Li dendrites not only result in cell short circuits that give rise to safety issues but also accelerate detrimental reactions with the electrolyte and the dissolved LiPS species [53]. The lithium anode becomes covered by thick insulating passivation layers and is finally pulverized, causing cell failure. MXenes demonstrate strong affinity toward Li by forming Li-C bonds, providing numerous nucleation sites for lithium deposition. The lamellar structured MXenes enable controllable lithium deposition into their nanoscaled gaps and the high surface area reduces the local current density, thus mitigating dendrite growth [52]. This concept was demonstrated by a flexible Ti3C2 MXene-lithium film anode prepared by a roll-to-roll mechanical approach. Lithium was mainly deposited in the gaps of the Ti3C2 nanosheets as illustrated by in situ TEM, and thus potential vertical growth of lithium dendrites was restricted (Fig. 20.10) [52]. Owing to the good electrical conductivity of the MXene, a very low overpotential (32 mV at 1.0 mA cm−2) and flat voltage profiles were observed during Li plating/stripping. The effectiveness of the Ti3C2-lithium anode was demonstrated by coupling it with a sulfur/carbon cathode in a full Li-S battery. The cell exhibited a high reversible capacity of 950 mAh g−1 and 840 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles, which was improved compared to the cell with a bare Li anode. However, the drawback of this concept is restricted by the limited in-plane gap of the MXene. After the gaps are fully filled, additional lithium will gradually deposit and form dendrites, as indicated by the authors.
20 MXene Materials as Electrodes for Lithium-Sulfur Batteries 395

sections.heading: Summary and Outlook
sections.text:
Significant advancement in developing high-performance Li-S batteries within the last few years – from rational designing of the host material to understanding the electrochemistry – has shortened the gap between fundamental research to practical applications. The excellent electrical conductivity, robust mechanical strength, and versatile surface chemistry of MXenes convey tunable properties as sulfur host materials. MXene phases show distinct improvement in suppressing the polysulfide shuttle via surface interactions, which is vital to the long-term cycling performance of Li-S batteries. High areal sulfur loading Li-S batteries for practical applications calls for electrodes with facile electron/Li+ ion pathways. Here, MXenes and their composites enable construction of a flexible structure that can maintain the integrity of the electrode while ensuring electron/ Li+ ion accessibility to the active sulfur/sulfide mass. The rich MXene surface chemistry also exhibits strong affinity toward lithium atoms, providing a stable high surface area substrate for Li deposition at the negative electrode that mitigates dendrite formation. Thus, the development of MXenes shows potential to solve some fundamental problems faced by Li-S batteries, and may open new avenues to achieve long cycle life, and high energy density with consideration of the following perspectives.
It is important to synthesize MXenes with uniformly distributed surface termination with the same type of moieties (i.e., hydroxyl). Though computation can simulate the interaction with LiPSs species by different individual surface groups, it is vital to understand and distinguish the interaction mechanism by experimental studies.
We note that only Ti-based MXenes have been used for Li-S batteries, but over 100 distinct MXene compositions have been synthesized and predicted to date. Computational studies could guide the selection of materials based on their interaction strength with LiPSs. Composites with other functional phases are also attractive to improve the surface reactivity, the mechanical robustness, and the electrical conductivity of MXenes, which are promising directions for high-sulfur loading electrodes by optimizing these parameters. It is especially important to note that for practical applications, the development of Li-S cells that utilize a low electrolyte volume is vital to push the field forward. Most studies conducted to date have not taken this factor into consideration; MXene phases may offer advantages in this respect over porous carbons.
The ability of MXene anode films to suppress lithium dendrite formation is a new avenue of exploration. A stable lithium metal anode will not only benefit LiS batteries but also could boost the energy density of current Li-ion batteries by replacing the graphite anode. However, more fundamental studies are necessary to uncover the underlying mechanism for dendrite suppression. Material engineering of MXenes and its composites to construct architectures with high surface area and porosity is also highly desirable in this respect.
396 X. Liang and L. F. Nazar

Mechanism of Electromagnetic Interference Shielding
sections.text:
Recent advances in the telecommunication industry coupled with the introduction of various electronic gadgets have revolutionized the modern era. However, the wide use of these new devices has also become a source of dreadful electromagnetic interference (EMI) pollution [1–5]. This interference in electromagnetic (EM) radiations disrupts the functioning and performance of many electronic devices, decreasing their efficiency and degrading their service life. Most importantly, the exposure of these EM radiations to humans may cause potential health hazards including cancer (long-term exposure) and nervous system disorders [6–9].
EMI shielding aims to minimize the transmission of EM radiation using a shield to maximize the reflection and/or absorption of EM waves incident at the interfaces between two media. EM waves transmit, reflect, or absorb in a medium. The electric and magnetic field components of EM waves are perpendicular to each other as well as to the propagation direction (Fig. 21.1). sections.heading: MXene-Based Electromagnetic Interference Shielding Materials
sections.text:
EMI shielding materials must possess high electrical conductivity. MXenes, discovered in 2011 [13], are a unique family of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal carbides and/or nitrides with the formula Mn+1XnTx, where M is an early transition metal (e.g., Ti, Zr, V, Nb, Ta, or Mo) and X is carbon and/or nitrogen [14]. MXenes possess an excellent electrical conductivity (~5000 S/cm), which
21 Electromagnetic Interference Shielding Using MXenes and Their Composites 403
makes them strong candidates for EMI shielding materials. Shahzad et al. [6] reported three types of MXene films (Ti3C2Tx, Mo2TiC2Tx, and Mo2Ti2C3Tx) and nacre-like MXene–polymer composite films (Ti3C2Tx–sodium alginate (SA)) with excellent EMI shielding performance. Figure 21.3 shows pristine MXene and composite films fabricated by using vacuum filtration of fully exfoliated MXene platelets with a thickness of 1 nm and sub-micron lengths. The microscopic images (Fig. 21.3a–d) depict the layer-by-layer assembly of the MXene flakes and the wellaligned MXene distribution in the MXene–polymer composite. Due to the excellent electrical conductivity of Ti3C2Tx (~5000 S/cm), 2.5- and 45-μm-thick Ti3C2Tx laminates exhibited extraordinary EMI SE values of 50 and 92 dB, respectively (Fig. 21.3e).
EMI SE values usually increased with increasing thickness of the shielding material, indicating that high EMI SE values were expected for thick samples. Surprisingly, at the same thickness level, the EMI SE of MXene was comparable to
404 C. M. Koo et al.
that of pure metal films with two orders of magnitude larger electrical conductivities. Moreover, the EMI SE was retained even when MXene flakes were added to the insulating SA polymer. In particular, an 8-μm-thick Ti3C2Tx–SA (90 wt. %) polymer composite film showed an extraordinary EMI SE value of 57 dB.
Shahzad et al. explained that the excellent EMI shielding capability of the MXene films originated from their exceptional electrical conductivity and partially from the customized architecture of the laminate films. When EM waves struck the surface of a MXene film of high electrical conductivity, most of them were immediately reflected because of the high impedance mismatch at the interface between air and the highly conductive MXene film with abundant free electrons, whereas the remaining EM waves passed through the MXene lattice structure, where interaction with MXene having a high electron density induced eddy currents that contributed to ohmic losses, resulting in a strong attenuation in the energy of the EM waves. The surviving EM waves, after passing through the first layer, encountered the next barrier layer, and the same process of EM wave reflection and attenuation was repeated. The MXene laminate, which is composed of several thousand MXene sheets, acts as multiple shields that enhances scattering and internal reflections. The process helped the MXene laminate to effectively absorb EM energy and dissipate in the form of heat. Therefore, MXene and MXene–composite films exhibited very high absorption loss behavior during the shielding. They further reported that these MXene films had additional advantages such as high electrical conductivity, easy processing, low density, and mechanical flexibility.
Electrically conductive polymer composites with good mechanical properties and long-term durability are highly desirable for EMI shielding. Generally, to achieve high electrical conductivity in polymer composites, large filler volumes are needed, which not only make the end product costly but also cause processing difficulties. Despite the excellent conventional intrinsic electrical conductivity of MXenes, a high MXene filler content is needed to develop conductive composites [16]. Sun et al. [15] demonstrated an electrostatic assembly approach for fabricating highly conductive MXene@polystyrene (PS) nanocomposites with a very low MXene content. Their concept was to utilize a segregated-structured composite to reduce the filler content while maintaining the electrical contact among MXene layers. As shown in Fig. 21.4a, positively charged PS beads with a diameter of 80, 310, and 570 μm were uniformly covered with negatively charged MXene sheets (zeta potential ~ −40 mV) through electrostatic interaction in an aqueous solution. The dried Ti3C2Tx-coated PS beads (Ti3C2Tx@PS) were molded by high-temperature compression molding. The Ti3C2Tx MXenes formed a segregated network in the composite (Fig. 21.4b–c). The electrical conductivity (σ ) rapidly increased with the increasing Ti3C2Tx volume fraction (ρ), which was according to the power law. Due to formation of the segregated structure, the composite reached the percolation threshold concentration at a very low filler content of 0.26 vol. %. The Ti3C2Tx@PS composite with a MXene filler content of 1.20 vol. % showed an electrical conductivity of 602 S/m, which further increased to 1081 S/m at a filler content of 1.90 vol. % (Fig. 21.4d). The effect of the high conductivity of the MXene–polymer composite was evident from the exceptional EMI shielding
21 Electromagnetic Interference Shielding Using MXenes and Their Composites 405
performance shown in Fig. 21.4e. Pristine PS showed negligible EMI SE owing to its insulating feature; however, when the filler (Ti3C2Tx) was introduced, the SE increased gradually and reached a remarkable value above 60 dB for the 1.90 vol. % Ti3C2Tx/polymer composite film with a thickness of 2 mm.
Sometimes, lightweight shielding materials are highly desirable for EMI applications, such as portable devices and aerospace fields. To achieve this, materials must possess low density. Liu et al. [17] reported an efficient and facile approach to fabricate freestanding, flexible, and lightweight Ti3C2Tx MXene foams with reasonable mechanical strength and low density. A MXene laminate film was fabricated via filtration and subsequently treated with hydrazine at 90 ◦C to induce the foaming process (Fig. 21.5a–d). The hydrazine treatment led to the formation of a continuous cellular structure and an associated volume expansion of the MXene film. After the foaming process, 1-, 3-, and 6-μm-thick MXene films were expanded to 6.2-, 18-, and 60-μm-thick MXene foams. The MXene films had an electrical conductivity of 4000 S/cm. The conductivities of the foams decreased to 588, 625, and 580 S/cm, respectively. Interestingly, the EMI SE values of the MXene foams were higher than those of their bulk counterparts even though the foams possessed lower electrical conductivities. The EMI SE of the 6-μm-thick (53 dB) MXene film improved to 70 dB for its foam counterpart (60 μm) (Fig. 21.5g–h). The considerably enhanced EMI SE values were ascribed to the multi-reflection and scattering of the incident waves within the porous structure of the MXene foam. Interestingly, the MXene foams had larger Ti/O and C/O ratios than pristine MXene films, indicating the partial removal of the oxygen functionalities during the foaming process. As a result, the MXene foams exhibited strong surface hydrophobicity and outstanding water resistance and durability, which was in contrast to the well-known hydrophilic nature of pristine MXene sheets (Fig. 21.5e–f). This foaming approach could overcome the instability of MXene films in moist environments by providing
406 C. M. Koo et al.
a hydrophobic surface as well as maintaining the properties of MXene, such as electrical conductivity and high EMI SE.
In addition to possessing the lightweight feature with excellent EMI SE, high mechanical strength is another essential property required for good shielding materials. Cao et al. [18] synthesized MXene/cellulose nanofiber composite paper with nacre-inspired structure possessing good mechanical properties and high EMI SE. Ultrathin and highly flexible Ti3C2Tx/cellulose nanofiber (CNF) composite papers bearing a nacre-like lamellar structure with varying content of MXene were fabricated via a vacuum filtration-induced self-assembly process (Fig. 21.6a). As a result of the interaction between one-dimensional (1D) CNFs and two-dimensional (2D) d-Ti3C2Tx (de-laminated) MXene, binary strengthening and toughening of the nacre-like d-Ti3C2Tx/CNF composite paper was achieved, leading to high tensile strength (up to 135.4 MPa) and fracture strain (up to 16.7%), as well as excellent folding endurance (up to 14,260 times). The as-prepared composite papers maintain the electrical conductivity expected from MXene-based polymer composites. Figure 21.6b shows the variation of electrical conductivity as a result of increase in the d-Ti3C2Tx filler content in CNFs. The d-Ti3C2Tx/CNF composite paper with 40 wt. % d-Ti3C2Tx content has an electrical conductivity of 0.6188 S/m, which was significantly improved to a value of 739.4 S/m when d-Ti3C2Tx content was increased to 90 wt.%. The composite papers with different filler contents (50, 80, and 90 wt.%) were subjected to EMI shielding measurements as shown in Fig. 21.6c, exhibiting excellent EMI SE of >20 dB at small thicknesses. High EMI SE was ascribed to large electrical conductivity as well as unique nacre-like structure that promotes the internal reflection and scattering of EM waves.
Conventional polymer composites comprising MXenes as nanofillers have also been shown to perform well for EMI shielding. For example, Liu et al. [19] used paraffin wax as a binder/matrix to fabricate MXene/paraffin composites using MXene sheets containing variable loads and tested their EMI shielding property in the 2–18 GHz frequency range. Results showed that the EMI SE values increased
21 Electromagnetic Interference Shielding Using MXenes and Their Composites 407
with increasing Ti3C2Tx filler content, and that the maximum SE value of 39.1 dB was reached for the Ti3C2Tx/paraffin composite with 60 wt. % Ti3C2Tx and a thickness of 2.0 mm.

sections.heading: MXenes as Microwave-Absorbing Materials
sections.text:
Another important aspect of undesirable EM radiation is microwave absorption (MWA). Microwave-absorbing materials have attracted extensive attention, as they can be used not only for general EMI shielding applications but also for crucial military stealth technology to make objects less detectable by radar. The minimum transmission of EM radiation for EMI shielding is simply achieved by high electrical conductivity, permittivity, and permeability. However, the control and design of microwave-absorbing materials is more challenging. MWA aims to minimize the reflection of EM radiation. For this purpose, EM-absorbing materials need an intermediate permittivity, moderate permeability, and low electrical conductivity to guarantee impedance matching at the interfaces between media and high energy loss in a lossy microwave-absorbing material.
408 C. M. Koo et al.
MWA is evaluated by reflection loss (RL), sometimes called as the reflection coefficient (RC). Unlike EMI SE, RL assumes no-transmission condition and is experimentally measured only when the microwave-absorbing materials are backed by highly conductive metal backgrounds that do not allow transmission. Thus, in the scheme of Fig. 21.2, medium 3 is replaced by a metal background. That is, the incident waves are either reflected or absorbed, without transmission.
RL is defined by the following eq.: [10]
RL = 20 log ∣∣∣∣ηin − η0ηin + η0 ∣∣∣∣ (21.12) where η0 is impedance of air and ηin is the characteristic input impedance of the material. ηin is expressed as follows: [10–11]

ηin is a function of ω, μ, σ , and ε. The first and the most important requirement for a microwave-absorbing material is impedance matching at the interface between the media, indicating that ηin should be matched with η0. A perfect matching condition minimizes the reflection of the incident wave at the surface of the microwave-absorbing material, which allows maximum penetration of the EM wave into the material. The second requirement is maximum energy loss through absorption in an absorber. To obtain maximum absorption loss, the materials should have a high attenuation constant. Since the electrical conductivity of microwaveabsorbing materials should be negligibly low for the impedance matching condition to be satisfied, the attenuation constant α is reconstructed by the following eq.: [3, 20]

The real parts of complex permittivity (ε ′ ) and permeability (μ ′ ) represent the stored potential electric and magnetic energy inside the material, respectively, whereas the imaginary parts (ε′′) and (μ′′) represent the loss as a result of heat dissipation due to various polarization mechanisms. Both dielectric loss tangent (tanδ = ε′′ε′ ) and magnetic loss tangent (tanδμ= μ ′′ μ′ ) are also used as key indicators of the loss mechanism. To understand peak patterns of RL curves, a quarter-wavelength matching model should be considered. The relationship between the absorber thickness (tm) and the
