peak frequency (fm) can be described by the following eq.: [21]
tm = nλ 4 = nc( 4fm √ (|εr | |μr |) ) ; n = 1, 3, 5, . . . (21.15)
where n and λ are the integer number and the wavelength of the EM waves, respectively, and |εr| and |μr| are the relative permittivity and permeability moduli at fm. When tm and fm satisfy the matching condition, the EM waves at the air–absorber interface and absorber–conductive metal background interface are out of phase by 180◦, resulting in their extinction at the air–absorber interface; consequently, the absorber possesses maximum absorption behavior at fm.
So far, various EM absorbents have been reported, including micro-/nano-sized magnetic or dielectric absorbing materials such as ferrite, magnetic metal powders, carbon-based materials, and intrinsically conducting polymers. Recently, Ti3C2Tx MXene materials have attracted extensive attention as microwave-absorbing materials due to their good electrical conductivity, unique surface characteristics, and ability to form heterostructures [22–23].
Qing et al. [24] reported the MWA properties of Ti3AlC2 (MAX)- and Ti3C2Tx (MXene)-filled epoxy composites. Ti3AlC2 was the source material for the fabrication of Ti3C2Tx. Both real and imaginary parts of the dielectric permittivity (ε ′ ′ and ε ′ ) of the Ti3C2Tx composites were much higher than those of the Ti3AlC2 powder composites with the same filler content (50 wt. %). Since Ti3C2Tx had a good electrical conductivity and better dispersion in the matrix than Ti3AlC2, the Ti3C2Tx composite had a much larger RL value (−17 dB) than the Ti3AlC2 composite (~ −3 dB) at a thickness of 1.4 mm and a much better microwave absorption bandwidth (RL < −10 dB with a frequency bandwidth of 6 GHz) as compared to no absorption of Ti3AlC2 composite in the given frequency range. The enhanced MWA properties of the MXene composites were ascribed to the improved dielectric polarization loss originating from their unique layered structure with a high aspect ratio, large number of defects, and large internal boundary layer capacitance.
Generally, the presence or creation of polarizable charges on the surface of nanomaterials enhances MWA. For example, Han et al. [16] reported that the partial oxidation of Ti3C2Tx had a positive effect on its EM absorption performance. When Ti3C2Tx was annealed at 800 ◦C in argon atmosphere, TiO2 nanoparticles in the form of anatase and rutile phases and amorphous carbon were partially formed on the surface of Ti3C2Tx. The partially oxidized Ti3C2Tx–wax composites showed much larger ε ′ ′ and ε ′ values than un-annealed Ti3C2Tx composites and corresponding MAX phase polymer composites, indicating a much larger dielectric loss. The dielectric composite with 50 wt. % annealed Ti3C2Tx exhibited an excellent RC of −48.4 dB at 11.6 GHz with a reasonable microwave absorption bandwidth of 2.5 GHz corresponding to RC value < −10 dB.
Han et al. [25] also reported the EM absorption performance of fully oxidized Ti3C2Tx. When Ti3C2Tx was annealed and fully oxidized at 800 ◦C in CO2, Ti3C2Tx was completely transformed into TiO2 nanoparticles (where TiO2 existed only in the rutile phase) and amorphous carbon (Fig. 21.7a). The as-synthesized
410 C. M. Koo et al.
laminated carbon/TiO2 were embedded in a wax matrix to fabricate polymer composites with different filler contents. The real and imaginary parts of permittivity of the composites increased with increasing filler content (Fig. 21.7b–c). The peak frequency (fm) of the RC curves decreased with increasing sample thickness due to the quarter-wavelength matching effect described in Eq. 21.15. The RC value reached −36 dB at 15.5 and 10.5 GHz for sample thicknesses of 1.6 and 2.2 mm, respectively (Fig. 21.7d). The effective microwave absorption bandwidth corresponding to RC value < −10 dB covers the whole Ku-band (12.4–18 GHz) with a thickness of only 1.7 mm, whereas for X-band, the effective microwave absorption is obtained from 8.7 to 12.3 GHz with a matching thickness of 2.2 mm.
Han et al. proposed the associated absorption mechanism based on the electrical conductivity, surface characteristics, and heterostructure of Ti3C2Tx MXenes in the composites. The dipole polarization caused by the surface functional groups, localized defects, and dangling bonds of Ti3C2Tx MXenes improved the dielectric loss. Additionally, because of the multilayered structure and high conductivity of MXenes, they could facilitate excited hopping charge carriers by constructing more conductive paths. Meanwhile, 2D-stacked Ti3C2Tx sheets could contribute to more interfaces, thus increasing the EM wave propagation path and electric current path
21 Electromagnetic Interference Shielding Using MXenes and Their Composites 411
discontinuities, which in turn led to further attenuation of the EM wave. Moreover, after annealing, the decrease in number of the hydroxyl terminal groups and the formation of amorphous carbon gave rise to orientation polarizations in the alternating EM field owing to its disordered character and a high concentration of structural defects and oxygen functional groups, as shown in Fig. 21.7e. Furthermore, the formation of the TiO2 phase optimized the impedance matching with free space because of the low permittivity of TiO2. Importantly, the incorporation of TiO2 nanocrystals and carbon could generate dielectric dipole interactions at multiple interfaces and the associated relaxation and could form a capacitor-like structure to induce strong energy loss in the EM wave.
Li et al. [26] reported a similar finding using Ti2CTx-based MXenes. Controllable heterogeneous structures were constructed via etching in an oxidation environment. The improved EM wave absorption capability of the as-prepared Ti2CTx/TiO2 and C/TiO2 nanocomposites compared to that of pristine Ti2CTx MXenes was attributed to their enhanced polarization loss and higher conductivity loss. The C/TiO2 nanocomposites attained a minimum RC of −50.3 dB at 7.1 and 14.2 GHz and an effective absorption bandwidth of 4.7 GHz corresponding to RC value < −10 dB (covering the entire X-band) for a thickness of 2.1 mm, which confirmed the excellent EM wave absorption properties of these heterogeneous structures.
In another report, Li et al. [27] showed that combining 2D Ti3C2Tx and 1D carbon nanotubes (CNTs) could significantly enhance the EM wave absorption properties of the composites. CNTs were uniformly distributed in the interlayers of Ti3C2Tx MXene flakes, as shown in Fig. 21.8a–b. Compared with pristine Ti3C2Tx MXenes and a-Ti3C2Tx MXenes (annealed), the Ti3C2Tx/CNT nanocomposites with a hierarchical sandwich microstructure provided excellent EM wave absorption performance in the frequency range of 2–18 GHz (Fig. 21.8c), including a higher absorption intensity (minimum RC was −30 dB), broader effective absorption bandwidth (4.46 GHz for corresponding RC value of < −10 dB), lower filler content (35 wt. %), and smaller thickness (only 1.55 mm).
Qing et al. [28] reported that the synergistic effect of nitrogen-doped graphene (N-GP) and Ti3C2Tx in epoxy composites could provide an exciting opportunity to tune the MWA properties of MXene-based composites. The N-GP/Ti3C2Tx/epoxy
412 C. M. Koo et al.
composite showed a highly improved dielectric constant (ε ′ ) and dielectric loss (ε ′ ′ ), which resulted in an excellent RL value of −52 dB for a thickness of 1.4 mm and a large absorption bandwidth of 7.1 GHz below RL value of −10 dB. The excellent performance of the as-synthesized composite was ascribed to the unique microstructure and numerous defects of the N-GP and Ti3C2Tx nanosheets, a larger internal boundary layer capacitance, the formation of a microcapacitor network, and the evolution of conductive/dielectric loss.
Similarly, Tong et al. [29] reported the synergistic effects of a conductive polymer (polypyrrole, PPy) matrix and Ti3C2Tx to improve the absorption of EM waves in MXene-based polymer composites with a wider effective bandwidth. Ti3C2Tx/PPy hybrids were synthesized via in situ polymerization of PPy in Ti3C2Tx dispersions. Compared with pristine MXenes, the EM parameters (real and imaginary parts of dielectric permittivity and dielectric loss tangents) increased when a conducting PPy polymer matrix was used, achieving a minimum RL of −49.2 dB at 8.5 GHz and an effective absorption bandwidth of 4.9 GHz corresponding to RL value < −10 dB (Fig. 21.9a–d). The enhanced absorption was closely correlated with the well-designed heterogeneous multilayered structure, extra heterogeneous interfaces, conductive paths, surface functional groups, localized defects, and synergistic effect
21 Electromagnetic Interference Shielding Using MXenes and Their Composites 413
of Ti3C2Tx and the conducting filler network, which significantly improved the impedance matching and dielectric energy loss.
Qian et al. [30] reported a mild method to prepare an urchin-like ZnO–MXene Ti3C2Tx nanocomposite through a co-precipitation process. The nanocomposite delivered a substantially enhanced EM absorption performance with an optimal RL of −26.30 dB that cover a wide frequency range (from 16.6 to 18.0 GHz) under RL value < −10 dB, significantly higher than that of pristine Ti3C2Tx (−6.70 dB). The large increase in RL was ascribed to the features and structure of the ZnO–Ti3C2Tx nanocomposite. The surface groups and localized defects on the Ti3C2Tx layers led to dipole polarization, which significantly affected the dielectric loss. In the ZnO– Ti3C2Tx nanocomposite, the balance between the complex parts of permeability and permittivity led the material to satisfy the impedance matching conditions, resulting in better absorption of the incident EM waves compared to that in pristine MXenes.
Coupling of magnetic materials with MXenes was attempted to improve the impedance matching, broaden the effective absorption bandwidth, and enhance the absorption intensity. Yang et al. [31] reported that coupling of Ti3C2Tx MXenes with a magnetic loss material, Ba3Co2Fe24O41 (Co2Z), could improve MWA properties of the formed composites, where Co2Z represents Z-type hexagonal barium ferrite
414 C. M. Koo et al.
(Fig. 21.10a). Polyvinyl butyral (PVB) was used as the matrix polymer. In the magnetic hysteresis loops (M–H), the PVB/Co2Z/Ti3C2 composite revealed an S-shaped curve and a saturation magnetization (Ms) of 16 emu/g. The magnetic properties were induced by the presence of magnetic Co2Z in the composite. The PVB/Co2Z/Ti3C2 composite had a minimum RL of −46.3 dB at 5.8 GHz and a very wide effective absorption bandwidth of 1.6 GHz for a thickness of 2.8 mm corresponding to RL below −10 dB (Fig. 21.10b). The excellent RL performance was attributed to various dielectric and magnetic loss phenomena. The magnetic energy dissipation of materials could be caused by hysteresis loss, eddy current loss and domain wall displacement, and natural resonance loss. Since magnetic hysteresis derived from irreversible magnetization was negligible under a weak applied magnetic field and domain wall motion loss was also negligible in the GHz region, eddy current loss and natural resonance loss were the main contributors to magnetic loss. In Fig. 21.10c, frequency independence of the μ′′(μ′)−2f−1 values in two frequency ranges, 2–9 and 13–18 GHz, verified the eddy current loss effect is dominant, while the strong peak value in 9–13 GHz supported the resonance loss effect (Fig. 21.10d). Additionally, high permeability features originating from magnetic Co2Z benefited the impedance matching.
Li et al. [32] also reported the absorption properties of Ni–Zn ferrite/Ti3C2 composites, where the main reason of using ferrite was to enhance the synergistic contribution of the two intrinsically different materials. The Ni–Zn ferrite/Ti3C2 composite with 5 wt. % Ti3C2 content exhibited a high RL of −42.5 dB at 13.5 GHz and a very broad effective absorption bandwidth of ~3 GHz (12–15 GHz) corresponding to RL below −10 dB. Like the PVB/Co2Z/Ti3C2 composite [31], the excellent microwave-absorbing performance was attributed to the magnetic loss, dielectric loss, conductivity loss, and internal reflection and scattering phenomena.

sections.heading: Future Prospects
sections.text:
EMI shielding using MXenes has attracted immense interest since the breakthrough discovery of MXenes in 2016. Several reports on the use of MXenes as primary or secondary constituents to investigate EMI shielding and microwave-absorbing properties have been published. However, the use of MXenes is still in its infancy, and there is considerable scope for further exploring these materials to improve its properties. One of the approaches could be to develop porous MXenes with high mechanical strength, where the void spaces inside MXenes could act as reflecting surfaces, thereby increasing the overall EMI SE. Developing lightweight and flexible conducting polymer composites based on MXenes composites also offers a new avenue of research. Single-layer MXenes possess excellent transparency comparable to graphene and can serve as a platform to develop transparent MXene films for next-generation telecommunication gadgets. Since MXenes have a large family and only a few MXenes have been explored for EMI shielding thus far, there is further scope to explore other MXenes for EMI shielding or MWA applications.
21 Electromagnetic Interference Shielding Using MXenes and Their Composites 415
Magnetic MXenes form an area of future research as they can not only improve the EMI shielding property but also significantly influence the MWA properties. The addition of other magnetic constituents in MXene-based polymer composite systems offers a great potential for the research and improvement of properties through the synergistic contribution of MXene and other filler materials.

sections.heading: MXenes for Environmental and Water Treatment Applications
Kashif Rasool, Ravi P. Pandey, P. Abdul Rasheed, Golibjon R. Berdiyorov, and Khaled A. Mahmoud
Introduction
sections.text:
MXenes are a large family of transition metal carbides, nitrides, and carbonitrides with a general formula of Mn+1XnTx (n = 1–3), where M is an early transition metal, X is carbon and/or nitrogen, and Tx denotes surface termination (-OH, -O, or F) [1]. MXenes are prepared from layered ternary metal carbides (MAX phases) by selectively etching of the group A element layer [2]. Numerous MXenes including Ti3C2, Ti2C, Nb4C3 [3], Ti3CN, Ta4C3 [4], Nb2C, V2C [5], and Nb4C3 were synthesized from MAX phases [3]. In addition, several MXene compositions have been developed with random arrangement of two or more transition metals such as (Ti0.5,Nb0.5)2C, (V0.5,Cr0.5)3C2 [6–10], and more complex structures have been theoretically predicted. Synthesizing MXenes from their respective MAX precursor has been done by two major routes: (1) direct use of hydrogen fluoride (HF) as the etchant solution or (2) with in situ HF formed by reacting hydrochloric acid (HCl) with a fluoride salt such as lithium fluoride (LiF), ammonium hydrogen bifluoride (NH4HF2), and ammonium fluoride (NH4F) [11, 12]. In most cases, only Al had been successfully etched from MAX phases to prepare MXene. However, synthesis of MXene through selective etching of silicon from titanium silicon carbide has been recently reported [13]. The first and most established MXene is titanium carbide (Ti3C2Tx), which is synthesized by etching Al from Ti3AlC2 [11]. Ti3AlC2 has a layered hexagonal structure with P63/mmc symmetry, forming strong Ti-C bonds, which are a combination of covalent, metallic, and ionic in nature, as well as purely metallic Ti-Al bonds [14, 15]. Different stacking patterns are predicted by X-ray diffraction spectroscopy (XRD) for MXene depending on the type of precursor and
K. Rasool · R. P. Pandey · P. A. Rasheed · G. R. Berdiyorov · K. A. Mahmoud ( ) Qatar Environment and Energy Research Institute (QEERI), Hamad Bin Khalifa University (HBKU), Doha, Qatar e-mail: kmahmoud@hbku.edu.qa
© Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2019 B. Anasori, Y. Gogotsi (eds.), 2D Metal Carbides and Nitrides (MXenes), https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-19026-2_22
417
418 K. Rasool et al.
preparation method [11]. For example, Ti3C2Tx prepared by (LiF/HCl) shows a (002) peak at around 7.82◦ corresponding to the c lattice parameter = 22.6 Å, which is higher than the c (19.6 Å) of Ti3C2Tx (HF) around 9.02◦. This is most likely due to the difference in the number of water layers between the stacks [12]. The diverse chemistries of the MX bonds in MXenes combined with their high surface functionality lead to a range of properties including high electronic and in some cases metallic conductivity, hydrophilicity, tunable band gaps, and plasmonic properties. For this reason, MXene research has been geared toward versatile applications in the fields of energy storage as supercapacitors and lithium ion battery electrodes [1, 6, 16–18], electronics as electromagnetic shielding materials [19], catalysis and photocatalysis [20–22], electrodes, sensors [23, 24], therapeutic agents [25–28], and substrates for surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) [29]. Meanwhile, different delaminated, multi-layered (ML) MXenes as well as MXene-based composites have found their niche in the area of water treatment and environmental remediation applications including ion separation membranes [30–32], heavy metal removal [33, 34], capacitive deionization [35], antimicrobial coatings [36], and photocatalytic degradation.
The previously mentioned wet chemistry synthesis routes result in ML and few layer (with proper delamination) flakes of MXene with surface functional groups. These functional groups (-OH, -O, or F) can react with the environment and affect the long-term stability of MXenes, posing a major obstacle toward scale-up and commercialization of MXene products. Pristine MXene flakes degrade by forming oxides when exposed to oxygen in the presence of water or when operating at high temperatures [37, 38]. The layered structure characteristic of MXene is destroyed during oxidation due to gradual nucleation of titanium dioxide (TiO2) crystals at the edges of flakes and over time forming TiO2 on carbon sheets. The oxidation of MXene to TiO2 precipitates corresponds to visual changes in solution color from translucent greenish-black to a cloudy white [2, 37]. Few approaches have been developed to overcome the shortcomings of MXene stability in aqueous media. Several MXene-based composites, for example, have been developed with the hope to impart a synergistic effect by reducing agglomeration, providing conductive pathways, and improving overall stability [36].
This chapter will focus on MXenes potential for environmental remediation applications including water purification using membrane separation, photocatalytic, and adsorptive properties. Bactericidal properties, toxicity, and environmental impact of MXenes will also be discussed.

sections.heading: MXenes for Water Treatment Membranes
sections.text:
Membrane desalination and water purification technologies have become more practical and energy-efficient means to secure freshwater resources globally. Ideal desalination and water treatment membranes should provide high flux, proper selectivity, improved stability, and resistance to fouling throughout their usable
22 MXenes for Environmental and Water Treatment Applications 419
lifespan. Also, membranes should be thin yet mechanically stable to maximize water permeability and consistent salt rejection. Two-dimensional (2D) carbon nanomaterials, such as graphene and graphene oxide (GO), have demonstrated exceptional performance as membranes with properties such as ultrahigh water flux, molecular and ionic sieving capability, and strong resistance to biofouling [39]. The layered structure and composition of MXenes provide unique advantages as water treatment materials like hydrophilicity, electronic and ionic conductivity, remarkable flexibility and mechanical stability, tunable interlayer spacing, and high accessible surface area.
The first MXene water treatment membrane was prepared by vacuum-assisted filtration (VAF) of MXene colloidal suspension on a hydrophilic substrate with a pore size below 0.50 μm. MXene sheets are easily assembled into layered stacks with a well-defined interlayer distance, which can act as selective transport channels. Nanometer-thin MXene sheets were stacked into a film with a 1.2 μm cross-section supported on a PVDF membrane, which was used for the charge- and size selective rejection of ions and molecules (Fig. 22.1(i)) [32]. The membrane also showed a water flux of ~37.4 L Bar−1 h−1 m−2, separating ions ranging both in hydration radius and charge. The membrane showed high selectivity toward single-, doubleand triple-charged metal cations and different dye cations.
Multiple-charged cations (Mg2+, Ca2+, and Al3+) with radii smaller than the interlayer spacing of MXene layers (∼6.4 Å based on XRD) were able to
420 K. Rasool et al.
migrate between the interlayer capillary pathways, causing an initial increase in the interlayer spacing. Further intercalation of ions eventually leads to shrinkage due to electrostatic attraction between the negatively charged MXene surface and the highly charged cations, as illustrated in Fig. 22.1(ii). This shrinkage results in slower permeation rates observed for the multiple-charged ions. Meanwhile monovalent ions such as (Na+) are able to move between the membrane layers and form an electric double layer on both sides of the channel, leading to repulsion of MXene sheets and enabling higher permeation rates (7–25 times faster than double- and triple-charged ions). Consequentially, the hydrophilic nature of MXene and the presence of water layers between the sheets promote high water flux. Ti3C2Tx membranes have demonstrated a higher performance than GO in the separation of higher charged cations.
Solvent-resistant nanofiltration (SRNF) membranes were prepared by incorporating Ti3C2Tx into two typical polymeric matrixes: hydrophilic polyethyleneimine (PEI) and hydrophobic polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS). In these composites, Ti3C2Tx nanosheets were horizontally aligned in the polymer matrix, generating obvious interference with polymer chain motion, promoting the transport of alcohol molecules by providing additional pathways along the surface of nanosheets via –OH adsorption sites (Fig. 22.2).
Steric effects and interfacial interactions of the uniformly dispersed Ti3C2Tx enhanced the thermal and mechanical stability, as well as solvent resistance of these polymer-MXene composite membranes. Alcohol flux of polymer-MXene composite membranes demonstrated 30% improvement compared to PEI membrane and 162% to PDMS membrane. At the same time, the rejection abilities have been significantly improved with a molecular weight cutoff (MWCOs) below 200 Da due to solute transfer blockage by the nanosheets [40].
Another lamellar membrane was prepared by tailoring the interspacing between MXene sheets in order to achieve a higher flux and improved selectivity of ion rejection. The membrane was prepared by intercalation of positively charged
22 MXenes for Environmental and Water Treatment Applications 421
Fe(OH)3 in the negatively charged MXene nanosheets followed by vacuum filtration on anodic aluminum oxide (AAO) substrate. Transport pathways were obtained by dissolving Fe(OH)3 nanoparticles (NPs) by hydrochloric acid solution (HCl) (Fig. 22.3) [41]. After removing Fe(OH)3, the membrane exhibited a remarkable water permeance of 1084 L m−2 h−1 bar−1 and a high rejection rate of 90% for Evans blue (EB), which was 5 and 10 times higher than that of the pristine MXene membrane and the membrane before removing Fe(OH)3 NPs, respectively. Membrane thickness also affected the rejection performance as a 0.8-μm-thick membrane exhibited 100% rejection of EB, cytochrome (Cyt. c) molecules, and 5 nm gold NPs. The membrane maintained its durability, rejection efficiency, and water permeance for over 28 h of continuous filtration. However, the major drawback of this type of membrane is the limited size range for rejection with low rejection of salts.
Various MXene-based membranes were prepared via VAF, the first example being MXene-based membrane filtered onto a polyethersulfone (PES) support. The prepared ultrafiltration membrane shows water flux of 115 L m−2 h−1 and 92.3% rejection of Congo red dye at 0.1 MPa pressure [30]. Another type of ultrathin 2D
422 K. Rasool et al.
MXene membrane was prepared for pervaporation desalination application [42]. The polyacrylonitrile (PAN) supported MXene with ~60 nm thickness showed 85.4 L m−2 h−1 water permeation and 99.5% NaCl rejection at 65 ◦C. Moreover, this membrane exhibited long-term durability and performance in a synthetic seawater system, highlighting the potential of MXene-based materials in the water treatment field.
Recently, a MXene composite membrane modified by silver NPs (AgNPs) was developed in an attempt to improve water permeation and antifouling properties [31]. AgNPs-modified MXene membrane (Ag@MXene) was prepared by selfreduction of silver nitrate on the surface of MXene sheets in aqueous medium. SEM images (surface and cross-section) of the PVDF substrate, pristine MXene, and 21% Ag@MXene composite membranes are given in Fig. 22.4(i). Crosssectional SEM image of the 21% Ag@MXene composite membrane exhibited layer by layer stacking of MXene nanosheets followed by stacking of AgNPs between the sheets (Fig. 22.4(i(d))). AgNPs attached on the surface of MXene created slit interspacing between the MXene nanosheets to provide additional
22 MXenes for Environmental and Water Treatment Applications 423
nanopores for water permeation as shown in Fig. 22.4(ii). The 21% Ag@MXene membrane showed improved water flux (~420 L m−2 h−1 bar−1) and rejection of methyl green (MG) (92.32%) and Rhodamine B (RhB) (79.93%) (Fig. 22.4(iii(a, b))). Additionally, the antibacterial activity of the 21% Ag@MXene composite membrane was studied and shown to inhibit the growth of more than 99% of E. coli on the membrane surface.
Water transport phenomena through layered 2D nanostructures including MXenes have been subjected to several theoretical and experimental investigations. Among the different computational methods, density functional theory (DFT) has been proven to be an effective method for describing a variety of unprecedented mechanical, chemical, and physical properties of MXene family materials, despite the complex structure of MXene consisting of light/heavy transition metals and organics. DFT has been used to explore water and ion transport through Ti3C2(OH)2 MXene [43, 44]. A particular focus was given to find the origin for charge selective ionic sieving through the material, which was related to surface charges of the material [32]. Charge calculations using the density derived electrostatic and chemical charges method showed the negative charges on the surface of Ti3C2Tx. A simple model, consisting of MXene bilayer and intercalating ions with the first hydration shell (Fig. 22.5(a–c)), was used to study the effect of the surface charges on the ionic sieving. The results show that the interlayer distance “d” decreases with increasing the charge state of the ions due to electrostatic interactions. Such a dynamic response of the bilayer MXene to intercalating ions was also obtained in the following DFT molecular dynamics (MD) simulations by the same authors [45]. The obtained results show the importance of surface functionalization in practical applications of MXenes in water treatment.
Reactive force field (ReaxFF) model was proposed for Ti3C2(OH)2 MXene [46], which in contrast to classical force fields [47, 48] is a general bond-order dependent potential that accounts for dynamic formation and dissociation of chemical bonds during the simulations. The ReaxFF was used to study theoretically the dynamics of water molecules in MXene membranes using MD simulations to address the stability of these membranes in hydrogenous media [46]. The calculated diffusion coefficient of water in such a confined space was in good agreement with the experiment. The ReaxFF MD simulations also predicted the reduction of the water self-diffusion coefficient by 2 orders of magnitude after the intercalation of potassium ions between the interlayer spacing. This indicates to enhanced operational stability of MXene against delamination after ion intercalation. The predicted dynamic response of MXene layers to intercalating ions (i.e., reduced c-L parameter) after ion intercalation (see Fig. 22.6) is in good agreement with DFT MD simulations [45].
424 K. Rasool et al.

sections.heading: Bactericidal Properties of MXenes
sections.text:
Understanding the antibacterial characteristics is an important success criterion for efficient application of MXene in environmental remediation and water treatment applications. The antibacterial activity of single- and few-layer Ti3C2Tx MXene flakes in colloidal solution against E. coli and B. subtilis was first revealed by our group [49]. It was concluded that Ti3C2Tx can be effectively used to inhibit bacterial growth as shown in Fig. 22.7. The antibacterial activity of Ti3C2Tx MXene was compared with GO, for both bacterial strains. Ti3C2Tx MXene showed higher bactericidal activity as compared to GO (Fig. 22.7i(a, b)), and Ti3C2Tx dispersions revealed much stronger antibacterial activity against B. subtilis than that of E. coli.
Contrary to Ti3C2, the antibacterial activity of Ti2C MXene did not show any significant bactericidal effects against gram-positive bacteria [50]. In a separate investigation, layered Ti2C and Ti3C2 sheets were synthesized from their Ti2AlC and Ti3AlC2 MAX precursors, respectively, by HF etching, and their bioactivities
22 MXenes for Environmental and Water Treatment Applications 425
were compared against gram-negative (E. coli) and gram-positive (Bacillus sp., S. aureus, and Sarcina) bacteria [51]. Given the similar chemical composition of Ti2C and Ti3C2, it was unclear if and how the different stoichiometry would influence their bioactivity. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) revealed that the interlayer distance in Ti2C was larger than Ti3C2 by 0.53 Å. It turned out that Ti2C had a minimal effect on the growth of gram-positive Bacillus sp., S. aureus, and Sarcina strains, and no bactericidal effect was observed against E. coli bacteria. On the other hand, Ti3C2 showed strong bactericidal properties against both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria. In conclusion, the changes in the structure of MXene at the atomic scale may have played a key role in their bioactivity. The anti-biofouling characteristics of micrometer-thick Ti3C2Tx membrane coatings were evaluated using colony count method and demonstrated significant inhibition of E. coli and B. subtilis growth on the membrane surface as shown by Fig. 22.8. Surprisingly, aged Ti3C2Tx membrane showed over 99% growth inhibition of both bacteria, much higher than that of fresh MXene coated membranes showing that partial oxidation of Ti3C2Tx membrane is beneficial to increase the overall antibacterial properties [52]. The antibacterial activity of the aged membrane surface was initially hypothesized to decrease due to membrane surface oxidation. However, the formation of TiO2 nanocrystals on the Ti3C2Tx membrane surface enhanced antibacterial performance. In another study, the antibacterial response and mechanical properties of MXenes have been enhanced by decorating AgNPs on MXene surface as shown earlier by in situ Ag reduction on Ti3C2Tx nanosheets [31]. This study showed excellent anti-biofouling response of 21% Ag@MXene composite membrane against E. coli strain, which was much more pronounced compared to that of the pristine Ti3C2Tx MXene membranes. Enhanced bactericidal activity was attributed to the formation of AgNPs and TiO2 NPs onto the MXene surface. It is important to note that there are several factors including synthesis methods and conditions such as nature of
426 K. Rasool et al.
MXene precursors, presence of different impurities, coexistence of different MAX phases, etching protocol, type of intercalants, stability, and temperature, which affect the physicochemical properties of MXenes and thus their performance in different applications [53].
There are several important aspects that could influence the antibacterial performance of MXenes including lateral size, shape, number of layers, surface modification, agglomeration, and dispersion. The shape of several nanomaterials such as AgNPs, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and graphene is reported to have a significant effect on their antimicrobial characteristics as it directly impacts the physical interaction between nanosheets, the bacterial membrane, and across the lipid bilayer [54]. Similar to graphene, the bactericidal properties of MXenes might be affected by the number of stacked sheets in a flake upon delamination [55]. Poor delamination can result in ML nanosheets, weakening the “nano-knife” effect, and aggregation of the nanosheets. It was found that MXene flakes with sharp corners and edges, analogues to graphene sheets, can easily impale the bacterial cell membrane [56]. Nevertheless, further investigations of the antibacterial mechanism of different type of MXenes are needed to determine the range of potential applications of these new materials. Similar to graphene, three major mechanisms can be proposed for MXene’s bactericidal activity—(i) oxidative stress induced with and/or without the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), (ii) nano-knives derived from the action of sharp edges, and (iii) wrapping or trapping bacterial membranes [55, 57–61]. Oxidative stress has been reported as a common mechanism of antibacterial activity of several nanomaterials other than 2D graphene [55]. The production and impact of ROS in MXenes are not well studied and need to be exclusively investigated. As for ROS-independent stress, glutathione serves as one of the major cellular antioxidant enzymes in bacteria, and its oxidation in the presence of different nanomaterials has been widely used as an indicator of the nanomaterial’s induced oxidative stress. Loss of glutathione was observed after reaction with Ti3C2Tx MXene possibly due to chemical reactions and/or physi-sorption [49]. Currently, there is no data available on thiols interaction with Ti3C2Tx and/or any other MXene. Further investigations
428 K. Rasool et al.
are needed to explore the possible mechanism associated with oxidative stress. The proposed mechanisms are physical damage of the cell membrane by direct contact of the MXene nanosheets followed by generation of ROS [49, 52]. More investigations of antimicrobial activity and mechanisms of different members of MXenes family using experimental and theoretical simulations are urgently needed. A systematic study of the experimental conditions (i.e., pH, temperature), degree of MXene delamination, intercalation, terminations, and potential impurities should also be done for a wholesome understanding of those parameters on the bactericidal activity.

sections.heading: MXenes for Photocatalytic Applications
sections.text:
MXenes can also be used for photocatalytic applications by altering their surface chemistries [62]. Even though some MXenes show narrow band-gap semiconducting behavior, their band-gap can be tuned by altering their surface termination groups (F, OH, or O) or by arranging the surface groups relative to the M atoms to satisfy the requirements for photocatalysis applications. For example, Ti3C2F2 and Ti3C2(OH)2 can be narrow band-gap semiconductors depending on how the surface groups (F or OH) are geometrically terminated [62, 63]. Theoretical investigations were carried out to study the structural, electronic, and optical properties of M2CT2 MXenes (where M = Ti, Zr, and Hf and T = F, O, and OH) with different geometries [64]. It was found that the M2CT2 MXenes with functional groups located above the opposite side of metal atoms have the largest cohesive energies and, therefore, are most energetically favorable. For this kind of MXene, the valence band maxima (VBM) is mainly composed of p orbitals of carbon atoms, while the conduction band minima (CBM) consists of M-d (M = Ti, Zr, Hf) states. Hence, the M2CT2 with the functional groups locating above the opposite side metal atoms have suitable band gaps (0.92 ~ 1.75 eV), visible-light absorption, high redox potential of photo-induced holes, efficient separation of electron-hole pairs, and exceptional carrier mobilities. All of these properties make this functionalized MXene suitable for photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants and water splitting technologies. Based on DFT and deformation potential theory, 2D Zr2CO2 and Hf2CO2 were considered promising photocatalysts for water splitting due to their remarkable anisotropic carrier mobility, strong optical absorption in both visible and ultraviolet wavelengths, and their stability in aqueous media [65]. Another DFT study demonstrated that Ti2CO2 and W2CO2 MXenes are the highly active catalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) based on number of HER active sites, conductivity, and intrinsic catalytic activity [66]. Among different MXenes (Sc2CF2, Sc2CO2, and Sc2C(OH)2) with the same energetically favorable geometries, Sc2CF2 had appropriate band structure and higher redox capability of photoactivated carriers, which leads to a better photocatalytic performance [67].
The first experimental attempt have used ML Ti3C2Tx MXene as a potential photo-catalyst for the degradation of MB and acid blue 80 [37]. MB was degraded
22 MXenes for Environmental and Water Treatment Applications 429
by 81% while interacting with MXene (Ti3C2Tx) under UV within 5 h, whereas only 18% degradation occurred in the dark. Up to 62% of acid blue was degraded after interacting with MXene under UV within 5 h. On the other hand, no degradation occurred in the dark even after 20 h. The formation of titanium hydroxide and/or TiO2 on the surface of MXene contributed to the photocatalytic effect under UV illumination. Nevertheless, the photo-catalytic activity of MXene is still limited due to fast recombination of photo-generated electron-hole pairs, narrow lightabsorption range, and limited stability in oxygen-obtained water [63]. This is most likely due to the presence of free electrons in the carbide layer of MXene beneath the oxide surface [68]. To overcome these disadvantages, TiO2/Ti3C2 nanocomposites have been synthesized and evaluated to determine the enhancement in photocatalytic activity by photodegradation of methyl orange under ultraviolet light irradiation [69]. Nanocomposites showed higher photocatalytic activity of 98% than individual TiO2 (77%) and Ti3C2 (42%). The increased photocatalytic performance can be attributed to more effective electron-hole separation in the composite system relative to pristine TiO2 and Ti3C2 samples under UV light irradiation, which may be due to the formation of a Ti3C2 and TiO2 heterojunction.
TiO2/Ti3C2Tx composites have been used for the production of hydrogen through photocatalytic water splitting [70]. In the TiO2/Ti3C2Tx composite, Ti3C2Tx provides a 2D platform for intimate interactions with TiO2 NPs and acts as an electron sink to promote the separation of photo-generated charge carriers. The photocatalytic performance of this material varies with the Ti3C2Tx content in the system. It was suggested that the intimate contact between TiO2 and Ti3C2Tx is essential for efficient charge transfer. Hence, the composites prepared by a hydrothermal route possess higher hydrogen yield in the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction than physical mixing methods. Around 400% enhancement in the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction was found for the TiO2/Ti3C2Tx (5 wt%) composite in comparison with pure rutile TiO2 under visible-light irradiation. Here, the enhancement of the photocatalytic hydrogen yield can be attributed mainly to the intrinsic properties of the metal carbide co-catalyst in the photocatalytic system.
Generally, in photocatalytic applications, exposing the highly active facets to the photoexcitation source has been regarded as a powerful approach to develop high-performance photocatalysts. It has been established that the (001) facet is the most active facet in TiO2 nanosheets, and coupling TiO2 nanosheets having (001) facets with other 2D materials can enhance photocatalytic activity effectively [60, 71, 72]. The photocatalytic performance of a composite comprised of (001) facets of TiO2 nanosheets and layered Ti3C2 has been fabricated and evaluated [73]. The highly active (001) facets of TiO2 in the composite can afford high-efficiency photogeneration of electron-hole pairs, as well as the carrier separation promoted by hole trapping effect by the interfacial Schottky junction with 2D Ti3C2, which acts as a reservoir of holes. DFT calculations show that the interface formation originates from the overlapping of the Ti d orbital and the O p orbital, as shown in Fig. 22.9a, b. The photocatalytic activity of the (001) TiO2/Ti3C2 toward photocatalytic degradation of methyl orange dye was evaluated under ultraviolet irradiation and found 2.3-fold higher degradation than that of particulateTiO2/ Ti3C2. Since the
430 K. Rasool et al.
Fermi level of Ti3C2 is more negative than the conduction band of TiO2, the transfer of electrons is forbidden at the interfaces between TiO2 (001) surfaces and Ti3C2. Also, the work function of –OH terminated Ti3C2 sheets (1.8 eV) is much lower than that of TiO2 (4.924 eV for (001) surface, 6.578 eV for (101) surface). A Schottky barrier may be established through their interfaces, and the photogenerated holes instead of electrons could be injected from TiO2 to Ti3C2-OH. The formed Schottky barrier at TiO2/Ti3C2 interfaces could effectively prevent the holes from flowing back to TiO2 (Fig. 22.9c). The (001) TiO2-Ti3C2 hybrid provides enhanced photocatalytic degradation of methyl orange by overcoming the problems of fast recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes and the utilization of highly active {001} facets of TiO2.
A hybrid of 2D Ti3C2 and Ti3+-doped rutile TiO2 exposing (111) facets has been evaluated for its photocatalytic activity in removing pollutants from water under visible irradiation [74]. The transformation of TiO2 octahedrons from (110) facets to (111) facets was increased by increasing the NH4F concentration during the synthesis process. In addition, the treatment of hydrazine hydrate induces the lattice vacancy by embedding the Ti3+ dopant within the bulk of TiO2 without affecting its
22 MXenes for Environmental and Water Treatment Applications 431
crystallographic structure and morphology. Here, the Ti3+ doping narrows the bandgap and the exposure of highly active (111) facets, enhancing the photocatalytic activity of the composite. Moreover, Ti3C2 NPs have been used as highly active cocatalysts on metal sulfide photo-absorbers for enhanced visible-light photocatalytic hydrogen production [75]. Hydrothermal reaction strategy was used to replace the – F terminations on Ti3C2 by –O/–OH terminations and coupled with cadmium sulfide to form a highly fused CdS/Ti3C2 composite photocatalyst. This photocatalyst displayed super-high-visible-light photocatalytic hydrogen production activity of 14,342 μmol h−1 g−1 and an apparent quantum efficiency of 40.1% at 420 nm. This enhanced photocatalytic performance arises from the favorable Fermi level position, electrical conductivity, and hydrogen evolution capacity of Ti3C2 nanosheets. The work toward the development of MXene-based nano-architectures gives a basic understanding about how to design a well-contacted heterojunction interface between MXenes and the other NPs in order to achieve a superior photoredox efficiency in photocatalysis and energy conversion applications.

sections.heading: MXenes Adsorbents for Water Purification
sections.text:
MXenes and their composites demonstrate strong ability to intercalate several ions. A number of cations such as Na+, K+, NH4+, Mg2+, and Al3+ and organic molecules (such as hydrazine, urea, and dimethyl sulfoxide) are easily intercalated between Ti3C2 MXene layers revealing the potential of MXenes to be used as adsorbents [5, 76]. In the past few years, MXene-based nanocomposites have been reported as effective adsorbents for several pollutants from different water/wastewater streams [77]. Ti3C2Tx MXene is the most utilized model in this field of study. Several theoretical studies based on DFT and modeling computations are performed to investigate the adsorption of various pollutants on MXene nanosheets [78]. The capacity of ML-Ti3C2 MXene toward adsorption of cationic dye methylene blue (MB) has been demonstrated. An increase in interlayer spacing was observed due to stacking disorder and formation of titania, showing MXene oxidation after adsorption [37]. MXene has also shown excellent adsorption ability for several heavy metals (such as lead, copper, and chromium) [33]. The pollutant can be adsorbed on MXene surface by interacting with OH− or F− groups [79, 80].
Alkaline-MXene (Ti3C2(OH/ONa)xF2−x), with activated hydroxyl group on Ti3C2, exhibited selective sorption of Pb2+. Sorption equilibrium was achieved in a short time of 120 s in presence of high concentrations of competing cations like Ca2+ and Mg2+ (Fig. 22.10) [81]. The adsorption of Pb2+ onto Alkaline-MXene was assigned to the presence of abundance activated Ti-OH sites.
In another study, theoretical prediction of heavy-metals adsorption behavior onto Alkaline-MXene was presented based on the first-principles calculations [82]. The formation of the hydrogen potential trap around the adsorbed heavy metal atom provided enough opposite-spin electron pairs to catch Pb2+ atom forming stable
432 K. Rasool et al.
Ti3C2(O2H2−2m) chemical bonds (Fig. 22.11). Theoretically, the ion adsorption efficiency of Alkaline-MXene decreases with increased occupation of the F atom; however, an increase in Pb2+ adsorption was calculated by the intercalation of Li2+, Na+, and K+ atoms into Alkaline-MXene nanosheets layers. Additionally, heavy metal ions could be potentially removed via an ion exchange process using AlkalineMXene as its surface. The presence of hydroxyl ions makes it an attractive choice to remove toxic metals ions [83].
The narrow interlayer spacing below 2 Å in between the nanosheets is a major challenge for using MXene in high-capacity pollutant removal. Such narrow spacing hinders the accessibility of pollutants with large hydrated radii. Intercalation of small organic molecules and/or cations into the structure of MXene not only improves the interaction affinities of surface anchored functional groups to inner channel walls but can also overcome the problem of narrow interlayer spacing by expanding the c-lattice parameter (c-LP) of MXene [5]. Likewise, the presence
22 MXenes for Environmental and Water Treatment Applications 433
of hydrophilic groups and weak bonding forces in hydrated MXene can bind a greater number of water molecules, resulting in reversible increase of c-LP [32]. Alkalization of MXene can significantly accelerate the removal of metal ions [84]. Thus far, experimental work on Pb2+ removal by MXene is limited only to Ti3C2Tx MXene. The effect of M2X(OH)2 structures (where M = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Mo, Hf, Ta, and X is carbide or nitride) on the adsorption behavior of Pb2+ was investigated theoretically by the first principles calculations [85]. The formation energies of Pb2+ adsorption on M2N(OH)2 are higher as compared to M2C(OH)2, suggesting that the transitional metal nitride is more effective than that of carbides for heavy metal adsorption. Additionally, theoretical modeling confirmed Ti2C(OH)2 as the most favorable MXene nanomaterial for heavy metal sequestration. Alternative M2X(OH)2 structures showed the ability to remove Pb2+
434 K. Rasool et al.
except Sc2C(OH)2 and Zr2C(OH)2 structures. Molecular dynamics simulation are performed to investigate the adsorption behavior of Pb2+ and Cu2+ on V2C and Ti2C MXenes. A theoretical Pb2+ adsorption capacity of 2560 mg g−1 Ti2C MXene is predicted [86].
Delaminated Ti3C2Tx nanosheets demonstrated distinctive in situ reduction ability of several metal ions including Cu, Ag, and Cr(VI) [33, 34, 87], opening a new promising function of MXene materials for environmental pollutant removal. It was found that highly delaminated Ti3C2Tx nanosheets efficiently and rapidly reduced Cr (VI) to Cr (III) followed by simultaneous adsorption of reduced Cr (III) from aqueous solution due to presence of plentiful oxygen-containing OH and F groups (Fig. 22.12a). In another study, delaminated Ti3C2Tx MXene showed a promise for reductive Cu2+ removal where oxygenated moieties in the layered structure of MXene enabled reduction of Cu2+ to Cu2O and CuO followed by adsorption of reduced products. Moreover, Ti3C2Tx demonstrated high adsorption capacity which was 2.7 times higher than that of a commercially available activated carbon [33].
A novel urchin-like rutile TiO2-C/TiC (u-RTC) nanocomposite was synthesized by in situ decomposition of Ti3C2 MXene in ethylene glycol, FeCl3, and isopropyl alcohol solution [88]. The u-RTC nanocomposite showed a selective adsorption capacity of 225 mg g−1 for Cr (VI) removal, which was much higher than that of the pristine MXene (62 mg g−1) in presence of high concentrations of various anions such as Cl−, SO42−, and NO3−. High sorption selectivity toward Cr (VI) was assigned to the strong inner-sphere complexation between u-RTC and Cr2O72− ions. Moreover, u-RTC composite maintained recyclability and performance for removing Cr (VI) from real industrial wastewater with adsorption capacity of 1120 kg kg−1, fulfilling the criteria of drinking water (0.01 mg L−1) by WHO [88].
MXene stability and recyclability have been reported to be improved by functionalization of MXene surfaces to achieve magnetic properties, providing a simple and effective method for adsorbate separation, recycling, and reuse. Sandwiched MXene-iron oxide (MXI) nanocomposite was synthesized for phosphate removal by intercalating ultrafine maghemite-Fe2O3 into the layered MXene nanosheets, resulting in a higher number of Ti-OH groups and increased interlayer distance coupled with high magnetic separation force [77, 89]. This sandwiched structure provided Fe-OH exchange sites and improved phosphate sorption selectivity with fast adsorption kinetics and simple separation feasibility by regenerating the exhausted adsorbent (Fig. 22.12b) [77]. The MXI nanocomposite exhibited higher selective adsorption capacity of 2400 kg-phosphate/kg-MXI in presence of common competitive anions such as SO42−, Cl−, and NO3−. In another study, very stable magnetic Ti3C2Tx MXene (MGMX) nanocomposite with super-magnetic properties was synthesized by depositing Fe2O3 onto the surfaces of Ti3C2Tx using a facile one-step hydrothermal synthesis method [89]. The super-magnetic nanocomposite was used for efficient removal of mercuric ions from aqueous solutions and real industrial wastewater (Fig. 22.13).The composite effectively removed Hg(II) with maximum adsorption capacity of 1128.41 mg g−1, considerably higher than other 2D nanomaterials [89]. Such high adsorption capacity of the MGMX nanocomposite
22 MXenes for Environmental and Water Treatment Applications 435
was to be attributed to the presence of different functional moieties such as Ti3C2-Fx, Ti3C2-Ox, and Ti3C2-(OH)x. The MGMX nanocomposite was reused for five adsorption-desorption cycles to investigate the recyclability of the nanocomposite. MGMX nanocomposite showed better recyclability than pristine MXene with more than 90% mercury removal in the four consecutive cycles.
436 K. Rasool et al.
MXenes have been proposed recently for the removal of the radionuclides from nuclear wastes for their good radioresistance and thermal structural stability [90, 91]. DFT has predicted the efficient removal of uranyl ion by adsorption onto Ti3C2(OH)2 and V2CTx MXene nanosheets [90]. Chemical interaction between uranyl and Ti3C2(OH)2 in presence of anionic ligands such as OH−, Cl−, and NO3− was found to be strong enough to form stable chemical bonds, showing the imperative role of chemical interaction and the hydrogen bonding in the adsorption process [78]. Experimental demonstration of U(VI) adsorption on hydrated Ti3C2Tx was studied as depicted in the Fig. 22.14 [92]. In this study, ML-MXene was synthesized under hydrated conditions to produce intercalated Ti3C2Tx-NaOH and Ti3C2Tx-DMSO MXenes with a significant increase in interlayer spacing with by expanding the c lattice parameter up to 20.18 Å. Adsorption of representative actinide U(VI) on DMSO hydrated MXene to obtain a maximum adsorption capacity of 214 mg g−1, five times higher than that for pristine Ti3C2Tx. Theoretical adsorption capacity of U(VI) on hydrated Ti3C2Tx was calculated to be as high as 595.3 mg g−1 [78]; however, experimental adsorption observed was roughly 54.5% of the theoretical value. It is notable that the zeta potentials of both pristine and intercalated Ti3C2Tx were the same, eliminating any role of electrostatic interaction in adsorption process.
22 MXenes for Environmental and Water Treatment Applications 437
In a recent study, the adsorption of uranyl ions [UO2(H2O)n]2+ onV2CTx MXene from aqueous solution was first time reported with an adsorption capacity of 174 mg g−1, better than several conventional inorganic nanomaterials [92]. Uranium adsorption onto V2CTx was heterogeneous by the formation of bidentate innersphere complexes, with hydroxyl groups attached to V atoms followed by an ion-exchange mechanism (Fig. 22.14). Moreover, insight into chemical interaction of V2CTx with uranium species was projected by mathematical modeling, proposing the maximum uranium adsorption capacity of 536 mg g−1 on V2C(OH)2 nanosheets to be much higher than the experimental removal performance [91]. Material optimization can still be done to increase adsorptive removal efficiency of uranium species. U(VI) is in the form of the uranyl ion, UO22+ and mononuclear and polynuclear hydroxo-complexes in aqueous solutions and forms mononuclear and polynuclear carbonato- and hydroxo-complexes in presence of carbonate anions [93]. These uranyl ion species are abundantly present in natural environmental
438 K. Rasool et al.
conditions. All aquo-, hydroxylated, and carbonated uranyl species depicted strong adsorption performance on hydroxylated V2CTx nanosheets; however, aqua-uranyl species showed the strongest adsorptive properties due to strong bonding between uranyl ions and OH of hydroxylated MXene.
Most of the above studies on uranium removal by MXene are predicted by computational studies using DFT, and there is a little evidence of practical applications. This implies the need for more advance experimental verification to use MXenes for nuclear waste management in the future.

sections.heading: Conclusions and Outlook
sections.text:
In summary, this chapter provides an overview on the recent advancements of single and multilayered MXenes in water treatment and environmental remediation applications including separation membranes, photocatalytic substrates, adsorbents, and antimicrobial agents. Also, numerous MXene-based composites have been developed with the hope to overcome the shortcomings of the pristine MXenes such as stability and at the same time impart synergistic effects to reduce agglomeration and provide conductive pathways. Thus far, Ti3C2Tx is the most utilized form of MXenes in water treatment and environmental remediation applications. To our knowledge, there is no experimental data available on the use other MXenes for adsorption of pollutants. MXenes have been used extensively for the reductive sequestration and/or adsorption of heavy metals from water and degradation of dyes.
Modification of MXenes could overcome their instability and improve their recyclability and biocompatibility, which would maximize their effectiveness in water treatment applications. Besides the well-demonstrated size and charge selective ion sieving using MXene membranes, good biocidal activities against gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria provide antifouling capabilities of the membranes. More efforts are still needed to fully explore the antibacterial potential and understand the mechanisms of MXene antimicrobial activities. Despite a limited number of studies about antimicrobial properties of MXenes, it is expected that the proposed mechanisms are analogous to graphene. Moreover, a life cycle analysis still needs to be done to assess the environmental hazards of MXenes from the point of production to their exposure into wastewater streams.
Pristine MXenes have some disadvantages toward photocatalytic applications such as poor photon absorption and high rate of charge carrier recombination. However, there are plenty of possibilities for MXenes to be used as efficient photocatalysts by changing their surface chemistry. MXene-based nanoarchitectures with higher light harvesting ability, satisfied quantum efficiency, and enhanced carrier separation can be used for efficient solar to chemical applications.
MXenes are quickly positioned among the most promising 2D nanomaterials being developed for various applications. Expansion of the family of MXene 2D materials offers new choices of structures, chemistries, and eventually valuable properties, which still needs to be further explored for sequestration of emerging
22 MXenes for Environmental and Water Treatment Applications 439
pollutants from water and wastewater streams. Finally, more research is demanded to safely design, use, and dispose of MXene containing products to avoid new risks to the environment.

sections.heading: Luke R. Johnson and Aleksandra Vojvodic
Introduction
sections.text:
Status quo: MXenes have in the last couple of years emerged as potential materials that could enable chemical transformations of relevance for achieving a sustainable energy future. This, for example, includes generation of clean fuels and chemicals such as production of hydrogen. In this chapter we introduce some of the so far studied chemistries of these MXene materials focusing on several catalytic reactions. As one of the first catalytic applications, MXenes were explored for the electrochemical hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [1, 2]. Both experimental techniques and computational tools have been utilized to discover properties of MXenes. One example of a combination between the computational and experimental efforts is the HER study in Ref. [1] where several M2X MXenes were computationally predicted to be HER active and experimentally synthesized and tested confirming the computational findings. It was, in particular, noticed that the basal planes of these active materials are functionalized under operating conditions [3]. In a followup study, it was demonstrated that the HER activity is highly sensitive to the details of the functional groups and that the functionalization can be experimentally tuned to a certain extent by controlling the type and concentration of the etching agent [4]. Recently more chemically and geometrically complex MXenes have been extensively studied for HER [3–19] and for other increasingly complicated electrochemical as well as thermal processes.
L. R. Johnson · A. Vojvodic ( ) Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA e-mail: alevoj@seas.upenn.edu
© Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2019 B. Anasori, Y. Gogotsi (eds.), 2D Metal Carbides and Nitrides (MXenes), https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-19026-2_23
445
446 L. R. Johnson and A. Vojvodic
MXenes have experimentally been considered for both the electrochemical oxygen evolution (OER) and reduction (ORR) reactions [20–23]. Very recently, the electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction has garnered some interest and has been computationally explored on M2X and M3X2 MXenes [24, 25]. Several computational studies have examined the reactivity of MXenes for CO2 abatement and their activity toward electrochemical CO2 reduction to different CHx and CHxOy species [26–28]. More complex systems than the single-metal-based stoichiometric MnXn−1 MXenes including multi-metal alloys and MXenes combined as catalysts or supports with other materials have also obtained attention due to their potential interesting chemical properties. Such examples are systems consisting of metal adatoms on the MXenes which have been theoretically and experimentally explored for thermal CO oxidation [29, 30]. Nanoparticles of Ru and Rh supported on MXenes have been studied for hydrolysis of sodium borohydride and hydrodechlorination of chlorophenols, respectively [31, 32]. Bimetallic nanoparticles on MXenes have been investigated for hydrogen production from hydrous hydrazine [33]. Mo2C nanoparticles embedded via electrospinning in nitrogen-doped carbon nanofibers have been studied as catalysts for both the HER and ORR [21]. Studies have also shown that Ti3C2 in addition to TiO2 and Cu2O composites derived from MXenes can be used to catalyze thermal decomposition of ammonium perchlorate and dehydrogenation of sodium alanates [34–37]. Another group of chemical reactions where MXenes might play a crucial role are photoelectrochemical reactions [5, 9, 10, 16, 19, 38–43]. While observation of different chemistries on MXenes has gained momentum over a short time period, the fundamental understanding of their chemistries is still in its infancy. We next present results from computational efforts on our current atomic-scale understanding of the MXenes as well as discuss potential ways to enhance or hinder reactions on MXenes.

sections.heading: Adsorption on and Reactivity of MXenes
sections.text:
As always with chemistries of novel materials, independently if they are 3D or 2D, there is a need to first establish reactivity measures of the surface if dealing with a 3D material or the basal plane in the case of a 2D material in order to gain an understanding of the most basic elementary steps of a reaction, which involve adsorption of chemical species that are the different intermediates of the chemical reaction of interest. In other words, a common approach is to first establish thermodynamic data before proceeding to chemical activity and selectivity measures and trends, which are many orders or magnitude more computationally costly and can in some cases be prohibited due to the combinatorial nature of the problem. Of course, more levels of complexity of the material itself can be introduced to tune and control the chemistry of interest by varying the chemical compositions of the adsorption site as well as the geometry of the adsorption site through different surface facets, edges, and kinks to name a few. One promising suggested aspect of MXenes is that their chemistry might be taking place on the basal planes at least for
23 Chemistry and Catalysis of MXenes 447
certain reactions. This is in contrast to some of the other well-known 2D materials such as MoS2 where the HER catalysis is occurring on the edges of nanoparticles [44] which has proven to be a challenge in terms of scalability. MXenes on the other hand have been synthesized with high surface areas and computationally identified to be basal plane active for HER [2, 4].
To calculate the adsorption energy, one typically uses the following equation:
Ea = Ema − Em − ∑
i
NiEa(g)
where Ema is the energy of a species adsorbed on the MXene, Em is the energy of a clean MXene system, and Ea(g) is the energy of gas species corresponding to the adsorbate. The adsorption free energy is calculated as:
Ga = Ea + ∑
i
Ni ( ZPEi − T Si)
where zero-point energies and entropies are computed using DFT and tabulated gas phase thermodynamic data. We first exemplify how reactive bare MXenes are by discussing results from studies where the focus has been on adsorption of different intermediates including atoms, radicals, and molecules on the unfunctionalized basal planes of MXenes as well as dissociation of simple molecules before moving to functionalized MXenes in the next section.
One of the first observations is that adsorption of most reaction intermediates (including atoms, radicals, and molecules) on the bare basal planes of MXene is strongly downhill in energy [24, 25, 28, 45, 46]. This by itself indicates the tendency of these bare MXenes to be terminated or passivated with functional groups. Hence, depending on the surrounding environment, these bare basal planes will be functionalized. This conclusion is further supported by reports where modeling dissociation kinetics of strongly bonded molecules such as N2 and CO2 on the bare basal planes of MXenes is possible with comparably low activation energies compared to other studied materials [24, 27]. For example, MXenes with the chemical formula M3C2 were shown to activate N2, and it was found that bare basal planes of V3C2 and Cr3C2 were possible candidate materials for two proposed N2 reaction mechanisms (see Fig. 23.1) [24]. Computational studies of CO2 reduction to different hydrocarbons also demonstrated activation of CO2 (see Fig. 23.2) [27]. In a recent study on CO2 uptake [28], it was confirmed that bare basal planes of MXenes can activate CO2 and that M2C MXenes are more active than the traditionally explored surfaces of bulk transition metal carbides and nitrides. To the best of our knowledge, experiments have so far not demonstrated existence of bare basal planes of MXenes, rather they find that the studied MXenes are terminated, decorated, or passivated with different amounts of functional groups on the basal plane which to a certain degree can be controlled by using different etching agents during the synthesis [4, 47–49]. In the next section, we discuss how functionalization of the basal planes can affect the MXene chemistry.
448 L. R. Johnson and A. Vojvodic
23 Chemistry and Catalysis of MXenes 449

sections.heading: Stability Diagrams of MXenes
sections.text:
In order to obtain a complete picture of a chemical process on a material, one should take care in modeling the system under as realistic conditions as possible. This includes dealing with coverage effects of the reaction intermediates under different chemical conditions and environments. For electrochemical reactions, the modeling should also include the applied potential and pH. Using the computational hydrogen approach [50–52], one can construct so-called Pourbaix stability diagrams to determine the termination or phase of a material under certain conditions. Figure 23.3 shows such a constructed Pourbaix diagram for two prototypical MXenes, Ti2C and Mo2C, with different modeled functional groups and terminations (Tx) including one monolayer (ML) coverage of adsorbed H, 2 ML of H, 1 ML of O, and 1 ML of OH [3]. It is found that the most stable functional group (lowest line at a given applied potential) changes as the applied potential changes from O∗ to H∗ , 2H∗ , or 3H∗ with decreasing negative voltages. At ambient conditions with no applied potential, the two MXenes are predicted to be functionalized with oxygen. However, the exact functional group and termination are material dependent and can also show combinations of mixed functional groups, for example, partial O and OH coverage. In addition, there might be an effect of pH. Figure 23.4 shows the linear pH dependence on the stability and its small effect on the stability ordering between the different functional groups of relevance for HER [2]. Stability diagrams give a reasonable starting point for modeling the activity of a system; however, they might have to be revised in an iterative way during the simulations of more complex intermediates.
450 L. R. Johnson and A. Vojvodic

sections.heading: High-Throughput Computational Screening of MXenes
sections.text:
A strategy that has been more and more applied in the discovery of materials for different applications is both experimental and computational high-throughput screening. One successful road map in identifying catalyst material candidates computationally has been to first generate thermodynamic (energetics of reaction intermediates) and kinetic (activation including dissociation and association barriers) data of relevant reaction steps, which of course depend on the explicit reaction pathways that one has chosen to study. Next the generated data is used to establish correlations between energetics of different intermediates, on one hand, known as adsorbate energy scaling relations, and between thermodynamics and kinetics, on the other hand, known as transition state scaling relations. Assuming a reaction mechanism(s), one can then identify a descriptor(s) which is(are) parameter(s) to describe the overall reaction properties. This approach can help to reduce the parameter phase space of the reaction mechanism and intermediates and allow for faster high-throughput computational screening. Together with micro-kinetic modeling, one can also describe the trends in activity usually for thermal reactions by ordering the different materials on a so-called activity volcano heat map, which in some cases can take the form of an inverse parabola, with the earlier identified descriptor(s) as parameters. At the top of this volcano plot, one finds the best candidate materials exhibiting the highest activity for an optimal descriptor value. For electrochemical reactions, on the other hand, one can calculate the limiting potentials for each of the elementary steps. For example, in the case of electrochemical hydrogen evolution, it was shown initially for metal catalysts that the hydrogen adsorption free energy GH can be used as a descriptor for HER activity [53] and has since been shown for other classes of materials [44, 50, 54– 56]. Electrochemical activity volcano plots for HER are generated by plotting the negative overpotential as a function of the activity descriptor that is GH (see
23 Chemistry and Catalysis of MXenes 451
Fig. 23.5). In general, the goal is to minimize the overpotential by finding the material with the ideal surface chemistry corresponding to an optimal descriptor value. The zoomed-in part of Fig. 23.5 reveals the top of the volcano with the best catalyst candidates for HER among the M2X MXenes. Despite that computationally both Hf2N and Sc2C are having among the lowest overpotentials those materials had not been experimentally synthesized at the time of the study. As the next best computationally best candidate MXene material for HER, one finds the Ofunctionalized Mo2C which is among the experimentally realized MXenes. Other studies have since used similar computational high-throughput screening methods to study the HER on MXenes with different chemical formulas including M3X2 and M4X3 with and without functional groups [8, 12, 13, 57]. In Ref. [50], a detailed discussion is provided on the HER activity trends as a function of the metal component, the nonmetal component, and the chemical formula of the MXene (see Fig. 23.6).

sections.heading: Functionalization-Property Relations
sections.text:
The functionalization of the MXene has an effect on the chemical reactivity and hence also the catalytic activity of the MXenes material. One of the first demonstrations that the composition of the etching agent altered the functionalization was reported a couple of years ago [47]. The relationship between the functional groups and their impact on catalytic activity was identified both experimentally and computationally for HER in Ref. [4]. It was found that the experimentally measured overpotential changed (see Fig. 23.7) by changing the concentration of the etchant and type, HF vs LiF vs HCl, when synthesizing the MXenes from their
452 L. R. Johnson and A. Vojvodic
corresponding MAX phase which was shown resulted from modifying the ratio of different functional groups as measured by XPS. The observed trend agrees with theoretical results, which found that an increase in the F to O functional group ratio yielded an increase in overpotential (see Fig. 23.8). In other words, F functional groups inhibit the HER. The potential of tuning the functionalization is key if we want full control of the chemical properties of MXenes for different applications such as chemical transformations, batteries, capacitors, etc.
23 Chemistry and Catalysis of MXenes 453

sections.heading: Future of Chemical Transformations with MXenes
sections.text:
The understanding of many chemistries and catalysis of MXenes is still in its infancy and will inevitably be part of future research. As has been outlined above, the chemistry of the MXenes is highly sensitive to the functional groups on the basal planes. However, the exact relationships between the functionalization and the chemical properties are mostly unknown and might be highly dependent on the specific chemical reaction of interest. The focus of the experimental efforts will certainly include how to synthesize new MXene materials: not only carbides, but carbonitrides and espeically nitrides, as well as how to control the type and quantity of certain desired functional groups. For example, a recent study developed a technique to synthesize Ti2N from etching in KF and HCl and sonicating in DMSO [58], while others have converted carbides to carbonitrides and nitrides through the use of ammoniation [59]. Computationally, one can help build a chemistry map and stability map of MXenes with respect to their chemical formula, including the trends with respect to the nonmetal and metal constituents and functional groups, as well as their geometry, including basal planes and under-coordinates sites and defects. Even in the computational efforts, the key challenge is to establish the state of the MXene under relevant operating chemical conditions. In addition, computational efforts can help explore and potentially control the chemistry of MXenes using external means using, for example, an applied potential, pH, temperature, pressure, mechanical strain effects, and supports, to name a few. The future of MXenes looks promising, as they are being considered as active materials in a plethora of thermal catalytic reactions and electrochemical reaction, as well as being considered as support materials investigated for sensors and in photoelectrochemical reactions.
454 L. R. Johnson and A. Vojvodic

sections.heading: Seon Joon Kim and Hee-Tae Jung
Sensors in the Society and Industry
sections.text:
Sensors are becoming ever more important in everyday life as the connectivity of our society continues to grow larger. Entering a new era of the information age, computing devices are now all interconnected with each other to relay various types of information in large amounts, which is termed the “Internet of Things (IoT).” One of the reasons that this has become possible is the autonomous collection of data by devices and machines, in which they obtain such data through sensors. If the central processing unit is the brain of a device, sensors can be considered as the eyes, nose, ears, and the fingers of a device. Currently, numerous types of sensors are being used in electrical devices. For example, the following are a few examples of sensors embedded into a typical smartphone: accelerometer, gyroscope, magnetometer (compass), Global Positioning System (GPS) sensor, barometer, proximity sensor, and light sensor. Different types of sensors used in other electrical sensors include color sensors, temperature sensors, humidity sensors, gas sensors, touch (tactile) sensors, IR sensors, flow sensors, and smoke sensors.
The performance of sensors continues to grow according to the development of new materials with enhanced properties where high-performance sensors are highly required for future devices. Nanomaterials have always been at the frontier of such development, rapidly opening up new possibilities in various types of sensors
