throughout the industry. In this chapter, we will discuss how MXenes played a role in the development of high-performance sensors, such as gas sensors, tactile sensors, and biosensors, and their future outlook.

sections.heading: Uses of Gas Sensors
sections.text:
Gas sensors are being used in a wide range of applications, playing an important role in the industry and society. To begin with, gas sensors can be found in a household. One of the easiest places to see gas sensors is in a household hygrometer where the indoor humidity is displayed on a screen. Gas sensors in households can also be seen in air purifiers, which show the indoor concentration of volatile gases that can be toxic at high concentrations. Sensors for gas leak detection, especially for detecting hydrocarbon gases in the kitchen/gas pipes, can be very important in preventing fires and explosions. Detecting toxic gas leaks is even more important in working environments such as laboratories or factories as there are much more chemicals present and a much higher probability to be exposed to toxic gases during operation. In an even larger scale, sensors are widely used for environmental monitoring to reduce air pollutants emitted from automobiles and factories. Typically monitored gases are acidic gases such as nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur oxides (SOx), and carbon monoxide (CO). Real-time concentration of such gases can be sometimes observed in display boards at downtown crossroads. Aside from these gases, collected data of carbon dioxide (CO2) and ozone (O3) concentration in the atmosphere is used to monitor the global environment.
Highly precise gas sensors are also used in the medical sector. These sensors are targeted to detect specific biomarkers, similar to the olfactory system of humans and sensitive animals that are able to detect gases at very low concentrations. The detection of volatile organic compounds such as acetone, toluene, and hexane allows the early diagnosis of various diseases from bacterial infection to cancer. Since the concentration of such biomarkers between a normal person and an ill person only differs by ppb levels, very high sensitivity is required for these types of sensors.
Precise gas detection is also required in the defense sector, as warfare toxins such as nerve agents, blood agents, and pulmonary agents are lethal at very small concentrations. As these gases are highly dangerous upon a short time of exposure, sensors that are able to remotely detect gases from a long distance (e.g., optical sensors) are favored in this field (Fig. 24.1).
24 MXenes for Sensors 459

sections.heading: Requirements for High-Performance Gas Sensors
sections.text:
Requirements for the practical use of gas sensors can be largely classified into performance requirements and practical requirements. A sensor’s performance requirements can be summarized into what is called “4S”: sensitivity, selectivity, speed, and stability. First, the sensitivity of a gas sensor is one of the most important performance criteria as the critical gas concentrations is very low in various situations. For example, 50 ppm of CO is the short-term exposure limit while the limit concentration is even lower for NO2 (5 ppm), SO2 (5 ppm), and H2S (10 ppm) [1]. Moreover, the required detecting concentration is extremely low for diagnostic applications. For example, ammonia can be used as a biomarker to distinguish patients infected with Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) through a concentration difference in exhaled breath compared to a healthy person [2]. As 50–2000 ppb of ammonia is usually present in a healthy person, a gas sensor should be able to detect at least 50 ppb to distinguish patients [3]. In actual gas sensing measurements, the sensitivity of a sensing channel can be represented by the signal-to-noise ratio where the gas concentration corresponding to a signal-to-noise ratio of 3 is regarded as the limit of detection [4]. Second, the selectivity of a gas sensor is as nearly equally important compared to sensitivity. Detecting only the target gas itself is highly important in practical applications, as poor selectivity can lead to misleading conclusions. However, it is highly difficult to synthesize channel materials that are able to detect only a single target molecule, as the chemical and physical properties of a gas molecules typically overlaps with another molecule to some degree, rather than being entirely independent. Therefore, most sensing systems utilize sensing arrays where the gas response of slightly modified sensing channels with similar structures are analyzed via pattern recognition. Third, fast response speed and fast recovery rate is another requirement for gas sensors. As gas response analysis can be reliably performed at saturated response values, a fast response speed toward early saturation is important to quickly obtain results. Also, fast response speeds are especially important in the case of gas leaks, where a small amount of delayed response can result in a critical situation for the exposed person. Fast recovery back to the baseline is also important as a constant baseline guarantees the same gas response over several sensing cycles. Finally, the stability of a gas sensing channel
460 S. J. Kim and H.-T. Jung
is important as it determines the sensor’s lifetime. Degradation of the gas sensing channel over time may result in the change of the baseline conductivity or the change in gas response to target molecules, leading to unreliable results. Although it is nearly impossible to develop sensing channels that are permanently stable, a higher stability will definitely enhance the accessibility of a gas sensor.
Aside from performance requirements, a few practical requirements may also be taken into consideration such as energy consumption and material cost. Energy consumption is especially more important for portable/wearable devices that operate on batteries. For efficient energy use, sensors that require minimum current and those operating at room temperature are favored. Depending on the specific device application of gas sensors, development may be focused on specific factors compared to other factors listed above (Table 24.1).

sections.heading: Types of Gas Sensors
sections.text:
Types of gas sensors can be classified by the mechanism in which they detect gas molecules. The most widely used type is electrical sensors (resistive sensors) where the adsorption of gas molecules on the channel surface induces a change in electrical conductivity. Electrical sensors are highly favored among various types of gas sensors due to compatibility with conventional device processing techniques. Their structure (active channel layer, source/drain/gate electrodes) can be entirely designed by lithographic techniques, and can be placed on substrates typically used in the industry. Also, as circuits can be designed at a nanometer-scale thickness, sensors can be miniaturized to fit small areas. Moreover, the very wide range of materials applicable to electrical sensors give a lot of room for development. Another widely used method is the colorimetric method where the color of a sensing channel changes upon gas reaction. Since no other components expect the gas inlet/out and active channel are required, colorimetric sensors can be made into small, hand-held sizes. Arrayed colorimetric sensors are typically used to recognize specific gases using pattern recognition. Gas chromatography methods are also used as gas sensors, sometimes coupled with sensors such as photoionization detectors
24 MXenes for Sensors 461
(PIDs). Chromatography methods show excellent selectivity and sensitivity, but they are highly expensive. Also, they require large spaces to operate, limiting their practicality. Other types of gas sensors include optical sensors, calorimetric sensors, and mass sensors (e.g., quartz crystal microbalances). The major advantages and disadvantages of various gas sensor types are shown in Table 24.2. In this chapter, we will focus on electrical sensors such as chemiresistors.

sections.heading: Materials Used as Gas Sensing Channels
Metal Oxide Semiconductors
sections.text:
One of the earliest materials to be used as gas sensing channels in traditional gas sensors were metal oxide semiconductors. Many types of metal oxide semiconductors, such as SnO2, WO3, In2O3, TeO2, CuO, ZnO, and V2O5, have been reported to possess gas sensing abilities for various types of gases [5]. Among various channel materials, metal oxides have been widely utilized due to good chemical, thermal stability, low cost, and very high sensitivity.
The gas sensing mechanism of metal oxide sensors is through the change of electrical conductivity induced by the charge depletion layer near the surface [6]. At high temperatures, oxygen molecules in the surrounding air environment adsorb onto metal oxide particles and then ionize into molecular species (O2−) or atomic species (O−, O2−). During ionization, oxygen molecules pull electrons from metal oxide channels, resulting in a charge depletion layer near the surface. As these depletion layers create a conduction barrier, the expansion or contraction of the
462 S. J. Kim and H.-T. Jung
depletion layer will result in a change in electrical conductivity. Depending on the reducing or oxidizing property of adsorbing gases, and the p-type or n-type majority carrier of the sensing channel, gases will either pull even more electrons from the channel, or push electrons back in upon adsorption. Therefore, gas responses will occur in opposite directions according to the shifting behavior of the charge depletion layer.
The size of individual metal oxide nanoparticles plays a major role in determining the gas sensing performance [7], as shown in Fig. 24.2. When the size of metal oxide nanoparticles becomes very small, close to the double thickness of the charge depletion layer, charge depletion occurs in most of the bulk particle volume to greatly enhance sensitivity. In this manner, numerous efforts were devoted to enhance the performance of metal oxide gas sensors by manipulating their morphology into structures such as nanoparticles and nanowires. Optimized metal oxide gas sensors show very high sensitivity, easily detecting various gases in the ppb level. Also, the response speed and recovery rate are very fast due to high temperatures.
For the optimal performance of metal oxide semiconductor sensors, high operating temperatures typically above 200 ◦C are necessary. Due to the high operating temperature, a few drawbacks exist. Continued operation at high temperatures induce the growth of metal oxide grains, potentially degrading the sensing performance due to decreased percentage of the depletion layer. Also, high temperatures may be dangerous when detecting potentially explosive gases. Finally, high temperature operation requires large power consumption, which is a critical disadvantage for the growing field of portable devices. Reports have also shown that metal oxide gas sensors and their composites can operate at room temperature to evade the
24 MXenes for Sensors 463
problems above; however, the sensitivity is greatly decreased, showing a limit of detection at ppm concentrations [8].

sections.heading: Metal Nanoparticles
sections.text: Only a few metals are known to have sensing properties in their pristine. Pt and Pd nanoparticles show a gas response to hydrogen gas (H2) based on a catalytic mechanism. Upon exposure to H2, hydrides (PtH2, PdH2) are formed on the metal nanochannels to induce a change in electrical conductivity. Reports have shown that the electrical conductivity changes by a larger amount for a thinner metal channel, leading to higher sensitivity [9]. Besides H2 detection, Ag nanostructures are known to selectively detect NH3 gases. However, as there is very little variability in the type of metals and also in the type of gases that are detectable, pristine metals have very limited uses as a gas sensing channel. Metal nanoparticles coupled with organic ligands were also utilized as sensing channels to detect VOC gases. Kahn et al. demonstrated sensors based on Au nanoparticles attached with various types of thiol-based ligands forming an interconnected Au nanoparticle matrix [10]. Pristine Au nanoparticles do not typically show sensing responses, while ligand-attached nanoparticles showed different gas response behavior upon bending, depending on the type of the attached ligand.

sections.heading: 1D Nanostructures
sections.text:
Among various 1D nanostructures, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have been widely used as a sensing channel for gas sensors. CNT sensors are able to detect dilute gases at room temperature, which is an advantage over high-temperature operating materials such as metal oxide semiconductors. However, as the electrical properties of CNTs differ greatly depending on the metallic/semiconducting property of each nanotube, it is rather difficult to reproduce similar electrical performance. Also, the functionalization of surfaces to some degree is necessary to activate the surface for gas detection.
Another type of 1D nanostructures widely used is Si nanowires. Silicon in its bulk form (film type) has barely any response to gases, but their nanowires in about few tens of nm in diameter have shown good sensitivity toward various gases [11].

sections.heading: Conventional Two-Dimensional Materials
sections.text:
Recently, 2D materials have shown great promise as gas sensing channels to overcome challenges faced with previously utilized materials. The surface-tovolume ratio of 2D materials is the largest among nanomaterials, due to the atomic scale thickness, which may lead to high sensitivity in gas sensors. One of the greatest merits of 2D material gas sensors is their ability to efficiently operate at room
464 S. J. Kim and H.-T. Jung
temperature. Also, as 2D films can be assembled into lithographically patternable thin films, they are one of the most optimal materials to be employed in micro-scale portable devices.
The operating mechanism of 2D sensors is based on a charge transfer process, originating from the adsorption of various gas molecules on the surface [12]. The gas response of a 2D sensor therefore relies on the amount and direction of charge transfer. The intensity of charge transfer typically shows a similar correlation with the binding energy of molecules to the channel; a larger amount of charge transfer for a stronger binding. Although not universal, polar molecules with specific functional groups tend to chemisorb on surfaces toward a strong binding, while nonpolar molecules tend to physisorb on surfaces toward a weak binding [13]. With regard to the direction of charge transfer, electrons can either move from the molecule to the channel (reducing molecule) or vice versa (oxidizing molecule) upon gas adsorption. Therefore, the electrical conductivity may increase or decrease depending on the gas molecule and the major carrier type of each 2D channel.
Gas adsorption properties can be controlled by altering the chemical properties of 2D materials, which can be easily manipulated by surface engineering or chemical doping. The active binding sites can be changed by attaching ligands to the surface, which can change the gas selectivity. Also, channels can be either p-doped or ndoped using electrical or molecular doping to change the gas response behavior. Such tunability leaves much room for the selective detection of target gases with 2D channel materials when optimally utilized.
Similar to metal oxide semiconductors, semiconducting/semimetal 2D materials such as MoS2, black phosphorus (BP), and graphene have so far been utilized as gas sensing channels. However, a trade-off between gas response signal and electrical noise has always existed in 2D gas sensing channels, as shown in Fig. 24.3. Semiconducting channels with a relative high bandgap, such as MoS2 or BP, tend to show a larger change in electrical resistivity (equal to gas response) due to high surface reactivity. For example, the electrical resistivity of semiconducting 2D channels can change over 20% upon adsorption of 100 ppm ethanol. However, the electrical noise of such channels is also high due to their relatively high electrical resistivity. As a result, there are limitations in achieving high signal-to-noise ratio. On the other hand, channels with a very small bandgap, such as graphene, show low electrical noise due to high electrical conductivity [14]. However, they show a rather small change in electrical resistivity as there are not many reactive/adsorption sites on the surface, also resulting in a limited signal-to-noise ratio. The introduction of adsorption sites, such as functional groups or defects, can enhance the gas response of graphene, however at the cost of degraded electrical conductivity due to the atomically thin nature of 2D materials. Due to these issues, conventional 2D material channel sensors have focused on optimizing the trade-off relation rather than overcoming it.
24 MXenes for Sensors 465

sections.heading: MXenes
sections.text:
MXenes have the potential to break the upper bound and the trade-off relation existing in conventional two-dimensional materials due to their unique combination of high-coverage surface functional groups and high electrical conductivity. The abundant –OH, –O, and –F functional groups can act as strong binding sites for gas molecules even in dilute concentrations, leading to high gas response. Also, the conductivity of MXenes can reach as high as 6500 S/cm, in the case of Ti3C2, which can lead to a very low electrical noise. Both of these features may lead to an ultrahigh signal-to-noise ratio at room temperature toward unprecedented sensitivity.
Moreover, another large advantage is that there are currently about 20 types of MXenes experimentally realized, even more to be synthesized [15]. While all MXenes are known to have abundant functional groups on the surface with similar
466 S. J. Kim and H.-T. Jung
species, each MXene has distinct electrical properties. Out of these, only a few MXenes have ever been studied as gas sensing channels (Table 24.3).

sections.heading: Theoretical Studies on MXene Gas Sensors
sections.text:
As previously mentioned, the operating mechanism of gas sensors based on twodimensional channel materials is the physical/chemical adsorption of gases on the surface. In this operation, the strength of adsorption plays a major role in the gas response behavior of two-dimensional channel materials. Thus, the adsorption mechanism is relatively simple compared to other materials such as metal oxide semiconductors and porous structures, allowing a rather easy estimation by simulations. Among various simulations, density functional theory (DFT) calculations have been widely used to calculate the adsorption between target gases and 2D channel materials in a local area. The binding energies are typically calculated by the following equation:
Ebinding = Egas adsorbed channel − ( Echannel + Egas )
Molecular binding energies calculated by DFT are typically correlated to the adsorption strength where a stronger binding energy was related to a higher gas response. Additionally, charge transfer values can be calculated to support simulated results.
24 MXenes for Sensors 467
Yu et al. first investigated the potential of MXenes to be employed as gas sensing channels by DFT calculations [16]. In their study, monolayer Ti2CO2 was mainly investigated, while the adsorption energies of other surface functionalities (Ti2C(OH)2) and other MXenes (Ti3C2O2, V2CO2) were also studied as well. Here, the adsorption energy and charge transfer calculations of various gases such as H2, CO2, O2, NH3, CO, and CH4 to Ti2CO2 were performed using DFT. The strongest adsorption was observed for NH3 on Ti2CO2 where the density of states of the solid channel and those of the gas molecules strongly overlapped. The calculated binding energy and charge transfer of NH3 to Ti2CO2 was −0.37 eV and 0.174 e, respectively, while the binding energy of all other studied gases did not exceed −0.01 eV. These results indicate that Ti2CO2 may have a very high selectivity detecting NH3 gases.
To demonstrate the outstanding potential of MXene gas sensors over previous channel materials, the performance of MoS2 and phosphorene as NH3 sensors were also compared. Both 2D materials are known to have a rather high binding energy to gases due to their abundant active sites and high surface reactivity. Similarly, the adsorption energy and charge transfer from NH3 to the 2D channel material was calculated. The adsorption energy of NH3 on MoS2 and phosphorene were −0.16 and −0.21 eV, respectively, which are both lower than that on Ti2CO2, showing the superior binding energy of MXenes.
Xiao et al. further investigated in detail the adsorption of NH3 on various oxygenterminated MXenes such as Zr2CO2, Sc2CO2, and Hf2CO2 under various conditions [17]. Moreover, they studied the possibility of not only the strong adsorption of gases, but also fast recovery. Achieving fast recovery is highly important for practical gas sensors, since retaining a constant baseline is critical in obtaining reproducible results over multiple detection cycles. In this manner, the adsorption behavior of gases onto two-dimensional channel materials is a two-sided coin: the strong adsorption can give a high gas response toward high sensitivity, but the relatively difficult desorption can result in a long recovery time or a higher release temperature.
This study showed that external charge injection can solve the issue of poor desorption and long recovery time originating from strong adsorption on MXenes. The adsorption of NH3 to a pristine Zr2CO2 surface was calculated to be −0.81 eV, which is a relatively high value, typically corresponding to chemisorption. On the other hand, the injection of charge (e−) to the outermost Zr atoms increased the adsorption energy of NH3 to be −0.20 eV, indicating a shift from chemical adsorption to physical adsorption. Such a shift to physical adsorption allows much faster desorption compared to chemisorption. Therefore, it is suggested that both a strong adsorption and fast desorption can be achieved upon charge injection, toward a highly reversible NH3 gas sensor.
Additional to the adsorption of ammonia gases, Kim et al. further investigated the adsorption of a representative VOC gas (ethanol) onto Ti3C2 MXene and also studied the influence of surface functional groups on their binding strength, as shown in Fig. 24.4 [18]. Results indicate that acetone adsorbed onto hydroxylterminated Ti3C2 (Ti3C2(OH)2) showed the highest binding energy, about −0.77 eV.
468 S. J. Kim and H.-T. Jung
This value was more than twice higher than the binding energy of acetone onto other 2D channel materials such as graphene, MoS2, and BP. On the other hand, the binding energy onto oxygen-terminated (Ti3C2O2) and fluorine-terminated (Ti3C2F2) was similar to other 2D materials such as graphene, MoS2, and BP. This implies that the high coverage of –OH surface functionalities may be crucial in achieving a high gas response toward VOC gases such as acetone.
It is relatively easier to study the properties of MXenes through theoretical methods than by experimental methods, as the molecular structure can be precisely controlled in computations. This is shown by the fact that out of over 50 MXenes reported so far, only about 20 types have been experimentally synthesized, while over 40 types have been studied by theoretical methods [15]. By using tools such as DFT, the gas adsorption or sensing properties of other MXenes will be continued to be predicted, paving the way for MXene sensors with ground-breaking performances.

sections.heading: Experimental Studies on MXene Gas Sensors
sections.text:
Compared to MXene models employed in theoretical studies, the situation for an actual MXene film is largely different in actually synthesized MXene gas sensors. First, surface terminations in synthesized MXenes are typically a mixture of –O, – OH, and –F functional groups, while metal atom exposed defect sites are also present. There are no techniques currently available to precisely control the spatial arrangement and composition of each surface functional group mentioned above. In simulations, the majority of MXene molecular simulations only consider one type of surface terminations at a time. Second, practical MXene films are typically synthesized as multilayered structures, rather than being monolayer flakes as in theoretical studies. Unlike monolayer flakes, the diffusion of gases through the interlayer spacing of stacked flakes may influence the gas sensing performance. Also, the presence of internal water layers between stacked MXene flakes may play a role in determining the selectivity of gas sensors.
24 MXenes for Sensors 469
Kim et al. conducted a thorough experimental investigation on Ti3C2Tx gas sensors [18], fully exploiting the unique combination of high electrical conductivity and abundant surface functionalities in MXenes. As previously mentioned, using a material with the highest intrinsic electrical conductivity would have the chance to yield the lowest noise. Therefore, Ti3C2Tx is one of the best choices in this manner as Ti3C2Tx shows a very high, metallic conductivity. It is also noteworthy that this is the first report on a pristine metallic channel for universal VOC gas detection.
In this study, Ti3C2Tx was prepared by LiF-HCl etching of Ti3AlC2 MAX phases, which were then delaminated into single flakes by sonication. The types of surface functionalities were investigated through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis, in which they showed that oxygen and hydroxyl groups are abundantly present, similar to previous reports on MXene surface functionalities. Elemental analysis via scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was additionally utilized to show that abundant surface groups were present on the surface. To obtain the lowest electrical noise as possible, it is very important to synthesize MXene films with high electrical conductivity. For this, Kim et al. synthesized Ti3C2Tx films by vacuum filtration, which allows the thickness-controlled fabrication of highly uniform films down to 10 nm scale. Thin Ti3C2Tx films of 70 nm thickness fabricated by vacuum filtration showed a low electrical resistivity, below 100 ohm, due to their intrinsic metallic conductivity. Also, films were subjected to postheating treatments in vacuum to remove residual water layers on the Ti3C2Tx films, which is also highly important in achieving low electrical resistivity. On the other hand, Lee et al. demonstrated Ti3C2Tx gas sensors synthesized by drop casting, which showed a much higher electrical resistivity around 10,000 ohm [19], which is a considerably high value regarding the fact that the typical conductivity of Ti3C2Tx films is usually about 4000–8000 S/cm. This is due to the fact that it is relatively difficult to achieve film uniformity in drop-casted films. Moreover, heat-drying methods were not employed in their study, also leading to a higher electrical resistivity.
The Ti3C2Tx films were then immersed in a sodium hydroxide solution to dissolve the sacrificial filter and promote the formation of –OH functional groups on the surface of individual flakes prior to the transfer onto sensing electrodes. The gas sensing performance of Ti3C2Tx sensors were evaluated for various VOCs such as acetone (ketone), ethanol (alcohol), propanal (aldehyde), and ammonia (amine) and acidic gases such as NO2, CO2, and SO2. Here, the gas response was calculated by relative change of resistance from the baseline, as shown in the equation below, which is a calculation method typically employed for chemiresistors based on 2D materials.
Gas response (%) = Rgas − Rbaseline Rbaseline × 100%
A positive response indicates an increase in the resistance and a negative response indicates a decrease in the resistance. In conventional semiconducting channels, the gas response behavior of VOC gases and acidic gases typically occur in opposite directions (positive/negative) [20, 21]. This is because the electron
470 S. J. Kim and H.-T. Jung
donating/accepting behavior is the opposite for the two groups. However, Ti3C2Tx sensors displayed an interesting behavior where the gas response for all species showed a positive response, which has been never observed. Such a phenomenon can be attributed to the metallic conductivity of Ti3C2Tx [22]. In a metallic channel, all types of adsorbed species act as scattering sites to degrade the electron transport property [23].
For an exposure to 100 ppm of each gas species, Ti3C2Tx films showed a much higher response to VOC gases compared to that of acidic gases, which is in accord to simulation results. The absolute gas response value itself was low, as the highest gas response (ethanol) was only 1.8%. The low gas response value is commonly observed in sensing channels with high electrical conductivity, whereas semiconducting channels such as MoS2 tend to show values around 20–40%. The high selectivity toward polar VOC gases may be also due to the gas molecules intercalating into the MXene interlayers. It is well known that polar molecules, especially amine-type molecules, readily intercalate due to the interlayer water layers, eventually expanding the interlayer distance by a considerable amount. This expansion of interlayer distance may lead to increased electrical resistivity, which can also partially explain the universal positive response. On the other hand, the intercalation of acidic gases is difficult compared to polar species.
Importantly, Ti3C2Tx sensors were also able to show very clear and significant gas responses in the ppb concentration regime at room temperature, one of the most important requisites for therapeutic diagnosis. As shown in Fig. 24.5, clear gas responses of VOCs were easily observed at room temperature even for very low gas concentrations of 50 ppb. Ti3C2Tx gas sensors are the first of room-temperature 2D sensors that are able to detect VOCs below 100 ppb concentration, as shown in Fig. 24.6. Although the detection of VOC gases below 100 ppb has been widely
achieved for gas sensors based on metal oxide semiconductors, all of these results were obtained at high operating temperature above 200 ◦C. The limit of detection for a gas sensor is widely accepted as the concentration point at which the signalto-noise ratio reaches 3 [4]. In certain setups where this point is difficult to be experimentally reached due to limits in synthesizing highly diluted gas mixtures, the limit of detection can be mathematically estimated based on a trend line (linear or power-law depending on the system). Based on this, the limit of detection for acetone and ammonia was calculated to be 0.011 and 0.13 ppb, respectively, which is one of the lowest values ever reported, also comparable to the best performing room temperature sensors such as Au nanoparticles or Si nanowires. This also indicates that Ti3C2Tx sensors will be able to detect VOC gases in the entire ppb
472 S. J. Kim and H.-T. Jung
range in ideal sensing platforms, demonstrating their potential to be utilized in therapeutic applications.
Ti3C2Tx MXene was also shown to greatly outperform other 2D materials in terms of signal-to-noise ratio. On a two-electrode sensing electrode, Ti3C2Tx displayed a very low noise of around 0.005%, lower than that of reduced graphene oxide, known to be one of the most conducting channels, which displayed an electrical noise of around 0.02%. In low-frequency noise measurements, the noise of Ti3C2Tx was even 10 times lower than that of reduced graphene oxide and 10,000 times lower than that of semiconducting MoS2 channels. Due to this low noise, the signal-to-noise ratio of Ti3C2Tx upon exposure to 100 ppm VOC gases was as high as 351 (ethanol) whereas the maximum was only about 11 for other 2D materials. Also, the signal-to-noise ratio still showed a relatively high value at very dilute gas concentrations (25.6 for 50 ppb of acetone). These results clearly show that the sensitivity of MXene greatly surpasses its counterparts, attributed to its unique combination of abundant surface functional groups and high electrical conductivity.

sections.heading: Future Outlook on MXene Gas Sensors
sections.text:
MXenes are very promising materials for high performance gas sensors due to the independent coexistence of high-density surface functionalities and electrical conductivity, and it is expected that many researches and significant advances will be made in the near future. However, there are several important issues to overcome for the efficient utilization of MXenes for gas sensors. Although MXene gas sensors have shown a high selectivity for VOC gases over traditionally responsive acidic gases, the selectivity between individual VOC gases has not been achieved. Therefore, arrays of several surface-modified MXenes need to be utilized in order to achieve high resolution selectivity. In this manner, two factors need to be taken into consideration. First, surfaces of channel materials should be able to be easily modified by physical/chemical treatments as surface property plays a major role in determining the selectivity of 2D channel materials. Fortunately, the very high coverage of surface functionalities on MXenes leaves much room for the modification of terminal groups. Under appropriate chemical reactions, ligands can be attached to these functional groups via crosslinking, etc. By this method, MXene films with different terminal groups can be synthesized. Second, the gas sensing performance of other MXenes besides Ti3C2 needs to be further investigated.
A large obstacle that needs to be overcome for practical application is the stability of MXene gas sensors. Achieving a constant device performance over elongated periods of time is crucial in determining the cost and efficiency of a gas sensor. MXene is known to be prone to oxidation when air or water is in the surrounding environment. Short exposures may simply result in water adsorbing to the surface, but longer exposures will oxidize MXenes to create transition metal oxide nanocrystals, which is an irreversible reaction leading to permanent degradation. In completely sealed devices such as coin cell batteries, additional water and air is blocked, so the initial device performance may be largely preserved.
24 MXenes for Sensors 473
However, regarding the operating mechanism of gas sensors, especially those dealing with breath analysis, it is hard to completely seal MXene films from oxidants as the gas adsorption sites are identical to those prone to oxidation.

sections.heading: Uses of Tactile Sensors
sections.text: Tactile sensors are used in numerous applications on both human and robots. Strain sensors are already being used to monitor human body movement in certain activities. First, they can be used to correct posture of people for better health. For example, sensors can also be placed on the back or on each foot to figure out the postural balance during sitting or walking. This technology can be intensively used for sport athletes. As athletes are involved in much intense body movement compared to the average person, they are prone to short-term and long-term injuries. By employing sensor-based training, an athlete can monitor their motion and weak points toward better performance. Second, sensitive sensors can used to detect signals such as heart rate and respiratory rates. One can personally monitor such health indicators over a long period of time, or give aid in monitoring realtime indicators of ill or older people that have difficulties moving around. Third, advanced tactile sensors can be used in robotic arms for remote surgery, or even in full robotic surgery in the future. In remote surgery, the motion of a human surgeon is copied onto the robotic arm that is directly acting on the patient. As the motions in a surgery need to be highly elaborate, it is critical that the robotic arm follows the motion of the human as precisely as possible. In these cases, the sensitivity and reproducible operation of sensors is of paramount importance. The most renowned application of tactile sensors nowadays is the “electronic skin,” which refers to an artificial surface able to highly mimic the mechanoreceptors of the human skin. This technology is highly important for allowing humanoid robots to follow human activities such as grabbing/holding objects, recognizing surface texture, or using writing instruments. Although these activities look simple to us, these require very high sensitivity in wide stimuli ranges and fast responses in order to implement in a robot.

sections.heading: Requirements for High-Performance Tactile Sensors
sections.text:
The main requirements for a high-performance tactile sensor can be summarized into sensitivity, range, linearity and reproducibility, and speed. First, sensitivity to very small force is highly important. For example, the high sensitivity of the human finger allows us to do elaborate behavior such as using tweezers or chopsticks to pick up small items. In order for artificial machines to mimic such elaborate behavior, they need to be able to detect very small stimuli. Sensitivity of a tactile
474 S. J. Kim and H.-T. Jung
sensor is typically demonstrated as the “gauge factor,” which indicates the relative response per unit stimuli. For example, in a resistive-type strain sensor, the gauge factor represents the relative change in electrical resistivity per strain. Sensors with low sensitivity may have a gauge factor below 10, while highly sensitive sensors may show gauge factors above 500. Besides force sensitivity, a high spatial resolution is necessary. In artificial devices, this is usually dependent on the size of individual receptors and the circuitry resolution of the device. The smaller the receptors and the denser the circuits are, the sensitivity will be higher. Second, the range of detection is important. Among various activities throughout a day, the applied external force can be very small in some cases, such as a bee sitting on a surface, or a finger touching a very soft object. On the other hand, the external force can be very large, such as in the case of weighing cargo or during collision. As future machines/robots many deal with numerous types of operations, sensors with a wide range of detection are highly desired. However, many conventional materials show a trade-off between sensitivity and detecting range, and fabricating sensors that have both high sensitivity and a wide detecting range is a challenge. Third, linearity and reproducibility are important for the reliable operation of a tactile sensor. Depending on the channel material and sensing system, electrical resistivity may not linearly correlate to external force. Such nonlinearity of the sensor makes calibration and reverse calculation highly difficult, leading to a lower resolution toward lower sensitivity. Moreover, extreme deformation in channels such as cracks or disconnections can break the original correlation curve to create nonlinearity in previously linear systems. This will greatly degrade the reproducibility of a sensor, limiting its use. Finally, the response speed of a sensor is important to catch small variations in external stimuli toward performing elaborate actions.

sections.heading: Types of Tactile Sensors
sections.text:
Tactile sensors can be classified by the specific mechanism of how the mechanical deformations are transduced into signals. Examples of sensors by this classification are resistive (piezoresistive), capacitive, piezoelectric, triboelectric, optical, and magnetic sensors. Due to practicality, easiness of fabrication, and the capability to be utilized into flexible/wearable devices, resistive sensors and capacitive sensors are mainly used over other types.
These two sensors can be further classified by the behavior of nanomaterials upon mechanical strain or pressure: piezoresistive, geometrical, and percolationbased sensors. In piezoresistive sensors, change in electrical resistance is caused by the structural deformation of the material itself in the atomic/molecular scale. Piezoresistors are highly sensitive and are able to function in small working areas. Semiconducting piezoresistors tend to show a larger sensitivity over metallic piezoresistors due to the fact that the change of bandgap upon atomic deformation can greatly change electrical resistance. However, piezoresistors made of a single material/component are typically fragile, as the intrinsic stretchability of materials
24 MXenes for Sensors 475
are not high. In geometrical sensors, change in electrical resistance is caused by the geometry change of films or structures, due to the fact that electrical resistance is not only dependent on the material’s resistivity, but also dependent on the length and cross-sectional area of a channel. In strain gauge sensors, very high levels of strain can not only deform the original geometry, but also disconnect films by forming cracks. This may lead to dramatically enhanced sensitivity, but may also result in irreversible and nonlinear performance. As the materials’ fragility can limit its use as a strain gauge sensor, many studies have embedded them into polymeric substrates. In percolation-based sensors, the change in electrical resistance is dependent on the junction density of conducting channels. By using fiber-like materials, such as carbon nanotubes or silver nanowires, matrix-like conducting channels can be created. In such channels, electrons are conducted through inter-fiber junctions, unlike in films where electrons are conducted through the entire plane. Stretching the sensor decreases the junction density per area, leading to increased electrical resistance. Percolation-based sensors are highly stretchable compared to other types, but typically show lower sensitivity (Table 24.4).

sections.heading: MXenes for Piezoresistive Sensors
sections.text:
Ma et al. first demonstrated piezoresistive tactile sensors using multilayered Ti3C2Tx MXene [24]. Sensing channels were prepared by pressing a drop of multilayered Ti3C2Tx with two polyimide tapes that function as the flexible substrate. This results in a roughly stacked Ti3C2Tx film with empty spaces of 3–12 nm thickness due to the irregular morphology of individual flakes. Due to such morphology, piezoresistivity occurred due to two major reasons.
In the first phase, initial pressure on the multilayer Ti3C2Tx film compresses the film in an out-of-plane direction, which gradually removes the originally present empty inter-flake spaces. This results in more Ti3C2Tx flakes being in direct contact with one another leading to a decreased electrical resistivity. Continually applying
476 S. J. Kim and H.-T. Jung
pressure in this stage will eventually reach a point when empty spaces are no longer present in the film, ending the first phase. In the second phase, higher pressure compresses the Ti3C2Tx film at a molecular scale. The interlayer distance of MXenes are typically larger compared to that of other layer-stacked materials, which is due to the presence of a water layer. These water layers are not in the bulk phase, and they are removable or compressible to some amount. Applying pressure decreases interlayer distance, which brings each Ti3C2Tx unit layer closer to each other, resulting in a decreased electrical resistivity.
As the conductivity change can be expected to be much larger in the first phase compared to the second phase, we can expect a higher sensitivity in a low strain regime. This is shown in actual results where demonstrated Ti3C2Tx tactile sensors show a high gauge factor of 94.8–180.1 for low strains below 1.0%, while the gauge factor was lower at 45.9–94.8 for strain values larger than 1.0%. The piezoresistive sensor was able to detect various human motions: eye blinking, cheek bulging, throat swallowing, and bending-release movement of the elbow, finger, ankle, and knee. Each motion resulted in an increase in electrical current due to the vertical contraction of MXene layers, demonstrating the practical use of MXene piezoresistive tactile sensors (Fig. 24.7).
24 MXenes for Sensors 477

sections.heading: MXene Composites for Strain Sensors
sections.text:
MXenes were also mixed with carbon nanotubes (CNTs) to form a composite film as strain sensors. Cai et al. repeatedly spray-coated MXene and CNT solutions by layer-by-layer assembly to form sandwich-like MXene-CNT layers on elastic substrates [25]. The fiber-like CNTs knitted the Ti3C2Tx MXene sheets to give elasticity in the composite film itself.
The sensing mechanism of the MXene-CNT composite mainly arose from the cracking of MXene flakes from external strain. Upon a small amount of strain, cracks begin to form in the MXene sheets connected by fibrous CNT, resulting in an increased electrical resistivity. Unless the film does not disconnect entirely, the cracking behavior may be reversible to yield stable performance over numerous cycles. Upon a very large strain, cracks can severely propagate to create islands that are completely disconnected from each other. This results in a dramatic change in electrical conductivity. However, the complete disconnection may not allow full reversibility to the film’s original morphology, resulting in an altered sensing performance.
Following the sensing mechanism of MXene-CNT strain gauge sensors, results show that the gauge factor dramatically increased as the strain intensity became larger. For a very small strain up to 0.6%, the gauge factor was only 4.35 while for a larger strain up to 30%, the gauge factor increased to about 64.60. In these strain regimes, identical sensitivity was demonstrated for up to 1000 cycles indicating the reversible operation of tactile sensors. Therefore, we can expect that the film does not fully disconnect at a strain of 30%. At strain values higher than 40%, the gauge factor rapidly increased to a value of 772.60 that can be expected to be due to the complete cracking of MXene-CNT films. The limited reversibility was also shown in the strain response at different cycles where the change in electrical resistivity became smaller for identical strains in latter stretching cycles. Compared to the piezoresistive case, the MXene composite strain sensor were demonstrated up to much larger strain values with greater gauge factors. The strain sensor was able to detect verbal patterns, responding to each syllable of a word, and human motions such as walking, running, and jumping. Each motion resulted in a decrease in electrical current due to disconnected junctions, showing opposite behavior to the previously introduced MXene piezoresistive sensors.

sections.heading: Future Outlook on MXene Tactile Sensors
sections.text:
MXenes have the potential to be widely used in tactile sensors as they can be easily fabricated into films on various types of substrates. Also, the stability issues arisen in gas sensors may be negligible for tactile sensors, as MXene channels can be embedded in polymeric matrixes to completely block oxygen and water vapor from reaching the MXene flakes. MXenes in their pristine form many not be the optimal choice for piezoresistive tactile sensors as they are highly conductive and their conductivity anisotropy (σ ‖/σ⊥) is relatively smaller than other layered materials,
478 S. J. Kim and H.-T. Jung
implying that the conductivity change many not be immense upon external force. On the other hand, as MXenes are two-dimensional materials, controlling their geometry and inter-flake structure (e.g., ion intercalation or film assembly control) may offer better performance when employed as strain gauge sensors.

sections.heading: Biosensors
sections.text: MXenes have also been demonstrated as biosensors where MXene-based field effect transistors (FETs) were used to detect target molecules at very low concentrations [26]. As the detecting mechanism of biomolecules onto MXene surfaces is similar to that of gas sensors, MXenes can be expected to show high performance as biosensors due to their high density of surface functionalities (strong adsorption) and high electrical conductivity (low noise). The biosensing applications will be further discussed in more detail in Chap. 26 (biomedical applications).

sections.heading: Overall Future Outlook on MXene Sensors
sections.text: MXenes have been just begun to be used in sensing applications, but surprisingly already showing excellent performances over previous materials. As MXenes have a very unique property among nanomaterials, and also due to the fact that there are over 50 types of possible MXenes, it is expected that MXene sensors will continue to show groundbreaking results in the near future. A major challenge to consider in the future direction of MXene sensors lies in the tunability of MXene morphology and its surface functionalities. So far, MXenes are synthesized by a top-down etching method in aqueous solutions. Therefore, their flake size and surface functionalities are in a large part predetermined by the etching environment. If further techniques to control such factors are developed, such as bottom-up chemical vapor deposition (CVD) synthesis or post-synthesis surface treatments, we can expect that large opportunities in tunable sensing applications will emerge.

sections.heading: MXenes for Transparent Conductive Electrodes and Transparent Energy Storage Devices
Introduction
sections.text:
Future personal electronics will be the shift toward optically transparent, touchable, flexible devices [1, 2]. Central to these devices is the development of transparent, conductive ultrathin films, also termed as transparent conductive electrodes (TCEs). Developing high-performance TCEs is crucial in many applications such as touch screens, displays, solar cells, and others [3]. Importantly, incorporating TCEs into energy storage devices, such as Li-ion batteries and supercapacitors, is a crucial technology for the next-generation portable, wearable electronics. Transparent energy storage systems will require the material of choice that can simultaneously act as current collectors to transport electrons and active material to store charge. This is quite challenging as dramatically increased sheet resistance is typically experienced when approaching high transparency of the TCEs. Consequently, the device charge storage properties become unsatisfactory.
Currently, the TCEs market is dominated by indium tin oxide (ITO). Although ITO possesses excellent optoelectronic properties, it showcases brittleness and needs high-temperature treatment during thin-film processing, adding high cost to manufacturing. This means that for future transparent energy storage devices, ITO is unlikely to be the material of choice. Instead, advanced alternative ultrathin films

481
482 C. J. Zhang and V. Nicolosi
need to be developed with good mechanical properties and excellent charge storage performance in order to enable the production of flexible, robust TCEs and their transparent energy storage devices.
Recently, a large class of two-dimensional (2D) metal carbide and nitrides, known as MXenes, have emerged. Selectively etching the A layer (typically Al or Ga) from the MAX phase (where M represents an early transition metal, X is C and/or N) in the hydrofluoric acid (HF)-containing solution, MXenes are obtained with a general formula of Mn+1XnTx (Tx stands for various surface functionalities such as –OH, –O, and/or –F, and n = 1, 2, or 3) [4–6]. Upon solvent intercalation and/or cation exchange followed by sonication or mechanical vibration, the multilayered (m-) MXene powders were delaminated into MXene nanosheets with lateral size typically less than one micrometers (μm). It is noteworthy that once the delamination is performed in water, an aqueous colloidal solution of single- and few-layer MXenes is obtained. This enables a facile and environmentally friendly processing of the MXene solution into any items, such as composites, coatings, and devices. Despite the presence of terminal surface groups, MXenes, especially the most intensively studied titanium carbide MXene, showcase a metallic conductivity [7–9]. The excellent electronic conductivity coupled with fast faradaic reactions results in impressive charge storage property, so-called pseudocapacitance [10], in the MXenes. In addition, monolayer MXene nanosheet is optically transparent, similar to the analogue graphene. Collectively, MXenes are quite promising for the high-performance transparent conductive coatings and transparent energy storage systems.
This chapter describes the electrode materials used for the transparent conductive films and transparent supercapacitors. Specifically, we highlight the fabrication of MXene transparent films and devices. Fundamentals and limitations of TCEs are also included. Considering that the number of publications on the TCEs grows enormously, this chapter is not attempting to include all the TCEs exhaustively; rather, it shows the important examples using MXenes to shed light on the main trends.

sections.heading: Fundamentals of TCEs
sections.text:
Transparent conductive films play a significant role in modern consumer electronics such as liquid crystal displays, flat panel displays, organic light-emitting diode (OLED), plasma displays, touch panels, video and still-image recorders, solar cells, lasers, and optical communication devices, [11] as shown in Fig. 25.1. Developing high-performance TCEs is the key to boost next-generation portable electronics.
Ideally, the TCE should possess both high transmittance across the UV-vis-NIR spectrum and low sheet resistance (Rs). In practical, we measure the transmittance spectrum of the TCE in a range of 350–800 nm (UV-vis wavelength range) and define the absorbance at 550 nm as the transmittance (T). The sheet resistance can be obtained by a four-point (or two-point) probe. Decreasing the film thickness will improve T but also inevitably increases Rs. For example, when carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are used to fabricate TCEs, a higher CNTs density results in more light
25 MXenes for Transparent Conductive Electrodes and Transparent Energy. . . 483
absorption; thus the transmittance is decreased. At the same time, due to a more developed charge percolation enabled by CNTs network, the Rs decreases [3, 12]. In other words, there is a trade-off between these two parameters. To facilitate the direct comparison among TCEs, some variations have been proposed with the most common one being the ratio of dc electrical conductivity (σ dc) to optical conductivity (σ op) [13]. Such a ratio is also defined as figure of merit (FoMe = σ dc/σ op), which can be obtained through Eq. (25.1):
T = (
1 + 188.5 Rs σop σdc
)−2 (25.1)
Actually the above formula is correct provided that (1) the wavelength of the incident light is larger than the film thickness and (2) the fraction of reflected light is much less than the absorbance [11]. For most of the TCEs, these two conditions are usually met; thus Eq. (25.1) is frequently employed to estimate the optoelectronic properties of the TCEs. For a given film with a specific thickness (t), the FoMe is calculated based on the measured T and Rs. According to t and Rs, the electrical conductivity of this film can be obtained through Eq. (25.2):
σdc = 1 Rst

A higher FoMe indicates better optoelectronic properties and maintains good electrical conductivity even at a high transparency (low thickness). On the other hand, TCEs with tailored optoelectronic properties can be used in different applications. For example, the touch panel requires T > 85% and Rs < 500 /sq., while liquid crystal display (LCD) screen T > 85% and Rs < 100 /sq. [11, 14–16] According to Eq. (25.1), the FoMe is calculated to be 4.5 in touch panel and 22.3 in LCD, respectively. Table 25.1 lists the minimum requirements of TCEs in different applications.
Generally, fabricating films with a higher FoMe is the ultimate goal in the TCE field. Although doped transition metal oxides, most commonly ITO showcases impressively high FoMe, its brittleness and high cost limit the future application in the portable electronics [17]. Therefore, questing advanced films with excellent mechanical and optoelectronic properties is the key to the next-generation touchable electronics. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs), graphene, silver nanowires, and other nanomaterials possess a quite high aspect ratio, rendering their TCEs mechanically flexible with high σ dc. For CNT-based TCEs, their optoelectronic properties are influenced by many factors such as type, diameter, and bundle length of CNT, film fabrication method, etc. [11] By controlling the film thickness made of single-, double-, or multi-walled CNT, effect of the number of walls of the CNT on the sheet resistance can be thus revealed. As shown in Fig. 25.2, less number of CNT walls results in lower Rs; this is because more walls inevitably increase the diameter of the nanotubes and increase the light absorption instead of conductivity. In addition, the methods to produce TCEs are also important to control the optoelectronic properties. Using roll-to-roll process give CNT TCEs with a very high FoMe (82.7) from the aligned CNT forest [18], and opening up vast opportunities in LCD and OLED displays, while spraying the SWCNT solution onto the substrate generally results in a lower FoMe (1.9) [3]. Despite that, the wet methods, such as spray/spin/dip coating, brush painting, vacuum filtration, etc., bring immediate advantages such as high production efficiency and compatibility with industrial scale.
Actually, in the CNT-based TCEs, the thickness of the film is typically tens of nanometer. For a uniform, homogeneous TCE made of SWCNT, the thickness is usually lower than 50 nm in the high transparency region (T > 70%). Thus, the film can be viewed as two-dimensional (2D) consisted of one-dimensional (1D) CNTbased networks. The charge carriers flow along a tube and then jump to another tube at the junction. Therefore, the model can be simplified and the sheet resistance is a sum of contact resistance on the junctions due to the overlapping of nanotubes
and the intrinsic resistance from the tube [11]. This simplified model can also be applied to graphene [14, 15, 19]. The highly conductive nature of these two kinds of sp2 carbons renders the intrinsic resistance negligible. Said otherwise, the junction resistance largely determines the optoelectronic performance in the CNT or graphene-based TCEs. According to the 2D percolation theory, the percolation threshold (Nc) can be described through Eq. (25.3):
Nc = 4.2362πLs2 ≈ 1/L (25.3)
where Ls and L are the individual length and the aspect ratio of the CNT, respectively [20]. For typical SWCNTs, the L is up to ~1000 which results in a quite low percolation threshold. This means that the surface coverage to form a path and conduct the charge carriers is low, leading to a high transmittance in the CNT-based TCEs. Actually, comparing to graphene TCEs, the surface coverage in CNT ones is lower, thus TCEs fabricated using SWCNT usually showcase higher transparency and demonstrate better optoelectronic properties than the graphene ones [3, 21, 22].
De and Coleman compared the optoelectronic properties of graphene-based TCEs from various published papers in detail, as shown in Fig. 25.3 [23]. For the CVD-grown graphene films, a highest FoMe (11) is observed. For the TCEs fabricated using RGO or CMG or liquid phase-exfoliated graphene flakes, the FoMe is much lower (<0.7, as shown in Fig. 25.3b). This can be explained that the interflake tunneling barriers, similar to junctions in the CNT networks, are much less in the quasi-continuous CVD-grown films than the solution processed films [23]. However, by doping the graphene films through chemical treatments, the FoMe can be substantially improved. This is highlighted by Ahn et al., who produced transparent graphene films using a roll-to-roll strategy followed by wetchemical doping of monolayer CVD-grown flakes (shown in Fig. 25.4) [2]. Notably, the films showcase excellent optoelectronic properties even superior to commercial
486 C. J. Zhang and V. Nicolosi
25 MXenes for Transparent Conductive Electrodes and Transparent Energy. . . 487
transparent ITO electrode. For example, the films demonstrate a T = 90% and a Rs = 30 /sq., indicating a FoMe as high as 116 according to Eq. (25.1).
Apart from the generally low FoMe in most CNT or graphene-based TCEs, there is another limitation. When thinning down the film thickness, the transmittance becomes higher and thus the TCE is more desirable. However, in the highly transparent region, the surface coverage is typically below Nc, which results in a dramatically increased sheet resistance. This issue is known as percolation effect, which is reflected by the deviation of bulk-like behavior in the T vs Rs and Rs vs t plot. Figure 25.5a–c shows the optoelectronic properties of P3-SWCNT TCEs [3]. As expected for bulk-like materials, for the thicker films, Rs scales inversely with film thickness, as demonstrated by the dashed line in (b). When the thickness
488 C. J. Zhang and V. Nicolosi
decreases further and below a critical value, tmin, dc, the deviation evolves with dramatically increased Rs, as percolation effects become important. We note such an effect can be encountered not only in the CNT or graphene-based TCEs [24], but also found in the CNT/polymer composite [25] and silver nanowire networks [13]. Despite an extremely high FoMe (~500) achieved in the silver nanowire TCE with film thickness > 300 nm (corresponding to T < 50%), in the highly transparent region (T > 90%), FoMe dramatically reduces to 30, as shown in Fig. 25.5e–i. Recently, formic acid-treated poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)/poly(styrene-4sulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS) was reported with an extremely low σ op (24 S/cm) coupled with high σ dc (936 S/cm), indicative of FoMe = 39. Most importantly, no percolation problems are encountered (shown in Fig. 25.6), suggesting exceptional uniformity for the highly transparent films (T = 99%) [26].

sections.heading: MXenes in the Transparent Conductive Electrodes
sections.text:
As previously discussed, the technologically viable devices should operate in the bulk-like regime, where the σ dc is roughly independent of T. Said otherwise, the notorious percolation problems should be avoided as much as possible. This is quite challenging, as the percolative conductive network is usually interrupted when thinning down the transparent films. Solution to this issue lies in developing novel materials that possess excellent electronic conductivity and a high aspect ratio, the latter endows less interflake tunneling barriers or junctions coupled with good mechanical flexibility.
25 MXenes for Transparent Conductive Electrodes and Transparent Energy. . . 489
Two-dimensional transition metal carbides, carbonitrides, and nitrides, also known as MXenes, have emerged and quickly become attractive since 2011 [4, 6]. To date, Ti3C2Tx is the most widely studied one with applications in energy storage devices [27–30], electromagnetic-interference shielding [31–33], water desalination [34], etc. Despite the existence of these surface functionalities, Ti3C2Tx showcases a metallic electronic conductivity with measured value even higher than that of graphene, rendering a great promise of this new 2D material in the TCE field [35].

sections.heading: Ti3C2Tx MXene TCEs
sections.text:
Pioneer work on the Ti3C2Tx transparent films was performed by Halim et al., who sputter deposited epitaxial Ti3AlC2 films followed by selective etching of the Al element [36]. The as-obtained epitaxial thin films were about 19 nm thick, corresponding to a T = 90% in the visible-to-infrared range. Despite that, MXene films fabricated by such a method raises up cost and scale-up concerns. For potentially large-scale production of TCEs, the film fabrication method must be scalable and low cost.
When multilayered Ti3C2Tx is sonicated under the inert gas, delaminated Ti3C2Tx nanosheets with a predominant monolayer distribution are obtained. Unlike the analogue graphene, Ti3C2Tx nanosheets possess a hydrophilic surface and thus can be easily dispersed in water, forming aqueous dispersions. Through a solution processing strategy, Ti3C2Tx-based TCEs can be fabricated with controllable thickness and, thus, tunable optoelectronic properties. It is important to point out that the aqueous solution processing immediately brings advantages to the thin film fabrication, composite formation, and device manufacturing. Compared to the ITO production which requires high-temperature treatment, solution processing of Ti3C2Tx aqueous solution at room temperature greatly simplifies the procedure and reduces the cost. In addition, the high aspect ratio of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets renders the resultant TCE with a high mechanical flexibility, in sharp contrast to the brittleness in the ITO-based films.
Spraying the Ti3C2Tx aqueous solution can produce transparent homogeneous films with thickness ranging from 5 to 70 nm, corresponding to 40–91% of transmittance. At T = 40% (thickness, t~70 nm), Rs = 500 /sq. Decreasing the thickness to 5 nm leads to T = 91%; as expected, however, Rs boosts to 8 k /sq. Taking this values together, FoMe in these Ti3C2Tx TCEs by spray coating is around 0.5–0.7 [37]. Despite the FoMe being far below to that of ITO, it is comparable to the analogue graphene [23, 24]. In another trial of spray coating of Ti3C2Tx, the resistivity reaches 3.4 × 104 /cm at a T = 86.7%, leading to a somewhat low FoMe [38]. We propose the undesirable FoMe in the highly conductive Ti3C2Tx MXene could be attributed to the thin film fabrication method. In the spray coating setup, the droplets are purged by the gas and sprayed onto the hot substrate, where the solvent (ethanol [37] or water [38]) gets quickly evaporated. The as-generated vapor bubbles and the nanosheets create plenty of voids/pores that negatively hinder the
490 C. J. Zhang and V. Nicolosi
smooth transport of charge carriers among the randomly stacked network. Another possible reason is that, despite a high σ dc observed in Ti3C2Tx, its σ op is also quite high, leading to a relatively low FoMe.
To further check the abovementioned hypothesis, we compared the optoelectronic properties of Ti3C2Tx-based TCEs using spray-coating and spin-casting methods, respectively. Figure 25.7 shows basic characterizations of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets and T vs Rs curves of two kinds of TCEs. The spray-coated films showcase an uneven surface with corners clearly seen, which should be a result of quick water evaporation. By adjusting the sprayed volume, a series of TCEs with different transmittance were obtained (Fig. 25.7d–e). Through fitting the T vs Rs data, we found the FoMe to be 1.7 in the spin-casted films while 0.6 in the spray-coated ones. The FoMe = 0.6 in our case falls exactly in the range of 0.5–0.7 in the first report on the MXene spray coating as discussed above [37]. The higher FoMe in the spin-casted films should be attributed to the highly ordered nanosheets forming compacted conductive network and the absence of randomly stacked sheets or voids, which will be discussed below.
Taylor et al. prepared a range of Ti3C2Tx TCEs using the spin coating method [39]. By tuning the spin speed from 400 to 1600 rpm, TCEs with different film thickness are thus obtained. The slower the spin rate is, the greater the overlap of the nanosheets is observed. For example, decreasing the spin rate from 1000 rpm
25 MXenes for Transparent Conductive Electrodes and Transparent Energy. . . 491
to 800, 600, and 400 rpm leads to a mean overlap of two, three, four, and five nanosheets on the TCEs, respectively. At 400 rpm, the TCE demonstrates a T of 77% and Rs of 437 /sq. However, at 1000 rpm, T improves to 85% at the cost of Rs, which dramatically boosts to 10 k /sq. due to the less amount of interconnected flakes [39]. In other words, the grain boundaries play a significant role in forming the continuous network. Taking these data together, the spin-cast Ti3C2Tx TCEs possess a high conductivity of 3092 S/cm and a FoMe of 3.1. Importantly, by vacuum annealing these wet films at 175 ◦C, Rs can be reduced substantially, which is a result of elimination of adsorbed water on the surface and between the nanosheets [39]. This also highlights the importance of films storage, as water gradually oxidizes the films, especially for the highly transparent ones. Using a similar method, Barsoum et al. fabricated Ti3C2Tx TCEs with an even higher conductivity, 6500 S/cm. The FoMe reaches 5 from the fitting of the bulk regime [40]. Unfortunately, percolation problems are still encountered in these spin-cast films.
By controlling the flake alignment using the spin coating approach, followed by vacuum annealing at 200 ◦C, we achieved various Ti3C2Tx TCEs with thickness ranging from 1.4 nm (T = 97.3%) to 189 nm (T = 12.3%) [9]. Under the effect of shear force, the Ti3C2Tx nanosheets, with several micrometers in lateral size (Fig. 25.8a), aligned parallel to the substrate and interconnected into a continuous film without protruding corners of flakes (Fig. 25.8b–c).
492 C. J. Zhang and V. Nicolosi
As previously discussed, percolation effects are typically found in the regime with a high transmittance. Due to the insufficient interflake tunneling barriers in the highly transparent Ti3C2Tx TCEs (T > 90%), the conductivity of the film switches from the bulk-type DC conductivity behavior in the single flakes to the percolation behavior. This is verified through the T vs Rs plot as the points fall below the dashed line (bulk-like conductivity), as seen in the spray-coated film in Fig. 25.7f.
To see the percolation effects clearly, Eq. (25.1) can be rearranged as
T −0.5 − 1 = 188.5 FoMe × Rs (25.4)
By plotting the T−0.5–1 as a function of Rs, we can determine the bulk-like conductivity behavior regime, the percolation regime, and the FoMe based on the slope of the fitted line [25]. Figure 25.8d shows that all measured data are roughly on the fitted bulk-type DC conductivity curve. The FoMe obtained by fitting the data in Fig. 25.8d is 15, surpassing almost all the carbon-based TCEs (Fig. 25.8e). By correlating Rs with film thickness, we found that, in general, Rs scales inversely with t (Fig. 25.8f), typically seen in the bulk-like materials. In other words, no apparent percolation problems are encountered in our Ti3C2Tx TCEs. This is further verified by the almost constant FoMe values in a range of thickness (or T, Fig. 25.9c). Impressively, our Ti3C2Tx TCEs demonstrate a σ dc = 5736 S/cm at T = 93% (t = 4 nm) and increase to 9880 S/cm at the cost of transmittance (T = 29%, t = 88 nm; Fig. 25.9b). The mean σ dc obtained from fitting the sheet conductance data in Fig. 25.9a, reaches 7350 S/cm.
In addition, the optoelectronic properties of TCEs are also influenced by the flake size and MXene type. As mentioned in Fig. 25.7f, the smaller flakes greatly reduce the FoMe from 15 to 1.7 when the size decreases from 3.2 μm to 268 nm. When small Ti2CTx flakes (~300 nm) are employed, the corresponding TCEs exhibit a FoMe of 0.5. Despite that, all MXene TCEs demonstrate a bulk-type conductivity, as all the measured points are on the dashed line showing in the inset of Fig. 25.9e. We note this is quite significant, which allows the TCEs to be more transparent without compromising the conductivity. In other words, the technologically viable devices based on the Ti3C2Tx thin films would render the DC conductivity roughly independent of T [9]. This unique property implies that for the highly transparent TCEs, the continuous Ti3C2Tx film could act as the efficient transparent current collector to transport electrons, as well as the active material to store charge at the same time. Namely, transparent supercapacitor can be thus built based on the Ti3C2Tx TCEs without the need of extra metals as current collectors.

sections.heading: Other MXene-Based TCEs
sections.text:
Inside the broad MXene family, there is certainly a need to investigate the optoelectronic and electrochemical properties of other MXenes and further explore their applications. Vanadium carbide (V2CTx) films were shown to have a conductivity up
25 MXenes for Transparent Conductive Electrodes and Transparent Energy. . . 493
to 1560 S cm-1 [41]. The challenging lies in the delamination of the m-V2CTx into d-V2CTx. Ying et al. delaminated the V2CTx in the 10 wt% tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH) solution [42]. The as-obtained V2CTx TCEs display a higher FoMe (6.5) than the Ti3C2Tx counterpart [40, 42]. It’s observed that annealing temperature plays an important role in achieving a high conductivity. For instance, the σ dc in the as-obtained films is 10 S cm−1, which dramatically increases to 3300 S cm−1 after annealing, an indicative of 300-fold increase [42]. The annealing process eliminates the trapped water molecules and thus improves the conductivity as a result. By further optimizing the synthesis recipe, such as employing less destructive etchant instead of HF, larger, cleaner sheets can be expected with less defects, thus higher DC conductivity. Consequently, the FoMe in the V2CTx TCEs can be pushed further.
494 C. J. Zhang and V. Nicolosi
Another example is Ti2CTx TCEs. Ying et al. prepared a concentrated Ti2CTx colloidal solution (25 mg ml−1) and thus a series of Ti2CTx TCEs. For the first time, a very high sheet conductivity has been achieved (5250 S cm−1) [43]. This is because the density of charge carriers is high [40, 44]. Benefiting from this, a high FoMe of 5 is obtained. It is reasonable to assume that the Ti2CTx TCEs have more advantages than the Ti3C2Tx counterpart, such as non-toxic, less expensive, and even better optoelectronic properties [43]. However, the stability of Ti2CTx aqueous colloidal solution as well as the TCEs should be addressed before the scalable production.

sections.heading: MXene for Transparent Energy Storage Devices
sections.text:
The fast growth of smart portable electronics requires the future products with exotic properties such as being flexible, stretchable, and transparent. To match with this trend, highly flexible and transparent power sources, most likely batteries and supercapacitors (SCs), should be developed [45]. In the past few years, significant efforts have been paid on building transparent solid-state SCs. For instances, through sandwiching the TCEs based on CNTs [46–48], graphene [49–52], metallic mesh and metal oxides [53–56], conducting polymers [57, 58], etc., with solid gel electrolyte as the separator, transparent SCs are thus developed. However, in some transparent SC reports, either complex procedures during the TCE fabrication were encountered [57, 58], or rigid substrates (such as ITO [55] or FTO [58]) were employed to provide efficient current collection, which limit the future of transparent SCs. Rather, by depositing the ultrathin films onto a robust plastic substrate in a scalable, simple strategy should be the option in building the nextgeneration transparent SCs. This requires the film as both efficient transparent current collector and high-performance transparent active material for capacitive (or pseudocapacitive) charge storage.
For any SC, the performance metrics are the stored energy (E) and power output (P):
E = 1 2 CV 2 (25.5)
P = V 2
4RESR (25.6)
In the perspective of materials, the electrode capacitance (C) should be maximized while the equivalent series resistance (RESR) be minimized. For the device, the operated voltage window (V) is limited by the aqueous electrolyte (1.2 V) and can be overcome by building the asymmetric configuration [59]. Consequently, both E and P of the transparent SCs are maximized. Other properties, such as excellent rate handling, long-term cycling, and reversible charge-discharge processes, are also desired for the as-fabricated transparent SCs.
25 MXenes for Transparent Conductive Electrodes and Transparent Energy. . . 495
In practical, for a given TCE, areal capacitance (CA) and volumetric capacitance (CV) are two most relevant measures and are related via CA = CVt. Both CA and CV are independent quantities and achieved in the absence of electron or ion transport limitations [26]. Although a TCE can be engineered with an ultrahigh T by making it sufficiently thin, the percolation problems become dominant, which results in a dramatically boosted Rs and thus negatively affect power. On the other hand, high T leads to much compromised CA and hence energy [3]. To quantify these trade-offs, CA is correlated with T for a set of TCEs through the expression: [3]
T = [
1 + 188.5 CV σopCA
]−2 (25.7)
For a given T, the ratio CV/σ op must be maximized to optimize the areal capacitance. Therefore, CV/σ op can be considered as a figure of merit (FoMc) for transparent capacitive films. Once FoMc is known, CV of the TCEs can be thus calculated by CV = FoMc × σ op. The higher this value is, the better the charge storage properties in the TCEs. Although ultrahigh FoMe values are achieved in the silver nanowire-based TCEs [13] and metallic mesh electrode [53], these metals do not possess a good charge storage capability. Alternatively, guest materials, such as conductive polymer and metal oxide, are deposited onto the highly conductive host [53, 59]. Again, this complicates the procedure in constructing high-performance transparent SCs.
Ti3C2Tx MXene is known for its ultrahigh electronic conductivity (up to 9880 S/cm) [9] and excellent electrochemical performance [7, 27], being the ideal candidate for transparent SCs. As previously stated, no percolation problems are encountered in the Ti3C2Tx TCEs which were fabricated through spin-casting the nanosheets solution followed by vacuum annealing [9]. This allows the device to be highly transparent since the metal or metallic mesh current collector is absent. In the three-electrode setup, the CV curves of T = 98% sample severely deviates from the quasi-rectangular shape, while electrodes with a lower T (such as T = 40%) well maintains the broad redox peak couple (Fig. 25.10a–c). Consequently, the measured areal capacitance as well as the rate capability is controlled by the film thickness. For instances, the T = 98% exhibits 0.13 mF/cm2 at 10 mV/s, a value that is close to PEDOT:PSS film [26] but substantially higher than that of graphene quantum dot-based TCE [50]. Increasing the film thickness to 60 nm (T = 40%) results in 3.4 mF/cm2 at 10 mV/s and maintains 3.0 mF/cm2 at 200 mV/s, as shown in Fig. 25.10d [9].
To reveal the intrinsic areal capacitance (CA) in the Ti3C2Tx electrodes, the data in Fig. 25.10d is fitted using Eq. (25.8):
C A = CA
[ 1 − ντ
