( 1 − e− Vντ )] (25.8)
where τ = RESR C is the time constant, V is the voltage window (0.65 V), and ν is the sweep rate. Although Eq. (25.8) greatly simplifies the complex electrochemical
496 C. J. Zhang and V. Nicolosi
behaviors, it still provides valuable insights for the TCE [26]. In general, CA is higher for the thicker TCE as expected. By correlating the CA with T, and further fitting these two parameters using Eq. (25.7), we are able to reveal the FoMc (CV/σ op) of the Ti3C2Tx as the transparent SC electrode. As demonstrated in Fig. 25.10e, a good fit is revealed with a FoMc of 1.3 F S cm−2, lower than that of PEDOT:PSS (1.9 F S cm−2) but substantially higher than the P3-SWCNT (0.3 F S cm−2) [3, 26]. Based on the FoMc and σ op, the CV of Ti3C2Tx films as transparent SC electrode was calculated to be 676 F/cm3, much higher than that achieved in the rest of all transparent SC electrodes, such as SWCNT [3, 60], graphene [61], or PEDOT:PSS [26], as shown in Fig. 25.10f.
It’s important to explore the device performance based on the Ti3C2Tx TCEs. By sandwiching two robust TCEs with gel electrolyte as the separator, transparent, flexible, solid-state SCs can be easily produced [9, 59]. Using the T = 91% as the electrode, the Ti3C2Tx-based symmetric SC reaches a transmittance of 80%. The as-fabricated device showcases highly capacitive behavior, including rectangular CV shape up to 200 mV/s, rapid current response upon voltage reversal, and linear galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) curves. The transparent, symmetric SC demonstrates an areal capacitance of 0.86 mF/cm2, slightly higher than the ruthenium oxide/PEDOT:PSS system [59] but much higher than the rest transparent devices, as shown in Fig. 25.11c.
25 MXenes for Transparent Conductive Electrodes and Transparent Energy. . . 497
By pairing two electrodes with different potential ranges and building asymmetric, transparent SC, the voltage window of the device can be further broadened, thus enhancing the energy density of the device. Figure 25.12a shows the CV curves of an asymmetric SC based on Ti3C2Tx//SWCNT TCEs. The transparent asymmetric device possesses a T of 72% and a wider voltage window (1 V), in contrast to 0.65 V in the symmetric device. As a result, the energy density has been improved by ~five-fold, reaching 0.05 μWh/cm2 at a power density of 2.4 μW/cm2. The ascalculated energy density based on the asymmetric device has surpassed any other transparent SCs. Moreover, no capacitance decay is observed after 20,000 cycles; the high Coulombic efficiency (100%) indicates the excellent performances are not due to other parasitic reactions [27].

sections.heading: Perspectives on Future Outlook
sections.text:
MXenes are a new class of 2D materials that possess many unique properties, rendering them quite attractive in various applications. As the widest studied MXene, multilayered Ti3C2Tx powder can be delaminated into monolayers in var-
498 C. J. Zhang and V. Nicolosi
ious solvents, which greatly facilitates the solution processing into films, coatings, composites, etc. Benefiting from its ultrahigh electronic conductivity, the solutionprocessed Ti3C2Tx TCEs showcase excellent optoelectronic properties including relatively low sheet resistance in the high transparency regime. Although the FoMe in the current Ti3C2Tx TCEs reaches 15, a relatively ordinary value and could not meet the requirement in the display field. However, there is still much room to further push the limits.
While the optimization of the MXene synthesis and composition should be effective, understanding the influence of surface functionalities on the MXene electronic properties may be more effective. This includes the selectively removal of undesirable terminations for the sake of higher conductivity. Second, understanding the movement of charge carriers along the tunneling barriers is also crucial. Finally, building the nanosheet mesh on the flexible PET can substantially improves the transmittance of Ti3C2Tx TCEs. This requires a delicate design of thin film fabrication.
On the side of charge storage, the Ti3C2Tx films are proved as an efficiently transparent conductor and active material for high-performance capacitive charge storage, including high areal and volumetric capacitances in the supercapacitor electrode, with long lifetime, high energy density, and power handing in the prototype transparent solid-state device. Through optimizing the electrolyte/electrode interface, the voltage window of MXene can be extended to a more negative potential, leading to a broadened voltage window for the device and, consequently, much improved energy density and power density.
The achieved optoelectronic properties coupled with excellent volumetric capacitance and prototype performance show that the flexible Ti3C2Tx TCEs hold great promise in many areas, such as touch panel, displays, organic solar cells, transparent energy storage devices, wearable electronics, etc., to name just a few.

sections.heading: Biomedical Applications of MXenes
sections.text: Flavia Vitale, Nicolette Driscoll, and Brendan Murphy

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Recent advances in biomedicine and nanotechnology are shifting paradigms in the diagnosis, management, and treatment of a variety of diseases. Fueled by the progress in nanomaterial synthesis and characterization, clinical care is transitioning from the era of biomedical devices implanted in the human body to support, restore, or replace functions at the organ or system level to the era of nano-biotechnologies that act at the cellular or subcellular scale to deliver therapeutic interventions. The success of these emerging techniques is critically dependent on the composition, morphology, structure, and physicochemical properties of the nanomaterials and how these affect the interaction with the biological system. When designing novel nano-biotechnology platforms, the issues of biocompatibility, biodistribution,

504 F. Vitale et al.
excretion, and cellular uptake of the nanomaterials are of paramount importance and must be taken into account to ensure the feasibility for clinical translation. Over the past few decades, several classes of nanomaterials with a wide range of topologies such as nanospheres, nanowires, nanoribbons, and cages have been successfully engineered for application in drug delivery, tissue engineering, molecular and DNA sensing, neuromodulation, and cancer treatment platforms.
Since the discovery of graphene and the recognition of its unique electronic, mechanical, and thermal properties compared to the 1D, 3D, and bulk forms of carbons, dimensionality has emerged as one of the most relevant material parameters for nanomaterials and one of the most influential factors in determining its performance in biomedicine. 2D nanomaterials possess extremely high surface area, which makes them uniquely suited for applications based on surface interactions at the microscale, such as drug delivery, biosensing, and anti-biofouling membranes. Furthermore, the surface-to-volume ratio and the high elastic modulus of many 2D nanomaterials make them particularly attractive as reinforcements for biocomposites or mechanically tunable scaffolds for stem-cell and tissue engineering. Finally, the extreme thinness and controllable size of 2D nanomaterials allow them to be easily internalized by the cells via physiological processes (i.e., endocytosis) and to rapidly respond to external stimuli, making them particularly useful for localized photothermal and photodynamic cancer treatments, or as nanocontrast agents for diagnostic imaging. Fueled by the excitement sparked by graphene discovery and extensive characterization, a number of 2D nanomaterials have been now explored in several areas of biomedicine (Fig. 26.1) [1, 2].
In light of these considerations, it is no surprise that in recent years, MXenes have also emerged as candidate 2D nanomaterials to interface with biological systems and to serve as building blocks in nano-biotechnology platforms. From the topological perspective, MXenes share all the advantageous properties of other classes of 2D nanomaterials stemming from their extreme thinness, high surface area, high surface-to-volume ratio, and mechanical toughness. However, there are several other features that are unique to MXenes and make them particularly attractive for biomedical applications. First, the rich chemistry on the surface of MXenes provides abundant reactive sites for enzyme or drug functionalization. The hydrophilic surface of MXenes makes them soluble in aqueous solutions, which avoids the need for potentially toxic organic solvents and enables facile solution processing and integration within high-throughput microfabrication schemes. Finally, the high surface area, volumetric capacitance, and metallic conductivity are highly desirable for low-noise, high fidelity biosensors.
Since 2016, MXenes have attracted significant attention in the biotechnology community, and an increasing number of studies have been dedicated to exploring the potential of MXenes in the biomedicine arena. As of March 2018, the published works on this topic have been focused on three main areas: (1) biosensors for biomarker detection, bioelectronic sensing, and wearable technologies, (2) localized multimodal therapy and diagnostic imaging for cancer theranostics, and (3) antimicrobial and anti-biofouling treatments (Fig. 26.1). In this chapter, we will first review and discuss the processing, fabrication, and characterization of
26 Biomedical Applications of MXenes 505
MXene-based biomedical technologies and compare their performance with other classes of 2D nanomaterials. Then in the last section, we will discuss the preliminary indications on biosafety and biocompatibility of MXenes when interfaced with biological systems, both in vitro and in vivo.

sections.heading: Biosensing
sections.text:
Biosensing has found wide applications in biological and medical research as well as in clinical diagnosis, environmental monitoring, and other analytical tasks. From probing individual molecules, to the activity of individual cells, to the measurement of whole-body motions, a host of versatile sensors have been produced to inform scientific studies and healthcare monitoring. In recent years, several classes of 2D nanomaterials have been at the forefront of biosensor technology development, thanks to their unique geometries, physicochemical properties, and biocompatibility. Since their introduction in 2011, MXenes have gained significant attention for their excellent electronic and physicochemical properties, with Ti3C2 in particular as the most widely studied MXene constituent [3, 4]. Ti3C2 MXene has so far been investigated for biosensing applications ranging from electrochemical
506 F. Vitale et al.
sensors for analyte and metabolite detection, chemical and electrophysiological monitoring of neural activity, and in wearable technologies.

sections.heading: Electrochemical Biosensors
sections.text:
At the molecular level, electrochemical biosensors can be used to detect a variety of analytes and metabolites such as nitrides, hydrogen peroxides, and glucose. Reactive oxygen species (ROS) and reactive nitrogen species (RNS) are important groups of free radicals that can induce oxidative and nitrosative stress leading to protein and cell damage and a range of severe functional consequences [5]. To understand the effect of these species on cell functions and their contributions to disease, it is essential to reliably detect and measure their concentrations in biological media. Mediator-free electrochemical biosensors rely on direct electron transfer (DET) between immobilized electroactive enzymes and the electrode surface after these enzymes facilitate redox reactions with the analyte of interest. However, the electroactive centers of most enzymes are located deep within the protein structure, and enzymes often denature and lose bioactivity when immobilized on an electrode [6]. Thus, it is crucial to design electrodes that provide a favorable microenvironment for enzymes to adsorb and retain their electroactivity. Several 2D nanomaterials, including graphene, layered MoS2, and titanate nanosheets, have been used to build efficient, mediator-free biosensors on account of their biocompatibility, high electrical conductivity, and high specific surface areas [7– 9]. More recently, Ti3C2 MXene has been demonstrated as another, extremely promising electrode material for mediator-free biosensors for a range of molecules.
Wang et al. proposed a scheme to immobilize hemoglobin (Hb) onto Ti3C2 MXene electrodes to perform highly sensitive detection of H2O2 with a wide linear detection range [10]. This scheme relies on multilayer Ti3C2 MXene processed into an accordion—or organ-like structure—with very large specific surface area to support enzyme immobilization. The organ-like structure funnels enzymes toward the interior of the nanolayers, and surface terminations (such as hydroxyl groups) support adsorption of enzymes onto the surface, thus promoting immobilization. This unique MXene structure provides a favorable microenvironment for enzyme entrapment while also increasing the chance of effective collisions between the substrate and redox protein; furthermore, it decreases the likelihood of enzyme detachment during reaction with the substrate. The performance of this MXene-based biosensor was investigated by amperometry and showed significant improvements in H2O2 sensing, with both a lower detection limit (20 nM) and a wider linear detection range (0.1–260 μM) than previously reported sensors (Fig. 26.2).
Electrochemical biosensing of metabolites also has clinical applications for chronic disorders such as diabetes, where blood glucose monitoring is a valuable tool in the management of the disease. Enzymatic glucose biosensors typically take advantage of glucose oxidase (GOx) for detection because of its high selectivity
26 Biomedical Applications of MXenes 507
for glucose. In this type of biosensor, immobilized GOx catalyzes the oxidation of β-D-glucose by molecular oxygen, producing gluconic acid and H2O2 [11]. Glassy carbon electrodes (GCE) are commonly used as the electrode material on which GOx is immobilized. However, the redox potential of H2O2 over the GCE is relatively high. Recently, Rakhi et al. demonstrated a novel glucose biosensor based on a composite of Ti3C2 MXene and gold (Au) nanoparticles [12]. The high specific surface area, metallic conductivity, and hydrophilic surface of Ti3C2 MXene make it
508 F. Vitale et al.
an excellent material for the transducing matrix of a glucose biosensor. The addition of Au nanoparticles into this matrix increased the activity of GOx and improved the electrical conductivity and enzyme immobilization characteristics of the electrode structure. A comparison between the performances of this MXene/Au glucose sensor to previously reported biosensors—many of which were based on composites of graphene and carbon nanotubes (CNTs)—showed comparable performance with regard to detection limit, sensitivity, and linear detection range. Furthermore, the MXene/Au glucose sensor showed excellent stability, reproducibility, and repeatability over time, retaining 93% of its initial response current after 2 months of storage.

sections.heading: Bioelectronic Sensors
sections.text:
In addition to enzyme-based electrochemical biosensors, MXene has also been incorporated into field effect transistor (FET) sensors for measuring the activity of neurons in culture. In their 2016 work, Xu et al. demonstrated a Ti3C2 MXene FET that could both measure dopamine concentrations and record the electrical activity of neurons cultured on the FET [13]. Taking advantage of MXene’s hydrophilic nature, the authors developed a microcontact printing method for micropatterning very thin layers of MXene, which enabled simple, high-throughput device fabrication. In contrast, micropatterning methods for other carbon-based nanomaterials are typically low-throughput, complicated, and time-consuming and thus preclude scale-up to large-scale manufacturing. Similar to the other electrochemical biosensors discussed above, the MXene FET could be used to detect small biological molecules, particularly the neurotransmitter dopamine. In this case, the method of detection relies on interactions between dopamine molecules and free electrons in the functional terminals on the MXene surface that increase the number of electron holes, resulting in increased conductance of the FET. The MXene FET offered detection limits as low as 100 nM and exhibited highly linear conductance modulation for concentrations ranging from 100 nM to 50 μM. This dopamine detection limit is significantly lower than previously reported values for graphenebased dopamine biosensors [14, 15]. Additionally, when neurons on the device fired action potentials, neurotransmitters were released and bound to the MXene surface, inducing a fluctuation of electrical signals. Thus, the MXene FET could also record the electrical activity of the neurons cultured on the device with high sensitivity. Furthermore, because the MXene patterns were ~5 nm in thickness, the device was nearly transparent, allowing for simultaneous calcium imaging microscopy to visualize neuron activity and confirm the correlation between FET current fluctuations and spiking events. This demonstration revealed that the MXene FET achieved far better temporal resolution than the widely used calcium-sensitive dye Fluo-4, because the FET captured action potentials that could not be resolved by calcium imaging alone, due to the slow dynamics of calcium signaling in neurons.
26 Biomedical Applications of MXenes 509

sections.heading: Wearable Sensors
sections.text:
Recently, stretchable, wearable electronics to monitor human motion and activity have attracted tremendous attention for personalized health monitoring, human motion detection, and closed-loop control of prosthetic devices [16–18]. Conventional strain gauge sensors based on metal and semiconductor materials can detect only a narrow range of strain (<5%) and exhibit low gauge factors (GF ≈ 2) due to their rigid nature. The GF is the ratio of relative change in electrical resistance to mechanical strain and is often used as a figure of merit for strain gauge sensors. Because of the limitations of brittle metals and semiconductors, a variety of alternative nanomaterials, including graphene, carbon black, CNTs, metal nanoparticles, and nanowires, have been used to design skin-like strain sensors with stretchabilities of up to 800% strain, GF as large as 3000, and sensing strain limits as low as 0.008% [19]. Despite these impressive advances, integrating a broad range of capabilities into a single, highly sensitive, tunable, microscale sensor to detect deflections as small as artery pulses and as large as entire body motions remains a challenge. In 2018, Cai et al. demonstrated a versatile Ti3C2 MXene/CNT composite-based strain sensor with ultrahigh sensitivity and a tunable sensing range [19]. Ti3C2 MXene and CNT layers were assembled in a “sandwich-like” structure created by using delaminated MXene flakes and hydrophilic single-walled CNTs assembled through a layer-by-layer spray coating technique. This composite structure allowed MXene and interconnected CNT layers to readily change their overlapping areas and interconnecting pathways through reversible slipping, allowing the network to maintain high conductivity during large strains. This skin-attachable strain sensor could reliably detect and differentiate small deformations of the throat during speaking of different words, as well as large deformations of the knee associated with walking, running, and jumping. The sensor could detect strains as low as 0.1% and as high as 130%, showed high sensitivity (GF as high as 772.6) and ultrathin dimensions (<2 μm in thickness), and could maintain reliable sensing performance through >5000 bending cycles. This MXene/CNT-based strain sensor, whose performance could in large part be attributed to MXene’s excellent electronic and mechanical properties, represents a significant improvement in the development of a wearable sensor for tracking physiological signals for health, robotics, and sporting applications.
Like strain gauge sensors, skin-wearable or implantable piezoresistive pressure sensors can also be used to monitor a range of human motions and physiologic phenomenon. Ma et al. took advantage of the unique multilayer structure of Ti3C2 MXene that results after selective etching of the Al layer in the precursor Ti3AlC2 MAX phase to develop a piezoresistive sensor that could detect human motions ranging from subtle changes in facial expression to the large knee, elbow, and ankle flexion/extension [20]. As pressure was applied, the distance between adjacent MXene layers changed and resulted in electric current that monotonically increased with pressure. This MXene pressure sensor, which was discussed in detail in Chap. 24, represents another biosensor application for which MXene has proven to be a very promising material.
510 F. Vitale et al.

sections.heading: Photothermal Therapy
sections.text:
Cancer is one of the leading causes of death worldwide, with the number of deaths projected to increase by more than 60% within the next two decades [21]. The fundamental mechanisms behind the cancer tumorigenesis, metastasis, and angiogenesis are still not well understood, and there is also a significant variability between the different forms of cancer. As a result, the outcomes of traditional treatments such as surgical resection, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy are still far from satisfactory. Furthermore, all these therapeutic approaches are highly nonspecific, invasive, and are often associated with increased risk of side effects and cancer recurrence.
Hyperthermia is attracting increasing attention as a cancer treatment option, and, when used in association with chemotherapy and radiotherapy, can improve therapeutic outcomes [22]. Among the various modalities that have been proposed to induce localized heating of the tumor tissue, such as focused ultrasound, magnetic field, and microwaves, photothermal therapy (PTT) with near infrared (NIR) radiation has emerged as a promising alternative to conventional treatments, because of the high site specificity, minimal damage to normal tissue, and high ablation efficiency. PTT platforms rely on the introduction of photothermal conversion agents (PTAs) inside tumor cells, which can be activated via NIR irradiation at low intensity/power density and wavelength in the first (650–950 nm) or second biological window (1000–1350 nm), where the low scattering and energy absorption allow maximum penetration of the radiation through the tissue [23, 24]. In the past few decades, a number of nanomaterials with different topologies have been explored as high-efficiency PTAs for PTT, including Au nanoparticles with different morphologies [24–26], nanoscale carbon allotropes [27–29], as well as other organic and inorganic nanomaterials like polypyrrole [30], PEDOT-PSS [31], CuS nanocrystals (NCs, [32]), iron oxide [33], and, more recently, several classes of layered 2D nanomaterials [34–36].
The first demonstration of a MXene PTT platform was based on Ti3C2 ultrathin nanosheets (NSs) [37]. To produce Ti3C2 NSs with lateral size compatible with cellular uptake (typically via endocytic pathways), the precursor MAX phase was subjected to prolonged chemical exfoliation with 40% HF for 3 days, followed by intercalation with tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH). This process yielded ultrathin Ti3C2 NSs with thickness of 0.6 nm and average lateral size of 150 nm (Fig. 26.3a). UV-VIS-NIR absorption spectroscopy on aqueous Ti3C2 solutions revealed a characteristic spectrum with peak absorption at ~800 nm, right within the first NIR absorption window (Fig. 26.3b). This optical behavior is similar to metal nanoparticles, such as Au and Ag, which exhibit localized surface plasmonic resonance (LSPR) effect, and it is different from that of other 2D nanomaterials with a broad absorption range from UV to NIR range. The favorable properties of Ti3C2 as a PTA were also confirmed by an extinction coefficient of
26 Biomedical Applications of MXenes 511
25.2 L g−1 cm−1 at 808 nm, which is significantly higher than graphene oxide NSs (3.6 L g−1 cm−1), Au nanorods (3.9 L g−1 cm−1), black phosphorous (BP) quantum dots (14.8 L g−1 cm−1) [38], and comparable to that of WS2 and MoS2 NSs [2]. Also, the photothermal conversion efficiency was found to be 30.6%, which is higher than Au nanorods (21%) [39], BP quantum dots (28%) [38], CuS2 NCs (22%) [40], and MoS2 NSs (24.4%) [35]. The excellent photothermal performance and stability were confirmed when Ti3C2 NSs were dispersed in aqueous solutions at 32 ◦C and exposed to 5 minutes on-off cycles of 808 nm laser irradiation at low power density (1.0 W cm−2). At concentrations as a low as 72 ppm, the temperature in the solution increased by more than 20 ◦C, and no performance deterioration was found during heating cycles (Fig. 26.3c, d). Although MXenes are stable in aqueous solutions for several weeks, the stability in saline solutions like the physiological extracellular fluid is rather poor, and precipitation of MXene NSs can be observed after just a few hours. In this work, Ti3C2 NSs were functionalized with
512 F. Vitale et al.
soybean phospholipids (SP), which significantly improved the colloidal stability in several physiological media without affecting the photothermal properties of Ti3C2. Analysis of Ti3C2-SP NSs performance as PTA for cancer ablation in vitro on 4T1 breast cancer cells revealed that after 4 hours of incubation, the cells that were exposed to NIR irradiation at 808 nm and 1.0 W cm−2 power density showed significant decrease in viability and evidence of apoptotic processes in a dosedependent manner (Fig. 26.3e, f). For comparison, no effect was observed on the control groups that were left untreated, only incubated with Ti3C2-SP NSs without NIR irradiation, or exposed to the NIR laser in absence of Ti3C2 NSs. When the Ti3C2-SP NSs were injected in vivo intravenously in 4T1 tumor-bearing mice, they preferentially accumulated in the tumor due to the characteristic high permeability of tumor blood vessels and poor lymphatic drainage, a process known as enhanced permeability and retention (EPR). Exposure to NIR laser irradiation at 808 nm focused on the tumor site for 10 minutes caused the temperature to increase from 30 ◦C to 58 ◦C and resulted in the complete ablation of cancer cells (Fig. 26.3g). The effectiveness of the treatment was confirmed by the complete disappearance of tumors, lack of recurrence at 16 days posttreatment, and significant increase in survival rates compared to the groups that were left untreated, treated with NIR or with Ti3C2-SP NSs only (Fig. 26.3h).

sections.heading: Theranostic Platforms: Combined Diagnostic Imaging and Photothermal Therapy
sections.text:
In addition to PTT, the accurate localization of the tumor site is of high significance for early diagnosis, for guiding the NIR irradiation and minimizing the risk of damage to the surrounding healthy tissue and for monitoring posttreatment outcomes. Typical imaging modalities employed in cancer diagnostics are magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), X-ray computed tomography (CT), and, more recently, photoacoustic imaging (PA). MRI is characterized by high sensitivity and soft-tissue contrast, CT offers very high spatial resolution, and PA allows higher penetration depths than optical modalities by detecting the ultrasound waves generated by the laser-irradiated tissue. The synthesis of novel contrast agents with concurrent multimodal imaging and therapeutic capabilities allows the development of theranostic platforms for synergistic imaging and treatment. MnOx NSs grown on Ti3C2 NSs via in situ redox reaction from a KMnO4 precursor followed by SP functionalization can act as contrast agents for a combined MRI, PA, and PTT theranostic platform [41]. The responsiveness of the surface MnOx NSs to pH results in a unique pHdependent increase in the MRI signal intensity in acidic conditions, which are characteristic of the tumor microenvironment (~pH 6.0 compared to pH 7.4 of healthy tissue). Additionally, Mn is an abundant element in the human body and has inherently higher biosafety than the clinically adopted Gd2+-based contrast agents for MRI, which have a long retention time in the body and have been
26 Biomedical Applications of MXenes 513
associated with potentially toxic side effects [42, 43]. Finally, the high photothermal conversion efficiency (22.9%) endows the MnOx/Ti3C2-SP with enhanced PA signal in the tumor post intravenous injection, which gradually increases with time due to the EPR effect, and high-efficacy in 4T1 breast cancer cell ablation and growth suppression, both in vitro and in vivo.
To realize a theranostic platform integrating the X-ray CT imaging together with MRI and PA modalities while retaining the high photothermal conversion efficiency and the abundant surface chemistry of MXenes, it is possible to substitute the Ti in the M-phase with Ta, a transition metal with a higher atomic number (Z = 73) and X-ray attenuation coefficient (4.3 cm2 g−1 at 100 keV) [44]. Ta4C3 MXene displays high, concentration-dependent light absorption in the broad UV-VIS-NIR wavelength range without the characteristic peak at ~800 nm of Ti3C2 [45, 46]. However, the photothermal conversion efficiency of Ta4C3 MXene (>30%) as well as the stability under on-off cycles of NIR irradiation is comparable to Ti3C2. Thus, Ta4C3 MXene functionalized with MnOx [45] or superparamagnetic ironoxide nanoparticles (IONP) [46] and stabilized with SP can realize a multimodal imaging and therapeutic platform for cancer theranostics, where the Ta component is employed for enhanced-contrast in situ CT imaging, the MnOx or IONP as contrast agents for MRI (Fig. 26.3i), and Ta4C3 as high-efficiency PTA for PA imaging for hyperthermia and ablation of cancer.

sections.heading: Synergistic Treatments: Drug Delivery and Photothermal Therapy
sections.text:
In addition to in situ growth of nanoscale contrast agents for enhanced tumor imaging, the high surface area and the rich surface chemistry of MXenes provide abundant anchoring sites for therapeutic drug molecules, thus offering the potential to integrate PTT, chemotherapy, and imaging within a single platform. For example, the surface-exposed (OH−) groups in Ti3C2-SP MXenes can electrostatically adsorb cationic molecules such as doxorubicin (Dox), a chemotherapeutic drug commonly used to treat cancer [47, 48]. Such functionalization scheme can result in drug loading capability as high as 211% [48]. Once the Ti3C2-SP-Dox NSs penetrate inside the cells, the release of the drug can be triggered endogenously, by the acidic tumor microenvironment through the interference of H+ ions with the electrostatic interaction between Dox and Ti3C2-SP, or exogenously via NIR irradiation. Compared to the individual therapeutic modalities, Ti3C2-SP-Dox for synergistic chemotherapy and PTT leads to enhanced inhibition of cancer cell viability in vitro and improves therapeutic and recurrence outcomes in vivo. Additionally, specific targeting, retention, and responsiveness can be improved by coating Ti3C2-Dox with molecules that can specifically target species that are abundant in the tumor microenvironment. For example, coating Ti3C2-Dox with hyaluronic acid increases colloidal stability and actively targets the surface protein CD44+ overexpressed in
514 F. Vitale et al.
breast cancer cells [47]. This work also demonstrated the potential of Ti3C2 MXene as a photosensitizer for photodynamic therapy (PDT), an additional localized cancer treatment modality. PDT is based on the release of cytotoxic reactive oxygen species (ROS) when a photosensitizer co-localized within the cancer cells is exposed to light radiation [49]. Upon NIR irradiation, the energy transfer of photoexcited electrons from Ti3C2 to triplet oxygen(3O2) generates singlet oxygen (1O2), similar to graphene quantum dots [50] and BP [51].
The schematic illustration in Fig. 26.4 summarizes the synthesis scheme and the therapeutic and diagnostic applications of MXene-based theranostic nanoplatforms against cancer, including PTT/PDT, drug delivery, and multimodal imaging.

sections.heading: Broadband Photothermal Conversion Agents
sections.text:
All the works discussed thus far in this section focused on exploring the performance of MXenes as PTAs in the NIR I biowindow. However, working in the NIR II biowindow offers several advantages, including maximum tissue penetration depth at wavelengths of 1000–1100 nm and higher maximum permissible exposure limit (1 W cm−2) compared to 808 nm (0.33 W cm−2) (ANSI Z136.1–2007, American National Standard for Safe Use of Lasers). While Ti3C2 and Ta4C3 MXenes display a marked optical absorbance and photothermal response only in the NIR I biowindow, Nb2C shows strong, broad, and almost constant optical
26 Biomedical Applications of MXenes 515
absorption encompassing the NIR I and NIR II biowindows [52]. The extinction coefficients of Nb2C stabilized with biocompatible polyvinylpyrrolidone are 37.6 and 35.4 L g−1 cm−1 at 808 nm and 1064 nm, respectively, while the reported photothermal conversion efficiencies are 36.5% at 808 nm and 46.65% at 1064 nm, thus confirming the potential of Nb2C as PTA in the broad NIR I–II range.
Finally, a very promising feature for enhancing the biocompatibility and translation potential of theranostic nanoplatforms is the possibility of controlling the lifetime of the nanoagents in the body and reducing the potential risks related to body retention of nanomaterials and their by-products. This could be achieved by designing active biodegradation schemes that leverage the natural clearance pathways of the body’s immune system. A first step in this direction is the biodegradation scheme for Nb2C NSs based on human myeloperoxidase (hMPO), a free-radical species generating enzyme expressed by neutrophils to carry out their antimicrobial activity [52]. In the presence of H2O2, hMPO generates hypochlorous acid and reactive radical intermediates, which degrade polymers and carbon-based materials. The incubation of Nb2C NSs in hMPO- and H2O2-enriched medium for 24 hours has been reported to cause the complete degradation and disappearance of NSs, thus demonstrating in vitro the feasibility of this enzyme-triggered degradation route for MXenes.

sections.heading: Antimicrobial Treatments
sections.text:
Wastewater treatment is a part of the broader field of sanitation and involves the conversion of wastewater (e.g., sewage or gray water) into a cleaner form, called “effluent,” which can be reused to satisfy human needs or else be returned to the environment with little-to-no adverse effects. Wastewater treatment remains an important challenge in the twenty-first century, motivated by factors like the increasing global population, higher standards of living, and climate change [53].
To improve current wastewater treatment processes, many noble metal nanoparticles, as well as CNTs, graphene oxide (GO), and other graphene-based nanomaterials, have been implemented as antibacterial coatings for wastewater treatment membranes. These nanomaterials share high specific surface areas, as well as the ability to generate ROS. A high specific surface area means that there are more sites for adsorption of contaminants onto the membrane, which facilitates large-scale removal of organic and inorganic contaminants from a wastewater environment [53]. Additionally, ROS can cause physiochemical damage to the structures of bacterial cells through the mechanisms of oxidative stress [53, 54], resulting in bacterial growth inhibition. Recent investigations into the antibacterial activity of MXenes have shown that they behave in ways unique and different from other nanomaterials that have been previously explored.
The high specific surface area and degree of hydrophilicity of MXenes promote the adhesion of particulates in the aqueous environment. This favorable adsorption behavior of MXene has been recently reported by Jastrzebska et al. [55], who
516 F. Vitale et al.
explored the biosorption properties of expanded Ti2C MXene nanosheets against three model bacteria: Bacillus sp. (found in the human gastrointestinal tract), S. aureus (common to the respiratory system), and Sarcina (found in the large intestine). After successfully splitting Ti2AlC MXene into individual sheets of Ti2C, cultures of the three bacteria in 0.05 mg/200 μL of Ti2C were suspended in a drinking water environment and incubated at 37 ◦C for 30 mins. Scanning electron microscopy imaging revealed that all strains of bacteria readily adsorbed onto the Ti2C sheets, with some cells even attached to sites between the individual layers (Fig. 26.5). Another interesting finding was that the zeta potential for the Ti2C MXene after the adsorption of each type of bacterial cell changed to reflect the zeta potential of the bacteria itself. The zeta potential reflects the stability existing between electrically charged components in a colloidal dispersion, such that this adjustment of the Ti2C zeta potential to that of the bacterial cells indicates that when bacteria adsorb to the Ti2C, they become electrically stabilized, thus implying a more stable adsorption process.
One major concern that arises in the case of other nanomaterials with high adsorption rates in antibacterial coatings is the issue of biofouling. For example, although adding hydrophilic metal oxide nanoparticles to a membrane increases its adsorption properties, as more bacteria adhere to the membrane, there is increased possibility that these cells will form a biofilm that reduces the permeability of the membrane and decreases its overall effectiveness [53]. One possible solution to prevent biofouling relies on damaging the bacteria that adhere to the membrane, and MXenes have proven to be very effective in this regard.
In 2016, Rasool et al. were able to fine-tune the antibacterial activity of Ti3C2 MXene by adjusting its concentration in a colloidal suspension [56]. Aqueous solutions of Ti3C2 at various concentrations were formulated, and colonies of E. coli and B. subtilis were treated with the mixtures for 4 hours. E. coli is a Gram-negative bacterium commonly found in the lower intestine, while B. subtilis is a Grampositive bacterium in the same genus as Bacillus sp. At a concentration of 2 μg/mL of Ti3C2, 92.53% of E. coli and 93.96% of B. subtilis cells survived contact with the MXene solution. These survival rates dropped dramatically to 35.31% for E. coli and 28.21% for B. subtilis, when the concentration of Ti3C2 was increased tenfold
26 Biomedical Applications of MXenes 517
to 20 μg/mL. At the maximum concentration of 200 μg/mL, bacterial inhibition reached 99% for both model strains. Comparatively, for bacterial cultures suspended in 200 μg/mL of GO in aqueous solution, roughly 90% of cells were inactivated (Fig. 26.6a, b). Thus, Rasool et al. demonstrated that the bacterial inactivation rate of Ti3C2 MXene could be fine-tuned to be higher than that of GO. More importantly, in the same report, it was found that the high antibacterial activity in Ti3C2 MXene was independent of the presence of ROS in the MXene nanoparticles themselves. This distinguishes MXenes from most of the nanomaterials explored for use in wastewater treatment processes, which are thought to inactivate bacterial cells through oxidative stress via ROS generation.
In a follow-up work, Rasool et al. investigated the mechanisms of antibacterial activity of MXenes in the form of coatings for water purification membranes [57]. A Ti3C2 coating was applied to a commercial polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) membrane, and E. coli and B. subtilis cultures were suspended on the surface of the membrane for 24 hours. After this time, 33% of the E. coli culture and 27% of the B. subtilis culture remained on the MXene-PVDF surface. When MXene coatings were allowed to oxidize for 24 hours before bacterial exposure, their antibacterial activity increased further, to the point that they inhibited >99% growth for both bacterial types upon exposure (see Fig. 26.6c). The highly hydrophilic Ti3C2 coating displayed a very rough topography, as well as a high density of surface defects, which were observed to cause physical damage and even rupturing of the bacterial cell wall. This study concluded that the stresses induced on the bacteria when in contact with the MXene coatings were more physical than oxidative in nature. It was found that damage to the bacterial cells resulted in cytoplasmic release and subsequent cell death. By directly causing cell death, the MXene coating effectively prevented formation of a bacterial biofilm on the PVDF membrane, thus mitigating the risk of biofouling.
518 F. Vitale et al.

sections.heading: Biocompatibility of MXenes
sections.text:
Compared to their bulk counterparts, the biocompatibility of nanomaterials cannot be directly inferred from their constituting elements as the size, shape, dispersion, surface charge, and hydrophilicity play a significant role in determining the body response to the foreign material. The primary mechanisms of nanomaterial-induced toxicity are (1) oxidative damage to the cells from the nanostructures themselves, by-products, or contaminants, (2) slow clearance through the renal pathway and accumulation in the organs, (3) damage to blood cells (i.e., hemolysis) and trombogenicity, (4) genotoxicity, and (5) specific toxicity to the reproductive, neural, or embryonic system. Thus, a comprehensive biosafety evaluation requires a thorough investigation of all the possible interactions between the nanomaterial and the living system, taking into account not only the different mechanisms of toxicity but also the effects of shape, size, and physicochemical properties of the nanomaterials themselves.
Though still in its infancy, the interest in MXenes for biomedicine has generated some preliminary data on the cytocompatibility and biocompatibility of MXenes, particularly in the field of cancer theranostics. To date, Ti3C2 is the most commonly investigated form of MXenes, and several recent reports [37, 41, 47, 48] evidence the lack of significant apoptosis or signs of cytotoxicity when cancer cells are exposed to few nanometer-thin Ti3C2 NSs with lateral size of ~150–250 nm, at concentrations ranging from 6 to 600 ppm (Fig. 26.3e, f). When Ti3C2 NSs are injected in the bloodstream, they are excreted in the urine via physiologic renal clearance pathways or are retained in the tumor tissue via the EPR effect, without accumulating in the major organs. The advantageous biodistribution and systemic biosafety of Ti3C2 appear to be confirmed even after intravenous injections of high doses (up to 20 mg/kg), with no evidence of body weight loss, alteration of blood indexes, or necrotic processes at the major organ level at acute (1 day), subacute (7 days), and chronic (30 days) time scales [37, 41, 48] (Fig. 26.7a, b). Additional preliminary work indicates no sign of hemolytic damage to red blood cells in presence of Ti3C2 NSs [47] (Fig. 26.7c). Similar findings have been reported for the cytocompatibility and systemic biocompatibility for Ta4C3 [45, 46] and Nb2C MXenes [52].
In addition to reports suggesting the biocompatibility of MXene NSs dispersed in saline solutions and injected in the bloodstream, there are preliminary indications of the safety of MXenes when micropatterned on electronic films. Primary hippocampal neurons cultured on the MXene FET show normal cell morphology and well-elaborated neurite outgrowth after 1 week of exposure [13], despite the higher sensitivity of primary neuronal cultures to material and surface properties compared to immortalized cancer cell lines.
26 Biomedical Applications of MXenes 519

sections.heading: Conclusions and Future Outlook
sections.text:
Nanomaterial-based platforms are emerging as promising alternatives to traditional therapies for the diagnosis and treatment of a broad range of diseases, thanks to their high-specificity, efficacy, minimal invasiveness, and reduced risk of side effects. MXenes hold great potential for application in biomedicine as they combine the topological advantages of 2D nanomaterials with unique physicochemical properties such as surface reactivity, hydrophilicity, and metallic conductivity. Since 2016 the potential of MXenes as novel biomaterials has been investigated in the areas of biosensing, cancer theranostics, and antimicrobial treatments.
In the context of biosensing, Ti3C2 MXene shows excellent performance as an electrode material for enzymatic, mediator-free biosensing of ROS and RNS, as well as for high-sensitivity glucose monitoring systems, which can find relevant application in diabetes diagnosis and monitoring. Furthermore, Ti3C2 MXene can be processed into FETs for monitoring the electrical and chemical activities of cultured neurons at high resolution. The modulation of the optoelectronic properties of the MXene films offers the possibility of performing simultaneous optical imaging, which could enable a number of applications in neuroscience studies. Finally, Ti3C2 MXene shows promising potential for versatile, stretchable strain and pressure sensors, which enables applications in human healthcare monitoring.
MXene-based theranostic platforms for multimodal imaging and ablation of cancer cells are characterized by higher photothermal conversion efficiency and optical absorbance in the NIR range compared to other nanostructures. The synthesis of
520 F. Vitale et al.
ultrathin MXene NSs with ~150–200 nm lateral size via prolonged chemical etching enables cell uptake via endocytic pathways and preferential retention within the highly vascularized tumor structure. Cancer hyperthermia treatments with NIR laser in presence of Ti3C2, Ti4C3, or Nb2C co-localized within the tumor cells result in complete ablation, necrosis, and improved survival and recurrence rates. Furthermore, thanks to their rich surface chemistry, MXenes can be engineered into nanocontrast agents for multimodal, localized diagnostic imaging as well as into drug delivery vectors via in situ functionalization with superparamagnetic nanoparticles and drug molecules.
When investigated as antibacterial membranes for wastewater treatment, Ti3C2 MXene exhibits stable bacterial adsorption at high rates, due to the high effective surface area and hydrophilicity. Ti3C2 MXene is also more effective than other nanomaterials at inhibiting bacterial growth: Ti3C2 coatings on PVDF membrane caused cell death for both Gram-negative E. coli and Gram-positive B. subtilis, despite the thickness difference in the cell walls between the two species. This finding has important implications for MXene use in true wastewater environments, because it implies that a MXene coating may have a certain degree of selectivity to allow for targeting only bacterial cells, without affecting other living cells in the same environment.
The introduction of new nanomaterials in the field of biomedicine requires a thorough evaluation of their biosafety and toxicity, as these are of paramount importance in determining the true potential for clinical translation. Given their relatively recent discovery, the amount of data regarding the biocompatibility of MXenes is still very limited. However, some preliminary assessments suggest that MXenes are compatible with cellular viability and growth and do not induce hemolytic damage to red blood cells in vitro. Furthermore, when engineered in ultrathin NSs, they can be excreted through the physiological renal clearance pathway and do not appear to induce any toxic effect in the major organs. These results are certainly encouraging and support the promising potential of MXenes as novel biomaterials. However, in order to establish the biocompatibility of MXenes, future extensive investigations must be conducted to take into account all the possible mechanisms of interaction between MXenes and living systems at chronic time scales.
The era of MXenes in biomedicine has just begun. The exceptional physicochemical properties and the number of species available in the library of MXenes open the unprecedented opportunity to fine-tune the material properties to the specific application and cellular targets, many of which are yet to be explored. Examples of areas for future investigation include mechanically and electrically responsive scaffolds for regenerative medicine [58], separation membranes for artificial organs [59], fluorescent intracellular probes [60], and implantable bioelectronic interfaces for neurotransmitter [61, 62] and bioelectronic signal detection [63].
26 Biomedical Applications of MXenes 521

In the 1960s, Hans Nowotny’s group in Vienna discovered [1] more than 100 new carbides and nitrides, including the so-called H phases and their relatives, Ti3SiC2 and Ti3GeC2.

These phases remained largely unexplored with only sporadic work until the mid-1990s, when Barsoum and El-Raghy [2] synthesized relatively phase-pure samples of Ti3SiC2 and revealed it to be a material with a remarkable combination of metallic and ceramic properties: good electrical and thermal conductivity, machinablility, and resistance to thermal shock and oxidation.

They later discovered Ti4AlN3, making it clear that these phases shared a basic structure and leading to the introduction of the nomenclature “Mn+1AXn phases” (n = 1, 2, or 3) or “MAX phases,” where M is a transition metal, A is an A-group element, and X is C and/or N [3, 4].
